This case study explores Boond Engineering & Development Pvt. Ltd., an Indian social enterprise mitigating rural energy poverty through decentralized solar microgrids, AI-enabled energy management, and community ownership models. Founded by Simran Grover and Rustam Sengupta, Boond integrates inclusive innovation and hybrid financing to deliver reliable, affordable energy to underserved regions. Findings highlight electrification of over 12,000 households, deployment of 550 microgrids, an 80% reduction in kerosene use, and creation of 2,300+ livelihoods, including significant female workforce participation. The study situates Boond within India’s renewable energy transition and Sustainable Development Goals (SDG 7 – Affordable and Clean Energy and SDG 13 – Climate Action), while identifying challenges related to remote logistics, talent retention, and regulatory volatility. The case illustrates how mission-driven enterprises can align technology, social equity, and climate resilience, providing a scalable pathway for just and sustainable energy transitions in emerging economies.

Contribution: This study contributes an empirical case of technology-enabled social entrepreneurship, offering insights into policy alignment, inclusive innovation, and replicable energy access models for emerging economies.

title: Rewards, Autonomous Motivation and Turnover Intention: Results from a Non-Western Cultural Context
affiliations: Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU) and Fatima Jinnah Women University

detail.title: Rewards, Autonomous Motivation and Turnover Intention: Results from a Non-Western Cultural Context
detail.abstract: The purpose of this study is to examine the influence of two reward types (i.e., monetary reward and non-monetary rewards, such as competence development, autonomy support, and recognition) on autonomous motivation and further explore whether autonomous motivation plays a mediating role in the relationships between rewards and turnover intention. The study used a survey data from 100 employees working in public sector banks in Pakistan. The hypothesized relationships were assessed using partial least squares structural equation modelling technique. The results revealed that monetary reward and competence development were positively related to autonomous motivation, which in turn had a negative association with turnover intention. The indirect effects of rewards on turnover intention were only supported for monetary reward and competence development, as there was no significant link from autonomy support and recognition to autonomous motivation. We discuss implications for research and practice.

title: TRUMP'S 25% TARIFF SHOCK: INDIA ECONOMIC & STRATEGIC MARKET IMPACT

detail.title: TRUMP'S 25% TARIFF SHOCK: INDIA ECONOMIC & STRATEGIC MARKET IMPACT
detail.abstract: This paper analyzes the economic and strategic implications of the 25% blanket tariff imposed by the United States on Indian exports, affecting over $86.5 billion worth of trade across core sectors such as pharmaceuticals, textiles, electronics, and auto components. Using a combination of Monte Carlo simulations, multi-scenario GDP modeling, and capital flow forecasting, the study quantifies the macroeconomic drag, projecting a potential decline in India's FY26 GDP growth from 6.4% to 5.2% in the downside scenario. Over 7 million jobs, largely in labor-intensive sectors and industrial clusters like Tirupur, Surat, and Bangalore, are at risk. The report further models exchange rate volatility, forecasting INR depreciation toward ₹92.7/USD, and anticipates foreign investment outflows exceeding $8 billion. The paper proposes a strategic response framework including export credit support of ₹25,000 crore, expedited trade negotiations with the UK and EU, and market diversification to mitigate over-dependence on the US. Investment recommendations include rotating into domestic-facing sectors while maintaining FX hedges. The tariff shock, while severe, also offers an opportunity for India to accelerate structural reforms, enhance trade resilience, and reposition itself in global value chains.

detail.title: Is The Future Jobless?

detail.abstract: Youth unemployment in developing countries remains one of the most pressing global challenges, threatening long-term economic development, political stability, and social cohesion. This paper critically examines the role of the World Bank in addressing youth unemployment, focusing on its policy frameworks, data infrastructure, funding mechanisms, and global partnerships. By analysing country-specific case studies and exploring evidence from initiatives such as Skills4Girls, S4YE, and Beti Bachao Beti Padhao, the study highlights the need for localized, data-driven, and inclusive employment solutions. It identifies the underlying structural barriersincluding education-employment mismatches, digital divides, and informal labour markets-that disproportionately affect marginalized youth, especially young women. Furthermore, the paper proposes a multi-pronged approach involving targeted education reform, scalable public-private programs, and greater accountability in monitoring and evaluation mechanisms. Drawing on data from the World Bank and UNDP, this paper contributes to a growing body of research that calls for urgent, collaborative, and innovative strategies to combat youth joblessness in the Global South. The findings underscore that while the World Bank has laid foundational frameworks, a shift toward participatory and equity-driven models will be crucial for sustainable outcomes.

title: Decentralized Management: A Paradigm Shift in Organizational Governance Enabled by AI, Blockchain, and Human Autonomy for the Digital Age

detail.title: Decentralized Management: A Paradigm Shift in Organizational Governance Enabled by AI, Blockchain, and Human Autonomy for the Digital Age

declarations.funderStatement: “The author received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article. The research and ideas presented are solely those of the author.”

detail.abstract:
This paper introduces Decentralized Management (DM) as a transformative organizational paradigm, synthesizing blockchain-enabled governance, AI-driven coordination, and human autonomy into a unified theoretical framework. we propose three core principles—distributed authority, dynamic accountability, and algorithmic transparency—and validate them through mixed-methods research (42 companies, 120+ interviews). Our findings reveal that DM outperforms hierarchies in innovation (+32%) and agility (+55% decision speed) but requires novel safeguards against power vacuums and ethical risks. We contribute to management theory by formalizing DM as a post-bureaucratic organizational form and provide actionable design principles for practitioners.

This paper synthesizes a new framework for decentralized management (DM) — an organizational model distributing authority away from hierarchical control toward networked, self-governing systems. Combining empirical case studies, technical architectures, and socio-economic analysis, we demonstrate how DM leverages blockchain-based trust, AI-driven coordination, and human autonomy to achieve superior resilience, innovation, and efficiency. We further introduce a scaling matrix for SMEs, enterprises, and governments, alongside ethical guardrails for sustainable implementation.

title: Please Customers or Prevent Wastage? Replenishment and Issuance Policy for a Perishable Product with Age-sensitive Demand
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and Indian Institute of Management (IIMB), Bangalore

detail.title: Please Customers or Prevent Wastage? Replenishment and Issuance Policy for a Perishable Product with Age-sensitive Demand

publicationDetails.detailsText: To appear in Manufacturing & Service Operations Management.

detail.abstract: An online retailer selling a perishable product can issue inventories of different remaining lifetimes in its preferred sequence. This creates a trade-off between customer satisfaction and outdating costs, since customers want freshness whereas the retailer desires units be sold within their lifetime. We study this trade-off by considering joint replenishment and issuance policy for a perishable product with a general lifetime. Methodology/results: We develop a periodic review model over a finite horizon and model customers' sensitivity to the received unit's remaining lifetime using a goodwill cost, which increases as the remaining lifetime decreases. Although customer satisfaction is likely to be maximized by the last-in, firstout (LIFO) issuance policy and the outdating cost is likely to be minimized by the first-in, first-out (FIFO) issuance policy, neither policy may be optimal. In particular, when the product lifetime is two periods, it is optimal to first issue new inventory until a threshold and then issue the remaining inventory in the FIFO order. Although the value function is always concave, the optimal issuance policy can become complex for longer product lifetimes. Consequently, we focus on bucket policies in which inventory of each remaining lifetime is issued in a single installment. Our experiments showcase that the best bucket policy's profit is within 0.1% of the optimal profit on average. Motivated by this result, we develop an easy-to-compute heuristic to determine a bucket policy and order quantity and computationally show that its performance is within 1.3% of the optimal profit on average. The heuristic also outperforms many replenishment and issuance policies proposed in the literature. Furthermore, the heuristic is asymptotically optimal with respect to the unit retail price. Managerial implications: Although optimal issuance policies that capture the trade-off between customer satisfaction and wastage due to expiry can often be complex, simple, effective, and easy-to-implement issuance policies can be identified; the performance of these policies is close to optimal.

title: Carrot or Stick? Asymmetric Effects of Emission Trading Scheme on Corporate Digital Transformation

detail.title: Carrot or Stick? Asymmetric Effects of Emission Trading Scheme on Corporate Digital Transformation
detail.abstract: Exploiting China’s carbon Emission Trading Scheme pilot in 2013 as a quasi-natural experiment and employing difference-in-differences estimation on 2010–2021 A-share listed firm data, this study identifies the causal impact of market-based environmental regulation on corporate digital transformation (DT). Results demonstrate that ETS adoption significantly increases treated firms’ DT intensity by 18.8%, with effects exhibiting lagged accumulation and peaking in the first post-treatment period. Heterogeneity analyses reveal stronger impacts among non-SOEs, non-polluting firms, and low-profitability enterprises—highlighting roles of ownership structure, compliance cost pressure, and marginal incentive elasticity. Mechanism tests indicate DT is propelled by ETS-induced green innovation, confirming a "green capability–digital transition" pathway. Policy implications emphasize tailoring allowance allocation and carbon asset collateralization to overcome financial constraints in high-pollution sectors, alongside integrated digital-carbon infrastructure for enhanced policy efficacy.

title: Exploring the Impact of Trauma on Residential Support Workers Assisting Young People in Out-of-Home Care: A Scoping Review
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Exploring the Impact of Trauma on Residential Support Workers Assisting Young People in Out-of-Home Care: A Scoping Review
detail.abstract: This study explores the trauma-related challenges of residential support workers (RSWs) assisting young people in out-of-home care. By employing the scoping review method, it synthesized findings from 18 studies, which were identified through a rigorous selection process involving four major databases and reference list reviews. The analysis included the challenges relating to burnout, secondary traumatic stress (STS), the emotional toll of managing trauma-related behaviours, systemic barriers, workplace violence, and socio-political influences that exacerbate the demands of the caregiving role, while emphasizing the need for trauma-informed interventions. The review suggests that the well-being of RSWs is closely tied to the quality of care provided to young people. Protective factors such as resilience and compassion satisfaction enhance caregivers’ effectiveness, yet significant gaps exist in trauma-informed training, peer support networks, and organizational resources. Addressing these gaps requires comprehensive support models prioritizing specialized training, relational practices, and systemic changes to foster resilience and promote well-being. This review underscores the moral and practical imperative of prioritizing RSWs’ well-being to ensure the stable and compassionate care of vulnerable young people. Future research may investigate the long-term impact of trauma-informed interventions on both caregivers and the outcomes for the young people they support, contributing to a more sustainable out-of-home care system.

publicationDetails.detailsText: Jay Katre, A Thematical Survey on Supply Chain Management with Advance Machine Learning Models(December 16, 2024).

detail.abstract: This survey articulates a comprehensive methodology for the enhancement of Supply Chain Management (SCM) through the application of machine learning and systematic frameworks. By synthesizing findings from diverse academic investigations, the research delves into the utilization of Conditional Generative Adversarial Networks (CGANs) to refine partner selection processes and optimize supply chain functionalities. Through the deployment of CGANs, the system is capable of scrutinizing intricate, multidimensional datasets to facilitate real-time decision-making, thereby augmenting the selection criteria for supply chain partners based on parameters such as reliability, cost-effectiveness, and operational performance. Moreover, the study investigates the incorporation of the SSH framework (Struts, Spring, Hibernate) to enhance the efficiency of SCM processes, thereby ensuring scalability, adaptability, and seamless integration among various system elements. The principal contributions of this research encompass the automation of decision-making processes, the enhancement of operational efficacy, and the promotion of collaboration within international supply chains. In addition, the paper deliberates on the ramifications of these methodologies for prospective SCM systems, underscoring the significance of data-driven strategies and accentuating the necessity for further inquiry into the amalgamation of IoT and blockchain technologies to bolster supply chain transparency, security, and overall performance. This research establishes a foundational framework for the development of intelligent, adaptive SCM systems capable of autonomously optimizing operations within an increasingly intricate, global marketplace.

title: Performance controls and accountability in African transport infrastructure megaprojects: A systematic literature review

detail.title: Performance controls and accountability in African transport infrastructure megaprojects: A systematic literature review

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

detail.abstract: Poor performance is common in the delivery of large-scale transport infrastructure. Despite previous studies examining the management of transport megaprojects, there is a lack of systematic reviews on performance Controls and Accountability in Megaprojects (CAMP). We analyze research on CAMP in Africa. Out of the 947 records retrieved, 35 articles published between 1980 and 2022 meet our inclusion criteria. We identify four main research themes: "project governance," "performance management," "project conceptual management," and "complexity management." Our findings indicate significant weaknesses in project governance and a lack of proper project conception. Practical implications involve restructuring project governance policies and implementing a multi-level project governance model. The research supports recognizing corruption as a characteristic of megaprojects, implementing project governance as a standard management practice, and improving governance in public-private partnerships. Additionally, future research should prioritize integrating and developing policies, strengthening institutions, implementing participatory governance mechanisms, and building capacity for project management.

title: Impact Of COVID-19 on the Branding Strategies of SMEs: Digitalization & CSR as Branding Strategies for SMEs in Post-Pandemic Times

detail.title: Impact Of COVID-19 on the Branding Strategies of SMEs: Digitalization & CSR as Branding Strategies for SMEs in Post-Pandemic Times

declarations.declarationOfInterest: This was my master's research dissertation as part of my Master's Grande Ecole program in IDRAC Business School, Lyon, France. Dr. GINOUX Anne-Celine, Associate Professor at IDRAC Business School, Lyon, supervised this research dissertation.

detail.abstract: This research dissertation aims to find the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the international branding strategies of SMEs. SMEs' International branding strategies are limited compared to large organizations due to the challenges SMEs face in terms of resources and capabilities. While the COVID-19 pandemic has impacted organizations of all sizes and industries, the impact on SMEs has been studied in this research dissertation. Although it had so many negative impacts on businesses, there were some positive impacts also. Also, this study looks at the effectiveness of digitalization and CSR as branding strategies for SMEs. A detailed reflexive thematic content analysis, a qualitative research methodology, has been performed to find the perception of managers in SMEs across the globe, and semi-structured interviews are used for data collection. The key findings of this research are that the impact of COVID-19 on the branding strategies of SMEs is both positive and negative. The valuable lessons and adaptations from the crisis have opened up new opportunities for SMEs for their international branding strategy. The branding strategies that have emerged from the difficult times for SMEs are digitalization, digital presence, digital marketing, innovations, utilization of digital platforms, and CSR. While digitalization and innovations can be very beneficial for SMEs in their branding strategies, the implementation of CSR is quite challenging with limited resources and capabilities. Although CSR can be an excellent tool for SMEs as their branding strategy, especially after the COVID-19 pandemic, the practical implementation still needs to be explored, which opens up the possibilities for future research. This research concludes by providing some suggestions for managers that they can apply practically in SMEs to enhance their branding strategy.

title: Secure Academic Certificate Authentication Using Blockchain Technology
affiliations: Rashtreeya Vidyalaya College of Engineering (RVCE) and Rashtreeya Vidyalaya College of Engineering (RVCE)

detail.title: Secure Academic Certificate Authentication Using Blockchain Technology
detail.abstract: Academic certificate fraud has become a significant concern for universities, institutions, and employers worldwide, as it directly affects the credibility and reliability of academic qualifications. Conventional methods for verifying certificates are largely manual, tedious, and prone to errors or manipulation, as they lack a centralized and tamper-resistant validation mechanism. The emergence of blockchain technology offers a revolutionary solution by enabling decentralized and immutable storage of certificate data, ensuring trust and transparency. This paper proposes and implements a blockchain-based academic certificate authentication framework that utilizes Ethereum smart contracts to securely record and manage certificate metadata. Additionally, the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) is integrated to facilitate decentralized and permanent storage of certificate files. The proposed system ensures that certificates are verified transparently, instantly, and without reliance on third-party intermediaries, thus streamlining the overall verification process. It empowers academic institutions to issue certificates securely while enabling verifiers to authenticate them efficiently, reducing administrative burden and minimizing the risk of document forgery. The results of the implementation demonstrate superior data integrity, operational performance, and user trust when compared to traditional verification approaches. This paper presents the existing challenges in certificate validation, details the methodology and design of the system, and provides experimental evaluations to establish its effectiveness for secure academic certificate verification.

title: Streamlining Pricing Strategy in the Financial Sector Using Microsoft Dynamics CRM: A Workflow-Driven Approach

detail.title: Streamlining Pricing Strategy in the Financial Sector Using Microsoft Dynamics CRM: A Workflow-Driven Approach
detail.abstract: Pricing in the financial industry requires accuracy, agility, and compliance. Manual pricing practices often lead to inconsistencies, delays, and missed opportunities. This article presents an automated, workflow-driven pricing strategy implemented within Microsoft Dynamics 365 CRM, using custom fields, Power Automate, and FX integrations. The result: improved proposal turnaround time, reduced human error, and enhanced visibility across global sales operations.

title: Adaptation and Mitigation in the Context of United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC): Global North-South Debate
affiliations: Jawaharlal Nehru University - Centre for International Legal Studies (CILS)

detail.title: Adaptation and Mitigation in the Context of United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC): Global North-South Debate

declarations.declarationOfInterest: NA
declarations.ethicsApproval: NA
declarations.funderStatement: NA

detail.abstract: The Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) is the primary international treaty that addresses this issue, providing a framework for global cooperation in mitigating greenhouse gas emissions and adapting to the impacts of climate change. However, the implementation of the UNFCCC's provisions has been met with various challenges and limitations, particularly concerning the differing responsibilities and capabilities of developed and developing countries. This paper examines the challenges and limitations faced by international environmental lawmakers in addressing climate change through the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). It focuses on the UNFCCC's provisions related to mitigation and adaptation approaches and the principle of "common but differentiated responsibilities" between developed and developing countries. The paper will also discuss the historical context of the divide between the Global North and Global South, highlighting factors such as Eurocentrism, industrialization, the unsustainability of the Global North, and resistance from the Global South. It compares the different approaches taken by the Kyoto Protocol and the Paris Agreement in addressing responsibilities between developed and developing nations. The paper argues that the UNFCCC's approach, which places the main responsibility on developed countries, does not adequately consider the historical context and differing priorities of the Global North and Global South. It highlights the challenges in balancing adaptation and mitigation efforts, the insufficient funding for adaptation in developing countries, and critiques from Third World Approaches to International Law (TWAIL) scholars regarding market mechanisms and the slow pace of implementation. Despite provisions in the UNFCCC that provide exceptions and support for developing countries, the paper argues that these measures do not sufficiently address the unique challenges faced by the Global South. The opposition of developed countries to the principle of "common but differentiated responsibilities" further hinders the development of an equitable and effective global response to climate change.

title: DFAS-EEP: Editorial Ethics Protocol for Governance Integrity in Scientific Publishing
affiliations: Institute of Certified Public Accountant ( ICPAP)

detail.title: DFAS-EEP: Editorial Ethics Protocol for Governance Integrity in Scientific Publishing

declarations.declarationOfInterest: We declare that there are no financial, personal, or institutional conflicts of interest associated with this study. This work was independently developed and authored without external pressure or influence from any journal, publisher, academic institution, or funding body. The protocol and governance tools introduced were conceived, designed, and validated solely by the author(s) in the interest of advancing ethical integrity in scientific publishing.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This study does not involve human participants, patient data, or clinical trials. Therefore, formal institutional ethics approval was not required. However, the manuscript adheres to the principles of academic integrity, transparency, and non-maleficence in its design, documentation, and governance protocols.
declarations.funderStatement: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors. It was entirely self-funded and produced independently as part of the broader Dynamic Financial Applied Science (DFAS) initiative to promote governance innovation and research ethics.

detail.abstract:
The DFAS-EEP (Editorial Ethics Protocol) introduces a branded, structured framework for enforcing governance integrity, authorship protection, and ethical accountability in scientific publishing. Developed under the Dynamic Financial Applied Science (DFAS) governance system, DFAS-EEP arises from a growing pattern of opaque editorial practices disproportionately affecting AI-governed models and doctrinal frameworks. This manuscript documents five emblematic cases — spanning Springer, Elsevier, and IJOEM — where manuscripts authored under the DFAS–FEP protocol were rejected without transparent justification, rigorous review, or doctrinal understanding. These events reveal a structural failure in editorial governance, notably the systemic misclassification of policy-oriented and non-empirical contributions.

DFAS-EEP is not a protest, it is a governance calibration tool. It introduces the Alaali Editorial Transparency Index (A-ETI), the Alaali Editorial Accountability Score (A-EAS), and the Alaali Gatekeeping Risk Level (A-GRL) metric to assess and document editorial conduct. Each case is archived using the Authorship Protection Documentation Protocol (APDP) and classified under the Alaali Gatekeeping Violation Matrix (A-GVM). Together, these tools institutionalize an ethical surveillance layer without politicized retaliation. DFAS-EEP is a mirror, not a weapon — designed to reinforce legitimacy, not dismantle editorial authority.

At its core, DFAS-EEP promotes reciprocal accountability: editors deserve respect, but not immunity from transparency. It dignifies editorial judgment by anchoring it within defined governance parameters, enabling reform without institutional erosion. The protocol also introduces the Alaali Authorship Integrity Record (A-AIR) and Editorial Response Classification Grid (ERCG) to track compliance with ethical and procedural standards.

In this manuscript, we argue that scientific innovation cannot flourish under ungoverned discretion. Through case-based evidence, documented classification, and forward-looking instruments, DFAS-EEP offers a doctrinal reset — one that ensures AI-governed models, framework manuscripts, and regulatory contributions are neither miscategorized nor silently suppressed (Alaali, 2025).

🛡️ "DFAS does not dismantle editorial authority, it dignifies it through transparency and reciprocal accountability."

"DFAS is not adversarial, it is a neutral governance compass, safeguarding integrity for both researcher and editor." "DFAS introduces ethical surveillance without politicized retaliation, it is a mirror, not a weapon."

title: Implementing Change Management to Healthcare Workers in a Traumatizing Environment of a Developing Country Experiencing Protracted War: An Interpretative Phenomenological Analysis

detail.title: Implementing Change Management to Healthcare Workers in a Traumatizing Environment of a Developing Country Experiencing Protracted War: An Interpretative Phenomenological Analysis

declarations.declarationOfInterest: I declare that there was no relationship with anyone that could have influenced the study.
declarations.ethicsApproval: Participants gave verbal and written consents. They were allowed to withdraw from the study if they felt uncomfortable at any stage.
declarations.funderStatement: The research needed no extra funds.

detail.abstract:
This qualitative phenomenological research explores the impact of a traumatic environment on the ability and willingness for change management of potentially traumatised healthcare workers living and working in the traumatic environment of a developing country experiencing protracted war. It identifies and explores factors influencing change management, attempts to understand how they impact change management, and suggests management recommendations to ensure effective change management.

Using a purposive sampling technique, data were collected from physicians, nurses, and health managers and triangulated for analysis. Cognitive distortion themes identified are not limited to compartmentalisation, allegiance, emotionalisation, rationalisation, resignation, dissociation, obligation, fear, and resignation. Participants’ willingness and ability to change were measured using a 7-point Likert scale. Scatter plots enhanced the visibility of results. An interpretation was reached. Individuals’ average scores of willingness and ability to change were plotted on a quadrant and management strategies developed accordingly.

Results underlined the role of stress hormones in influencing cognitive functions and behaviors, suggesting that effective change management must incorporate strategies that regulate these biological responses to manage resistance and foster healthier and more supportive work environment.

Limitations included that negligible bias could not be entirely ruled out due to potential synchrony in brain activity despite the researcher’s self-awareness. Possible tailored responses could have caused the Hawthorne effect. Ungeneralizable results from the small sample size, gender imbalance, and context. Time constraints and language barriers.

Recommended research includes investigating change management strategies in similar subjects of study within comparable environments, across multiple projects in developing countries, to develop targeted approaches for these unique contexts. Examining the impact of stress hormones on the willingness and ability to implement change management in other traumatizing environments, to explore the applicability of existing change management models and theories from developed countries in unstable and uncertain contexts of developing countries.

title: Assessing the Independence of the Nigerian Electricity Regulatory Commission in Form and Substance

detail.title: Assessing the Independence of the Nigerian Electricity Regulatory Commission in Form and Substance
detail.abstract: Three mutually exclusive interests converge on the independent regulatory model of governance table: the desire of consumers for affordable and sustainable power supply; the quest of investors of sunk and immovable resources to have a return of their investments; and finally the desire of government for peace and social harmony devoid of exploitation and market abuse. In balancing these competing interests, an umpire, the Nigerian Electricity Regulatory Commission, was established to moderate the competing interests. It is designed to be and be seen to be independent of all the players in the value chain in its decision-making processes in order to ginger credibility, accountability, legitimacy and transparency and is also required to act objectively, impartially, and consistently, without conflict of interest, bias or undue influence-in other words, independently. This paper problematizes the institutional design of the Nigerian Electricity Regulatory Commission to ascertain its alignment with the conceptual benchmarks of independence in both form and substance. The paper finds that while the enabling law largely captures the essence of the model, the de facto landscape under which the Nigerian Electricity Regulatory Commission operates is dotted with distortions, misalignments characterized by state and regulatory capture thus betraying its weak independent status and proffers veritable mitigating pathways out of the challenges.

reference: Disability and Health Journal, 2025[10.1016/j.dhjo.2025.101931]
title: Work from Home and Job Satisfaction: Differences by Disability Status among Healthcare Workers
affiliations: Rutgers University - School of Management and Labor Relations, Rutgers School of Management and Labor Relations - New Brunswick, Indiana University, Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey, Miami University and Rutgers University

detail.title: Work from Home and Job Satisfaction: Differences by Disability Status among Healthcare Workers
detail.abstract:
Background: Many workers with disabilities face negative stereotypical attitudes, pay gaps, and a lack of respect in the workplace, contributing to substantially lower job satisfaction compared to people without disabilities. Work from home may help to increase job satisfaction for people with disabilities.

Objective: This study analyzes how different measures of job satisfaction vary between people with and without disabilities, and the extent to which working from home moderates the relationship between disability and job satisfaction.

Methods: We use multivariable regression analysis to examine if the ability to work from home moderates the relationship between disability and indicators related to job satisfaction. The dataset draws on a novel survey of healthcare professionals.

Results: Results show that people with disabilities have relatively greater turnover intentions, lower sense of organizational commitment and support, weaker perceptions of openness and inclusion in the workplace, and worse relations with management and coworkers. Regressions indicate that working from home helps to improve most perceptions of work experiences but does so more for people without disabilities than for people with disabilities.

Conclusions: The findings suggest that (a) some accommodations typically viewed as exceptions to meet the needs of people with disabilities have even greater benefits for the workforce at large and (b) because workers with and without disabilities benefit from remote work, we cannot expect those accommodations to close the gaps caused by inequities.

title: Small Business Favoritism
affiliations: University of Pennsylvania - The Wharton School

detail.title: Small Business Favoritism
detail.abstract:
This Article offers the first comprehensive account of how federal law, in ways both conspicuous and obscure, systematically privileges small businesses. Small firms enjoy exclusive access to government grants and loans, preferential treatment in federal contracting, and exemptions from regulations that constrain their larger competitors. Agencies must consider their interests during rulemaking and, in some instances, subsidize their participation in that process. In total, as this Article documents for the first time, more than 1,300 statutory provisions explicitly confer legal advantages on small firms.

Despite the pervasiveness of these legal preferences, their scope and implications have largely escaped scholarly attention. Prevailing accounts tend to emphasize the supposed advantages of large firms in terms of political power and regulatory compliance costs. Yet when considered in the aggregate, these provisions constitute a regime of small business favoritism embedded in federal law. This Article argues that the costs of this regime--undermined statutory objectives, misallocated public resources, ossified regulatory processes, and inefficient firm sizes--are both significant and underappreciated. Meanwhile, some of the supposed benefits--creating jobs, promoting innovation, and correcting imbalances in political power--are highly contested.

These findings call for a fundamental reassessment of small-business favoritism in federal law. The Article concludes with a range of reform proposals, including the replacement of categorical exemptions with uniform standards, size-based regulatory tiers modeled on progressive taxation, or, for laws targeting negative externalities, production-based taxes calibrated to the size of the harm.

reference: Journal of Financial Regulation and Compliance
title: Geopolitical Shocks, Capital Outflows, Financial Inclusion and Digital Financial Inclusion

detail.title: Geopolitical Shocks, Capital Outflows, Financial Inclusion and Digital Financial Inclusion
detail.abstract: This study examines the effect of capital outflows, induced by geopolitical shocks, on financial inclusion and digital financial inclusion in emerging markets and developing economies. Several measures of financial inclusion and digital financial inclusion were analysed for 17 emerging markets and developing economies from 1999 to 2023. The data were estimated using the median quantile regression and generalized linear model regression methods. The findings reveal that capital outflows, induced by geopolitical shocks, have a negative effect on financial inclusion and digital financial inclusion. Greater capital outflows, induced by geopolitical shock, decrease the level of financial inclusion through a contraction in the number of commercial bank branches in emerging markets and developing economies. Also, greater capital outflows, induced by geopolitical shock, decrease the level of digital financial inclusion through a decrease in the number of people using the internet to access commercial bank branch services and automated teller machine services. Political stability, GDP growth, population growth, unemployment, tax revenue and regulatory quality are significant determinants of financial inclusion and digital financial inclusion. The social implication is that geopolitical shocks and capital outflows adversely affect society by limiting access to essential financial services. The managerial implication is that financial managers will constantly need to anticipate geopolitical risk, its effect on financial services and develop safeguards to cushion its effect on financial service providers and customers.

title: Disability, Job Satisfaction, and Workplace Accommodations: Evidence from the Healthcare Industry
affiliations: Rutgers University - School of Management and Labor Relations, Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey, Indiana University, Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey, Miami University and Rutgers University

detail.title: Disability, Job Satisfaction, and Workplace Accommodations: Evidence from the Healthcare Industry
detail.abstract:
Purpose. This paper examines the extent to which job satisfaction, requests for accommodations, and the likelihood of a request being granted vary by disability status. We further analyze whether being granted workplace accommodations moderates the relationship between work satisfaction and disability. 

Methods. We use a novel survey of healthcare workers centered on disability status, perceptions of work experiences, and the provision of accommodations. The data are used in a descriptive analysis and multiple regressions to examine the moderating effect of accommodations on the relationship between disability and indicators related to job satisfaction. 

Results. Results show that people with disabilities have more negative perceptions of their work experiences than people without disabilities. Although people with disabilities are more likely to request accommodations than people without disabilities, they are equally likely to have their requests wholly or partly granted. Regression results indicate that the negative relationships between disability status and most measures of work experience are largely eliminated when accounting for the disposition of accommodation requests. The main exception is turnover intentions, in which the adverse relationship with having a disability does not change even when an accommodation is granted. Partly granting accommodations is helpful only for some metrics of job experience. 

Conclusion. Our paper shows that fully granting accommodations can go a long way to closing the disability gap in job satisfaction between people with and without disabilities.

title: North Korea's Totalitarian Regime: A Comparative, Academic, and Popular Analysis

detail.title: North Korea's Totalitarian Regime: A Comparative, Academic, and Popular Analysis
detail.abstract: Since its foundation, North Korea has developed into one of the most extreme and resilient totalitarian states in modern history. Under the dynastic rule of the Kim family (Kim Il Sung → Kim Jong Il → Kim Jong Un), the regime enforces absolute obedience using a rigid ideological system, pervasive surveillance, propaganda, and brutal repression. This article examines North Korean totalitarianism across nine thematic categories-ideology & cult of personality; mass surveillance & repression; propaganda & censorship; political loyalty systems; social & economic control; everyday life and indoctrination; punishment & prisons; enforcement through militarization; and international response. It draws on UN reports, human-rights investigations, defector testimonies, and academic literature.

title: Equity and Security in the Smart City Era: A Dual-Framework Approach to U.S. Broadband Infrastructure

detail.title: Equity and Security in the Smart City Era: A Dual-Framework Approach to U.S. Broadband Infrastructure
detail.abstract:
Broadband internet access serves as the foundation of smart city development, enabling critical services such as traffic control, public safety, healthcare delivery, and digital civic engagement. As cities modernize their infrastructure, broadband is no longer a luxury; it has become essential public infrastructure. However, significant gaps persist in how broadband is deployed and secured, particularly for historically underserved populations (Turin et al., 2022; National Telecommunications and Information Administration [NTIA], 2022)

The Broadband Equity, Access, and Deployment (BEAD) program, enacted under the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA) in 2021, allocates $65 billion to expand high-speed internet across the United States (Office of Inspector General, n.d.). Despite its scale, early assessments of state implementation plans reveal inconsistent attention to digital equity and a weak integration of cybersecurity practices (Dine, 2024; Kumar et al., 2024). Without a cohesive framework, broadband investments may reinforce existing inequalities and leave smart city systems exposed to cybersecurity risks.

This proposal introduces a dual-framework model that combines the Digital Equity Lens with the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Risk Management Framework (RMF). This approach addresses both social inclusion and technical security throughout the broadband deployment lifecycle. The goal is to ensure that future smart city initiatives are equitable, secure, and sustainable from the outset.

title: Forecasting the International Cocoa Prices: A Model Selection Approach
affiliations: Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology, Kumasi, Ghana, Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology, Kumasi, Ghana, Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology, Kumasi, Ghana. and Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology, Kumasi, Ghana

detail.title: Forecasting the International Cocoa Prices: A Model Selection Approach
detail.abstract: Cocoa is a significant agricultural product and a major source of foreign exchange for several West African countries. However, the global market is influenced by its extreme price changes. The primary purpose of this study is to assess historical data and formulate a time series model to forecast future cocoa price levels, using monthly data obtained from the Bank of Ghana database website, covering the period from 1st January 2003 to 31st December 2022 comprising 240 observations. Four (4) univariate time series techniques Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA),Autoregresssive Fractionally Inte- grated Moving Average (ARFIMA),Exponential Smoothing (ETS), and Neural Network Autoregressive (NNAR) were employed to analyze historical international cocoa price data. Competing techniques were constructed for all four (4) techniques, and based on their information criteria the best technique was selected from each using a differencing order ’1’ for the Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA) and Neural Network Autoregressive (NNAR) methods and a differencing order ’0.498’ for the Autoregresssive Fractionally Integrated Moving Average (ARFIMA) models. These models Autoregres- sive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA) (0,1,1), Autoregresssive Fractionally Integrated Moving Average (ARFIMA) (1, 0.498,1),Exponential Smoothing (ETS) (M, A, N), and Neural Network Autoregressive (NNAR)(3,3) were found to be the best models from the constructed competing models with the lowest Akaike Information Criterion (AIC), Cor- rected Akaike Information Criterion (AICc), and Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC) values and Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Mean Abso- lute Squared Error (MASE) and Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) for the Neural Network Autoregressive (NNAR) models. These models forecast values were compared to choose the best-fitting model, using four (4) error metrics to calculate their accu- racy (Root Mean Squared Error(RMSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Mean Absolute Squared Error(MASE), and Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE)). Autoregresssive Fractionally Integrated Moving Average (ARFIMA) (1, 0.498, 1) was found to be the best fitting model due to its minimum error metrics value, Root Mean Squared Error(RMSE) with value 102.8925, Mean Absolute Error(MAE) with value 87.87030, Mean Absolute Squared Error(MASE) with value 0.24438 and Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) with value 3.55481. This study provides valuable insights into cocoa price forecasting, which can benefit producers, stakeholders, traders, and consumers in the cocoa market. Accurate forecasting can help improve the international cocoa market sector, optimizing supply chain management and making informed decisions. Finally, the predicted values indicated a steady decrease in the future international market cocoa price.

title: The Existence of Ghostly-Spirits: Debunking Paranormal Skepticism

detail.title: The Existence of Ghostly-Spirits: Debunking Paranormal Skepticism

declarations.funderStatement: Self-Funding research

detail.abstract: The debate on the existence of ghost in the human being world has been one of the ongoing controversies globally, especially based on a very ancient idea that a human body is separate from their soul, and when the body dies, the spirit can still live on nor remain trapped in the living world under certain circumstances. This research paper explores the existence of ghosts, aiming to compel the readers and making them aware of their potential reality based on historical accounts, eyewitness testimonies, and scientific inquiry. The study analyses a range of documented experiences, captured documentaries, cultural perspectives, and paranormal investigations to build a case for the credibility of ghost phenomena. Qualitative methods were primarily used, including the examination of secondhand interviews, case studies from paranormal researchers, and content analysis of reports from reputed researchers and organisations. Additionally, secondary data from scientific studies on electromagnetic fields, infrasound, and psychological responses were evaluated to support or challenge claims of ghostly encounters. The research findings reveal more about the factors or reasons behind the manifestation of ghostly spirits in the living world, the distinction between ghosts and spirits, the types of ghost hauntings, forms of ghosts and technology behind the detection of ghostly spirits. The findings suggest that while scepticism remains valid, there is compelling evidence that warrants further open-minded investigation into the paranormal: existence of ghosts.

title: Trump's 25% Tariff Shock: India Economic & Strategic Market Impact

detail.title: Trump's 25% Tariff Shock: India Economic & Strategic Market Impact
detail.abstract: In this report, we unpack the practical risks India could face, and the ways it might adapt, if the U.S. goes ahead with 25% tariff on Indian goods.Using a Monte Carlo simulation across five scenarios—from a minor negotiated compromise to a full-blown trade war—we try to capture the range of possible outcomes shaped by today’s shifting geopolitics. Our 10,000-run model suggests India could see a GDP hit of roughly –35 basis points in FY2026, a sharp (30%) drop in U.S.-bound exports, and rupee volatility touching the ₹87–90/USD range before gradually settling. The analysis spotlights electronics, textiles, and gems & jewelry as the sectors most at risk, putting 3.8 million jobs and $31.4 billion of annual trade in jeopardy. We also anticipate foreign investor outflows of as much as –$12 billion by March 2026. Drawing from these findings, we offer practical recommendations for policymakers (like scaling up export credit, fast-tracking FTAs) and for businesses (from currency hedging to supply chain diversification). Our goal is to give both government leaders and industry decision-makers the timely analysis and actionable ideas they need to weather volatility and strengthen India’s long-term position in global trade.

title: Online Learning Under Complex and Dynamic Changing Environments

detail.title: Online Learning Under Complex and Dynamic Changing Environments
detail.abstract: This paper presents novel algorithms for online optimization in complex and dynamic changing environment, especially those with non-convex, non-differentiable loss functions in non-stationary environments. The study covers complete information and bandit settings, focusing on sufficiently s-weakly convex functions and functions with α-homogeneity w.r.t the minimum. The proposed algorithms derive regret bounds considering the functions' continuity conditions. The techniques have potential applications in various domains, including time series analysis, finance, stock market analysis, supply chain management, healthcare, and energy management.

title: Enhancing Students' Self-Confidence and Critical Thinking Ability in Identifying Physical and Chemical Changes Using Technology-Assisted Constructivist Approaches
affiliations: Benue State University, Prince Abubakar Audu University, Anyigba Kogi State and University of Nigeria

detail.title: Enhancing Students' Self-Confidence and Critical Thinking Ability in Identifying Physical and Chemical Changes Using Technology-Assisted Constructivist Approaches
detail.abstract: Purpose: This study examined the effectiveness of technology-assisted constructivist approaches-namely, the Predict-Explain-Observe-Explain (PEOE) and Invitation-Exploration-Proposing Explanation-Taking Action (IEPT) models-in enhancing senior secondary students' self-confidence and critical thinking in identifying physical and chemical changes. Methodology: A quasi-experimental, non-randomized pre-test, post-test control group design was employed. Instruments used were the Physical and Chemical Changes Self-Confidence Scale (PCCSS) and the Critical Thinking Ability Test (CTAT), both validated by subject experts. The study population consisted of 5,543 SS1 Chemistry students in Dekina Local Government Area, Kogi State, Nigeria. A sample of 228 students from six schools was selected through multi-stage sampling. Four research questions and four null hypotheses guided the study. Data were analyzed using mean, standard deviation, and Analysis of Covariance (ANCOVA). Findings: Results indicated statistically significant differences in students' mean self-confidence and critical thinking scores across the PEOE, IEPT, and traditional discussion groups [F(2, 227) = 2325.074, p < .05; F(2, 227) = 209.004, p < .05]. However, no significant interaction effects were found between instructional method and gender on students' self-confidence or critical thinking scores [F(2, 227) = .085, p > .05; F(2, 227) = .225, p > .05]. Significance: The study concludes that technology-assisted constructivist strategies significantly improve students' cognitive and affective engagement in Chemistry. It is recommended that Chemistry educators integrate the PEOE and IEPT models to foster deeper understanding, self-confidence, and critical thinking in distinguishing between physical and chemical changes.

title: The Influence of Project Communication Planning Skills in Implementation of Water Projects in Kenya
affiliations: Jomo Kenyatta University of Agriculture and Technology, Jomo Kenyatta University of Agriculture and Technology - School of Business and Entrepreneurship and Jomo Kenyatta University of Agriculture and Technology

detail.title: The Influence of Project Communication Planning Skills in Implementation of Water Projects in Kenya

declarations.declarationOfInterest: There are no potential conflicts of interest present in this study

detail.abstract: This study is to determine the influence of communication planning Skills on implementation of water projects in Kenya. Communication accommodation theory was referred to and literature review was done. Descriptive survey research design adopted. The target population was from the eight water projects being implemented across the country and the accessible population was 1,675 staff members in the eight service boards in the country. Proportionate stratified random sampling technique was applied. Questionnaires based on a five-point Likert type scale were distributed through drop and pickup method for collection of primary data. Reliability of the instrument was measured using Cronbach alpha coefficient and the variable returned satisfactory scores above 0.7. Validity of the study constructs was done through factor analysis and results were significant. One hundred and seventy-four (174) questionnaires were distributed out of which one hundred and forty-four (144) were returned. The descriptive results showed a positive bearing on implementation of water projects, and the same applied to the moderating variable. A regression model was fitted to the data and it was found to be statistically significant. Communication planning explained 36.4% variation in implementation of water projects. There was Strong positive correlation between communication planning and implementation of water projects in Kenya. Concluded that communication planning, had a positive and significant influence on implementation of water projects in Kenya. Recommended that there should be regular communication between top management and project team members on project matters, for purposes of ensuring that all relevant information was disseminated in a timeous way.

title: Optimizing Consumer Credit Risk Models through Predictive Analytics

detail.title: Optimizing Consumer Credit Risk Models through Predictive Analytics

detail.abstract: The United States financial system is evolving rapidly as data science advances and the demand for more equitable credit access increases. Traditional credit models such as FICO remain a key benchmark, but they often fail to capture the full financial story of individuals who lack extensive credit histories. This paper examines how predictive analytics and modern data techniques can strengthen credit risk modeling, improve approval accuracy, and expand access to credit. Based on firsthand experience with projects at Bread Financial, a public company known for its focus on consumer lending, the paper highlights how practical applications of modeling and analytics can lead to better credit portfolio outcomes. These innovations support business outcomes and align with national goals related to financial inclusion, economic mobility, and responsible innovation.

title: The Influence of Work-life Balance on the Commitment of Female Employees in the IT sector in India
affiliations: IBMR, IPS Academy and IBMR, IPS Academy

detail.title: The Influence of Work-life Balance on the Commitment of Female Employees in the IT sector in India
detail.abstract: "This article investigates how work-life balance factors influence employee commitment in the IT sector."The study employs Exploratory Factor Analysis (EFA) on a sample of 480 respondents from IT companies in Bangalore, condensing 16 work-life balance statements into five key attributes. The proposed model explores how these work-life balance attributes influence employee commitment in the IT sector. The findings reveal that factors such as the working environment, decision-making power, personal role, work support, and conflicts with colleagues significantly affect employee commitment in this sector. As a result, HR managers in IT companies should prioritize these factors to enhance employee commitment. Through multiple linear regression analysis, the study further highlights that factors such as the working environment, decision-making authority, personal role, work support, and conflicts with colleagues significantly influence employee commitment within the IT sector.

title: A Keynesian Intertemporal Synthesis (KIS) Model: Towards a Unified and Empirically Grounded Framework for Fiscal Policy

detail.title: A Keynesian Intertemporal Synthesis (KIS) Model: Towards a Unified and Empirically Grounded Framework for Fiscal Policy
detail.abstract: This paper develops a new generation of the Keynesian Intertemporal Synthesis (KIS) Model, a macroeconomic framework designed to reconcile the empirical strengths of the Post-Keynesian (PK) and New Keynesian (NK) traditions. The central innovation of this work is the abandonment of the traditional Cobb-Douglas production function in favor of a Constant Elasticity of Substitution (CES) specification. This modification is directly motivated by the compelling evidence from the meta-analysis by Gechert et al. (2021), which emphatically rejects the hypothesis of a unit elasticity of substitution between capital and labor. We integrate this finding with the conclusions from a wide range of meta-analyses on the statedependent heterogeneity of fiscal multipliers (Gechert and Rannenberg, 2018), the productivity of public capital (Bom and Ligthart, 2014), the effectiveness hierarchy of spending instruments (Gechert, 2015), and the empirical failure of Ricardian Equivalence (Stanley, 1998). The resulting KIS-CES model, while based on intertemporal optimization, incorporates household heterogeneity, non-standard preferences that value wealth and penalize debt, and a monetary policy constrained by the zero lower bound. The mathematical derivations reveal that the elasticity of substitution, calibrated to an empirically plausible value of σ < 1, becomes a key parameter that modulates income distribution and magnifies the crowding-in effect of public investment. The model generates an endogenous MPC, a nonlinear fiscal multiplier that increases dramatically in crises, and a multiplier for public investment that is structurally higher than that for consumption, thus offering a unified, rigorous, and, above all, empirically disciplined theoretical framework.

title: Socio-Economic Status, Truancy, Learning Styles, Peer Pressure and Gender as Correlates of Undergraduate Students' Academic Performance in Taraba State University Jalingo, Nigeria
affiliations: Taraba State University and Benue State University

detail.title: Socio-Economic Status, Truancy, Learning Styles, Peer Pressure and Gender as Correlates of Undergraduate Students' Academic Performance in Taraba State University Jalingo, Nigeria

keywords: Peer Pressure and Gender and undergraduate Students’ Academic Performance

detail.abstract: The study investigated socioeconomic status, truancy, learning styles, peer pressure and gender as correlates of undergraduate students' academic performance in Taraba State University (TSU), Jalingo, Nigeria. The study adopted correlational research design. The sample of this study was made up 150 undergraduate students of faculty of Education TSU was selected using multistage sampling techniques. The instruments used for data collection were socioeconomic status, truancy, learning styles, peer pressure and gender questionnaire (STLPGQ) and CGPA of undergraduate school in faculty of education, TSU for 2018/2019 session. STLPGQ was validated by three experts in education related disciplines and one expert in measurement and evaluation. STLPGQ was trial tested which yielded the reliability coefficient of 0.89 using Cronbach Alpha. Five research questions raised in the study were answered using multiple regression analysis while the five null hypotheses formulated in the study were tested using ANOVA of regression analysis. The study revealed among other that there is no significant relationship between socioeconomic status and undergraduate students academic performance in TSU, Jalingo [F1, 133 = 6.331; p>0.05]. There is significant relationship between truancy and undergraduate students academic performance [F1, 133 = 18.090; p<0.05]. There is no significant relationship between learning styles and undergraduate students academic performance [F1, 133 = 17.009; p>0.05]. There is significant relationship between peer pressure and undergraduate students academic performance [F1, 133= 19.119; p<0.05]. There is no significant relationship between gender and undergraduate students academic performance [F1, 133 = 10.319; p>0.05]. It was recommended among that, educational administrators and lecturers should set up disciplinary measures to reduce truancy and peer pressure. Parents should help in proper monitoring of undergraduate student activities curb truancy and peer pressure in order to enhance academic performance of students in TSU, Jalingo.

title: Strategic us Energy Market Insights: A Data-Driven Analysis of U.S. Fuel Consumption, Pricing Trends, and the Rise of Electric Vehicles
affiliations: Wright State University, Wright State University and Wright State University

detail.title: Strategic us Energy Market Insights: A Data-Driven Analysis of U.S. Fuel Consumption, Pricing Trends, and the Rise of Electric Vehicles

publicationDetails.detailsText: American Journal of Interdisciplinary Studies, volume 06, issue 01, 2025[10.63125/6bka3w37]

detail.abstract: This project explores the evolving landscape of the U.S. energy market with a focus on identifying strategic growth opportunities within the fuel distribution sector. Due to the limited availability of proprietary or company-specific data and the fragmented nature of regional market operations, a comprehensive analysis based solely on internal business metrics was not feasible. As a result, the study relied extensively on publicly accessible datasets from the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA), covering the period from 1983 through September 2024. While these datasets offered significant historical breadth, they also posed challenges such as missing values, inconsistent formatting, and incomplete time series, requiring substantial preprocessing and data transformation using Microsoft Excel. Following the data cleaning process, Python was employed to conduct sector-wise analytics and generate time-series forecasts for the years 2025 and 2026. To enhance interpretability and support insight communication, Tableau was used to create a series of interactive and static visualizations. These visualizations illustrated energy consumption and pricing patterns across key sectors, including residential, commercial, industrial, and transportation. One of the study's central observations was the consistent decline in gasoline and oil consumption in recent years. However, the precise drivers behind these trends could not be fully isolated, as the dataset lacked essential variables such as inflation adjustments, technological innovation indicators, and energy efficiency metrics. This limitation restricted the analysis from reaching definitive conclusions on behavioral or macroeconomic influences. Nevertheless, the study delivered key insights such as the dominant role of the transportation sector in oil consumption, the observable impact of electric vehicle (EV) adoption on traditional fuel demand, and region-specific pricing fluctuations. These findings support strategic initiatives such as expanding infrastructure investment into alternative fuel options, aligning pricing strategies with seasonal demand cycles, and focusing on high-consumption geographic markets. Although constrained by data scope and granularity, the project offers a robust, datadriven perspective on contemporary U.S. energy market dynamics and informs strategic decision-making in an industry facing structural transition.

title: Impact of Implicit Government Guarantees on Auditor Choice: Evidence from Chinese SOE Defaults
affiliations: Shenzhen University, Central University of Finance and Economics (CUFE) - School of Accountancy, Central University of Finance and Economics (CUFE) - School of Accountancy, Central University of Finance and Economics (CUFE) - School of Accountancy and Guangdong University of Foreign Studies - School of Accounting

detail.title: Impact of Implicit Government Guarantees on Auditor Choice: Evidence from Chinese SOE Defaults
detail.abstract: This study exploits the first bond default event of Chinese state-owned enterprises (SOEs) to examine whether and how the decline in implicit government guarantee (IGG) affects firms’ auditor choices. Our results show that the decline in IGG following an SOE’s bond default leads to a higher tendency for SOEs to engage Big 10 or industry expert auditors. Mechanism tests indicate that SOEs facing greater financial constraints have a higher incentive to engage a higher-quality auditor. Our cross-sectional analyses suggest that the main results are more pronounced when SOEs are bond-issuing firms, when they are in regions with lower bank competition, and when they are more important clients to original auditors. Among high-quality auditors, SOEs tend to hire domestic audit firms. At the same time, both central SOEs and local SOEs demonstrate a demand for high-quality auditors following a decline in the IGG, and SOEs located in regions with stronger government fiscal support are more likely to engage high-quality auditors. Moreover, following the decline in IGG, SOEs that hire high-quality auditors can secure stronger bond financing capacity.

detail.abstract:
In today's characteristically unstable era, marked by heightened volatility, uncertainty, complexity, and ambiguity (VUCA), national security has become an increasingly intricate domain that demands innovative, contemporary approaches. This article examines the importance of integrating artificial intelligence (AI) into national security strategies, particularly for enhancing adaptability and managing risk. Countries that harness AI's capabilities for risk management are better equipped to address the myriad challenges posed by global instability and can respond to them promptly and effectively. 
Amid complex geopolitical dynamics, globalisation and the persistence of hybrid and active warfare, the nexus between national security and economic stability has acquired unprecedented significance alongside the growing importance of AI methodologies in achieving it. This paper examines national security in times of instability and proposes an AI-enabled adaptation and risk-management strategy based on an economic-mathematical model. Our study highlights how economic vulnerability can compromise national security and how strategic economic policy can enhance security measures, as well as how AI capabilities should be tailored for effective risk management.
The research highlights innovative avenues for integrating economic and security policy through proactive economic diversification, investment in critical infrastructure and the cultivation of strategic international partnerships. Data from the G7 nations, Ukraine, Israel, Iran and Syria over the past fifteen years were analysed, and an economic–mathematical model of AI’s impact on national security was constructed. This model underpins the strategy “National Security in Conditions of Instability: Adaptation and Risk Management Using AI”, enabling a holistic approach that views economic viability as a fundamental component of national resilience.

title: Entrepreneurship as a Catalyst for Innovation: The Role of Opportunity Recognition and Contextual Influence
affiliations: University of the West of Scotland

detail.title: Entrepreneurship as a Catalyst for Innovation: The Role of Opportunity Recognition and Contextual Influence
detail.abstract: The paper explores the complex interplay between innovation and entrepreneurship, noting that the capacity to identify opportunities and on the other hand exploit the opportunities, is among the key drivers of success in entrepreneurship. It combines both theoretical and empirical research to describe how entrepreneurial actions are both facilitated and inhibited by environmental and contextual conditions. The interdependence between innovation, entrepreneurship, and external ecosystems is demonstrated at the international level reflecting the innovativeness of such companies as Tesla, Netflix, Walmart, and Starbucks. The discussion summarizes that creativity and initiative are not enough in the case of entrepreneurs who need to learn to adjust and utilize the contextual environment surrounding them.

title: Digital Public Relations: A Leading and Cost-Effective Channel for Public Awareness in the Public Sector

detail.title: Digital Public Relations: A Leading and Cost-Effective Channel for Public Awareness in the Public Sector
detail.abstract: This article examines the pivotal role of digital Public Relations (PR) as a primary and highly cost-effective channel for achieving public awareness, particularly within governmental, regulatory, environmental, and health organizations. The paper outlines digital PR as the online evolution of traditional PR, emphasizing its strategic application across diverse digital platforms, including websites, social media, and Web 2.0 channels. A central argument advanced is that consistent publishing of online content through digital PR activities represents the most economical method for cultivating widespread public awareness and attention. Furthermore, the analysis explores the crucial complementary function of digital PR, demonstrating how exposure through traditional mass communication channels often motivates individuals to seek additional information online, thereby reinforcing the overall impact of integrated campaigns.

title: Unveiling the Essence of School Leadership Styles: A Transcendental Phenomenological Investigation of Principals' Lived Experiences
affiliations: Al Sharqyia School , New Era University, New Era University and New Era University

detail.title: Unveiling the Essence of School Leadership Styles: A Transcendental Phenomenological Investigation of Principals' Lived Experiences
detail.abstract: School leadership is crucial for the success of educational institutions. While governments invest significantly in education to promote sustainable development and quality, many schools still fall short of the desired standards, highlighting concerns about the role of leadership in ensuring institutional effectiveness. This transcendental phenomenological study investigated the lived experiences of school principals to uncover the essence of their leadership styles and their perceived impact on educational environments. Using qualitative interviews and thematic analysis, the study addressed three core dimensions: principals' conceptualizations of leadership, their enacted practices, and their perceived influence on school climate, culture, and student outcomes. Findings revealed six key themes: adaptive and dynamic leadership; communication, collaboration, and inclusivity; positive school climate and work culture; monitoring academic outcomes and continuous improvement; personal and professional development; and authenticity and role models. Principals perceive leadership as inherently adaptive, distributed, and dynamic, emphasizing flexibility and shared responsibility. In practice, they prioritized communication, collaboration, and inclusivity to engage stakeholders, fostering positive school climates and cohesive cultures. Principals viewed their leadership as instrumental in driving student success through data-informed decision-making, continuous improvement, and staff development. Authenticity emerged as central to their identity, with principals serving as ethical role models to inspire trust and accountability. The study highlights how responsive, relational, and valuesdriven leadership cultivates environments that support institutional growth and student achievement. Practical implications call for leadership training programs and policies integrating these holistic strategies, bridging managerial efficiency with human-centered approaches. By capturing principals' experiential insights, this study advances a nuanced understanding of how intentional leadership styles transcend conventional paradigms to shape thriving educational ecosystems.

detail.abstract:
Viksit Bharat, one of the strongest slogans spelled out by the leader of the day is an inclusive notion that requires India to
achieve healthy and concrete development in every sector for which, the education sector is the foundation that channelizes
trained and permanent resources to every sector. Therefore, achieving the targets of Viksit Bharat without making the education sector a Viksit domain is impossible. Therefore, a paper titled “Empowering Education with AI to Reach Development Milestones in Viksit Bharat- A study on higher education institutions at Hyderabad” is proposed to examine whether modern technologies like Artificial intelligence (AI) can aid the education sector to make the diction of Viksit Bharat, a reality. The study has surveyed faculty members at higher education institutions in Hyderabad to determine the ground reality of the benefits of implementing AI in teaching practices. It also examined the feasibility of replacing traditional teaching/learning strategies with AI technology in improving classroom teaching. It illuminates that how AI- based evaluation methodologies help teacher in the assessment of individual student’s learning skills. It concludes that AI cannot be set aside in designing the modern teaching methods that turn India into Viksit Bharat.
