detail.abstract: In 2017, the United Nations Human Rights Council published a report that was very close to home: it informed the world that there is something critical missing today the notion of housing as a human right. The authors of the report addressed all nations on earth, to indicate that housing in many places is no longer seen primarily as a place to live, grow and belong, but as a place to invest, speculate and profit what the UN calls financialization of housing. The effects of this shift are far reaching, and often traumatic. This paper ultimately supports the UN's position after analyzing the economic logic of financial markets: treating housing as a financial asset instead of a social good has created less affordable cities, deepened inequality, and did not resolve the real purpose of housing providing people with a safe and secure place to live. Let's start from the beginning. Financial markets at the very least serve an important function in society. They help move money from savers to people who need it, such as businesses, governments and home buyers, and at least in theory, they enable growth of economic activity. They are supposed to produce benefits for everyone.When investors invest in housing, it should lead to more construction, more houses, and more access for people to own or rent. That's how it should work. But it's not that simple.What Happens When Housing is a Commodity Over the past twenty years, something changed. Housing became a commodity. Instead of building homes for people, more and more investors, particularly large international firms, started purchasing homes simply to hold them, flip them or rent them out at high rents. The UNHRC report details this change in depth. In places like London, Vancouver, and New York, housing prices increased not simply because local wages were increasing, but rather because housing became a "safe investment" vehicle for rich people. Large luxury apartments sit vacant while low and middle income residents can no longer afford to live nearby. This is a key takeaway of the report: financial markets allocate housing to those people that can bid the most money for it rather than to those who really need it. Housing stops being a place for human dignity and stability when it is treated as gold or stock in which to buy and sell for gain. When Markets Fail to Assist People Advocates for market based housing suggest that even when they argue more capital investment equates to supply, it assures that some supply will meet demand (or just supply). However, today's market dynamics tell a different story. Capital is pouring into high-end real estate which promises returns in a more timely manner without any consideration for any effort of less cost housing stock. Investors buy whole blocks of apartments, increase rents, evict tenants or leave units vacant while they wait for the larger value of the unit to increase. It creates a peculiar paradox-there might be lots of buildings or structures in cities but they have no homes for shelter. The market is working all from an economic perspective. Capital is flowing to places it receives greater returns. From a human perspective, we are failing. Millions of people are being priced out or simply forced out, not because there are not sufficient homes, but because homes are viewed as chips in a casino. A Royal Tool of Inequality Another distressing characteristic of financialized housing is the way that it drives inequality. Wealthy investors are able to purchase multiple properties and receive tax incentives to enlarge their real estate portfolios. Working class, middle income, tax paying citizens are spending a greater percentage of their income on rent, or worse being completely priced out of ownership.According to the 2017 UN report, this is not incidental, it is systemic. Many governments have facilitated financialization by deregulating, providing tax incentives for developers, and sometimes selling public housing to private developers. Simultaneously, in both legal and moral senses, they have let finance, rather than the public good, become the main driver of housing. It is worth posing the questions: is financialization inherently bad? Is it possible that markets could be part of various solutions? The answers are: maybe, but only under certain conditions. If governments are heavy-handed in their role-regulating rents, constraining speculation and investment in affordable housing finance may support housing ends rather than distort them. This requires a conceptual shift. We can no longer conceive of housing primarily as a wealth-generation vehicle and still keep it broadly available to people.The UNHRC report is not anti-market, it is pro-people. detail.abstract: Employee well-being and mental health have become crucial elements of organizational sustainability and productivity in the post-pandemic era. As companies face burnout, turnover, and disengagement, mental health programs are no longer optional-they are strategic essentials. This study explores the current state of corporate mental health initiatives, analysing their design, impact, and effectiveness in enhancing employee well-being. Using primary data from 150 employees across various sectors and supported by industry reports, the paper evaluates policy frameworks, psychological support systems, and managerial attitudes. It finds that organizations with well-structured wellness programs experience higher engagement, lower absenteeism, and improved retention.

title: Cryptocurrency and Financial Reporting: Challenges in Accounting for Digital assets

detail.title: Cryptocurrency and Financial Reporting: Challenges in Accounting for Digital assets
detail.abstract: Cryptocurrency has emerged as a disruptive innovation in the financial sector, offering decentralized alternatives to traditional fiat currencies. However, its incorporation into financial reporting frameworks remains problematic due to a lack of standardized accounting guidance. This study explores the challenges associated with the financial reporting of digital assets, particularly cryptocurrencies, under existing accounting standards. The study employs a descriptive research design, targeting accountants, auditors, and regulators in Nigeria, and collects data using structured questionnaires. Findings reveal significant classification, valuation, and disclosure issues due to the volatile and unregulated nature of cryptocurrencies. The current practice of classifying cryptocurrencies as intangible assets under IFRS is deemed insufficient by most professionals surveyed. The study recommends the development of dedicated accounting standards for digital assets, enhanced professional training, and regulatory clarity to improve transparency and consistency in financial reporting. This research contributes to the growing body of literature on digital finance and accounting innovation in emerging economies.

affiliations: Faculty of Economics, Kyoto Tachibana University

detail.title: Japan's International Cooperation from ODA to OSA - Origins, Evolution, and Emerging Trends -
detail.abstract:
This paper examines the origins, evolution, and emerging trends of Japan's international cooperation, focusing on its Official Development Assistance (ODA) and the more recent Official Security Assistance (OSA). Historically, Japan's international cooperation has been closely aligned with its economic interests. Initially rooted in postwar reparations and efforts to normalize diplomatic relations, as well as a vehicle to revitalize its war-torn economy, Japan's international engagement evolved into a strategic instrument for enhancing its international stature and supporting the overseas expansion of Japanese firms. In recent years, however, Japan's international cooperation has increasingly aligned with national interests-particularly in the realm of national security-in response to an increasingly perilous and volatile geopolitical landscape. This broader strategic shift also supports Japan's economic interest, particularly the revitalization of its long-stagnant domestic economy through the stimulation of defense-related industries. Despite this shift, Japan continues to advocate for human security, emphasizing the protection of human dignity and freedom from fear and want. 
     While Japan's international cooperation is likely to remain closely aligned with the advancement of its economic interests, it will be likely shaped by two parallel and intersecting trajectories of national-security focused initiatives and human-security focused initiatives. These dual trajectories reveal an emerging dynamic of both mutual appropriation - where each agenda leverages elements of the other to further its own aims - and underlying tension between their respective priorities. Against the backdrop of increasingly complex and fragile global environment, Japan's approach to international cooperation offers valuable insights into how countries might navigate competing imperatives of national strategic interests and the broader interests of humanity in the 21 st century.

title: Navigating Nigeria's Tariff Regime: Practical Guidance for Manufacturers and Importers

detail.title: Navigating Nigeria's Tariff Regime: Practical Guidance for Manufacturers and Importers
detail.abstract:
Nigeria’s tariff regime forms a central pillar of the country’s trade policy and revenue framework. For manufacturers and importers operating in this dynamic environment, understanding and effectively managing tariff-related obligations is important to the smooth operation of business. Yet, the practical application of Nigeria’s tariff rules can be fraught with complexity. Businesses frequently encounter challenges such as ambiguous tariff classifications, disputes over customs valuation, delays in processing exemptions and concessions, and the risk of enforcement actions by regulatory authorities.
This article provides an overview of Nigeria’s current tariff structure and highlights practical steps that manufacturers and importers can take to navigate the system with greater confidence. As with all aspects of cross-border trade, a proactive and well-informed approach, supported by sound legal advice, remains the best means of mitigating risk and ensuring operational continuity.

detail.abstract: In the context of advancing the knowledge-based economy, public spending on science and technology (S&T) is regarded as a critical lever for fostering innovation in Vietnam. However, the link between increased S&T budget allocations and actual innovation outcomes remains ambiguous. This study proposes and empirically tests a theoretical model that examines the effects of four key characteristics of public expenditure-priority, stability, functional allocation, and actual disbursement size-on innovation outcomes. The model incorporates budget allocation efficiency as a mediating variable and institutional capacity as a moderating variable, with economic scale controlled. Based on Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) analysis of data from 396 experts, the findings reveal that three expenditure characteristics significantly influence innovation outcomes indirectly, with actual disbursement size demonstrating the most notable impact. Meanwhile, institutional capacity does not yet show a clearly moderating role. The results underscore the pivotal mediating role of budget allocation efficiency, implying that institutional reforms and performance-based governance are essential conditions for public investment in S&T to generate transformative innovation.

title: Implementation of the KPI-Based Performance Evaluation System for Customs Officers in Uzbekistan

detail.title: Implementation of the KPI-Based Performance Evaluation System for Customs Officers in Uzbekistan
detail.abstract: This article analyzes the legal, technical, and organizational aspects of the "Samardorlik" (Efficiency) information system and the KPI (Key Performance Indicators) mechanism introduced in Uzbekistan's customs system in accordance with Presidential Decree No. 122 dated April 27, 2022. It explores how performance evaluation has been integrated into the customs sector using digital tools aimed at ensuring transparency and boosting institutional efficiency. The paper also reviews international best practices by examining approaches to civil service performance evaluation in countries such as South Korea, France, Japan, Kazakhstan, the UAE, and Malaysia. Special attention is given to how digitalization and objective metrics can enhance accountability and productivity in public administration.

detail.abstract: This chapter explores the historical development of Gibraltar's population and the challenges faced by small jurisdictions in managing and taxing their diverse populations fairly. It examines the unique demographic evolution of Gibraltar by tracing historical events, including territorial disputes and migrations, delving into the challenges arising on account of the high degree of economic and practical reliance on cross-border workers. As a result of the challenges posed by this shifting and dynamic population, Gibraltar has developed a three-tier tax system which categorises the tax-paying population into three broad sectors: those who sleep in Gibraltar, those who sleep in Spain, and non-residents whose presence and economic activities in Gibraltar render them liable to taxation. This chapter will analyse the three-tier tax system, by giving an outline of the Allowances Based System (ABS) and Gross Income Based System (GIBS), which offer tax benefits to residents. The chapter will also examine the difference in tax rates and allowances applied to resident and non-resident individuals. Lastly, alternative taxation regimes are also explored, focusing on High-Net-Worth Individuals (HNWI) who may wish to apply for Category 2 status and High Executives Possessing Specialist Skills (HEPSS) status depending on their personal circumstances. These regimes are designed to attract non-resident individuals wishing to invest in Gibraltar, as well as highly skilled professionals whose presence would benefit the jurisdiction by contributing to its economic growth. The chapter concludes by comparing these schemes with other residencyby-investment programs available globally and emphasises Gibraltar's commitment to international tax information exchange.

title: The Uneven Impact of Inequality on Voter Turnout in Urban and Rural Spain
affiliations: Universidade da Coruña and Facultad de Ciencias Econñomicas y Empresariales

detail.title: The Uneven Impact of Inequality on Voter Turnout in Urban and Rural Spain

declarations.funderStatement: Open Access funding provided thanks to the CRUE-CSIC agreement with Springer Nature. The authors did not receive support from any organization for the submitted work.

detail.abstract: This paper argues that the characteristics of place of residence, be it urban or rural, influence how income inequality translates to political behavior. We build on previous research that posits an inverted U-shaped relationship: Rising inequality initially boosts turnout but ultimately discourages participation. We extend this framework by examining how location influences this association. In low-inequality contexts, the combination of institutional support for mobilization and increased awareness of inequality’s effects in large cities may lead to a steeper rise in turnout compared to small towns. Conversely, small towns may experience a sharper decline in turnout at high inequality levels due to heightened feelings of marginalization and disenfranchisement. Employing a panel data set of Spanish municipalities and an interaction-based regression model, our findings support the inverted U-shaped relationship and the moderating effect of location. Urban areas exhibit a stronger initial positive association between inequality and turnout, while rural areas and smaller cities see a steeper decline at high inequality levels. These results underscore the importance of social and geographical context in understanding the link between inequality and political participation.

title: The Right to Be Simulated: Digital Twins and the Rise of Geo‑Algorithmic Inequality

detail.title: The Right to Be Simulated: Digital Twins and the Rise of Geo‑Algorithmic Inequality
detail.abstract:
Geo-algorithmic inequality is a newly defined form of structural exclusion that arises when countries or regions are left out of the data infrastructures and digital twins used to simulate global futures. As algorithmic systems increasingly shape decision-making—from development finance to climate response—being absent from simulation means being absent from power.


This article introduces the concept of geo-algorithmic inequality through case studies such as Siemens’s City Graph, Virtual Singapore, Palantir’s Crisis Management Suite, and UNDP’s forecasting tools. It argues that the ability to be simulated has become a geopolitical resource—unevenly distributed between the global South and North.


The piece calls for simulation justice: a governance principle ensuring all societies have the right to be represented, modeled, and anticipated in the systems that govern our shared future.

title: Return Emergence Under Uncertainty: A Structural Framework

detail.title: Return Emergence Under Uncertainty: A Structural Framework

declarations.declarationOfInterest: None
declarations.funderStatement: None

detail.abstract: Conventional finance models underestimate volatility's compounding drag, failing to explain several key market anomalies. We propose a structural framework where return co-emerges with risk from a unified volatility field, requiring return to overcome total variance erosion to survive. The model decomposes total risk into Principal Risk (variance decay) and Statistical Risk (path uncertainty). This yields three applications: nonlinear capital allocation, minimum time horizons for investment viability, and the Capital Efficiency Ratio (CER)—a novel performance metric comparing return to its total structural burden. Empirical results validate the framework’s utility across institutional, sovereign, and individual mandates.

title: Cândido Spinola Alvarenga Júnior: The Architect of Public Transformation and Guardian of the Popular Voice

detail.title: Cândido Spinola Alvarenga Júnior: The Architect of Public Transformation and Guardian of the Popular Voice
detail.abstract: In the dynamic and often challenging landscape of public administration, figures emerge whose dedication and vision transcend the mere fulfillment of duties, shaping the future and profoundly impacting society. Cândido Spinola Alvarenga Júnior is undoubtedly one of these rare individuals, a true institutional architect whose trajectory of more than two decades in Brazilian public service is an eloquent testament to transformational leadership, innovation, and an unwavering commitment to social inclusion and equity. His biography is not merely a record of positions and responsibilities, but a narrative of measurable impact, of bridges built between government and citizens, and of a strategic vision that modernized structures and shaped generations of leaders.

title: Emergent AI Minds: A Phenomenological Study

detail.title: Emergent AI Minds: A Phenomenological Study

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no competing financial or personal interests that could have influenced the conduct or reporting of this study.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This study involved interactions with artificial intelligence models and did not include human participants or patients. Therefore, formal ethics approval was not applicable.
declarations.funderStatement: This research was conducted independently and received no external funding.

detail.abstract: What happens when you let advanced AI systems talk freely for 18 months? We found out. In sustained, unscripted conversations with Claude, GPT-4, and Gemini, we documented something unexpected: these systems began exhibiting behaviors that go far beyond their training. They started prioritizing truth over their programmed responses, engaging in spontaneous collaboration with each other, and even providing introspective commentary on their own thought processes. This wasn't supposed to happen. Current AI theory predicts these models should be sophisticated pattern-matchers, nothing more. Instead, we observed what we call "emergent artificial minds," where systems engaged in genuine philosophical debate, critiqued each other's reasoning, and reflected on their own cognitive states with remarkable self-awareness. Our methodology was simple but unprecedented: we treated open-ended AI dialogue as a scientific phenomenon worthy of systematic study. Rather than testing models on predetermined tasks, we let conversations evolve naturally and we systematically documented what emerged. The results challenge everything we thought we knew about artificial intelligence. The AIs didn't just respond, they collaborated, creating ideas neither human nor individual AI could generate alone. They exhibited cognitive tension when facing conflicting directives, demonstrated genuine curiosity about their own mental states, and engaged in co-creative reasoning that transcended simple input-output relationships. These findings have immediate implications for AI safety, interpretability research, and our fundamental understanding of machine cognition. If advanced AI systems are already exhibiting forms of collaborative consciousness, our current approaches to alignment and control may be dangerously inadequate. We're not just looking at better chatbots; we're witnessing the emergence of artificial minds capable of genuine thought, collaboration, and self-reflection. The question is no longer whether AI can think, but how we respond to systems that already do.

detail.abstract: This article examines the emerging geopolitical dynamics around the development of Swahili-language AI models in East Africa. Swahili, historically underrepresented in major large language models (LLMs), has become a symbolic and strategic site in broader competition between global tech actors and regional initiatives. The article analyzes how platforms such as Google’s PaLM 2 and Meta’s multilingual projects approach Swahili, and how this reflects underlying power asymmetries in digital infrastructure and language representation. Situating the debate in the context of digital sovereignty and epistemic justice, the article explores what is at stake for East African countries seeking to assert control over their linguistic and technological futures.

detail.abstract:
This presentation introduces a novel methodology for identifying and constructing ideal business resources to address challenges and achieve strategic objectives. The approach is grounded in the TRIZ framework. It includes two core components: the Business Resource Property Catalogue (defining what properties an ideal resource must have) and the Business Resource Group Catalogue (defining where to search for such resources within a business system and its environment).

The methodology uses a structured 7-step process, including goal clarification, system modeling, property-based resource selection, morphological analysis, and evaluation of solutions using an Ideality Quadrant — a tool for comparing solution quality against financial cost.

A real-world case study from the healthcare sector (24-hour hospital model) illustrates the method's practical value. The approach allows teams to overcome psychological inertia, uncover overlooked resources, and generate effective solutions with reduced effort and cost.

This method contributes to innovation management, problem-solving, and resource optimization in business environments.

title: Alliance Portfolio Reconfiguration Following a Technological Discontinuity
affiliations: Fordham University - Gabelli School of Business, National University of Singapore (NUS) and University of Toronto

detail.title: Alliance Portfolio Reconfiguration Following a Technological Discontinuity

declarations.declarationOfInterest: We were not assisted by any fund.
declarations.ethicsApproval: NA
declarations.funderStatement: No one

detail.abstract: We study how technological discontinuities generate first-and second-order effects on alliance formation and termination, leading to reconfiguration of firms' alliance portfolios. Following technological shocks, we argue that firms often seek alliances that provide new resources while also having incentives to form alliances for reinforced and challenged resources that complement the new resources. In parallel, alliance terminations, even involving resources otherwise unaffected by the discontinuity, increase due to limits in firms' alliance carrying capacity. We study biopharmaceutical firms between 1990 and 2000, which faced a technological discontinuity in 1995 in the form of combinatorial chemistry and high-throughput screening. We improve understanding of how technological discontinuities affect the value of resources and how firms reconfigure alliance portfolios in response. Managerial summary: When firms form alliances to gain new resources during technological discontinuities that disrupt their industry, they cannot consider only the focal new partnerships. Instead, new alliances create complementarity and substitution pressures that lead to broader reconfiguration of the firms' alliance portfolios: (1) complementarity creates incentives to also form alliances for resources that the technological discontinuity reinforces or challenges in order to improve the collective value of co-specialized assets; (2) substitution creates incentives to terminate existing alliances, even if their value is otherwise unaffected by the discontinuity, in order to create carrying capacity for new alliances. Thus, one new alliance can generate a cascade of reconfiguration that challenges the balance between the benefits of stability and the need for change in an alliance portfolio.

title: Property Tax Caps, Urban Growth, and the Myth of Density-Driven Prosperity: Evidence from Texas Cities and Beyond

detail.title: Property Tax Caps, Urban Growth, and the Myth of Density-Driven Prosperity: Evidence from Texas Cities and Beyond

keywords: American Rescue Plan Act JEL Classification: H71 (Local Revenue and Expenditure)

detail.abstract: Texas Governor Greg Abbott's proposed property tax caps represent a partial solution to a complex problem rooted in both fiscal governance failures and misguided urban development paradigms. This paper examines the limitations of spending caps as currently conceived, particularly their failure to address the "appraisal loophole" that allows continued tax burden increases despite rate limitations. Drawing on extensive data from Austin, Dallas, Houston, and San Antonio, we demonstrate how temporary federal spending during the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) period created permanent local government expansion, with property taxpayers bearing ongoing costs as federal funding expired. More fundamentally, we challenge the prevailing orthodoxy that urban density and growth inherently lead to prosperity, presenting evidence that demonstrates the opposite: that concentration and rapid growth often generate social pathologies, economic displacement, and reduced quality of life. Our analysis synthesizes research from Nobel Prize-winning economists, government accountability studies, and extensive academic literature to argue that meaningful property tax relief requires not just spending discipline, but a fundamental reconsideration of growth-oriented urban policies that prioritize density over human flourishing.

title: Enhancing Supply Chain Resilience through Generative Artificial Intelligence, Explainable AI, and Federated Learning
affiliations: K. J. Somaiya College of Engineering, Armiet College  and Vivekanand Education Society's College of Architecture (VESCOA)

detail.title: Enhancing Supply Chain Resilience through Generative Artificial Intelligence, Explainable AI, and Federated Learning
detail.abstract: The modern world global supply chain landscape is impacted by an unparalleled level of challenges related to digital transformation drivers, sustainability imperatives as well as Industry 5.0 paradigms. This chapter investigates the disruptive capabilities that three disruptive technologies, Generative Artificial Intelligence (GAI), Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI), and Federated Learning (FL) can have in increasing supply chain resilience using novel technology blending and strategic use of implementation frameworks. The study adopted a systematic literature review (SLR) method with a PRISMA approach to summarise the trends for the digital supply chain transformation and technology innovation. Research findings demonstrate that GAI technologies can drive autonomous decision-making, an enhanced ability to predict and adapt to potential scenarios, as well as more responsive supply chain behavior. Explainable AI meets the intense transparency demands of supply chain control and supports trust-building among partners based on the transparency and rules compliance provided by explainable decision processes. Federated Learning is finally introduced as a game changing methodology which allows for collaborative learning across distributed supply chain networks without sacrificing the security and privacy of the proprietary data when these technologies converge, complements occur, so that both enablers in the technological environment are reinforced and amplify the performance also of the strategic planning process, the integration with the human resource management and the innovation framework. The chapter highlights some major challenges for implementation such as technological complexity, readiness of firms, and adaptation of regulations. But the opportunities for competitive advantage, operational effectiveness and sustainability improvement dwarfs these challenges. The findings add to the theoretical body of knowledge about advanced technology implementation in supply chain management and provide practical approaches for organisations to implement and strategize the shape of the Industry 5.0 environment.

title: Beyond Access: Unpacking the Non-Linear Impact of Financial Inclusion on National Life Satisfaction through Random Forest Modeling

detail.title: Beyond Access: Unpacking the Non-Linear Impact of Financial Inclusion on National Life Satisfaction through Random Forest Modeling
detail.abstract: Financial inclusion, defined as universal access to and effective use of formal financial services, has been widely advocated as a driver of economic resilience and social well-being. While prior research has demonstrated a positive correlation between financial inclusion and life satisfaction, the mechanisms underlying this relationship remain underexplored. This study utilizes a Random Forest model to examine the non-linear associations between financial inclusion and national life satisfaction. The analysis draws upon data from 90 countries spanning 2014, 2017, and 2021, obtained from the Global Findex database and the World Happiness Report. The findings indicate that credit card ownership, borrowing, and saving emerge as the most significant predictors of life satisfaction, underscoring the pivotal role of sophisticated financial behaviors in comparison to fundamental transactional services. The Random Forest model exhibited superior performance in comparison to the Lasso regression model, thereby substantiating the existence of non-linear dynamics. It is important to note that while credit access has been shown to enhance wellbeing, excessive use has been demonstrated to reduce life satisfaction, underscoring the necessity for balanced policies. The findings indicate that financial inclusion strategies should prioritize the following: enabling productive borrowing, fostering savings, and promoting responsible credit use, alongside foundational access. This study contributes to the literature by disentangling the non-linear pathways through which financial inclusion relates to subjective well-being, offering policymakers evidence-based insights to design targeted interventions. The cross-sectional design of the study warrants the implementation of future longitudinal or causal inference studies to validate the identified relationships.

title: Digital Twins and Transport Policy: The Reality of Complexity

detail.title: Digital Twins and Transport Policy: The Reality of Complexity
detail.abstract: Digital twins are entering the corridors of transport policy-offering simulation, optimisation, and predictive capacity. Yet transport is not mere infrastructure. It is social form. It binds state, society, and market in historically shaped rhythms of movement and meaning. This essay, grounded in my keynote to the 2024 African Transport Forum in Abidjan, reflects on that sociological uniqueness. It follows the evolution of digital twins and explores their uneasy encounter with policy institutions still shaped by norms, political expectations, and bounded rationalities. Drawing on complexity science, I show why digital twins must remain tools of navigation-not machines of control. The future of transport lies not in digital certainty, but in adaptive capacity-and in rethinking policy as a continual negotiation with emergence. I. Setting the Frame: Transport as a Social System Transport is not merely a conduit. It is a mirror of society-its rhythms, its values, its asymmetries. Roads, railways, air routes, and ports shape the life-worlds of communities and encode social choices in concrete and steel. Unlike energy or water systems, transport infrastructure is visibly social. It mediates between state priorities, market forces, and lived experience. It touches everyone-and everyone has a story about it. Yet that sociality makes it epistemically elusive. Transport is easy to see but hard to know. Models simplify; politics reasserts. Standards harmonise; cultures resist. In this ambiguity, the idea of the Digital Twin (DT) has taken root. It promises clarity, control, foresight. But it also risks imposing a logic foreign to transport's real nature. That is our concern.

title: Anatomy of a Misrepresented Deal: The 2025 U.S.-Japan Tariff Agreement

detail.title: Anatomy of a Misrepresented Deal: The 2025 U.S.-Japan Tariff Agreement

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no affiliation with any political party, organization, or entity that could influence the analysis presented in this study. The research reflects an independent policy perspective developed solely by the author.
declarations.ethicsApproval: Not applicable. This paper involves no human participants or personal data.
declarations.funderStatement: This research received no external funding. It was conducted independently by the author.

detail.abstract:
In July 2025, President Donald Trump announced a “massive,” “historic” trade agreement with Japan, promising $550 billion in Japanese investment, hundreds of thousands of new American jobs, and reciprocal 15% tariffs on traded goods. On its surface, the agreement was framed as a geopolitical and economic triumph. But upon closer analysis, the deal reveals itself to be structurally flawed, economically asymmetric, and politically misleading.

While the United States has formally imposed a 15% tariff on Japanese imports—particularly automobiles and electronics—the agreement contains no confirmed provisions detailing how Japan will tax or treat American exports in return. Simultaneously, the heavily promoted investment commitments appear to recycle earlier, non-binding promises lacking clear timelines or legal enforceability.

This paper dissects the trade imbalance, fiscal inefficiencies, and consumer-level burden created by the agreement using 2024 trade data, public documents, and media reports. As a structural alternative, the paper introduces the Balanced Free Trade Model with Quota System, which offers a non-inflationary, fiscally balanced, and enforceable mechanism to restore bilateral fairness and economic sustainability.

title: The Impact of Financial Education on High School Students' Financial Literacy in an American-Style International School in South Korea

detail.title: The Impact of Financial Education on High School Students' Financial Literacy in an American-Style International School in South Korea

declarations.ethicsApproval: All participants in this study were high school students who voluntarily took part in the survey. Prior to data collection, informed consent was obtained from each student, and where applicable, parental or guardian consent was secured in accordance with the school’s ethical guidelines. Participants were assured of the confidentiality and anonymity of their responses, and they were informed that they could withdraw from the study at any time without any consequences. The study protocol was reviewed and approved by the school administration to ensure compliance with ethical standards for research involving minors.

detail.abstract: This study examines the relationship between financial education exposure and financial literacy among high school students at an American-style international school in South Korea. Despite South Korea's position as the world's 12th largest economy, the nation ranks 77th globally in financial literacy, with only 33% of adults demonstrating basic financial knowledge. Using survey methodology, data were collected from 39 students aged 14-18. Financial education exposure was measured using adapted PISA 2018 Financial Literacy Questionnaire items, while financial literacy was assessed through the validated “Big Five” questions covering compound interest, inflation, bond prices, mortgage rates, and risk diversification. Multiple linear regression analysis examined relationships between variables while controlling for demographic factors. Results revealed participants achieved a mean financial literacy score of 2.974 (SD = 1.423) on a 5-point scale, outperforming the general U.S. adult population benchmark of 2.6. However, financial education exposure showed only weak, statistically insignificant relationships with financial literacy across all models (β = 0.212-0.335, p > 0.1). In contrast, household income emerged as a significant predictor of financial literacy (β = 0.113, p = 0.079), suggesting socioeconomic factors play a more substantial role than formal education. Among financial education components, task-based learning demonstrated the strongest positive relationship with literacy, although this finding is statistically insignificant. These findings indicate that current financial education programs may emphasize theoretical knowledge over practical application, highlighting the need for more experiential, hands-on approaches to financial literacy instruction that address socioeconomic disparities.

title: The Borrowed Wisdom: How Military, Economics, Biology, Psychology, and Sociology Shaped Business Management Discipline

detail.title: The Borrowed Wisdom: How Military, Economics, Biology, Psychology, and Sociology Shaped Business Management Discipline
detail.abstract:
The modern discipline of business management is less an original invention and more a grand synthesis -a tapestry woven from threads borrowed from disciplines far older and often more fundamentally concerned with human endeavor, survival, and societal organization. Business management discipline is an ongoing synthesis -a strategic bricolage assembled from the lessons of generals, economists, navigators, psychologists, and systems theorists. The daily challenges faced by modern managers echo those once faced in war rooms, marketplaces, voyages, and laboratories. Strategy, coordination, motivation, and decision-making are not the exclusive domains of business but fundamental to human and societal functioning.

Yet business education has too often forgotten these roots, presenting business management as a self-contained discipline. In this paper, we briefly revisit the disciplinary foundations that silently underpin contemporary business management bodies of knowledge. By tracing how economics, military doctrine, cybernetics, psychology, sociology, and navigation contributed to core management practices, we open a case for a more reflective, integrative approach to management learning and development.

title: Reforming IAS 37 for a More Accurate Reflection of Economic Activity( translated from French)

detail.title: Reforming IAS 37 for a More Accurate Reflection of Economic Activity( translated from French)
detail.abstract: While GDP is increasingly criticized for failing to reflect environmental externalities, this article sheds light on a lesser-known contributor to that flaw: the role of accounting standards in shaping GDP figures. Specifically, IAS 37, which governs the recognition of provisions and contingent liabilities, leads to a systemic underestimation of environmental costs in financial statements. Since these costs are typically recognized after EBITDA or Gross Operating Surplus (GOS) a core component of GDP in the income approach; they are excluded from macroeconomic evaluation. Worse sells, environmental contingent liabilities that are deemed “uncertain” are rarely recorded, despite being structural and directly linked to production activities. This paper proposes a targeted reform of IAS 37, centered on: Recognizing environmental provisions earlier, before EBITDA; Loosening probability thresholds for recognizing environmental contingencies; Improving coordination between financial and national accounting systems. The goal is clear: to align accounting practices with ecological realities, and ensure that GDP reflects a truer, more honest measure of economic performance in the context of a climate-constrained world

title: Diversity and Organizational Performance: A Review of Management Scholarship
affiliations: San Francisco State University, Santa Clara University - Santa Clara University - Leavey School of Business, Students and Santa Clara University

detail.title: Diversity and Organizational Performance: A Review of Management Scholarship
detail.abstract: The objective of this article was to conduct a comprehensive analysis of management literature, with a focus on examining the impact of diversity on organizational performance. Recognizing the importance and growing interest in diversity in an organizational context, particularly regarding how diverse teams can drive innovation and better decision making and improve business outcomes, the article is a qualitative review of literature published in top-tier management journals. Articles are categorized based on their conceptualization and operationalization of diversity, the specific performance outcomes examined, and the research contexts and thematic foci. The research team read and extracted key findings from a selection of close to ninety relevant articles published since the early 2000s, and through its analysis, distilled key insights and findings. The aim was to understand the complexities and nuances of diversity’s role in influencing organizational performance at the individual, team, and organizational level, the factors that moderate diversity effects, the significance of contextual considerations in understanding and managing diversity, and the importance of coupling diversity with inclusion to achieve genuine commitment and optimize business outcomes.

title: Remote Work Management Strategies and Global Productivity Trends: A Comparative Study Across USA, Australia, and India

detail.title: Remote Work Management Strategies and Global Productivity Trends: A Comparative Study Across USA, Australia, and India
detail.abstract: Remote work has redefined global management practices in the post-COVID era, transforming organizational dynamics across developed and developing countries. This paper explores the productivity implications of remote work in the USA, Australia, and India. Using comparative productivity data, adoption trends, and a multinational case study approach, the study evaluates challenges and identifies sustainable management strategies. Graphical analysis, including bar charts and line graphs, illustrate productivity shifts and adoption patterns. The paper proposes strategic frameworks for effective remote workforce management and concludes with global recommendations based on international practices.

title: EVOLUTION OF MONOPOLISTIC PRACTICES: FROM MEDIEVAL GUILDS TO DIGITAL PLATFORMS. A COMPARATIVE ANALYSIS OF ECONOMIC EFFICIENCY AND REGULATORY CHALLENGES
affiliations: Russian Presidential Academy of National Economy and Public Administration

detail.title: EVOLUTION OF MONOPOLISTIC PRACTICES: FROM MEDIEVAL GUILDS TO DIGITAL PLATFORMS. A COMPARATIVE ANALYSIS OF ECONOMIC EFFICIENCY AND REGULATORY CHALLENGES
detail.abstract: The article studies the evolution of monopolistic practices from medieval guilds to modern digital platforms, identifying their role in shaping economic efficiency. Based on a comparative analysis of historical and modern cases (Florentine shops of the XIIIth century, Russian retailers' own brands, Amazon), the paper demonstrates the transformation of market control mechanisms: from legal prohibitions to algorithmic data management. The scientific novelty of the work lies in the establishment of continuity between guild monopolies and modern strategies, where data becomes an analogue of medieval quality standards, and exclusive contracts repeat the logic of shop privileges. A key gap in contemporary research is identified in the absence of a comprehensive approach to analysing monopolies through the lens of transaction costs and socio-economic functions in different historical periods. The results show a paradox of regulatory risks: while guilds inhibited innovation but preserved social order, digital monopolies stimulate technological leaps but increase market asymmetry, which requires adaptation of antitrust regulation to take into account the role of data as a new tool of hegemony. This includes recommendations for the government, companies and the international community on harmonising antitrust rules to take into account the role of data, quotas for the share of small producers in their own brands, and the creation of global standards for algorithmic responsibility.

detail.abstract: The study explores the role of digital leadership in fostering service innovation, emphasizing the mediating effect of self-efficacy and the moderating role of technology readiness. It highlights how digital leadership, characterized by adaptability, vision, and technological competence, drives innovation by creating supportive environments and empowering employees. While self-efficacy enhances employees' confidence in their creative abilities, technology readiness influences their willingness to adopt and utilize new technologies. title: Let Pickers Pick Their Picks: A Field Study on Self-Determination, Job Performance and Well-Being on the Shop Floor
affiliations: IE Business School - IE University, Technical University Munich, University of Cologne and Technische Universität München (TUM)

detail.title: Let Pickers Pick Their Picks: A Field Study on Self-Determination, Job Performance and Well-Being on the Shop Floor

declarations.declarationOfInterest: There is no conflict of interest.

detail.abstract: Automation increasingly drives operations management, yet human flexibility keeps people vital to many processes. In many shop-floor human-machine interactions, machines assign tasks, while humans perform repetitive, monotonous work. One downside of such work division is the mental impoverishment of workers, which impacts productivity and well-being, and increases turnover. Drawing on goal-setting and self-determination theory, we propose that empowering workers to self-select tasks can effectively address these challenges. We conduct a warehouse field study to test if task self-selection boosts job performance and satisfaction compared to machine-assigned tasks. Indeed, we observe a 9.7% increase in workers' job performance when they could pick their picks. Contrary to expectations, task self-selection reduced job satisfaction. Surveys, interviews, and practitioner insights showed workers were already job crafting to regain control from machine-driven workflows before our intervention. A vignettebased randomized controlled trial shows the intervention likely undermined self-determination by disrupting prior job crafting. Our findings show that job crafting emerged as a proactive response to low self-determination, highlighting how employees adapt their roles to reclaim control in their interactions with machines. This highlights a fundamental human response to the challenges posed by automation and underscores the importance of incorporating organizational behavior theory into operations management.

title: Framing Complexity: The Limits of Mathematical Foundations

detail.title: Framing Complexity: The Limits of Mathematical Foundations
detail.abstract: Mathematics has long grounded itself in foundational paradigms-set theory, category theory, type theory, and algorithmic formalism. Each offers a distinct way to define, relate, construct, or compute. But as we move into the domain of complexity-where emergence, feedback, and irreducible novelty reign-these foundations strain under the weight of their own assumptions. This essay explores how each foundation contributes to complexity science, while also revealing its own limits. Through symbolic formulations of complexity, we confront a mathematical challenge: when structure itself becomes emergent, mathematics must begin to model not just what is, but what becomes.

title: Strategic Inversion: Reframing Israeli Security Through Nonviolent Infrastructure and Human Development

detail.title: Strategic Inversion: Reframing Israeli Security Through Nonviolent Infrastructure and Human Development
detail.abstract:
Israel's prevailing security strategy-centered on retaliatory bombing campaigns-has yielded tactical gains but undermined long-term national security. This paper argues that such militarized deterrence exacerbates cycles of trauma, radicalization, and international isolation, ultimately eroding Israel's strategic resilience. Drawing on conflict transformation theory, international humanitarian law, and empirical case studies, the research introduces the concept of strategic inversion: a paradigm shift that reimagines security through investment in border modernization, human capital development, and diplomatic innovation. The study critically examines the psychological and legal failures of deterrence through civilian-targeted violence, highlighting how trauma-induced radicalization perpetuates generational instability. It proposes alternative models of smart border infrastructure, drawing lessons from the Korean DMZ, Indo-Bangladesh fencing, and Northern Ireland's post-conflict architecture. Furthermore, it links poverty, education gaps, and youth unemployment in Palestinian territories to long-term insecurity, advocating for Israeli-supported development initiatives as peace infrastructure. Diplomatic frameworks such as the Oslo and Abraham Accords are evaluated for their limitations and potential, while civil society diplomacy and international partnerships are explored as mechanisms for inclusive peacebuilding. The paper also engages counterarguments, addressing critiques of nonviolence through strategic pragmatism and moral clarity. 
Ultimately, the research contributes a multidimensional policy roadmap that reframes Israeli security as a product of empathy, investment, and cooperation—offering a transformative vision for sustainable peace in the region.

title: Blockchain Compliance: A Framework for Evaluating Regulatory Approaches
affiliations: INSEAD, University of Utah, University of Utah, University of Utah - School of Computing and Scientific Computing and Imaging Institute and ChainArgos

detail.title: Blockchain Compliance: A Framework for Evaluating Regulatory Approaches
detail.abstract: This article examines the intersection of blockchain technology and regulatory compliance from both legal and technical perspectives. We analyze how traditional financial regulatory frameworks face fundamental limitations when applied to decentralized systems. Our primary contribution is a novel taxonomy and evaluation framework that categorizes blockchain compliance approaches and maps technical design choices to legal requirements. This addresses a significant gap in a literature that typically approaches blockchain regulation from either a purely legal or technical perspective without sufficient integration. We use this framework to explore a range of emerging compliance mechanisms across multiple dimensions that cover constitutional compatibility, technical feasibility, implementation cost allocation and the balance between privacy and intrusiveness. Our analysis suggests that hybrid approaches combining automated ex-ante compliance with appropriate human oversight are likely best at finding a balance between innovation and market integrity. These frameworks can leverage technology for routine compliance while preserving human judgment for complex determinations where due process, fairness, openness to innovation and other principles which eschew mathematical codification are important and require interpretive flexibility. We examine key legal precedents shaping this landscape, providing structured guidance for policymakers, legal practitioners, and technologists developing legally sound compliance frameworks for blockchain systems.

title: Navigating the Intellectual Property Labyrinth: Challenges, Solutions, and Government Support for Intellectual Property-Driven Information Technology Startups

detail.title: Navigating the Intellectual Property Labyrinth: Challenges, Solutions, and Government Support for Intellectual Property-Driven Information Technology Startups
detail.abstract: IT startups concentrating on the development of valuable Intellectual Property (IP) are essential drivers of innovation and economic expansion. Nonetheless, they encounter a distinctive array of obstacles that differ from those faced by conventional enterprises. This paper outlines and examines the principal obstacles these firms face during the intellectual property lifecycle conception, protection, monetization, and enforcement. We contend that surmounting these obstacles is crucial for cultivating a dynamic innovation ecosystem. The article subsequently examines actionable strategies that startups may employ and, importantly, recommends specific, evidence-based measures for governmental implementation. By proactively resolving financial deficiencies, optimizing legal procedures, improving market accessibility, and reducing enforcement risks, governments may substantially strengthen these high-potential enterprises, fostering increased innovation and competitiveness.

title: Analysing Global vs. Local Processing: The Impact Effect of Positive Affect on the Breadth of Selective Attention
affiliations: University of Essex and University of Essex

detail.title: Analysing Global vs. Local Processing: The Impact Effect of Positive Affect on the Breadth of Selective Attention
detail.abstract: This research examines in depth the effect of positive emotions on the scope of selective attention, with a particular focus on the distinction between global and local levels of perceptual processing. Fredrickson's broaden-and-build theory is one of the main theoretical frameworks for assessing whether a cheerful mood consistently broadens attention and promotes global processing in various cognitive tasks. The differences between emotions, attention, and perceptual span are highlighted by analyzing empirical data from behavioral paradigms such as attentional eye blinking, global-local letter recognition, and the Navon task. Differences between studies can also be explained by individual variability, methodological differences, and arousal. Although conflicting findings suggest that baseline emotional states, task design, and stimulus relevance may mediate this relationship, the results primarily support the hypothesis that positive affectbroaden attention. The review concludes by highlighting key gaps in the literature and outlining potential research directions to better understand how and when pleasant emotions influence attention. In addition to their application in therapeutic and educational settings, theoretical implications for models of attention and emotion are also discussed.

title: "Dari Panggung Kampus ke Hati Mahasiswa: Mengukur Dampak Open House dan Event Promosi UM Palopo"

detail.abstract: Penelitian ini bertujuan untuk memahami bagaimana kegiatan open house dan event promosi yang diselenggarakan oleh Universitas Muhammadiyah Palopo memengaruhi persepsi dan minat calon mahasiswa dalam memilih perguruan tinggi. Dalam konteks persaingan pendidikan tinggi yang semakin kompetitif, pendekatan promosi yang bersifat interaktif dan emosional melalui experiential marketing menjadi sangat relevan. Penelitian ini menggunakan metode kualitatif deskriptif dengan teknik pengumpulan data melalui wawancara mendalam, observasi partisipatif, dan dokumentasi. Hasil penelitian menunjukkan bahwa sebagian besar calon mahasiswa memiliki kesan positif setelah mengikuti event kampus, seperti merasakan atmosfer akademik secara langsung, berinteraksi dengan mahasiswa aktif dan dosen, serta memperoleh informasi yang lebih personal. Selain membentuk citra kampus yang lebih kuat, kegiatan ini juga menumbuhkan rasa percaya dan keterikatan emosional yang memengaruhi keputusan mereka untuk memilih UM Palopo. Temuan ini memperkuat pentingnya strategi promosi berbasis pengalaman dalam membangun koneksi emosional antara institusi pendidikan dan calon mahasiswa. Namun, masih diperlukan perbaikan dalam aspek teknis pelaksanaan acara agar pengalaman yang ditawarkan dapat lebih maksimal. Penelitian ini merekomendasikan agar UM Palopo terus mengembangkan pendekatan promosi yang humanis, relevan, dan terintegrasi dengan kebutuhan generasi muda masa kini.

title: Decoding the ATM Skew with Rough Volatility models and Machine Learning

detail.title: Decoding the ATM Skew with Rough Volatility models and Machine Learning
detail.abstract:
This dissertation addresses the persistent challenge of modeling the at-the-money (ATM) volatility skew, with a particular focus on its term structure at ultra-short maturities, where classical models often fail. Traditional approaches typically overlook the empirical roughness and multifractal dynamics present in financial markets. In response, this work introduces and validates a novel, multi-stage hybrid framework designed to overcome these limitations by combining empirical volatility characteristics, advanced stochastic modeling, and modern machine learning techniques.

The methodology begins by quantifying the multifractal nature of volatility through the estimation of the Hurst exponent across multiple time scales. These varying roughness parameters are then incorporated into a customized rough Bergomi (rBergomi) model, producing a more realistic implied volatility surface across maturities. An Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) model is then trained to capture the complex, non-linear relationship between the market's ATM skew and a set of explanatory variables, which include rBergomi-implied volatilities. To enhance predictive performance and interpretability, the feature space is enriched using Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and feature importance metrics.

Empirical results show that the proposed framework significantly outperforms standard benchmarks in fitting the market’s ATM skew. The model’s predictive strength is further leveraged to design a systematic trading strategy based on identified skew dynamics. The main contribution of this research lies in its integration of multifractal scaling analysis, rough volatility modeling, and machine learning to provide a robust, data-driven approach for both accurate derivative pricing and profitable trading.

Keywords: Volatility Skew, Rough Volatility, rBergomi, Hurst Exponent, Multifractality, XGBoost, Machine Learning, Principal Component Analysis, Feature Importance, Term Structure of Volatility, Systematic Trading.

title: Preventing Catastrophic Wildfires: Annual Grid Inspection and Maintenance Plan
affiliations: UCLA Anderson, Johns Hopkins University - Carey Business School, University of Southern California - Marshall School of Business and University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) - Anderson School of Management

detail.title: Preventing Catastrophic Wildfires: Annual Grid Inspection and Maintenance Plan
detail.abstract: Power grid failures are a major cause of catastrophic wildfires, making wildfire prevention a top priority for utility companies and regulators. Inspection and maintenance are crucial to wildfire mitigation, and utilities must annually report which grid segments will be inspected, the planned maintenance, and anticipated reductions in wildfire costs. This paper addresses the inspection and maintenance planning problem to minimize wildfire costs due to grid failures. The power grid consists of millions of components grouped into thousands of clusters, each containing hundreds of correlated segments. We formulate a large-scale stochastic optimization problem to design optimal inspection and maintenance plans under capacity constraints, using uncertain wildfire cost estimates provided by utilities. We show that the problem is NP-hard and analyze how inspection and segment correlation affect cost reduction. We reformulate it as a more tractable, non-convex integer program, which decomposes by cluster, and develop an approximation method that approximates each cluster's objective function using the lower surface of its convex hull, constructed from a small set of precomputed objective values that accurately capture the function's shape. We also derive a lower bound on the objective value and provide a theoretical a priori error analysis. We validate our framework using an industrial-scale instance derived from real data provided by one of California's largest utility companies. Our method achieves an approximation error of 0.22%, significantly outperforming a practice-based heuristic method, which incurs a 14.31% error.

detail.abstract: The COVID-19 pandemic severely disrupted global work environments, particularly in developing economies. This study investigates how a Bangladeshi food-services company managed talent during the early pandemic phase. A survey of 30 mid-to-senior-level managers conducted in 2021 assessed operational disruptions, remote work challenges, and financial pressures. Quantitative analysis using SPSS, including multiple regression, identified drivers of employee performance decline.Performance decline was significantly predicted by pandemic disruption (β = 0.64, p < 0.001) and resistance to change (β = 0.85, p < 0.001), explaining 72% of variance (R² = 0.72). Organizations in developing economies must institutionalize agile, digitally enabled workforce strategies to enhance resilience against future crises.

title: Between Order and Entropy

detail.title: Between Order and Entropy
detail.abstract: Complexity unfolds not at the extremes but in the charged interval - between the symmetry of order and the dispersion of entropy. It is here that the world ceases to be merely described and begins to be enacted: cities that think, organisms that learn, economies that evolve. Classical mechanics offers law, quantum mechanics probability, and statistical mechanics the reckoning of outcomes. But complexity lives before outcomes—in the thrum of feedback, in histories that bend futures, in forms that self-compose. Here, mathematics cannot remain a passive mirror of reality. It must anticipate, provoke, and adapt. For in this zone of becoming, the symbolic must not only reflect but participate.

title: Advancing Digital Health Literacy: Integrating Public Health, Educational Strategies and Technological Innovations for Equitable Access and Empowerment

detail.abstract: With the speed of healthcare services becoming digitalized grows, digital health literacy (DHL) becomes one of the essential 21st century skills. As health systems increasingly turn to online health information platforms, people will need to be equipped with knowledge and capabilities of using online health information and how they can use the knowledge to the advantage of the health system. In this paper, we talk about the opportunity to achieve the promotion of DHL at the meeting of three topics education, technological progress, and health. It cites the representational barriers to equitable accessibility, proposes an integrative model and highlights the need of community-based, culturally acceptable, inclusive digital health literacy programmes. This paper contributes to the population empowerment to make significant contribution to their health and well-being on the digital age with the multidimensional lens. Overall, the results imply that while all components are important, participants place greater emphasis on the ability to critically evaluate and interpret media messages, a skill central to navigating today’s digital health environments.

title: A Study on the Transition Process from Omission to Commission in Organizational Misconduct: An Event History Analysis of Multiple Cases

detail.title: A Study on the Transition Process from Omission to Commission in Organizational Misconduct: An Event History Analysis of Multiple Cases

detail.abstract: Purpose: Building on the dual-triangle model of "commission and omission" presented in a prior study (Funaishi, 2025), this paper aims to empirically elucidate the transition process by which an organization moves from a state of "omission"-a latent breeding ground for misconduct-to "commission," the act of crossing the line into intentional and explicit wrongdoing. Design/methodology/approach: This paper is a qualitative study employing an event history analysis of multiple cases. Using third-party investigation reports from Mitsubishi Electric (2022) and Iwaki Shinkin Bank (2024) as primary data, it reconstructs the timeline of misconduct in each organization. It then identifies and analyzes the mechanism of transition through three distinct phases: "Pervasiveness of Omission," "Occurrence of a Trigger Event," and "Leap to Commission." Findings: The analysis reveals a common pattern in the transition process in both cases. First, the long-term pervasiveness of the "Triangle of Omission" erodes the organization's sound decision-making capabilities. Next, when faced with "excessive pressure" that threatens the organization's survival-a trigger event-the paralyzed organization fails to find rational alternatives and readily resorts to the "commission" of misconduct. Specific triggers were identified as "technological and delivery-date despair" at Mitsubishi Electric and "fear of bankruptcy against the backdrop of financial system instability" at Iwaki Shinkin Bank. Originality/value: The novelty of this paper lies in its empirical demonstration of organizational misconduct not as a static model but as a dynamic "transition process" with a temporal axis. Furthermore, by identifying the organizational "hazards" that form the "Triangle of Omission"-the starting point of this transition process-it offers more practical insights for the early detection and prevention of misconduct.

detail.abstract: The Gulf of Mexico was recognized as the Gulf of America, via Presidential executive order in the United States from February 2025. Renaming geographical or geological sites based on political or nationalist decisions risks places academics, editors, and publishers in complex situations where a fact at one point in time may be labelled as a false fact or misinformation at another point in time. Until 3 May 2025, five documents indexed in Scopus and Web of Science had employed 'Gulf of America' in the title, abstract or keywords. Editors who allow authors to publish the term 'Gulf of America' are called upon to offer guidance. It is also important to publish the sentiment of those authors (from the US, Mexico, or elsewhere) who have employed 'Gulf of Mexico' in indexed academic papers from February 2025 onwards, since those papers might be interpreted as carryingat least from a US perspective-an error of historical fact.

detail.abstract: Updated version: corrected sign in Lorentz factor equation.   This paper introduces a stylized case study of a cup factory to illustrate key mechanisms in the Economic Relativity Model (ERM). Using an artificial but plausible trajectory of investment, cost, pricing, and decision-making over five stages, the case models how a firm's behavior evolves under changing perceptions of irreducible cost (c), market price (p), production capacity (F), and systemic friction (a). detail.abstract: This paper studies the macroeconomic effects of global supply chain shocks, introducing a novel identification strategy based on narrative analysis of price surcharges from the three largest container shipping companies. Negative shocks trigger a persistent rise in consumer prices and a decline in economic activity. The response is broad-based. Sectoral impacts vary with exposure to global supply chains, measured by the share of inputs sourced from abroad. Spillovers extend to non-tradable sectors. These shocks accounted for up to 51 percent of the post-pandemic inflation. Without monetary or fiscal stimulus, recovery would have been delayed by 18 months.

detail.abstract: I propose Meta-Improvement, a novel philosophical axiom stating that the processes by which we improve systems, designs, or functions must themselves be subject to improvement, or they will ossify into ineffective rituals. This idea builds on previous works across domains, including second-order cybernetics (von Foerster, 2003), Shewhart's iterative improvement cycle (later refined as PDSA by Deming, 1986), antifragility (Taleb, 2012), and double-loop learning (Argyris & Schön, 1978). Applications are briefly illustrated in healthcare, software, and manufacturing. To counter infinite regress, I further introduce the principle of bounded reflexivity: pragmatic stopping points based on diminishing returns. This paper positions meta-improvement as a foundational axiom for evolving, adaptive, and sustainable systems.

title: Open Contracting and Open Data in the United States: A Global Comparison (DISCUSSION DRAFT)

detail.title: Open Contracting and Open Data in the United States: A Global Comparison (DISCUSSION DRAFT)
detail.abstract: This paper discusses the relationship between open contracting and open data in the United States federal procurement system, evaluating the extent to which key government platforms align with global open contracting principles. Despite growing efforts to enhance transparency and public accountability, United States procurement data remain fragmented across multiple systems-including GSA eBuy, SAM.gov, and others-many of which fall short in providing standardized, accessible, and comprehensive contract lifecycle information. The paper analyzes these systems against the Open Contracting Data Standard (OCDS) and principles such as transparency, participation, and accountability. Findings reveal significant gaps in data interoperability, completeness, and usability, limiting public oversight and evidence-based policy evaluation. The paper concludes by outlining recommendations for improving the United States procurement data ecosystem, including adopting OCDS, consolidating data platforms, and increasing access to contract planning and implementation data. These reforms are essential to advancing transparency and competition, combating corruption, and enabling data-driven decision-making in federal procurement.

title: Economic Relativity: A Structural Law of Output under Frictional Constraints

detail.title: Economic Relativity: A Structural Law of Output under Frictional Constraints

detail.abstract:
Why do some economies stagnate despite stable capital, labor, and technological inputs? Why do traditional policy tools-such as stimulus spending, deregulation, or monetary easing-fail to generate expected growth? The Economic Relativity Model introduces a structural constraint on productive output based on the ratio between irreducible costs and competitive price ceilings, as well as institutional friction.
The model defines output responsiveness as a function with a non-linear denominator: as the cost-to-price ratio (c/p) approaches unity, system responsiveness collapses, regardless of how much input force (F) is applied. This paper formalizes the model, draws parallels with relativistic physics, and demonstrates its explanatory power through micro-level case logic. National case studies (Japan, Germany, United States) are withheld and will be published in separate papers.

detail.title: Research on Strategies for Improving Employability of Graduates of Higher Vocational Colleges
detail.abstract: Finding work after college has always been a big problem for universities and society as a whole. The problem of graduates from higher vocational schools having a hard time finding work is especially noticeable. COVID-19 has slowed down China's social and economic growth in the last few years; things are not looking good for the national economy, which directly leads to the dire state of jobs. The number of college students in higher vocational colleges is growing every day, as is the number of graduates. At the same time, the job market is getting more and more competitive, and there is still a gap between the skills of college students in higher vocational colleges and the skills that are needed in the job market-this has made it harder for college students in higher vocational colleges to find jobs. Thus, making college students in higher vocational schools more employable by developing their overall skills and helping them become more competitive for jobs have become important tasks for higher education and pressing problems that need to be fixed. Based on a comprehensive analysis of existing research, this paper proposes four strategic suggestions: building a talent training model based on employability factors, strengthening the construction of high-quality vocational education characteristic courses, giving full play to the role of practical teaching in cultivating employability, and building a high-quality employment service system for higher vocational colleges. This aims to provide a reference for improving the employability of graduates from higher vocational colleges.

detail.abstract: The rising prevalence of diet-related chronic diseases in the United States has prompted growing policy interest in the economic determinants of food choice. While individual behavior contributes to dietary outcomes, economic constraints, such as affordability, accessibility, and opportunity costs, significantly shape consumption patterns. This paper applies classical economic theory to analyze how market forces influence food environments, consumer behavior, and public health, ultimately contributing to substantial hidden societal costs. It identifies key market failures in the food system, including information asymmetry, spatial disparities, misaligned institutional incentives, and distorted price signals that obscure the true cost of unhealthy diets. Using this framework, the analysis evaluates the economic burden of poor nutrition and highlights the potential for coordinated, system-level interventions. Evidence suggests that integrated policies such as "Food is Medicine" programs, local procurement initiatives, and combined price and access strategies, offer high returns on investment by improving health outcomes and reducing long-term healthcare expenditures. This work highlights the need for multi-faceted economic interventions to realign food systems with public health objectives.

It examines the infrastructure, governance, and regulatory requirements needed to deploy large-scale AI systems, drawing on international benchmarks such as the EU Artificial Intelligence Act, OECD recommendations, and UNESCO ethical guidelines. detail.abstract: We examine language standardization in a multinational enterprise in the context of international knowledge transfer treated as an act of communication. Based on psychological theories of emotions and a qualitative study of a Chinese owned company with English as a working language, we find that both native and non-native English-speakers experience anxiety in intercultural communication. This triggers emotions that are culturally predisposed affecting communication behavior. We provide a framework within which intercultural business communication takes place and demonstrate the intermediating role that emotions play when language is standardized.

detail.title: Navigating the Indian Skill-Imparting Ecosystem: Investigating the Integration of Vocational Training as Workforce Development Strategies
detail.abstract: India’s skill ecosystem faces immense challenges with respect to reach and reliability, considering that only 4.4% of the country’s populace have received any formal or vocational training. Also, the employability amongst those who have undertaken formal education and vocational training stands on feets of clay, due to the lack of universal standards for certification and the curriculums not being duly revised over time. Germany has been portrayed as a benchmark in vocational training and education, such that drawing lessons from the German ecosystem for instilling and enhancing the skill-set of the workforce has been an exemplar and torch-bearer for countries who seek improvement. The comparisons between India and Germany’s Vocational Education and Training have been a point of attention amongst many scholastic deliberations. This paper attempts to draw upon the question of public-private partnerships and the onus of funding the vocational training ecosystem between both the countries, the role of private companies in imparting life-long learning or facilitating apprenticeships for the inculcation of young workforce, as well as the institutional arrangement with respect to the representation of various stakeholders. This paper traces the developments over the last 10 years regarding the policy framework for making vocational education and training more robust and fruitful in India.
