detail.abstract: This paper explores the critical role of administrative efficiency in enhancing sustainability initiatives within environmental offices. As organizations face increasing pressure to reduce their environmental impact, integrating strategic management and digital solutions becomes essential. The study examines how implementing digital document management systems, streamlining workflows, and promoting crossdepartmental collaboration can drive both ecological and operational benefits. It highlights the importance of clear communication, employee engagement, and continuous evaluation in overcoming bureaucratic and resource-based challenges. Case studies from companies like Patagonia and Interface demonstrate the positive outcomes of aligning business strategies with environmental stewardship. Ultimately, this research provides actionable recommendations for improving administrative processes, promoting sustainable practices, and positioning organizations for long-term success in a rapidly evolving environmental landscape.

title: An Analytical Study on Customer Complaint Behaviour in the Two-Wheeler Segment: A Case study of Bhagyalakshmi Automobiles

detail.title: An Analytical Study on Customer Complaint Behaviour in the Two-Wheeler Segment: A Case study of Bhagyalakshmi Automobiles
detail.abstract: The two-wheeler segment has emerged as a critical pillar in India’s automotive industry, accounting for nearly 75% of total motor vehicle sales due to its affordability, fuel efficiency, and suitability for congested urban and semi-urban environments. As competition intensifies, customer expectations regarding product reliability and service quality have significantly risen. Despite robust sales, dealerships face mounting challenges related to customer dissatisfaction, manifested in the form of diverse complaints that, if unresolved, can undermine brand loyalty and market reputation. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of customer complaint behaviour at Bhagyalakshmi Automobiles, a prominent Bajaj dealership located in Andhra Pradesh. Adopting a descriptive and analytical research design, the study utilizes primary data collected from 185 respondents via structured questionnaires, complemented by in-depth interviews with service personnel. The research examines the nature, frequency, and root causes of complaints across different stages of the customer journey—pre-sales, delivery, and post-sales service. It further explores the influence of demographic variables such as age, gender, occupation, educational attainment, and income on complaint tendencies. Findings indicate that the majority of complaints pertain to recurring technical issues, delays in service and repairs, lack of transparency in communication, and perceived inadequacies in staff behaviour and responsiveness. Younger customers (particularly those aged 21–30) and students were identified as the most vocal groups, reflecting higher service expectations and greater propensity to use digital channels for grievance redressal. Additionally, respondents with higher educational qualifications exhibited a stronger inclination to formally report and escalate complaints. The study underscores the critical need for Bhagyalakshmi Automobiles to enhance its complaint resolution frameworks by adopting proactive service audits, implementing digital grievance tracking systems, and offering tailored communication strategies to different customer segments. By strategically addressing these areas, the dealership can strengthen its service quality, mitigate negative word-of-mouth, foster deeper customer trust, and achieve sustainable competitive advantage in the rapidly evolving two-wheeler market.

detail.abstract: This study predicts and analyzes the mediating role of innovation capability (IC) on the relationship between digital transformation (DT) and economic competitiveness (CP) of SMEs of SMEs in the creative industry sector in the digital age business landscape, by proposing model construction. The survey method was carried out by distributing research instruments to 98 respondents as SME actors in Indonesia, the collected data was used to analyze the relationship between digital transformation, innovation ability and competitiveness, also used to test hypotheses. Evaluation of predictions through structural equation models with partial least squares-structural equation modeling (PLS-SEM). The results of model measurement and the results of the evaluation of model suitability show that model suitability is achieved and guarantees model suitability. The findings from the structural model analysis showed that all hypotheses are accepted, and IC has a mediating effect on the effect of digital transformation on the economic competitiveness of SMEs. There is an important component that must be considered to strengthen the contribution of DT and IC to the improvement of CP, namely a set of competencies and resources that must be prepared. A model of increasing the economic power of MSMEs in the creative industry sector based on innovation and digital transformation capabilities involving a set of competencies including digital competencies of human resources and economic resources as fundamental inputs that strengthen them, becomes this novelty to fill the existing gap. The contribution of this research broadens the horizons on the effectiveness of highly competitive businesses in this era, where digital transformation capabilities, digital skills and innovation capabilities must be prepared, which emphasizes the importance of a set of skills and capabilities, digital competency, human resources digital transformation and economic resilience among actors and related partners in this sector.

title: Testing the Authenticity of Public Official Diplomas in Indonesia: Scientific Study of the Joko Widodo Case
affiliations: Trisakti University - Faculty of Economic and Business (FEB)

detail.title: Testing the Authenticity of Public Official Diplomas in Indonesia: Scientific Study of the Joko Widodo Case
detail.abstract: The controversy surrounding the authenticity of President Joko Widodo's bachelor's degree issued by Universitas Gadjah Mada (UGM) in 1985 has sparked wide public and political debate in Indonesia. This issue underscores the need for a robust framework for diploma verification, particularly for pre-digital documents. This study adopts a qualitative descriptive approach, combining legal, archival, and document forensic analysis, and draws on international case studies (Pakistan, Germany, Liberia). The findings reveal that diploma authenticity can be verified through a two-layer verification system: document forensic analysis (paper, ink, watermark, embossing, signatures) and administrative audits (serial numbers, university registers, graduation lists). The study also clarifies the distinction between physical forgery (a counterfeit document) and process forgery (a genuine document obtained illegitimately). As a contribution, this study formulates a standard for diploma verification to be used by universities, courts, and government institutions, while also providing policy recommendations to strengthen the authentication system for public officials' educational documents. It further highlights communication gaps that fuel public skepticism and offers strategic steps toward a more transparent and reliable diploma verification framework.

title: Regulatory Legitimacy without Referents: On the Syntax of AI-Generated Legal Drafts

detail.title: Regulatory Legitimacy without Referents: On the Syntax of AI-Generated Legal Drafts
detail.abstract: This article analyzes how AI-generated legal texts simulate legitimacy without referencing a sovereign authority. Based on a provenance-verified corpus of machine-generated documents, including contracts, terms of service, and automated policy clauses, the study shows that the legislator is structurally displaced by recurring patterns of passive voice, normative conditionals, and chains of subordinate clauses. The result is legalidad sin fuente (sourceless legality), where the appearance of regulatory authority is produced by syntactic form rather than institutional attribution. Comparing these drafts with traditional legislative writing, the article outlines a typology that instantiates autoridad no referencial and identifies a dual risk: loss of authority traceability and an accountability gap in the binding effects of these texts. This syntactic delegation constitutes a paradigm of regla compilada, situated within the tradition of formal grammars, in which language enacts governance without a governing subject.

title: Stratify, Don't Personalize: Balancing Implementation Complexity and Outcome Disparity in Medical Care

detail.title: Stratify, Don't Personalize: Balancing Implementation Complexity and Outcome Disparity in Medical Care

declarations.declarationOfInterest: None.
declarations.funderStatement: None.

detail.abstract: Clinical practice guidelines often overlook heterogeneity in patient characteristics, offering uniform recommendations that fail to address disparities in outcomes across subpopulations. Fully personalized medicine can mitigate these inequities but is operationally complex, costly, and difficult to implement at scale. To address this gap, we develop a decision-aware stratification framework that partitions a heterogeneous patient population into a small number of interpretable subgroups, each assigned a tailored policy. To enhance interpretability and facilitate adoption in clinical settings, the partitioning is restricted to decision trees over observable covariates, aligning the segmentation structure with how clinicians design and apply guidelines. The tree is optimized via mixed-integer programming within a constrained multi-model framework to minimize average disparity while preserving operational feasibility. We apply our framework to the design of post-treatment surveillance policies for head and neck cancer, a setting where early recurrence detection is critical and surveillance costs are substantial. In our case study, we find that as few as five interpretable strata can reduce population-level treatment delay disparities by more than 60-75% relative to a uniform guideline, without resorting to fully individualized policies. Compared with traditional similarity-based clustering, our approach yields superior equity outcomes while maintaining interpretability and scalability. These findings demonstrate that carefully designed stratified care can serve as a practical, equitable, and cost-conscious alternative to both one-size-fits-all and fully personalized clinical decision-making.

title: Repositioning Adr in Nigerian Legal Education: A Framework for Reform (Part I)

detail.title: Repositioning Adr in Nigerian Legal Education: A Framework for Reform (Part I)
detail.abstract: This article focuses on the one thing legal pedagogy in Nigeria is meant for – equipping law students with the requisite legal knowledge and skills necessary for meeting the demands of a rapidly evolving Nigerian society. Given the enactment of the Arbitration and Mediation Act 2023, and the National Policy on Arbitration and Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) 2024, amongst others, the article argues that ADR can no longer be safely termed “alternative” as far as Nigeria's justice system is concerned. And that, for socio-economic justice, ADR has to be mainstreamed, particularly in legal education, to put a stop to Nigerian legal profession's limp on one litigational foot; enabling us to run on all that ADR options has to offer. Consequently, it opines that there is an urgent need to review the current Nigerian legal curriculum to maintain the relevance of not just legal practitioners, but the legal profession in the arena of dispute resolution in Nigeria. This article is contained in three papers. This first paper highlights the benefits of mainstreaming ADR in the Nigerian legal curriculum, especially the economic benefits that will accrue from effective commercial dispute resolution. Paper two focuses on the benefits to the economy when ESG Disputes are also effectively resolved using ADR mechanisms. Paper three discusses the avenues through which ADR can be entrenched in the Nigerian legal curriculum, possible resistance to this entrenchment, and recommend possible solutions. In this first paper, the doctrinal and empirical research methodologies are both used. Legislations, writings of jurists, etc. are examined and analysed, as well as a few statistics, which reveal the overwhelming need to review the Nigerian legal curriculum to help students adopt a more diversified approach to justice delivery in Nigeria. Findings analysed reveal that diverse commercial disputes are either designated by statute or necessarily require one or more ADR options as the appropriate mechanism to resolve them. There is therefore the need to review the Nigerian legal education to reflect current societal changes and the demands of socio-economic justice in contemporary and evolving Nigeria. It is hoped that this paper will spur more research in this regards in Nigeria.

detail.abstract: The main objective of this research is to develop a training program to develop the DCIS to PR towards innovation in Health Region 2. The research was conducted in four stages: (1) studying basic data and guidelines, (2) creating and validating the program, (3) experimenting by organizing training, and (4) evaluation. The results showed that the training program consists of 5 main components: 1) principles, 2) objectives, 3) content, 4) skill development process, and 5) measurement and evaluation of results. The skill development process component consists of 7 sub-components: Step 1: Suggestion, Step 2: Identifying issues, Step 3: Setting Hypothesis, Step 4: Define, Step 5: Choosing an alternative solution, Step 6: Decision, Step 7: Analyzing and Evaluation, and Step 8: Summarizing. The Kaiser-Meyer-Olkin test to measure the sampling adequacy (KMO) at 0.914, and Bartlett’s test of sphericity found the variables of the model to be correlated significantly (p-value < 0.001). The results of the training program showed that 1) knowledge after skill development was significantly higher than before skill development at the .01 level, 2) skill and productivity after skill development were significantly higher than the 70% criterion at the .01 level, and 4) public health personnel had skills to be innovators after receiving development that were higher than the 70% criterion, with statistical significance at the .01 level. The level of satisfaction with DCIS was at a good level. Therefore, it can be concluded that the developed training program can be applied to other offices.

title: Will AI Replace Human Jobs? A Literature Review
affiliations: MindBridge Innovative Network and MindBridge Innovative Network

detail.title: Will AI Replace Human Jobs? A Literature Review

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The authors declare no conflict of interest related to the publication of this research.
declarations.ethicsApproval: Ethics approval was not required for this literature review, as no human participants were involved.
declarations.funderStatement: This research received no external funding.

detail.abstract: The following literature review evaluates new research regarding the conversation around whether artificial intelligence (AI) is taking your job, and consolidates the outcomes of four contemporaneous studies. The literature reviewed shows that AI presents both possible displacement and enrichment. Traditionalists focus on ethical, emotional, or existential issues and carry fears about AI; others focus on a future where humans and intelligent systems work in the same environment by continuously reskilling and developing new response strategies to workforce changes. An important dichotomy has emerged on issues of AI and labor, further divided by "automation AI," which removes labor, and "augmentation AI," which enables labor, often culminating in differences in wages and polarization of labor. The literature suggests there is a reduced risk of displacement occurring for high-skilled workers with AI encompassing elements of enhancement, whereas low-skilled workers are most at risk of displacement. Notably, areas such as the human characteristics of trust, transparency, and dignity are also key drivers of how people respond to the integration of AI into their working lives. In conclusion, the literature does not represent an absolute replacement of human labor, but rather human-machine collaboration in the evolving world of work, given timely educational, policy, and organizational considerations. This study will support the existing body of literature and clarify contributory arguments for educators, policy-makers, and organizations considering navigating the uncertain future of jobs created by an AI paradigm.

title: What Can Delaware Learn from the U.K.'s Moelis Moment?
affiliations: University of Cambridge - Faculty of Law and University of Cambridge - Faculty of Law

detail.title: What Can Delaware Learn from the U.K.'s Moelis Moment?

publicationDetails.detailsText: University of Cambridge Faculty of Law Research Paper No. 16/2025
publicationDetails.journalName: University of Cambridge Faculty of Law Legal Studies Research Paper Series

detail.abstract:
The 2024 Delaware case West Palm Beach v. Moelis created tremors across the business world when the court held that many terms commonly adopted in contractual stockholder agreements were unenforceable by virtue of infringing Delaware's statutory default granting the board managerial authority. Statute trumps contract. In response to practitioner backlash, Delaware enacted legislation proposed by senate bill "SB 313" reversing Moelis, which itself caused significant consternation in the academic community.

Some 35 years prior to Moelis, the U.K. had its Moelis moment in the case Russell v. Northern Bank, the O.G. of statutory primacy. Again, certain common stockholder agreement terms were rendered invalid with the stroke of a pen. Unlike Delaware, a SB313-esque legislative response was not forthcoming. Tapping into the U.K.s experience, this article offers unique insights into Moelis and SB 313.

We show that while commercial practice has not collapsed, Russell introduced a plethora of uncertainties that remain unresolved more than three decades later. We highlight similar uncertainties readily apparent from Moelis, and further uncertainties that may have emerged if SB 313 had not been enacted. This article makes an argument seldom proffered in academic commentary-SB 313 was a necessary and important response to Moelis. We further use the U.K. experience to suggest a solution to protect stockholders fearing abuse from stockholder agreements post-SB 313. SB 313 is not perfect, but look to Britain for how worse things could have been.

title: Defending Prosperity: Security Industrial Policy for Small Open Economies in the Age of Intangibles

detail.title: Defending Prosperity: Security Industrial Policy for Small Open Economies in the Age of Intangibles
detail.abstract: Canada’s defence strategy must adapt to a security landscape redefined by economic and security vulnerabilities in its digital infrastructure, rapid advances in AI-enabled and autonomous systems, and the challenge of an economically adversarial security partner. To meet its defence spending commitments while optimizing economic outcomes requires shifting from acquisition-heavy approaches to innovation-centric ones, leveraging dual-use technologies where Canada holds comparative advantages. This paper argues for sovereign control over critical digital infrastructure to close a cloud-sized security gap; modernization of the Investment Canada Act to prevent the leakage of intangible assets and young, potentially high growth firms given the regional economics shaped by increasing returns and absence of transportation costs in the innovation space; industrial policy orientation to preserving Canadian technology capabilities, including nationalization of failing domestic innovation firms, if necessary; and targeted procurement to scale national capabilities. Such a framework would leverage the trillion-dollar commitment Canada has made to defence upgrading to enhance Canada’s military readiness, to simultaneously address the source of Canada’s lagging productivity that emerged in the data-driven economy era, and secure long-term economic resilience in the age of intangibles.

title: Automation and Incentives: The Effect of Robot Penetration on CEO Compensation
affiliations: Western Michigan University - Finance & Commercial Law, Western Michigan University and Western Michigan University - Finance & Commercial Law, Washington State University

detail.title: Automation and Incentives: The Effect of Robot Penetration on CEO Compensation
detail.abstract: We investigate the relationship between industrial robot adoption and CEO compensation, with a particular focus on how this relationship is influenced by firm-level labor and capital structures. Our findings show that CEOs receive significantly higher compensation in firms with greater robot investment, implying that boards view automation as a strategic initiative worthy of reward. Furthermore, we explore interaction effects with human capital intensity and capital intensity measures. We find that the positive association between robotization and CEO pay becomes weaker in labor-intensive firms, suggesting possible organizational resistance or disruption. In contrast, robot investment has a stronger positive effect on compensation in capital-intensive firms, particularly when capital is measured relative to sales, indicating improved production efficiency. We contribute to the literature by highlighting the importance of aligning CEO incentives with technological transformation under different organizational settings.

title: Dimensional Reasoning Theory: A Multi-Plane Framework for Complex Decision-Making in Human and Organizational Systems

detail.title: Dimensional Reasoning Theory: A Multi-Plane Framework for Complex Decision-Making in Human and Organizational Systems

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no personal or financial relationships with any individuals or organizations that could be perceived to have influenced the research.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This study did not involve human participants, patient data, or animal subjects. Ethics approval was therefore not required.
declarations.funderStatement: This research received no external funding. It was independently conceived, developed, and authored by the researcher.

detail.abstract:
Dimensional Reasoning Theory (DRT) applies the concept of dimensional reasoning to high-stakes decision-making. It maps choices across seven concurrent planes of logic: moral, strategic, legal, operational, financial, social/emotional, and political. A transcendent layer of faith frames questions of identity, conviction, and ultimate purpose. Each plane has its own internal structure, value system, and systemic effects. Decisions are inherently dimensional rather than linear.

The theory introduces original constructs such as cross-plane misalignment, the post-diagnostic bridge, systemic fluency, incentive distortion, time horizon friction, signaling planes, and decision triage under duress. These dynamics show why rational decisions often fail even when supported by skill, resources, and intent.

Seven formal decision plane profiles serve as diagnostic lenses for identifying where decisions live, why they collapse, and how unseen dimensions can carry decisive weight. Four applied case studies, drawn from professional experience, constructed scenarios, and contemporary events, demonstrate how dimensional reasoning surfaces blind spots, explains systemic breakdowns, and guides the design of more principled systems of leadership and choice.

Rather than simplifying complexity, Dimensional Reasoning Theory provides the language and structure to perceive it more fully. It enables leaders, strategists, and decision-makers to act with greater clarity, consistency, and integrity in environments where competing logics coexist.

title: Conflicting Values in Judicial Valuations

detail.title: Conflicting Values in Judicial Valuations
detail.abstract: Do courts employ finance neutrally and consistently, or do different courts fashion financial tools in court-specific ways? I assemble 20 years (52,000 pages) of judicial opinions, legal briefs, and expert reports from three settings where statutes assign courts an ostensibly shared job of valuing business interests: Delaware Chancery shareholder appraisals, Tax Court estate & gift tax cases, and Bankruptcy cramdowns. With natural language processing, a large language model, and hand-performed review, I show each court's valuation approach is siloed, including use of nearly non-overlapping financial scholarship and expert witnesses. These silos are meaningful: Chancery methodological choices, meticulously explained, systematically increase valuations of private and weakly traded business interests, while Tax Court choices decrease them. A typical private firm minority interest is worth roughly twice as much for appraisal purposes as for gift tax purposes. Bankruptcy Court methods, conversely, are so unspecified as to be unreconstructable. Are these differences a feature, where each court's valuation practice productively serves each underlying law's distinctive role, or a bug? Bankruptcy opacity plausibly speeds reorganizations and resolves holdup problems, but generates costs from bias. Delaware jurisprudence risks windfalls, but suits transactional planning and is mostly aligned with its imperative to bolster corporate governance. Tax Court methods, however, not only undermine the estate & gift taxes on a scale larger than previously understood, but also incentivize poor corporate governance as an unintended result. Delaware corporate law's "fair value" standard provides a novel solution to these tax pathologies, which are often rooted in the Treasury's "willing buyer, willing seller" conception of valuation.

title: Information Sharing to Optimize the Wait-Time Experience
affiliations: Korea University Business School, Dartmouth College - Tuck School of Business and Dartmouth College - Tuck School of Business

detail.title: Information Sharing to Optimize the Wait-Time Experience
detail.abstract:
Problem definition: We develop a model to optimize the frequency of wait time updates for customers in an unobservable queue. Rather than assuming a predefined cost function for waiting, the model incorporates cognitive biases — loss aversion and discomfort with uncertainty - to quantify customer disutility during the wait. Embedded in an M/G/1 queueing framework, the model evaluates a class of information policies where a customer's expected wait time is revealed upon arrival and then updates are delivered periodically during the wait, i.e., every m service completions. 

Methodology/results: We find that for purely loss-averse customers, sharing information only upon arrival (m=+\infty) is optimal, while sharing all information (m=1) is optimal for customers who focus on uncertainty. For customers who experience both sources of disutility, the paper derives a tractable approximation for highly-utilized systems. Analysis of the approximation finds that as system utilization or service-time variability increases, it is optimal to increase m and reduce the update frequency. We also show that a policy that does not reveal any information, and in particular does not even reveal expected wait time upon arrival, is never optimal. Numerical experiments confirm the robustness of the approximation and sensitivity analysis, even when server utilization is moderate. 

Managerial implications: While waiting for service, customers can feel both frustration because of dashed expectations and anxiety due to uncertainty. A firm may ameliorate these emotions by updating the customer with information about the remaining wait. We find that both too much, and too little information can be damaging, and we derive a simple formula for the optimal rate of updating. In general, this work contributes a behavioral optimization framework to the queueing literature and offers practical insights for service providers aiming to enhance the customer experience through information sharing.

title: How is AI Reshaping Managerial Decision-Making and Workforce Organisations?

detail.title: How is AI Reshaping Managerial Decision-Making and Workforce Organisations?
detail.abstract:
This paper explores how artificial intelligence is changing the way management decisions are made and how work is organised within companies. It argues that AI is doing more than simply automating tasks. It is reshaping organisational structures, shifting decision making authority, and changing how value is created between people and machines.

The paper builds on classical management thinkers like Adam Smith and Peter Drucker, and uses Amazon and McKinsey as case studies. At Amazon, AI systems take over routine physical tasks so that human workers can focus on supervision and improvement. At McKinsey, AI tools support strategic thinking by helping consultants draw insights from large sets of data, speeding up the work and improving accuracy.

The paper also discusses ethical risks such as bias, lack of transparency, and the danger of overdependence on automated systems. The main argument is that AI does not replace human judgement but redefines it. As AI becomes more involved in decision making, future managers will need new skills, including ethical awareness, the ability to interpret data, and a wider view of how systems work. These changes are not just technical but deeply affect the human role in management.

detail.abstract: This paper examines the dual legal frameworks governing marriage in Nigeria by comparatively analyzing statutory and customary systems. Employing a doctrinal methodology, it investigates how legislative instruments such as the Marriage Act and Matrimonial Causes Act interact with indigenous customs in regulating marriage formation, validity, spousal rights, and dissolution. detail.abstract:
The Philippine electoral system continues to suffer from political dynasties, corruption, and a lack of enforceable accountability mechanisms. Campaign promises often lack follow-through, weakening democratic institutions and voter trust. In response, this paper introduces The Statesman’s Affidavit (2025), a one-page, voluntary, and notarized document that binds candidates to measurable campaign promises, including a self-imposed penalty clause. Operating outside legislative mandates, the affidavit converts rhetoric into enforceable moral commitments through civil notarization and public transparency. 

The paper examines its theoretical foundations and reform potential, comparing it to classical political principles such as social contract theory. Rooted in the author’s 2022 mayoral candidacy and further developed in 2025, the affidavit represents a citizen-led solution to pre-election accountability. Although it originated in the Philippines, it offers a scalable and globally applicable model for democratic reform, reframing campaign promises as both moral and civic obligations to empower voters before a single vote is cast.

title: Algorithmic Authority and the Complexities of Delegated Decision-Making: Case Studies on Ethical Challenges for 21st-Century Leadership

detail.title: Algorithmic Authority and the Complexities of Delegated Decision-Making: Case Studies on Ethical Challenges for 21st-Century Leadership
detail.abstract: The rapid integration of AI into high-stakes decision-making has outpaced traditional mechanisms for human oversight and accountability, leaving leaders without clear guidance on how to leverage algorithmic systems responsibly. To address this gap, we conducted a comparative qualitative study of four landmark AI deployments: the UK A-Level grading algorithm used during the COVID-19 pandemic, Amazon's automated hiring tool, the COMPAS recidivism risk score in the U.S. criminal justice system, and the Dutch SyRI welfare-fraud detection system. Drawing on 61 publicly available government reports, internal memos, and media articles, we applied a rigorous two-phase grounded-theory coding process in NVivo, producing a comprehensive 32-item codebook and achieving substantial inter-coder reliability. We then quantified thematic occurrences across 110 coded segments and conducted chi-square tests to confirm consistent application of themes across cases. Our analysis yielded four actionable principles: 1) Intentionalityleaders must consciously elect to involve AI rather than default to automation; 2) Interpretability-systems should provide accessible explanations for bias detection and decision justification; 3) Moral Authorship-human actors must explicitly claim ultimate responsibility for outcomes; 4) Justice-delegation structures must be designed to prevent the perpetuation of existing inequities. Together, these principles form a reproducible analytical roadmap and offer practical guidance for accountable AI governance in highstakes contexts.

title: Evidence of Position Bias in Canadian Long Ballots (preprint 1.0)
affiliations: Memorial University of Newfoundland (MUN) - Faculty of Business Administration

detail.title: Evidence of Position Bias in Canadian Long Ballots (preprint 1.0)
detail.abstract: This study investigates the potential democratic impact caused by extremely long ballots in Canadian federal elections, driven by the strategic use of "candidate stuffing", a tactic in which activist groups recruit numerous individuals to run for office, for motives unrelated to winning. Candidate stuffing inflates ballot length and frustrates voters which attracts media attention, and provides a platform for activists to spread their views. In three federal Canadian elections, candidate stuffing resulted in ballots with up to 91 candidates, spanning over a meter in length. This study examines whether candidate stuffing may have impacted democratic integrity. One of the most well-documented ballot design biases is called "position bias", where candidates at the top receive disproportionately more votes, with a vote share advantage that often ranges from around 1-5%--more than enough to alter election outcomes. Since position bias increases with ballot length, we analyzed the vote patterns of three candidate stuffed elections, to assess if the Canadian data matches the same position bias pattern observed in research from thousands of elections. This paper also presents a method for converting two-column ballot layouts into numerical coordinates suitable for statistical analysis, along with a technique for reconstructing individual-level voting data with candidate position coordinates. Using publicly available data from Elections Canada, the analysis shows strong evidence of position bias in all three elections. The data suggests that candidate stuffing has likely altered the vote share in each case and may have changed the outcome in one election. More broadly, the study concludes that all Canadian federal elections may be influenced by position bias to some degree, and that long ballots, which amplified this bias, may have revealed a democratic shortcoming that was previously harder to detect. The paper concludes that candidate stuffing poses a credible threat to electoral integrity and may represent a national security concern. The paper closes with several suggestions, shaped by public feedback.

detail.title: From Value to Market: The Meta Business Model Value-Centric Business Modeling
detail.abstract: How can firms design value architectures that remain adaptive in socio-technical turbulence? This paper reconceptualises the business model as an ontological structure of economic meaning. Drawing on systems theory, design research and philosophy of science, it articulates a Minimal Viable Business Model (MVBM) comprising four nested loops: Value Design, Internal Value Cycle, External Value Network and the Extended SocioEconomic Environment. A dual-case, theory-replication analysis of Suno (AI music) and Armedangels (circular fashion) demonstrates diagnostic power across industries. An Innovation Evaluation Matrix and Basic Business Logic Loop are positioned as managerial heuristics, and business modelling is theorised as semiotic mediation that aligns material flows with stakeholder world-views. Limitations and avenues for empirical testingsurvey, experiment, longitudinal study-are outlined. The contribution is to shift strategy discourse from static artefacts to ontological interventions in complex systems.

detail.abstract: This socio-legal article critically examines the multifaceted dimensions of rape law and justice in India, navigating the complex interplay between statutory provisions, judicial interpretations, law enforcement practices, and lived experiences of survivors. Drawing upon an extensive range of legal texts, NCRB crime data, judgments, and feminist literature, the study exposes the persistent gaps between codified laws and their on-ground implementation. It interrogates the caste, class, and gender hierarchies embedded in the justice system, explores the implications of carceral feminism, and compares adversarial legal frameworks with survivor-centric models. With a focus on contemporary developments-including the new Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, debates on marital rape, and alternative justice pathways-the research calls for a systemic overhaul rooted in legal reform, community accountability, and reparative justice. By centering the voices of marginalised survivors, the study contributes to reimagining justice beyond punitive paradigms towards a more humane, equitable, and responsive legal system.

title: Unveiling Patterns in ESG Performance and Volatility: Insights from Listed Indian Firms Using ML Techniques

detail.title: Unveiling Patterns in ESG Performance and Volatility: Insights from Listed Indian Firms Using ML Techniques
detail.abstract: Sustainability is no longer a choice but a necessity in today's landscape. In recent times, more investors are channelizing their funding towards greener and sustainable firms. This incentivizes firms to adopt environmentally responsible practices. And to evaluate the extent of sustainability among corporates, ESG scores are widely being deployed. This study analyses the case of 22 Listed Indian firms for the time period 2015-22. The goal of this paper is to uncover hidden patterns among firms based on ESG scores, stock price volatility and financial indicators with the help of ML techniques. From the analysis, 3 distinguishable patterns were found among firms based on clustering; High ESG score firms in general had low volatility and a healthy financial standing. On the contrary, firms with low ESG score had high volatility and poor financial standing. Firms with mid-level ESG scores showed moderate volatility and financial standing. Anomaly detection results indicated the presence of anomalies among the 22 firms. Random Forest Regression was performed to compare prediction with actuals. Feature Importance concluded EBIT as the most important feature followed by CSR. The findings provide valuable insights on how ESG scores and financial indicators relate to stock price volatility which in turn influences investor decisions.

title: The Politics of Acting First: Introducing Anticipated Steps Initiation (ASI) as a Strategic Framework of Power and Preemptive Political Behaviour

detail.title: The Politics of Acting First: Introducing Anticipated Steps Initiation (ASI) as a Strategic Framework of Power and Preemptive Political Behaviour
detail.abstract: Background: Prevailing strategic frameworks in politics such as game theory and crisis response tend to prioritise reaction after events unfold. However, in contemporary governance, actors increasingly shape outcomes through subtle, preemptive behaviours that escape conventional models. Scope and Purpose: This paper introduces Anticipated Steps Initiation (ASI) as a foundational framework of behavioural foresight. ASI explains how political actors initiate influence before formal events through symbolic cues, layered timing and informal leverage. It seeks to provide scholars, policymakers and strategists with a more predictive lens for understanding and navigating strategic behaviour in both democratic and hybrid regimes. Methodology: The paper applies a conceptual approach, grounded in comparative theoretical review and real world case studies from Malaysia, Singapore and Indonesia. The analysis is supported by the Overt-Covert Analysis model, which maps ASI behaviours across governance transparency and activation visibility. Analysis: ASI is built on seven behavioural mechanisms: initiation, symbolic encoding, temporal layering, narrative conditioning, informal leverage, instinctive futures and formal advantage. It defines three operational typologies: offensive, defensive and latent. Through illustrative cases, the paper shows how ASI actors shape institutional responses before rivals are even aware. Implications: ASI offers new diagnostic and planning tools for public sector agencies and think tanks. It also raises critical ethical questions regarding preemptive strategy in fragile democracies and transitional states. ASI thus marks the beginning of a broader discipline in behavioural foresight for governance.

title: Revolutionizing Diagnostic Radiology in Low-Resource African Settings: Indigenous Innovations, Technological Gaps, and the Ethics of Clinical Visibility

detail.abstract:
Background: Diagnostic radiology is a cornerstone of modern healthcare. However, in low-resource African settings, technological gaps, supply chain constraints, and structural inequalities lead to an endemic "clinical invisibility," severely compromising diagnostic capacity. Despite these challenges, local healthcare practitioners are developing innovative, frugal solutions tailored to their specific contexts. Objective: This study explores the indigenous innovations emerging within African diagnostic radiology ecosystems, analyses persistent technological gaps, and proposes a contextual ethical framework addressing the visibility-invisibility dichotomy in clinical decision-making. Methods: A qualitative, multi-site exploratory study was conducted in three urban centers in the Democratic Republic of Congo: Kinshasa, Lubumbashi, and Kisangani. Data collection involved 30 semi-structured interviews with radiologists, 15 in-depth interviews with biomedical engineers, and non-participant observations in clinical settings. Data were thematically analyzed using NVivo software.
Results: Innovations identified included the creative use of mobile phones with AI-powered applications for point-of-care ultrasound, and locally fabricated radiological supports using recycled materials. However, technological gaps persisted, notably with a 70% failure rate in heavy diagnostic equipment (CT, MRI), compounded by unreliable maintenance infrastructures. These gaps produce an ethical crisis of clinical invisibility, forcing clinicians into decision-making under epistemic uncertainty.
Conclusion: Endogenous innovations represent a form of "resistance intelligence" against structural diagnostic invisibility. However, sustainable progress requires a rethinking of technological sovereignty and the adoption of an "Ethics of Visibility" tailored to low-resource settings. This study proposes a novel conceptual framework to guide equitable diagnostic practices in Africa.

title: Cognitive Gravity and its Singularity: A Unified Physics of Expert Cognitive Inertia and Organizational Adaptive Inertia

detail.abstract: A fundamental paradox pervades the history of scientific and commercial innovation: why do the most successful intelligent entities, from Einstein to Kodak, so often become prisoners of their own success? To resolve this enigma, we introduce and formalize a unified dynamical framework centered on the Principle of Cognitive Gravity. Our core thesis posits that the cognition of any intelligent entity operates within a "cognitive spacetime" whose geometry is warped by historical experience. Success accumulates Cognitive Mass (M c) within this space, and when this mass exceeds a critical threshold, it undergoes gravitational collapse, forming what we term a Cognitive Singularity (or "cognitive black hole")-a region that systematically distorts and captures conflicting paradigmatic information. Through systematic analysis of the cross-scale structural isomorphism between Einstein's resistance to quantum mechanics and Kodak's failure in the digital revolution, we provide compelling preliminary evidence for the principle's scale invariance. Crucially, the theory moves beyond explanation to prediction: it hypothesizes that the effects of cognitive gravity are diffuse and global, detectable at the neural level via seemingly unrelated priming tasks-a forecast that starkly contrasts with traditional cognitive models. Ultimately, this framework offers a novel "cognitive physics" perspective for understanding cognitive inertia and lays the scientific foundation for an emerging applied discipline, Cognitive Systems Engineering, by providing a testable prediction about the diffuse effects of gravity that fundamentally challenges existing paradigms.

Lean thinking has revolutionized manufacturing—but its power doesn't end there.

In Lean in Government and Education, internationally recognized Lean expert Mohammed Hamed Ahmed Soliman takes readers beyond the factory floor to explore how Lean principles can radically improve public sector services and educational institutions. detail.title: A Critical Review of Money Lender Laws in Nigeria: A Case Study of Lagos and Akwa Ibom State
detail.abstract: This paper critically assesses the regulatory frameworks within which money lending occurs in Nigeria, with Lagos and Akwa Ibom States as case studies. The paper exposes differences between the two states in respect to the protection of borrowers, accountability of lenders, and mechanisms for enforcement. Though Lagos had demonstrated a more organized regulatory framework, including licensing and usury rates, its implementation is problematic, with the operation of informal lenders still being visible. On the other hand, the less formalized framework in Akwa Ibom presents significant risks of borrowers being exploited by unregulated lenders. In this paper, the socioeconomic implications of such a regulatory difference with regard to borrower vulnerability, cycles of debt, and financial insecurity are analyzed using secondary data in a qualitative manner. The findings bring to the fore the need for a standardized yet adaptable federal framework that harmonizes regulations, promotes financial inclusion, and protects borrowers across Nigeria. Recommendations include strengthening enforcement capacities, smoothing the process of licensing, and implementing borrower education programs in order to have a more level and fair money lending environment.

detail.abstract: The acceleration of digital transformation has had a major impact on organizational management strategies in various sectors. To remain competitive, organizations are required to adopt a managerial approach that is responsive to technological changes and market dynamics. This article aims to examine effective management strategies that can improve organizational performance in the digital age, through a literature review and case studies. Key focuses include digital leadership, data-driven decision-making, agile management, and digital human resource development. The case study of PT Telkom Indonesia shows that successful digital transformation requires visionary leadership, technology infrastructure support, and an adaptive organizational culture. Conclusion: An effective management strategy in the digital era must be flexible, collaborative, and supported by the optimal use of digital technology. Tip: Organizations are advised to develop a measurable digital roadmap, improve digital HR competencies, and strengthen technology integration in managerial processes to support performance sustainability.

title: Digital Innovation in Public Service: The Role of M-Paspor in Immigration Information System Management

detail.title: Digital Innovation in Public Service: The Role of M-Paspor in Immigration Information System Management
detail.abstract: The development of information technology has driven digital transformation in public services, including in Indonesia's immigration system. The Directorate General of Immigration has responded to this need by launching the Mobile Passport (M-Paspor) application, aimed at digitizing the passport application process. This article aims to analyze the effectiveness of the M-Paspor application in supporting the immigration information management system, particularly in terms of data integration, process efficiency, and service quality. The study employs a qualitative descriptive method based on literature reviews and secondary data. The findings show that M-Paspor has improved administrative efficiency, accelerated data flow between units, and enhanced information accuracy. Nevertheless, challenges remain, such as digital gaps, dependence on technology infrastructure, and the need for improved human resource competencies. Recommendations include enhancing system interoperability, strengthening data security policies, and developing digitally skilled human resources.

title: The Connect Framework as a Bridge Between Education and Marketing Strategy

detail.title: The Connect Framework as a Bridge Between Education and Marketing Strategy
detail.abstract: Traditional marketing strategies, which focused primarily on mass communication and short-term conversions, have increasingly been recognized as insufficient in an environment where personalization, emotional resonance, and long-term trust are prioritized. As consumer expectations continue to rise alongside technological capabilities, the need for relationship-based marketing approaches has grown. In response to this shift, the CONNECT methodology was developed in 2019 as a structured, seven-stage framework initially designed to support international student success. In this paper, the CONNECT model-Cultivate Trust, Optimize Pathways, Nurture Motivation, Network Strategically, Engage Continuously, Collaborate with Stakeholders, and Track & Transform-is reinterpreted through the lens of modern marketing theory and practice. Supported by academic literature, case analyses, and conceptual integration, the CONNECT methodology is proposed as a transformative tool for emotionally intelligent, data-driven, and consumer-centric marketing strategies.

title: Understanding Private Tutoring Online Platforms: A Deep Dive into Online Education Marketplaces
affiliations: WHU - Otto Beisheim School of Management

detail.title: Understanding Private Tutoring Online Platforms: A Deep Dive into Online Education Marketplaces
detail.abstract: The global rise of online education has significantly transformed the private tutoring industry, giving way to a new wave of digital marketplaces. These platforms connect students and tutors across borders, offering flexible, personalized learning experiences. This study explores the current landscape of online tutoring marketplaces by analyzing market size, growth trends, and platform business models. It examines the power dynamics between tutors, platform providers, and learners, highlighting how the scarcity of qualified educators, increasing demand for personalized instruction, and the proliferation of technological tools are reshaping value creation in this sector. Through a strategic analysis using Porter’s Five Forces framework, the publication reveals the competitive pressures and innovation imperatives that define this fast-evolving ecosystem. Additionally, it addresses challenges such as quality assurance, platform dependence, and competition from free educational resources. The findings offer insights into the economic and structural foundations of modern tutoring marketplaces and provide recommendations for stakeholders aiming to navigate or disrupt this growing sector.

title: Utilization of Management Information System to Support Human Resource Management at the Immigration Office "Prepared to Fulfill One of the Assignments for the Management Information System Course"

detail.title: Utilization of Management Information System to Support Human Resource Management at the Immigration Office "Prepared to Fulfill One of the Assignments for the Management Information System Course"
detail.abstract: This paper explores the role of the Management Information System (MIS) in supporting Human Resource Management (HRM) at the Immigration Office, a public service institution under the Directorate General of Immigration. In the digital era, effective HR management requires real-time data, transparent processes, and integration across organizational units. MIS provides a solution by enabling efficient employee data processing, performance evaluation, attendance tracking, and training documentation. The paper discusses how MIS implementation improves the quality of HR services, promotes accountability, and enhances public service delivery. Additionally, this study identifies the challenges faced in MIS implementation and offers strategic recommendations to optimize its use in the context of public sector HRM.

title: Supply Chain Resilience through Blockchain Technology: Cybersecurity, Digital Twin Integration, and Predictive Maintenance
affiliations: K. J. Somaiya College of Engineering, Armiet College  and Vivekanand Education Society's College of Architecture (VESCOA)

detail.title: Supply Chain Resilience through Blockchain Technology: Cybersecurity, Digital Twin Integration, and Predictive Maintenance
detail.abstract: The current global supply chain terrain is full of challenges-geopolitical tensions, natural disasters, cyber-attacks, and technological disruptions, all of which require innovative approaches to maintaining operational resilience and business continuity. In this chapter, we discuss how blockchain technology can be leveraged as a seminal infrastructure to reinforce the resilience of supply chains incorporating integrated cybersecurity approaches, digital twin deployment, and predictive maintenance policies. The paper is building upon current literature and trends to discuss the potential of blockchain's immutable ledger capabilities to develop resilient, digital twin-based supply chain ecosystems optimized for dealing with and rebounding from supply chain disruptions. The investigation presents the blockchain technology as an essential facilitator for real-time visibility, traceability, and trust among complex supply networks as well as for cybersecurity with decentralized authentication and cryptographic protections aspects. Integration of digital twins enhances these advantages by generating digital representations of physical supply chain assets and operations, to provide continuous observation and simultaneous simulation and optimization of processes. Predictive maintenance apps also improve resilience by using machine learning models and IoT sensor data to predict equipment breakdowns before they occur and streamline maintenance scheduling. The chapter further points to important opportunities for organizations to use these intersecting technologies for competitive advantage and discusses some potential barriers of success such as technology complexity, standards issues and organizational preparedness needs. The paper adds to the emerging work in supply chain digitalization and offers a practical perspective for managers interested in building operational resilience through adoption of emerging technologies.

title: Digital Twins and Human Agency: The Imperative and Place of Complexity Science

detail.title: Digital Twins and Human Agency: The Imperative and Place of Complexity Science
detail.abstract: Digital twins are reshaping the governance of infrastructure-but not without risk. Born in the lunar ambitions of NASA, the digital twin has migrated into civil domains, promising precision, foresight, and efficiency. Yet beneath that promise lies a world of complexity-where transport systems are social, institutional, and deeply historical. This essay traces the twin's ascent, surveying national policies and global trends, then unpacks the five interwoven layers of the digital twin ecosystem. It argues that without the lens of complexity science, the digital twin becomes reductionist-amplifying false certainty. True value lies not in perfect simulation but in adaptive co-evolution, where human agency, judgment, and institutional memory remain indispensable. Digital twins, reframed, must help us steer-not solve-complexity.

title: Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning for Supply Chain Resilience: Risk Assessment and Decision Making in Manufacturing Industry 4.0 and 5.0
affiliations: K. J. Somaiya College of Engineering, Armiet College  and Vivekanand Education Society's College of Architecture (VESCOA)

detail.title: Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning for Supply Chain Resilience: Risk Assessment and Decision Making in Manufacturing Industry 4.0 and 5.0
detail.abstract: Adoption and incorporation of artificial intelligence and machine learning in supply chain management have become one of the key enablers in strengthening resilience and risk management in an evolving Industry 4.0 and 5.0 context. This chapter offers a thorough exploration about how AI and ML applications are disrupting the risk assessment and decisionmaking activities for manufacturing supply chain. 6.2 PRISMA Findings Synthesising emerging trends and future directions in AI-enabled SC resilience. To consolidate the state of the art in the field, this study review adopted a PRISMA methodology that catalogues the empirical and theoretical literature. The research finds that machine and deep learning, reinforcement learning, and ensemble algorithms, are increasingly used for predictive analytics, real-time risk monitoring, and autonomous decision-making in supply chain management. Key use cases are identified, such as demand prediction, supplier risk management, inventory optimization, and disruption prediction in complex manufacturing network. The study identifies significant progress in such technologies as digital twins, edge computing and human-centric AI systems, which all represent the move from Industry 4.0 to Industry 5.0. The data quality and data interoperability problems, algorithmic transparency issues, and the requirements of robust cybersecurity framework are identified as the challenges ahead. Results reveal that AI driven supply chain resilience strategies can lower the operational risks by 45% and increase the reaction speed towards market volatilities by 60%. This chapter adds to the AI/ML literature by developing an organized taxonomy of how AI/ML is currently and prospectively being used to enhance supply chain resilience and by offering an illustrative application for manufacturing companies to become intelligent, sustainable, and human-focused supply chain ecosystems.

title: Gravity Modelling of Intercontinental Supply Chains Considering a New Port Location
affiliations: Alma Mater Europaea – European Center, Maribor, Technical University of Cartagena (UPCT), Technical University of Cartagena (UPCT) and University of Texas at Dallas - Naveen Jindal School of  Management

detail.title: Gravity Modelling of Intercontinental Supply Chains Considering a New Port Location

publicationDetails.detailsText: Central European Journal of Operations Research, 0[10.1007/s10100-024-00909-0]

detail.abstract: We study intercontinental supply chains, with each continent having cargo hubs competing with location advantages and efficiency. We estimate and compare the sequence of flows between nodes using gravity models (GM). However, in studying the global location advantages of a port, these sequences should be well connected, a case not treated in the literature. We combine a multi-echelon supply chain approach with well-combined sequential gravity mechanisms where the time distances, waiting time in the ports, and GDP of origin and destination play a central role. Our approach represents a novel approach to the intercontinental supply chain design and evaluation. In GM, the time distance variable is a proxy for transportation cost and enables us to jointly estimate transportation and waiting time influences. The time distance better measures impact of a pollutant on the environment of a supply chain than the geographic distance. With the time distances as a major factor in the GM formula, the GM is embedded in three consecutive sections of the intercontinental supply chain formulation and strongly connects them. The approach enables us to estimate the advantages of opening a new port in Cartagena, as the main port of Murcia, Spain. This investment would reduce the waiting lines of ships in other ports of the northern Mediterranean Sea and attract more containerized vessels to the area. Using sequential gravity mechanisms, we find that the Cartagena area in Murcia was appealing enough to begin investing in a new port, which could be among the top 100 international ports.

title: Entrepreneurship as Rebellion: Social Pressure, Colonial Legacies, and the Collapse of Support Systems for Youth in Rural Kashmir

detail.title: Entrepreneurship as Rebellion: Social Pressure, Colonial Legacies, and the Collapse of Support Systems for Youth in Rural Kashmir

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no competing interests. This research was conducted independently and received no external funding or institutional support that could have influenced the study.
declarations.ethicsApproval: Ethical approval was not required for this study due to its nature. All participants gave verbal informed consent, and no identifying information was collected. Pseudonyms were used, and data were securely stored in accordance with ethical research practices.

detail.abstract: This article examines the sociocultural and structural barriers that inhibit youth entrepreneurship in rural Kashmir. Drawing on semi-structured interviews with 48 participants aged 16 to 32, including secondary school students and young adults preparing for government jobs or civil services, the study applies Social Cognitive Career Theory (SCCT) to understand how familial pressure, colonial occupational hierarchies, and institutional exclusion discourage entrepreneurial aspirations. Findings suggest that entrepreneurship in this context is perceived not only as economically risky but also as a deviation from socially sanctioned norms of respectability. The paper argues that addressing these barriers requires context-sensitive interventions that include mentorship from local role models, curriculum reform, and improved dissemination of entrepreneurship schemes. The study contributes to scholarship on youth agency, education, and economic development in conflict-affected societies.

title: Supply Chain Resilience through Internet of Things, Big Data Analytics, and Automation for Real-Time Monitoring
affiliations: K. J. Somaiya College of Engineering, Armiet College  and Vivekanand Education Society's College of Architecture (VESCOA)

detail.title: Supply Chain Resilience through Internet of Things, Big Data Analytics, and Automation for Real-Time Monitoring
detail.abstract: The supply chain environment today presents new and unprecedented challenges in the form of Volatility, Uncertainty, Complexity, and Ambiguity (VUCA) which has significantly aggravated the need for resilient systems. This chapter analyses the emergent transformation provided by Internet of Things (IoT), big data analytics and automation technologies to bolster supply chain resilience by offering real-time visibility. The study examines how such nascent digital technologies, a cornerstone of Industry 4.0 and the emergent Industry 5.0 notions, enable agile and responsive supply chain ecosystems that can adapt to and recover from such uncertainties. The integration of smart manufacturing and advanced digital technologies for operational efficiency and inventory management optimization: A literature review using the PRISMA method Results show that IoT enabled sensors and devices produce massive amounts of real-time data, and when integrated with advanced Big Data analytics platforms, offer deep insights and predictive power for supply chain networks. Automated technologies can also extend these abilities by engaging in decision making and other responses that can react nimbly to changing situations. The study shows that firms utilising these integrated technological solutions are able to enhance supply chain agility, risk reduction and overall resilience. But there are struggles ahead, such as cyber security worries and the difficulty of integration, as well as the cost of major infrastructure spending. The chapter adds to the current literature by developing an integrated structure for understanding the interrelated impact of these technologies on supply chain resilience which includes operationalization of these concepts within the framework, and practical implications for organizations wishing to transform their supply chain in an environment characterized by enhanced digitalization and connectivity.

title: Resilience and Sustainability in Supply Chains through Circular Economy: Environmental Impact, Climate Change Mitigation, and Waste Management
affiliations: K. J. Somaiya College of Engineering, Armiet College  and Vivekanand Education Society's College of Architecture (VESCOA)

detail.title: Resilience and Sustainability in Supply Chains through Circular Economy: Environmental Impact, Climate Change Mitigation, and Waste Management
detail.abstract: The implementation of circular economy (CE) principles into the supply chain is becoming an important approach for accomplishing environmental sustainability with the reduction of impacts of climate changes in the modern business world. This chapter provides a comprehensive review of how circular economy strategies, improve supply chain resilience based on environmental impacts, waste management dilemma, and sustainable targets covering the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. Based on a systematic literature review using the PRISMA methodology, this study reviews state-of-the-art application cases, approaches, frameworks, and future trends of sustainable SCM. It was found that the implementation of a circular economy in supply chains substantially decreases the environmental impacts via waste minimization, optimal resource use efficiency and circular material flows. Key results show that companies practicing circular supply chain models are more resilient to disturbances, increase in resource security and can achieve significant reductions in greenhouse gas emissions. Findings reveal key success factors: stakeholder collaboration, technological innovation, alignment with regulation and evaluation systems. But challenges remain in terms of capital demands when it comes to the initial investment cost, the complexity of the coordination systems, and the standardization of circular metrics. It also advances the body of knowledge by bridging circular economy principles and supply chain resilience in an integrated manner, offering practical implications for the stakeholders. Possible future research directions are advanced analytics for circular supply chain optimization, adoption of emerging technologies such as blockchain and artificial intelligence in traceability and efficiency, and cross-industry collaboration models for scale of the circular economy.

detail.abstract: This article analyzes the legal, technical, and organizational aspects of the "Samardorlik" (Efficiency) information system and the KPI (Key Performance Indicators) mechanism introduced in Uzbekistan's customs system in accordance with Presidential Decree No. 122 dated April 27, 2022. It explores how performance evaluation has been integrated into the customs sector using digital tools aimed at ensuring transparency and boosting institutional efficiency. The paper also reviews international best practices by examining approaches to civil service performance evaluation in countries such as South Korea, France, Japan, Kazakhstan, the UAE, and Malaysia. Special attention is given to how digitalization and objective metrics can enhance accountability and productivity in public administration.

title: A Practical Guide to Hedge the Risk of Logistic Cost Volatility using a Financial Approach
affiliations: University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus and Nottingham University Business School, Malaysia Campus

detail.title: A Practical Guide to Hedge the Risk of Logistic Cost Volatility using a Financial Approach
detail.abstract: Seaborne is the backbone of international trade. Seaborne trades contribute over 80% of the international trade volume. However, with the increasingly tense geopolitical events, sea freight prices have become significantly volatile, and this has threatened the business-as-usual of the international businesses. Although prevailing logistics and supply chain studies advocate other long-term risk reduction strategies such as China-plus-one, setting up alternative local suppliers, etc, this study contributes a totally different perspective on the risk mitigation strategy using a financial approach with step-by-step guidance provided. This study explores the direct hedging and cross-hedging instruments and apply the financial hedging strategies that can be used to mitigate the risk of seaborne rate volatility based on the Shanghai Containerized Export Freight Index (SCFI). This study employs the simple ordinary least squares (OLS), vector autoregressive (VAR), vector error correction (VEC), and maximal overlap discrete wavelet transform (MODWT) models to evaluate the direct hedging and cross-hedging effectiveness of the futures contracts with different underlying assets, such as various commodities and stock indices. Among all estimated hedge ratios, multiscale hedge ratios perform the best, simple OLS perform moderately, while static hedge ratios estimated by VAR and VEC models underperform. Surprisingly, the direct hedge is not always the most effective hedging instrument for the risk of sea freight rate over the medium to longer-term period, but it remains the most effective hedge over the short-term period. In addition, steel futures and European stock index futures outperform other crosshedges and even the SCFIS (Europe) futures contract in some cases.

title: FinFluence: Utilizing AI to Customize Financial Certification Preparation for Employed Individuals -A Research Framework Asif Raza, ACCA(UK), CMA (USA) MSc in Professional Accountancy University Of London ( UK)

detail.title: FinFluence: Utilizing AI to Customize Financial Certification Preparation for Employed Individuals -A Research Framework Asif Raza, ACCA(UK), CMA (USA) MSc in Professional Accountancy University Of London ( UK)
detail.abstract: Obtaining advanced financial certifications (CFA, FRM, CPA, CFP, etc.) is essential for professional progression in the competitive finance industry. Nonetheless, working professionals have substantial obstacles: rigorous schedules, disparities in knowledge based on experience, and the ineffectiveness of general "one-size-fits-all" preparatory programs. This paper presents and elaborates on the conceptual foundation for "FinFluence"-an AI-driven platform aimed at transforming financial certification preparation via hyper-personalization. FinFluence employs adaptive learning algorithms, detailed knowledge assessments, predictive analytics, and curated material distribution to customize study plans according to an individual's specific profile, learning speed, knowledge level, available time, and career objectives. We delineate the fundamental AI modules (Diagnostic Assessment Engine, Dynamic Knowledge Mapping & Pathfinder, Temporal Optimization Scheduler, Content Intelligence & Recommender, Predictive Performance Analytics), examine the foundational technologies (machine learning, NLP, knowledge graphs), and evaluate the prospective effects on pass rates, study efficiency, knowledge retention, and learner satisfaction. The study emphasizes the intersection of artificial intelligence, educational technology, and finance, offering a scalable remedy to a widespread industrial issue. Validation methodologies, ethical considerations (including bias reduction and data protection), and prospective research objectives are also examined.

detail.abstract: This narrative reflection explores how everyday communication practices in residential aged care can support the implementation of Strengthened Standard 6: Food and Nutrition, part of Australia's updated Aged Care Quality Standards. Drawing from firsthand experience as a catering assistant, the piece highlights how small interactions-such as conversations with carers, feedback from residents, and staff collaboration-play a critical role in delivering safe, person-centred, and meaningful mealtime experiences. Through these practical insights, the reflection illustrates how communication can function as a system-strengthening tool, helping to translate policy into daily care. The piece is intended to inform aged care practitioners, managers, and policymakers seeking to align food service with reform goals and improve quality of life for older adults in care.

title: Backward-Bending Supply: Economists' Biggest Mistake
affiliations: Chienkuo Technology University - Department of International Business

detail.title: Backward-Bending Supply: Economists' Biggest Mistake
detail.abstract: The most glaring failure of economists is surely their inability to derive a positive labor supply curve. What they have obtained so far is a hybrid one with backward-bending slopes. This paper disproves the bend, so that such a supply relation can only be negative, and further reveals how the abnormal supply is flawed. Instead, this paper proves that the relation actually describes the negative cross-demand for labor. Subsequently, this paper also defines cross-demand relation for capital, and cross-supply relations of output.

title: Return-Adjusted Hierarchical Risk Parity and Schur Portfolios: A Comprehensive Theoretical and Empirical Study

detail.title: Return-Adjusted Hierarchical Risk Parity and Schur Portfolios: A Comprehensive Theoretical and Empirical Study
detail.abstract: This paper introduces Return-Adjusted Hierarchical Risk Parity (RA-HRP), a novel portfolio allocation methodology that incorporates expected returns to HRP de Prado [2016]. We develop comprehensive theoretical foundations for RA-HRP, providing formal proofs of optimality conditions and establishing when the method should outperform traditional approaches. As a secondary contribution, we extend Cotton [2024] Schur Complementary Allocation framework by introducing three distinct Schur portfolio variants with enhanced theoretical foundations. Using a diversified portfolio of 15 major US stocks from 2010 to 2024, our empirical analysis demonstrates that RA-HRP achieves exceptional performance with a Sharpe ratio of 1.336, representing a statistically significant 5.31% annual excess return over traditional HRP. This breakthrough stems from RA-HRP's ability to systematically allocate toward high-Sharpe ratio assets while maintaining robust diversification through hierarchical clustering. Our Schur portfolio extensions demonstrate competitive performance, with the Risk-Adjusted variant achieving a Sharpe ratio of 1.049. The theoretical framework provides precise predictions about optimal deployment conditions, and our comprehensive empirical validation strongly confirms these predictions. This work establishes RA-HRP as a superior alternative to traditional HRP and contributes valuable extensions to spectral portfolio construction methods.
