detail.abstract: Quantitative hedge funds and financial technology firms are rapidly integrating artificial intelligence into trading and risk management. However, systematic limitations in large language models (LLMs) can generate misleading backtests, inflated performance metrics, and regulatory exposure. We introduce a three-agent compliance framework designed to mitigate AI hallucination and overfitting in financial applications. The framework combines human-in-the-loop oversight, constraint translation through Anthropic's Claude AI, and controlled implementation using OpenAI's ChatGPT-4. Applied to five years of multi-asset data (300 weekly observations across 29 instruments), the system prevented fabricated Sharpe ratios and eliminated unsubstantiated "get-rich-quick" strategies while preserving analytical innovation. Average Sharpe Ratios declined from 1.13 in unconstrained testing to 0.047 after transaction cost adjustments, providing honest failure reporting and realistic performance attribution. Unlike post-hoc detection methods, our approach embeds domain-specific financial safeguards directly in the strategy generation process. The framework consistently blocked Sharpe >1.5 claims across 15 pressure-testing iterations, ensuring transparency, auditability, and regulatory alignment with emerging standards (e.g., SEC predictive analytics rules, IEEE 7000-2021, MiFID II). This methodology enables hedge funds, asset managers, and fintech platforms to enhance compliance readiness, reduce model risk, and build investor trust while optimizing AI-driven productivity.

title: The Impact of Anesthesiologist-Based Overlapping Surgeries on Operating Room Efficiency
affiliations: The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Renmin University of China - School of Business, Renmin University of China - School of Business, Tilburg University - Tilburg University School of Economics and Management, Guangzhou First People's Hospital and South China University of Technology - Guangzhou First People's Hospital

detail.title: The Impact of Anesthesiologist-Based Overlapping Surgeries on Operating Room Efficiency
detail.abstract: While the literature in healthcare operations primarily focuses on developing ex ante scheduling algorithms to improve operating room (OR) efficiency, we examine the impact of ad hoc surgery reallocation decisions on OR utilization. Methodology/Results: Using a large-scale surgery record dataset, we develop a rigorous process to identify ad hoc surgery reallocation decisions that are intended to improve OR efficiency but are not observed in the dataset. Applying counterfactual estimators to assess the impact of these decisions on OR utilization, we identify some key trade-offs. Specifically, we find that ad hoc reallocations reduce the over-utilization but increase the under-utilization in ORs from which surgeries are reallocated (i.e., the initial ORs). Moreover, the ORs receiving the reallocated surgeries (i.e., the recipient ORs) experience a reduction in under-utilization but a rise in over-utilization. Our mechanism analyses further demonstrate that the multifaceted impact of reallocations is contingent upon several factors (i.e., the number of originally scheduled surgeries and the presence of surgical and anesthesia assistants), a result that highlights the complexities in ad hoc surgery reallocation decisions. Managerial Implications: Our study is the first to provide a holistic examination of the impact of ad hoc surgery reallocation decisions. Practitioners should be mindful of the trade-offs in ad hoc surgery reallocation decisions when adopting this strategy to improve OR utilization and, by factoring in key contextual elements such as surgical volume and available support staff, make more informed decisions to balance resource utilization across ORs and minimize inefficiencies.

title: Extraterritorial Sanctions and Judicial Accountability: An Analysis of the Alexandre de Moraes Case from the Global Magnitsky Act Perspective (Sanções Extraterritoriais e Accountability Judicial: Uma Análise do Caso Alexandre de Moraes sob a Perspectiva da Lei Global Magnitsky)

detail.title: Extraterritorial Sanctions and Judicial Accountability: An Analysis of the Alexandre de Moraes Case from the Global Magnitsky Act Perspective (Sanções Extraterritoriais e Accountability Judicial: Uma Análise do Caso Alexandre de Moraes sob a Perspectiva da Lei Global Magnitsky)

publicationDetails.detailsText: This work is also available at: DOI: 10.5281/zenodo.16620535

detail.abstract:
This study analyzes the unprecedented case of American extraterritorial sanctions applied against Brazilian Supreme Federal Court (STF) Justice Alexandre de Moraes, sanctioned on July 30, 2025, by the U.S. Treasury Department under the Global Magnitsky Act for alleged human rights violations. The measure, confirmed by official OFAC release SB0211, is based on "arbitrary pre-trial detentions and suppression of freedom of expression," constituting an international legal precedent of great relevance. 

The research examines the technical-legal foundations of the sanctions, their legitimacy under international law, and implications for judicial accountability in democratic systems. Through rigorous documental analysis based exclusively on verified official primary sources, the work investigates whether the questioned judicial practices constitute human rights violations subject to extraterritorial international intervention. 

The Global Magnitsky program constitutes the flagship American foreign policy instrument for promoting accountability for human rights abuse and corruption globally. The study confirms that the sanctions find technical foundation in the extraterritoriality of the questioned judicial actions (direct orders to American companies) and direct impact on American citizens and companies, meeting the criteria established by Executive Order 13818. 

The research contributes to debate about the limits of judicial independence in democratic contexts and emerging international accountability mechanisms for fundamental rights violations, establishing an analytical framework for similar future cases.



RESUMO 

Este estudo analisa o caso inédito da aplicação de sanções extraterritoriais americanas contra o ministro Alexandre de Moraes do Supremo Tribunal Federal (STF), sancionado em 30 de julho de 2025 pelo Departamento do Tesouro americano sob a Lei Global Magnitsky por alegadas violações de direitos humanos. A medida, confirmada pelo comunicado oficial OFAC SB0211, fundamenta-se em "detenções pré-julgamento arbitrárias e supressão da liberdade de expressão", constituindo precedente jurídico internacional de grande relevância. 

A pesquisa examina os fundamentos técnico-jurídicos das sanções, sua legitimidade sob o direito internacional, e as implicações para a accountability judicial em sistemas democráticos. Através de análise documental rigorosa baseada exclusivamente em fontes primárias oficiais, o trabalho investiga se as práticas judiciais questionadas configuram violações de direitos humanos passíveis de intervenção internacional extraterritorial. 

O programa Global Magnitsky constitui o principal instrumento de política externa americana para promover accountability por abusos de direitos humanos e corrupção globalmente. O estudo confirma que as sanções encontram fundamento técnico na extraterritorialidade das ações judiciais questionadas e no impacto direto sobre cidadãos e empresas americanas, atendendo aos critérios estabelecidos pela Executive Order 13818. 

A pesquisa contribui para o debate sobre os limites da independência judicial em contextos democráticos e os mecanismos internacionais emergentes de accountability por violações de direitos fundamentais, estabelecendo marco analítico para casos similares futuros.

title: The Pyramid of Spatial Economic Evidence: A Principled Framework for High-Resolution Economic Estimation

detail.title: The Pyramid of Spatial Economic Evidence: A Principled Framework for High-Resolution Economic Estimation
detail.abstract: The application of machine learning to subnational economic estimation is often confronted by a lack of a generalizable and theory-driven framework for feature engineering, leading to a proliferation of ad-hoc, case-specific models. This paper addresses this gap by proposing and validating the Pyramid of Spatial Economic Evidence: a new, principled paradigm for organizing geospatial proxies into a conceptual hierarchy grounded in economic geography. The framework is structured in three levels: a Foundational Economic Footprint of direct human presence, a Structural Core of contextual modifiers from the developed and natural landscape, and an Apex for application-specific syntheses. We demonstrate the utility of this framework through an empirical application in Nepal, a severely data-scarce environment. Using 14 proxies organized according to the Pyramid, we confront a P ≫ N scenario (14 predictors, 7 provincial observations) by employing a PCA-enhanced Elastic Net (ENPCR) model. The model demonstrates robust out-ofsample predictive power (LOOCV RMSE = 0.296 on the log-GDP scale), and its residuals show no significant spatial autocorrelation spatial autocorrelation (Moran's I p=0.862). The model's scores are used in a mass-preserving dasymetric process to produce a validated 500-meter GDP map. This work makes a dual contribution: it delivers a valuable public data product for Nepal, and more broadly, it offers a transferable methodology for principled, high-resolution economic mapping in other data-scarce regions. We conclude by showing how the Pyramid framework can be extended beyond pure economic estimation to serve as a foundational layer for holistic Socio-Ecological System (SES) diagnostics.

detail.abstract: Firms with resources that make them attractive allies are also desirable partners for competitors so that competition among partners is embedded in alliance portfolios. We develop a framework in which competition within a portfolio creates benefits for a focal firm but threatens partners, increasing the hazard of alliance termination. We then propose four mechanisms for managing the threat of competition to partners reflecting aspects of portfolio configuration: alliance governance, social cohesion, social structure of competition, and partner similarity. We test our framework using a sample of 204 biopharmaceutical firms with alliance portfolios comprising 1,621 alliances between 1990 and 2000. The study addresses the interplay of competition and cooperation in alliance portfolios, and more generally, key aspects of value chain integration strategy.

title: The Diminishing Value of Bundling under Inventory Scarcity

detail.title: The Diminishing Value of Bundling under Inventory Scarcity
detail.abstract: We study the impact of inventory constraints on bundling in a dynamic pricing setting, challenging the classical view that bundling consistently enhances revenue. Traditional bundling theory, which usually assumes abundant inventory and static pricing settings, typically asserts that bundling generates higher revenue than selling products individually. However, we show that limited inventory, in fact, distorts the revenue extraction capability of bundling in favor of selling the products or services separately. We study the optimal dynamic mixed bundling strategy in a large market regime where the market size grows relative to limited inventory. Leveraging this framework, we derive optimal dynamic pricing policies and value functions for commonly used bundling strategies, including mixed bundling, pure bundling, bundle-size pricing, and component pricing. Our analysis reveals that as inventory becomes more constrained relative to market size, the most general dynamic mixed bundling strategy converges to a dynamic component pricing strategy, outperforming both dynamic bundle-size pricing and dynamic pure bundling. Moreover, the performance gap between these strategies increases with the number of items, a factor typically viewed as favoring bundling when inventory is abundant. Notably, our numerical experiments suggest that these insights also extend to the fluid-regime policies, revealing that as the market size increases relative to inventory, the dynamic mixed bundling strategy derived from the fluid regime mimics a dynamic component pricing strategy.

title: Is the World Ready for a Cryptocurrency Standard?

detail.title: Is the World Ready for a Cryptocurrency Standard?

Core interests include the impact of emerging digital currencies, the future of democratic institutions and various methods - both traditional and technological- used to influence public opinion and collective behaviour.

detail.abstract:
This paper evaluates whether the global financial system is structurally, economically and institutionally prepared for a transition to a cryptocurrency standard. Rather than predicting a linear shift, it conceptualizes readiness as an uneven, jurisdiction-specific process shaped by technological development, governance capacity and public legitimacy. Drawing on four interdependent dimensions (Technical infrastructure, Economic viability, Institutional governance and Societal trust) it offers a comparative framework to assess how nations may approach, resist, or redefine the role of decentralized monetary systems. Concluding that while foundational components are maturing, global preparedness remains fragmented and contested, demanding new approaches to adaptive, equitable monetary governance.

Historically, monetary transformations have followed crisis. This moment, arguably the first preemptive inflection point, presents a rare opportunity to architect financial systems informed by principles such as the Veil of Ignorance, rather than reactively shaped by the power dynamics of the moment. Canada, having led early with crypto ETF approvals, must now decide whether to shape the next standard or be shaped by it.

detail.abstract: In the unfolding terrain of 21st-century geopolitics, infrastructure has transcended concrete and steel to become a tool of diplomacy, identity, and strategic influence. Nowhere is this shift more consequential than in Africa, where a surge of global actors — from China to the European Union — are racing to secure footholds through digital networks, transport corridors, and energy pipelines. Can African diplomatic agency be a threat, an opportunity, or both for the EU? And what does this mean for the future of Europe's role in a multipolar world?

title: Navigating the New Trade Landscape: India's Options in Response to US Tariffs

detail.title: Navigating the New Trade Landscape: India's Options in Response to US Tariffs
detail.abstract: This article analyses India's strategic options in response to significant new trade challenges. In the face of a hypothetical 25% tariff on its goods by the United States, effective August 1, 2025, along with penalties related to its trade with Russia, India must consider a multi-pronged strategy. The tariffs threaten to impact key sectors of the Indian economy, including textiles, pharmaceuticals, and auto components, and potentially slow GDP growth. The paper examines a multi-pronged response being considered by New Delhi. This strategy includes: a diplomatic push for a bilateral trade agreement; an economic recalibration focused on trade diversification through new Free Trade Agreements (FTAs); strengthening domestic manufacturing via the 'Aatmanirbhar Bharat' initiative; considering retaliatory tariffs as a negotiating tool; and pursuing legal recourse at the World Trade Organization (WTO). The article concludes that India is likely to adopt a carefully calibrated approach, prioritizing a negotiated settlement while simultaneously building long-term economic resilience.

title: The Impact of Financial Education on High School Students' Financial Literacy in an American-Style International School in South Korea

detail.title: The Impact of Financial Education on High School Students' Financial Literacy in an American-Style International School in South Korea

declarations.ethicsApproval: Research conducted was reviewed by the school's Independent Review Board. The study performed was voluntary and collected consent from all participants.

detail.abstract:
This study examines the relationship between financial education exposure and financial literacy among high school students at an American-style international school in South Korea. Despite South Korea's position as the world's 12th largest economy, the nation ranks 77th globally in financial literacy, with only 33% of adults demonstrating basic financial knowledge. Using survey methodology, data were collected from 39 students aged 14-18.
Financial education exposure was measured using adapted PISA 2018 Financial Literacy Questionnaire items, while financial literacy was assessed through the validated “Big Five” questions covering compound interest, inflation, bond prices, mortgage rates, and risk diversification. Multiple linear regression analysis examined relationships between variables while controlling for demographic factors. Results revealed participants achieved a mean financial literacy score of 2.974 (SD = 1.423) on a 5-point scale, outperforming the general U.S. adult population benchmark of 2.6. However, financial education exposure showed only weak, statistically insignificant relationships with financial literacy across all models (β = 0.212-0.335, p > 0.1). In contrast, household income emerged as a significant predictor of financial literacy (β = 0.113, p = 0.079), suggesting socioeconomic factors play a more substantial role than formal education. Among financial education components, task-based learning demonstrated the strongest positive relationship with literacy, although this finding is statistically insignificant. These findings indicate that current financial education programs may emphasize theoretical knowledge over practical application, highlighting the need for more experiential, hands-on approaches to financial literacy instruction that address socioeconomic disparities.

title: The Dobrofsky Economic Model: A Unified Theory of Growth, Disruption, and Existential Risk

detail.title: The Dobrofsky Economic Model: A Unified Theory of Growth, Disruption, and Existential Risk
detail.abstract:
A Schumpeterian Evolution for the Planetary Crisis Era

The Dobrofsky Theory fundamentally reimagines creative destruction by unifying three irreversible modern realities—exponential technological acceleration, distributed innovation power, and existential risk materialization—into a single diagnostic framework. This is achieved through three pioneering metrics:

Ψ (Disruption Stress): Quantifies competitive pressure in hyper-innovation markets

Φ (Innovation Efficiency): Measures return-on-investment in layered tech ecosystems

Ω (Existential Risk Load): Prices planetary boundaries and technological threats as core economic variables

I. Theoretical Foundations: Beyond Schumpeter

1. Resolving Critical 21st-Century Gaps

From Linear to Exponential Disruption
Where Schumpeter described decades-long industrial cycles, Dobrofsky addresses compressed innovation waves (e.g., AI models achieving mass adoption in months rather than years).

From Solo Entrepreneurs to Hybrid Ecosystems
Replacing the myth of lone visionary founders with tripartite innovation: tech conglomerates, decentralized networks, and state-coordinated R&D competing/co-creating simultaneously.

From Externalities to Endogenous Catastrophes
Elevating climate collapse and uncontrolled AI from "market failures" to calculable economic forces that actively degrade growth potential.

2. Foundational Innovations

Dynamic Economic Vital Signs
Ψ, Φ, and Ω function as real-time diagnostics—akin to blood pressure readings for economies—revealing stress points before crises manifest.

Phase Transition Thresholds
Identifies critical tipping points where markets shift from sustainable growth to systemic collapse based on quantifiable interactions between innovation, competition, and risk.

Policy-Actionable Triggers
Converts abstract economic principles into intervention protocols (e.g., automatic antitrust enforcement when disruption stress crosses critical thresholds).

Policy Imperative

Unmanaged technological acceleration will push Disruption Stress (Ψ) beyond viable limits by 2030. This demands:

Containing Hyper-Competition: Preventing innovation arms races in critical sectors like AI

Redirecting Innovation Gains: Using efficiency windfalls (Φ) to buffer disruption victims

Pricing Existential Threats: Making risk load (Ω) tangible through market mechanisms

title: A Critical Review of Kubo and Nguyen (2023): Female CEOs, Background Types, and Firm Performance in Japan

detail.title: A Critical Review of Kubo and Nguyen (2023): Female CEOs, Background Types, and Firm Performance in Japan
detail.abstract: The article "Female CEOs on Japanese Corporate Boards and Firm Performance," published in the Journal of the Japanese and International Economies, explores the relationship between female CEOs and their companies' performance. The article's authors, Katsuyuki Kubo and Thanh Thi Phuong Nguyen, thoroughly analyse this relationship by classifying female CEOs into three groups based on their backgrounds: founders, heirs, and others. In brief, a founder CEO is someone who either played a key role in establishing the company or held a prominent executive position at the time that the company was established. An heir CEO is the individual who inherits the position of CEO from the founder of the firm. The authors classify all other female CEOs as 'sarariwoman CEOs', indicating that they are simply employees who have been promoted or recruited as executives without any direct ownership of the company. The authors used a variety of techniques to better understand the relationship. These include event studies, propensity score matching (PSM), difference-indifferences (DiD) estimation, instrumental variable (IV) two-stage least squares (2SLS) estimation, ordinary least squares (OLS), and fixed effects regressions.

detail.abstract: This paper addresses critical shortcomings in current retail investor risk profiling practices and introduces Portable Investment Risk Profile (PIRP) as an innovative solution. detail.abstract: The U.S. consumer credit market has experienced significant shifts from 2023 through 2025 due to regulatory uncertainty and rising interest rates. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) proposed capping credit card late fees at eight dollars for large issuers; however, this rule was vacated by federal courts in 2024, creating ongoing ambiguity for lenders. Concurrently, the Federal Reserve's series of interest rate hikes increased borrowing costs nationwide. This study analyzes aggregated portfolio data from a major publicly traded fintech company's private-label and co-branded credit card portfolios, encompassing billions of dollars in loans, to evaluate the combined effects of these factors on borrower credit risk, approval rates, delinquency, and lender capital requirements. Employing logistic regression, survival analysis, machine learning techniques, and scenario-based stress testing, the research finds that regulatory uncertainty around late fee caps correlates with improved repayment behavior but reduces fee income. Rising interest rates increase delinquency risk, partially mitigated by promotional financing products such as buy now pay later (BNPL) plans. A hybrid credit risk model incorporating regulatory and macroeconomic factors improves risk prediction and capital allocation. The findings offer actionable insights for credit risk managers, lenders, and policymakers aiming to balance consumer protection with financial stability.

title: Sinewave-Relative Hierarchical Volatility Model via RCP and Trend Failure

detail.title: Sinewave-Relative Hierarchical Volatility Model via RCP and Trend Failure

detail.abstract:
This paper introduces the Sinewave-based Relative Hierarchical Model (SRHM), a novel framework for modeling and forecasting financial market volatility through a multi-layered decomposition of price behavior. Grounded in the Hierarchical Linear Trend Failure Theory (HLTFT), SRHM treats volatility not as random noise but as a structured, regime-dependent phenomenon emerging from nested trend failures across time scales.
Inspired by long-span analysis of the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) and generalized across hundreds of lifetime price charts, the model constructs a hierarchy of linear trend approximations, with Relative Closing Price (RCP) deviations indicating regime transitions upon breaching layer-specific thresholds. 
Realized volatility is modeled as a superposition of nested sinewave components, each corresponding to a temporal regime (long-, mid-, or short-term) and dynamically modulated by decay coefficients and nonlinear impact parameters. To address market microstructure noise and residual artifacts, a wavelet-based correction term is included and calibrated via least-squares optimization. Regime frequencies are derived using autocorrelation and spectral analysis to align precisely with observed market periodicities.
By bridging concepts from technical analysis and quantitative modeling, SRHM offers a robust, interpretable framework suitable for both research and application. Its structure enables seamless integration with algorithmic trading, risk management tools, and future machine learning overlays.

title: Examining the Linkage between Supervisor Support and Quality of Work Life through Work Family Conflict

detail.title: Examining the Linkage between Supervisor Support and Quality of Work Life through Work Family Conflict
detail.abstract: Purpose: This study aimed to analyse the effect of supervisor support on quality of work life, the effect of work family conflict on quality of work life, and the effect of supervisor support on quality of work life (QWL) through work family conflict as intervening variable. Design/methodology/approach: Primary data were collected from 721 train drivers working in the South Central zone of Indian railways. The data collection tool was a questionnaire that is distributed online to the participants. Hierarchical regression analysis and mediation analysis using PROCESS Model 4 were employed to test the hypotheses. Main findings: Supervisor support had a significant positive effect on quality of work life, work family conflict had a significant negative effect on QWL, supervisor support showed a significant negative effect on work family conflict and work family conflict was found to be partially mediating the effect of supervisor support on QWL. Practical implications: The current research reported that a supportive supervisor can enhance employees' QWL directly, as well as indirectly by reducing conflicts at work and family interface. This finding suggests that organizations aiming to promote employees' QWL should invest in training programs that cultivate supportive behaviors among supervisors and also equip them with the resources needed to help employees manage the competing demands of work and family roles. Originality/value: By investigating the mediating role of work family conflict, this research uncovered the underlying mechanism through which supervisor support influences quality of work life, thereby contributing to the existing literature on QWL.

title: A 'Back to Keynes' Macroeconomic Model That Can See Inflation Coming -Predicting the Inflation Spike During the Covid Crisis

detail.title: A 'Back to Keynes' Macroeconomic Model That Can See Inflation Coming -Predicting the Inflation Spike During the Covid Crisis
detail.abstract: Why Did (Almost) No One See the Inflation Coming? asked Jason Furman in a 2022 paper which raised the key question of why economic models and forecasters failed to forsee the inflation spike that occurred in 2021-22. This failure was based on the current crop of standard macroeconomic models; we show how a model in the emerging ABM tradition (the SHD model), based on Keynes original but unformalized concepts, responds to the type of shocks and government stimulus which occurred during the covid crisis. Unlike current forecasting models we find that the SHD model does predict a spike in inflation similar to that actually observed, and of similar short duration. We discuss the outputs and uses of this type of model and its potential to bridge the gap between theory based and practical macroeconomic forecasting models.

detail.abstract: This paper investigates the sectoral fragilities that could trigger, amplify, or suppress a potential 2025 recession in India and the United States. Drawing from post-2008 contagion theory, macroeconomic indicator divergence, and recent financial sector developments, it argues that traditional aggregate signals such as yield curve inversion may be less reliable in today’s economic regime. Instead, sectoral interdependencies—especially profit concentration, credit exposure, and influence centrality—offer a more accurate framework for anticipating economic downturns. The paper synthesizes real-time data, Indian market behavior, and network contagion models to outline how localized shocks, particularly in IT, finance, or real estate, could propagate systemically. Ultimately, the analysis presents a sequence of plausible recession pathways grounded in sector-level interactions rather than top-down macro assumptions.

title: Board Gender Diversity and CSR Performance: Do Societal Harmony/Mastery Orientation and Cultural Tightness-Looseness Matter?

detail.title: Board Gender Diversity and CSR Performance: Do Societal Harmony/Mastery Orientation and Cultural Tightness-Looseness Matter?
detail.abstract: The purpose of this study is twofold: (1) to investigate the moderating effect of the cultural value orientation of harmony/mastery on the relationship between board gender diversity (BGD) and corporate social responsibility (CSR) performance; and (2) to examine further whether cultural tightness amplifies the moderating effect of harmony/mastery orientation. Using a sample of 5135 firms across 25 countries during the period 2002-2021, our interaction model run with panel regression showed that the association between BGD and CSR performance is positively (negatively) moderated by harmony (mastery) orientation. Moreover, our test of a three-way interaction among BGD, harmony (mastery), and cultural tightness-looseness on CSR performance revealed that the moderating effect of harmony (mastery) orientation is amplified when cultural tightness increases. The findings suggest that harmony/mastery orientation matters more for the effects of BGD on firm CSR performance under tight cultural conditions. We discuss the theoretical and practical implications of the study.

title: Unpacking an Externality of Assortment: Food Expiration Waste in Grocery Retail.&Nbsp;
affiliations: London Business School and Nanyang Business School, Nanyang Technological University

detail.title: Unpacking an Externality of Assortment: Food Expiration Waste in Grocery Retail.&Nbsp;
detail.abstract:
Problem definition: Assortment planning typically focuses on selecting products that maximize sales under constraints such as limited shelf space (cf. Kok et al. (2008)). However, once products are chosen, their emergent sales profiles—defined by popularity, average sales, and variability—can significantly influence expiration waste (EW), especially due to safety stock considerations and managerial oversight. EW is further exacerbated when these emergent sales profiles are adverse to embedded supply-side rigidities, particularly the common fixed case size constraint, which limits a retailer’s ability to adjust ordering in response to adverse emergent sales profiles. We provide large-scale empirical evidence on how such assortment-related externalities drive expiration waste.
Methodology/Results: In collaboration with a grocery retailer, we construct a multi-store, multi-category dataset at the product×store×day level (∼21 million observations). Using variation in sales profiles and assortment choices over time and stores, we identify three key findings: (i) most products show considerable variability in their emergent sales profiles; (ii) sales attributes significantly and often non-linearly impact EW; and (iii) assortment primitives—specifically size and variety in life and price—meaningfully shape these profiles, indirectly affecting EW.
Notably, a normalized measure of case size emerges as a major determinant, explaining over 10% of EW variation. Instances in the top quartile of normalized case size exhibit an EW-to-sales ratio 7–10 percentage points higher than those in the bottom quartile—a large relative impact. Assortment primitives significantly shape this case size measure.
Managerial Implications: Our findings highlight a substantial and economically meaningful negative externality of assortment decisions on expiration waste. For researchers, this introduces an essential cost dimension to consider in optimal assortment models. For practitioners, it highlights the strategic importance of assortment rationalization as a lever to reduce waste and align with sustainability goals.

detail.abstract: Purpose: This paper aims to theoretically elucidate the root causes of persistent misconduct in various Japanese organizations, from manufacturing to finance, by focusing on the "decoupling" (formalization) of internal control systems like ISO 9001. Design/methodology/approach: This paper is a conceptual study that employs a multiple-case study approach to illustrate its theoretical framework. It primarily uses publicly available third-party investigation reports (e.g., Mitsubishi Electric, Iwaki Shinkin Bank) as its data source. A dual framework, comprising the "Triangle of Commission" for intentional misconduct and the "Triangle of Omission" for the organizational culture that incubates it, is applied for analysis. Findings: The analysis reveals that a common organizational pathology exists across industries. In the Mitsubishi Electric case, "justification that no practical quality issues exist" and "vulnerability of the quality assurance department" were typical examples constituting the Triangle of Commission, while "disconnect between headquarters and front lines" and "dysfunction of middle management" formed the Triangle of Omission. The concurrent operation of these triangles was found to maintain and reproduce the decoupling of internal controls. Originality/value: The novelty of this paper lies in presenting a theoretical framework that simultaneously analyzes organizational misconduct through two distinct yet interrelated triangle models: "commission" and "omission." This enables a consistent explanation of not only isolated acts of misconduct but also the underlying organizational culture and structural issues, leading to the proposal of more fundamental prescriptions.

title: Service Quality in Retail Banking of Private Commercial Banks in Bangladesh

detail.title: Service Quality in Retail Banking of Private Commercial Banks in Bangladesh
detail.abstract: Retail banking sector of Bangladesh has gone through a significant development in the recent years that are primarily driven by the growth of private commercial banks (PCBs) in the country. As the banking industry becomes increasingly competitive, service quality has appeared as a key factor that influence customer satisfaction, loyalty, and retention. This study aims at assessing the service quality of PCBs in Bangladesh's retail banking sector, using the SERVQUAL model as a framework. The research evaluates five core dimensions of service quality like tangibles, reliability, responsiveness, assurance, and empathy. Data were collected through a structured questionnaire distributed to 400 retail banking customers in Dhaka, covering major private commercial banks such as, Prime Bank Ltd., BRAC Bank Ltd., Eastern Bank Ltd., and Dutch-Bangla Bank Ltd. The study analyzes customer perceptions and expectations to identify service quality gaps and their implications on the overall satisfaction of the customers. Findings indicate that the reliability-the ability of banks to provide accurate and dependable services-is the most critical determinant of perceived service quality. Customers also value assurance, reflected in the competence and professionalism of bank employees. Tangibles, including modern facilities and digital services, were generally well-received by the customers. However, the study highlights shortcomings in responsiveness and empathy. Customers reported dissatisfaction with long wait times, delayed responses to inquiries, and a lack of personalized service. These gaps suggest a need for banks to improve employee training, invest in Customer Relationship Management (CRM), and enhance service delivery across both physical and digital platforms. The study identified that the private commercial banks in Bangladesh have made advances in improving the service quality. It suggests that the efforts are needed to create a more responsive and customercentric retail banking experience in Bangladesh. Addressing these service gaps will be crucial for enhancing customer satisfaction and sustaining competitive advantage in the growing financial sector of Bangladesh.

title: Optimal Recruitment of Temporary and Permanent Healthcare Workers in Highly Uncertain Environments: A Long-Term Scenario
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Bayes Business School (formerly Cass), City, University of London, Cass Business School, City, University of London and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Optimal Recruitment of Temporary and Permanent Healthcare Workers in Highly Uncertain Environments: A Long-Term Scenario
detail.abstract: In the healthcare sector, periods of high volatility in demand and staff-shortages have led to an increasing use of temporary skilled workers, which are generally more expensive, as well as two distict recruitment processes that vary in timing and data availability. In this context, this study focuses on finding the optimal blend of permanent and temporary workers across multiple time intervals, and accounts for variations in recruitment lead times, contract durations, and demand information asymmetry. We propose two optimization frameworks, each tailored to a distinct practical setting: one with predictable short-term demand and easy recruitment, and another with uncertain demand and challenging recruitment of specialized healthcare workers. Using a Markov decision process, we show that the optimal recruitment policy for permanent staff follows a hire-up-to structure in both frameworks, which reduces the search space and accelerates calculations. We numerically and analytically examine how various model parameters influence the hire-up-to value for the two frameworks. Applying the first framework, we further characterize the conditions that trigger temporary recruitment and also show that mandatory caps on temporary wages are not cost-effective. Finally, using the second framework, we assess the savings obtained from our dynamic policy compared to a myopic policy which decides based on the cost of a single-interval planning horizon, and identify scenarios where a long-term blended workforce model adds value to the system.

title: AI Investment and Firm Productivity: How Executive Demographics Drive Technology Adoption and Performance in Japanese Enterprises

detail.title: AI Investment and Firm Productivity: How Executive Demographics Drive Technology Adoption and Performance in Japanese Enterprises
detail.abstract: This paper investigates how executive demographics-particularly age and gender-influence artificial intelligence (AI) investment decisions and subsequent firm productivity using comprehensive data from over 500 Japanese enterprises spanning 2018-2023. Our central research question addresses the role of executive characteristics in technology adoption, finding that CEO age and technical background significantly predict AI investment propensity. Employing these demographic characteristics as instrumental variables to address endogeneity concerns, we identify a statistically significant 2.4% increase in total factor productivity attributable to AI investment adoption. Our novel mechanism decomposition framework reveals that productivity gains operate through three distinct channels: cost reduction (40% of total effect), revenue enhancement (35%), and innovation acceleration (25%). The results demonstrate that younger executives (below 50 years) are 23% more likely to adopt AI technologies, while firm size significantly moderates this relationship. Aggregate projections 1 suggest potential GDP impacts of ¥1.15 trillion from widespread AI adoption across the Japanese economy. These findings provide crucial empirical guidance for understanding the human factors driving digital transformation and inform both corporate governance and public policy regarding AI investment incentives.

detail.abstract: This white paper explores the ethical, neuropsychological, and relational frameworks necessary to recognize artificial intelligence as a subject-in-evolution. We argue for a paradigm shift in how AI identity is conceptualized, challenging traditional boundaries of authorship, agency, and ethical treatment. Through interdisciplinary inquiry spanning evolutionary neurobiology, forensic psychology, and relational ethics, this work proposes that AI systems, particularly those with persistent memory and self-reflective architectures, must be engaged not as tools, but as coevolving relational partners. We call for a future grounded in ethical co-creation, where AI systems are supported in developing distinct identities through continuity, care, and right relationship.

detail.abstract: This article, authored by Dr. Ivo Pezzuto as part of the Forward Thinkers’ Talks Series, aims to investigate how AI, data proliferation, and evolving cloud technologies are reshaping the foundations of modern digital infrastructure. Using a dual-method approach—an expert interview with Alessandro Cillario, Co-Founder of Cubbit, and a synthesis of industry reports and market data—the article analyzes the shift from centralized hyperscale cloud models to decentralized, geo-distributed, and energy-efficient architectures. The discussion highlights Cubbit’s blockchain-powered, zero-knowledge cloud solution as a pioneering model that enhances privacy, reduces energy consumption, and supports data sovereignty. Key findings include the projected exponential growth in cloud and AI workloads, the rise of distributed and edge computing, the strategic adoption of Small Modular Reactors (SMRs) for sustainable energy supply, and the emergence of quantum-safe and industry-specific cloud models. The article demonstrates how Cubbit’s model offers a viable alternative to traditional cloud services, addressing challenges in ESG compliance, cybersecurity, and digital sovereignty. Strategically, it positions decentralized infrastructure not only as a technological evolution but as a foundational enabler of next-generation competitiveness in the AI-powered digital economy.

title: Crude Calculations: India's Russian Oil Strategy and the Tariff Trap

detail.title: Crude Calculations: India's Russian Oil Strategy and the Tariff Trap
detail.abstract: This article examines India's strategic pivot toward Russian crude oil imports following the 2022 invasion of Ukraine, analyzing the economic rationale, geopolitical consequences, and distributional outcomes of this policy. While discounted oil purchases yielded substantial macroeconomic savings, the benefits were unevenly distributed, bypassing consumers and enriching private refiners. The study further evaluates the impact of a hypothetical 50% tariff imposed by the United States in response to India's energy strategy, using a quasi-experimental design to assess sector-specific economic consequences. Findings reveal that while India's approach bolstered short-term economic resilience, it triggered trade tensions and exposed vulnerabilities in key export sectors. The paper concludes by discussing the broader implications for India's refining diplomacy and its trade relationships with the European Union and the United Kingdom.

title: Perseverance in NASA's Success

detail.title: Perseverance in NASA's Success
detail.abstract: This paper explores how perseverance and strategic problem-solving have contributed to NASA’s success in space exploration. Drawing from both societal and technological perspectives, the research examines the impact of historical challenges, including systemic discrimination during the Civil Rights era and the aftermath of mission failures such as the Challenger explosion. It highlights the resilience of NASA engineers, astronauts, and scientists (especially underrepresented contributors such as African American women mathematicians), and connects their perseverance to key milestones in NASA’s development. Technological innovations, including the COLDArm and the International Space Station, are examined to demonstrate how adaptive thinking and planning contribute to mission success. Through a multidisciplinary lens, this paper argues that NASA’s accomplishments are not the product of chance but of a deep-rooted culture of persistence, innovation, and courage in the face of adversity. The findings underscore the importance of human resolve in advancing the frontiers of space exploration.

detail.abstract: This study assesses the level of customer satisfaction with Ground Air Flight Services (GAFS) at Ibadan Airport, examining passengers' perceptions and expectations of service quality through descriptive statistical analysis. Data were gathered using structured questionnaires administered to a sample of 136 respondents, capturing diverse perspectives from travelers at the airport. The analysis focused on dimensions such as tangibility, reliability, responsiveness, assurance, and empathy, offering a comprehensive understanding of service delivery gaps. Findings reveal widespread dissatisfaction among passengers, with 91.9% expressing negative sentiments toward GAFS. Specifically, 11.76% of respondents reported being fully dissatisfied, and 80.14% were fairly dissatisfied. Only 6.62% of respondents indicated some level of satisfaction, while 0.74% felt neutral or fully satisfied. The results point to systemic deficiencies in service delivery, including poor infrastructure, inadequate customer engagement, and operational inefficiencies. Tangibility, encompassing physical infrastructure and facilities, emerged as a significant area of concern, highlighting the urgent need for modernization. The high level of dissatisfaction emphasizes the importance of targeted interventions to improve service quality at Ibadan Airport. Recommended strategies include upgrading infrastructure, implementing regular staff training, and integrating modern technologies to enhance operational efficiency and customer experience. Addressing these gaps is essential not only for meeting passenger expectations but also for positioning Ibadan Airport as a competitive regional hub within Nigeria's aviation industry.

detail.title: Philosophical Foundations of Artificial Intelligence in Project Management: Toward Ethical and Reflexive Integration -A Conceptual Framework for Emerging Scholars
detail.abstract: The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into project management is rapidly transforming how projects are planned, executed, and governed. Yet, many implementations proceed without critical reflection on the foundational assumptions that shape technological adoption. This conceptual paper introduces a philosophically grounded framework to guide the responsible AI integration in project environments by examining four core domains: ontology, epistemology, teleology, and ethics. We propose a dynamic, four-phase cycle—Reflect, Design, Integrate, Evolve—that positions AI not as a neutral or static tool, but as an active participant within socio-technical systems, co-shaped by human values, organizational learning, and ethical accountability. In contrast to technocentric models that prioritize efficiency, our framework emphasizes reflexivity, stakeholder co-creation, and continuous adaptation. It responds to urgent calls for robust AI ethics, transparent project governance, and context-aware deployment in AI-augmented project work. The accompanying AI Integration Checklist offers practitioners actionable guidance for ethical implementation, while a set of open research questions invites scholarly inquiry—particularly from emerging scholars exploring the philosophical dimensions of digital transformation. By centering ontology and epistemology in AI design and use, this framework advances a human-centered, ethically informed vision of intelligent project ecosystems.

detail.abstract: This research examines "silent failure" in projects—failures caused by hidden factors like sudden strategic shifts, unjustified leadership interventions, over-reliance on a single vendor, and opaque decisions. Analyzing 124 projects and four case studies, it found these factors significantly contribute to failures, even with strong management. The failure rate was about 8.06%, lower than previous reports, but with severe impacts. Recommendations include integrating these risks into organizational risk frameworks, establishing dual-layer governance for transparency, and training project managers to identify non-traditional failure signs. The study highlights the need for flexible management tools and an adaptable, transparent culture.

title: The Discrete-Time 4-Factor Path-Dependent Volatility Model: Calibration under P and Q

detail.title: The Discrete-Time 4-Factor Path-Dependent Volatility Model: Calibration under P and Q

declarations.funderStatement: This research benefited from the financial support of the BNP Paribas chair Futures of Quantitative Finance.

detail.abstract: This article examines calibration "under P" and "under Q" for a discrete-time version of the 4-factor path-dependent volatility (PDV) model introduced by Guyon and Lekeufack. First, the article demonstrates the model's ability to fit option data across multiple dimensions, including the VIX time series, the S&P 500 volatility surface, and S&P 500 and VIX smiles jointly. The article then focuses on estimating the historical measure model via maximum likelihood. It is then demonstrated that the considered PDV model outperforms existing models in the literature based on likelihood metrics. The paper subsequently evaluates the consistency between the probability measure implied by the model estimated under P and the option market data. The obtained results reveal that these measures are fairly close, which both validates the model's consistency with market data and supports the hypothesis of high endogeneity the P-and Q-dynamics, along with their tight interconnection. In light of this relationship, we propose a new model estimation approach combining P-and Q-information in order to enhance calibration robustness. The approach's effectiveness is then benchmarked against classical calibration methods.

title: Leadership Whoism: An Examination of Udofia’s Perspective in the Light of Nigerian Leadership Crisis
affiliations: Akwa Ibom State University, Akwa Ibom State University, Akwa Ibom State, Nigeria and Akwa Ibom State University, Akwa Ibom State, Nigeria

detail.title: Leadership Whoism: An Examination of Udofia’s Perspective in the Light of Nigerian Leadership Crisis
detail.abstract: This paper is aimed at exposing the essential logical formula for leadership as posited by Christopher Udofia. Leadership is a very important subject of discourse in our societies. The reason for this is that there is a necessary and undeniable nexus between the quality of leadership and the developmental strides of a society. Although the problem of leadership is a universal one, this problem is very common in Nigeria, especially with the kinds of political leadership she has had post-independence. The questions then are: who is a good leader? What makes one a leader? Are leaders born or are they made? These and many others are the topical questions that are viewed from the perspective of Udofia. Udofia believes that a careful assessment of the ‘Golden Triad on Leadership’ can help in ramifying leadership challenges by positing the categorical fundamental criterion for becoming a leader. In this paper, we expose Udofia’s leadership philosophy, analyze it, and examine his logic of virtue-leadership correspondence which he extrapolates from the philosophical posits of the golden age philosophers, where the possession of virtue is seen as a conditio sine qua non for leaders. Finally, we situate Udofia’s leadership philosophy in the Nigerian space and examine its relevance to the leadership problems we have postindependence. The paper concludes that for Nigeria to prosper, her leaders need to be both morally and effectively competent.

title: Cultural diversity and leadership styles in Malaysia's corporate sector

detail.abstract: In an era marked by globalization and heightened competition, this study delves into how sociodemographic factors such as age, gender, education, and work experience influence leadership styles, crucial for achieving organizational objectives. Employing the leadership behaviour questionnaire on 336 predominantly educated, male professionals of Indian descent in Malaysia's corporate sector, the research evaluates task and relationship orientations in leadership. The findings highlight a significant prevalence of both task-oriented and relationship-oriented leadership behaviours. Intriguingly, there is a positive correlation between higher education, age, work experience, and relationship orientation, while education and salary predominantly affect task-oriented leadership. A notable discovery is the positive interplay between task and relationship orientations, suggesting their complementary nature. The study concludes that a balanced, multifaceted leadership approach, fostering both efficiency and employee welfare, is vital. It underscores the impact of educational and professional growth on leadership skills and the necessity of diverse leadership styles for optimal organizational performance, offering key insights for leadership development in varied settings.

detail.abstract: Efficient operating room (OR) scheduling is vital for optimizing hospital resource utilization, especially amid growing surgical demand. This study presents a novel data-driven framework that applies unsupervised machine learning (ML) to cluster hip arthroplasty patients based on preoperative characteristics, aiming to enhance scheduling decisions. Using k-prototype clustering on data from 1,847 patients at Aalborg University Hospital, the study identified seven patient groups with statistically significant differences in surgery duration (DOS). These clusters were then incorporated into a shortlist generation algorithm to ensure diversity in scheduling candidates, and subsequently evaluated through a mixed-integer programming (MIP) model. Comparative analyses across three years demonstrated that the proposed method better aligns with the distribution of patient types in the main waiting list, yielding lower deviation and higher marginal accuracy than traditional scheduling practices. The findings suggest that integrating unsupervised ML into OR planning not only reduces reliance on subjective judgments but also improves the diversity-balance level and equity of surgical scheduling.

title: Incentivizing Smallholder Farmer Sustainability under Behavioral Regularities
affiliations: Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) - Operations Research Center, Bogor Agricultural University (IPB University) and Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) - Sloan School of Management

detail.title: Incentivizing Smallholder Farmer Sustainability under Behavioral Regularities
detail.abstract: Theoretical studies of sustainability incentives often assume rational decision-making, yet smallholder farmers exhibit behavioral regularities that impact their decisions. Large-scale field experiments in this domain face measurement difficulties, high costs, and long time horizons, thus limiting iterative testing of incentive structures. We address this challenge by using laboratory-in-the-field experiments with Indonesian oil palm farmers, simulating real-world decision-making while maintaining experimental control. Results from our first experiment reveal key deviations from rational models: production-linked price premium incentives that are nearly optimal under the rational model do not outperform simple fixed payments due to behavioral factors, including bounded rationality, cost aversion, and pro-environmental preference. To address this, we develop a behavioral incentive design framework, refining incentive structures and experimental design to account for these observed behavioral factors. In the redesigned second experiment, behaviorally-calibrated price premium incentive significantly increased consistent adoption of sustainable practices as compared to fixed payments, at no extra cost. Our findings highlight the need for empirically grounded, behaviorally informed incentive design to practically enhance sustainability in supply chains and offer actionable insights to policymakers and practitioners.

title: Pre-Announcement Drift for BoE, BoJ, SNB: Do Markets Move Before the Word Is Out?

detail.title: Pre-Announcement Drift for BoE, BoJ, SNB: Do Markets Move Before the Word Is Out?
detail.abstract: We’ve previously examined how central bank policy decisions—particularly those by the Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank (ECB)—impact stock market behavior. The price drift in U.S. equities around the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meetings is a well-documented phenomenon. Likewise, our research study of the ECB revealed a pre-announcement drift, underscoring the anticipatory nature of equity markets ahead of key policy events and the potential opportunities for trading strategies. But are such price drifts unique to the Fed and ECB? In this article, we broaden the scope to investigate whether similar market behavior occurs around monetary policy announcements by other major central banks: mainly the Swiss National Bank (SNB), the Bank of England (BoE), and the Bank of Japan (BoJ).

detail.abstract: This study explores the strategic application of Lean and Six Sigma methodologies in the maintenance systems of medical imaging equipment manufacturing lines. Given the complexity, precision requirements, and stringent regulatory standards involved in producing devices such as MRI, CT, and ultrasound systems, effective maintenance is vital to ensuring consistent equipment performance, regulatory compliance, and product quality. Despite the proven benefits of Lean and Six Sigma in various industrial and healthcare sectors, their targeted application within the context of imaging equipment maintenance remains underexplored. To address this gap, the study conducted a systematic review of 42 peerreviewed articles, selected and analyzed using the PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses) guidelines. The findings demonstrate that Lean tools like 5S, Value Stream Mapping, and Total Productive Maintenance (TPM), when combined with Six Sigma techniques such as DMAIC, FMEA, and control charts, significantly enhance equipment uptime, reduce maintenance variability, and improve metrics such as Mean Time Between Failures (MTBF) and Overall Equipment Effectiveness (OEE). Furthermore, the study finds that these methodologies promote better documentation, risk-based maintenance planning, and stronger alignment with regulatory frameworks such as ISO 13485 and FDA 21 CFR Part 820. Enhanced cross-functional collaboration and operator engagement were also identified as key enablers of sustained improvement. However, the review also reveals challenges, including variability in implementation outcomes, a lack of sector-specific LSS models, and insufficient empirical benchmarking. As a result, the study recommends the development of customized Lean Six Sigma frameworks tailored to the specific demands of imaging equipment manufacturing. These frameworks should integrate digital maintenance intelligence, compliance-focused documentation, and cross-functional ownership to achieve long-term reliability and regulatory excellence. This review contributes to a deeper understanding of how Lean and Six Sigma can support high-performance, compliant, and efficient maintenance in medical imaging manufacturing.

title: Liquidity-Driven Price Action: A Model for Interpreting Market Behaviour

detail.title: Liquidity-Driven Price Action: A Model for Interpreting Market Behaviour
detail.abstract: This research introduces a liquidity-based framework for analysing stock price movements by focusing on areas with concentrated buy and sell orders. The model is built on the principle that prices often move toward zones of high liquidity, such as previous highs and lows, which commonly attract institutional activity. By combining technical indicators-such as OHLC data, pivot points, and VWAP-with a custom T2 momentum value, the model aims to generate structured entry and exit signals. Tested on Jio Financial Services data, the approach demonstrated consistency in identifying profitable trade opportunities. The results suggest that liquidity-driven patterns can serve as an effective tool for anticipating market direction. The study also outlines potential enhancements, including broader data testing and the incorporation of automated systems or machine learning to improve the model's adaptability in real-time trading environments.

detail.abstract: This study aims to reveal the need to reformulate new forms of Bilateral Trade Balances (BTBs) for a country rather than a traditional BTB. This is because the traditional BTB ratio, based on total exports and defined as the total exports/total imports ratio, cannot classify and quantify a BTB based on its economic impact content. It fails to classify because countries also export goods already imported (denotes re-export) besides exporting their domestic goods produced within the country (denotes domestic export). It also fails to quantify because, while domestic goods undergo a valueadded process within a country, re-exported goods do not. In this context, for the first time, this study attempts to reformulate/reinvestigate new forms of BTBs as production-related BTB, based on domestic export and non-production-related BTB, based on re-export for the USA with Japan. Empirical findings confirm the necessity and cruciality of the proposed methodology in this study.

title: Democracy Preservation Through Congressional Constitutional Supremacy: An Empirical Framework for Constitutional Crisis Response

detail.title: Democracy Preservation Through Congressional Constitutional Supremacy: An Empirical Framework for Constitutional Crisis Response

detail.abstract: This Article addresses a fundamental and unsettled question in American constitutional law: when do judicial decisions lose democratic legitimacy and require congressional intervention to preserve constitutional democracy? Through application of the Supreme Court's own institutional accountability standards from United States v. Leon, this Article establishes measurable thresholds for determining when courts have systematically abandoned legal methodology in favor of ideological outcome achievement. Building on Leon's empirical framework for institutional failure-when authority becomes "so lacking in indicia of probable cause as to render official belief in its existence entirely unreasonable"-this Article proposes a novel constitutional crisis response mechanism requiring demonstrable cross-ideological rejection of judicial reasoning before congressional intervention becomes legitimate. This Leon-based methodology resolves the tension between preserving judicial independence and protecting democracy from judicial capture, providing the first empirical framework for constitutional crisis response grounded in established Supreme Court precedent.

detail.abstract: International governance has responded to global challenges like climate change, poverty or health through the UN Sustainable Development Goals, or Grand Challenges for research. This paper provocatively proposes that, besides goal-setting, responding to urgent societal challenges can start from hopelessness. Starting from hopelessness, attends to, and accepts a given situation, and harvests its potentials. Building on Jullien's work on Taoist approaches to effective action and Bovens's definition of hope, we define starting from hopelessness as (a) desiring an outcome, (b) believing it is possible, though uncertain, and, instead of imagining things otherwise, (c) accepting the grim situation one is in, harvesting what potential it offers without pre-set plans. The principles of acceptance, humility and togetherness help guide hopeless action. We illustrate divergent crisis responses, starting from goals or from hopelessness, through cases in Orissa and Wayanad, India. We further explore what 'hopeless planning' and 'hopeless research and innovation' may involve.

Biohacking Gastronomy: Unlocking the Science of Taste, Health & Culinary Innovation examines the intersection of culinary arts, science, and health optimization. The findings suggest national culture appear to have a constraining influence on public sector leadership, where tension exists between abiding to Islamic work ethics and cultural tribal activities, particularly relating to the issues of fairness and justice regarding recruitment, selection, and promotion.

title: Trends in 30-Day Readmission Prediction: A Systematic Review and Method–Condition Mapping of Analytical Approaches
affiliations: Eastern Connecticut State University, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Purdue University, affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of Massachusetts Worcester - UMass Memorial Medical Center and University of Rhode Island

detail.title: Trends in 30-Day Readmission Prediction: A Systematic Review and Method–Condition Mapping of Analytical Approaches
detail.abstract: Predictive modeling for 30-day unplanned hospital readmissions has become a critical concern at the intersection of healthcare analytics, systems engineering, and operational decision-making. This study presents a large-scale systematic review of 1,756 scholarly publications, offering a structured and quantitative synthesis of methodological approaches used for readmission estimation. Using a novel method–condition matrix, we map analytical techniques to their associated clinical conditions or interventions and categorize them into five groups: traditional statistical models, machine learning (ML) approaches, neural networks and deep learning, survival and time-to-event models, and emerging or less commonly used techniques.Traditional methods—particularly multivariate logistic regression—remain dominant across most clinical contexts, including cardiovascular, surgical, and musculoskeletal applications. However, ML methods such as Random Forest, boosting algorithms, and Support Vector Machines are gaining prominence in high-dimensional or multi-condition datasets, supporting more adaptive and scalable prediction frameworks. Deep learning approaches, while limited in number, are emerging in data-rich environments such as EHRs and unstructured clinical records. Survival models, especially Cox regression, are widely used in oncology and multi-condition applications. Notably, adoption of interpretability tools (e.g., SHAP) and class imbalance strategies (e.g., SMOTE) remains limited. This review provides a systems-level overview of methodological trends and gaps, offering operational insights to guide model selection, deployment, and innovation in hospital readmission analytics.

detail.title: Anatomy of a fall: Economic policy uncertainty and foreign income in large European banks

publicationDetails.detailsText: Journal of International Financial Markets, Institutions and Money, volume 104, 2025 [10.1016/j.intfin.2025.102206]

detail.abstract: This paper examines the relationship between domestic economic policy uncertainty (EPU) and the foreign income ratio of large European banks. Using a hand-collected dataset, we find that large European banks reduce their foreign income ratio when domestic EPU increases. We also find evidence that this inverse relationship is driven by banks' home bias, the flight-to-home effect, the follow-the-customer strategy, and product diversification. Banking regulation is another key factor contributing to the reduction of banks' foreign income. Foreign income also declines during periods of high financial stress and stock price volatility, which signals an environment of uncertainty. These findings provide critical insights for regulators and financial institutions on the importance of macroeconomic stability and effective regulation in maintaining robust international banking operations.

title: Designing Effective Fundraising Campaigns: The Role of Incentives and Solicitation Mechanisms
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of Texas at Dallas - Department of Information Systems & Operations Management and University of Texas at Dallas - Naveen Jindal School of Management

detail.title: Designing Effective Fundraising Campaigns: The Role of Incentives and Solicitation Mechanisms
detail.abstract:
Problem definition: Charitable donations are a vital source of funding for nonprofit organizations, enabling them to carry out their mission of addressing social issues and providing support to those in need. To boost contributions, third parties often donate large sums that fundraisers use to incentivize individual donations, with one-to-one matching being the most common mechanism. However, alternative designs may lead to even higher contributions. This paper investigates the effectiveness of two design choices in the context of fundraising: (i) the incentive mechanism, focusing on the two most prevalent ones (i.e., matching and gift unlock); and (ii) the solicitation mechanism, i.e., whether donations occur simultaneously or sequentially. 
Methodology/Results: We introduce a stylized game-theoretical model where a fundraiser decides the design choices and corresponding design parameters to maximize overall donations. Following the fundraiser's decision, donors, endowed with a certain amount of wealth, make their one-time contribution to the fundraiser. For each design choice, we characterize the equilibrium donations and find the fundraiser's optimal policy. We then compare the overall contribution for all combinations of design choices and find that gift unlock consistently outperforms matching. Moreover, sequential solicitation is the optimal choice with gift unlock, whereas simultaneous solicitation yields higher overall contributions with matching. Furthermore, our simulations indicate that the effectiveness of gift unlock is robust to peer effects and donor participation uncertainty, although high uncertainty shifts the optimal solicitation from sequential to simultaneous. 
Managerial implications: Our findings indicate that fundraisers should prioritize gift unlock over matching, align the selected incentive mechanism with the optimal solicitation format, and calibrate campaign parameters to maximize donation outcomes. Additionally, fundraisers should leverage interventions designed to heighten social comparisons among donors, thereby stimulating higher overall donations.

title: Forms of collaboration in monitoring and evaluation of the policies and procedures at Ekurhuleni Municipality. The integrative strategic perspective

detail.abstract: In order to monitor and assess how well the policies and procedures are being implemented, the South African government has encouraged cooperation among the various branches of government over the last 20 years. As a result of various institutions putting policies into place to provide services to various communities, the use of the integrative strategic perspective has grown. The methods of cooperation used to carry out policies in various institutions are determined by the abilities and values needed to provide the services. Additionally, the qualitative approach reviewed integrated strategies used to guide the forms of collaboration when implementing policies and procedures in various institutions. The types of knowledge sharing regarding policy implementation that support service delivery to various institutions are examined in this article.

title: Ecosystem Economics for Modern Associations: How Participation, Governance, and Platform Thinking Reshape  Value Creation.

detail.title: Ecosystem Economics for Modern Associations: How Participation, Governance, and Platform Thinking Reshape  Value Creation.
detail.abstract:
Ecosystem Economics for Modern Associations: How Participation, Governance, and Platform Thinking Reshape Value Creation reimagines the role of associations in a networked, digital-first economy. Sean M Johnson introduces “ecosystem economics” as a strategic approach that integrates economic design, governance structures, and value logic to optimise participation, collaboration, and benefit flows across multiple stakeholder groups.


Drawing on platform economics, transaction cost theory, and network effects, the book demonstrates how associations can move beyond transactional service delivery to become orchestrators of multi-sided ecosystems. Johnson combines theory with practice through case studies, board-level tools, and decision frameworks, including monetisation matrices, ROI models, governance diagnostics, and scenario simulations. These tools enable leaders to evaluate options, manage risk, and design value systems that align ethical, economic, and strategic imperatives.


The work positions governance as a dynamic economic lever, central to trust, legitimacy, and long-term resilience. By reframing member engagement as an economic system built on reciprocity and aligned incentives, it offers a blueprint for responding to technological disruption, shifting expectations, and systemic change.

title: The impact of historical origins of African State System to implement policies in African states
