detail.abstract: This paper considers the impact of historical origins of African State System to implement policies in African states and how these intersect with the country's corporate image. There's no doubt that the historical origins identify the thin line between politics and governance in African states. The evolution of identity politics hiding behind tribalism, create the appetite for the young people to form their political parties in different regions. It is the battle of Goliath and David in different Southern African states, where the Goliath (Big men) are good at politicising everything in different institutions and David (the youth) so keen to promote good governance. It considers the demographic economic and drivers of politics in African states and their 2 consequences for promoting effective development. In African politics the big men call the shots, the youth are expected to listen and follow the guides to implement the policies at all costs. This has led to the uneven development in different communities, before using the legislation emerged alongside governance. Turning to the forms of African politics that have shaped economic developments mapping the "state of the discipline" of the youth to historically and geographically contextualise governance. This has been carving a route through a wide range of existing literatures relevant to the politics and governance in managing the economy of African states. The different literatures identify key gaps in African politics and indicate potential directions for governing of the African states. The findings for this paper are diverse governance structures, arbitrary borders, the struggle for independence and ineffective regional integration. As a result, the findings are closely linked the identification recommendations, which provide guides to change African states systems of governing.

title: The Quality of Public Administration in Southern African states: A spectrum of failure or success
affiliations: IIE ADvTECH, Durban University of Technology, IIE ADvTECH and IIE ADvTECH

detail.title: The Quality of Public Administration in Southern African states: A spectrum of failure or success
detail.abstract: The quality of Public Administration in Southern African states is either a spectrum of failure or success when governing the institutions. While some countries have made significant strides in improving public administration, others continue to face substantial obstacles. The quality of public administration in Southern African states is influenced by a complex interplay of factors, including historical legacies, 2 governance structures, capacity challenges, and socioeconomic conditions. The purpose of this study is to explore quality of Public Administration in Southern African states: A spectrum of failure or success. The challenges of quality of Public Administration requires targeted reforms, investment in human resources, and a commitment to transparency and accountability to enhance governance and service delivery in the Southern African region. Adaptation of the quality of Public Administration impacts the Southern Africa states which is a key pillar of change governance, and local governments have historically played a major role in the implementation of these policies. An array of political, economic, institutional, social and individual factors influences in using the adaptation policy instrument to government institutions. The quality of Public Administration is governed by policy instrument choice pursuing diverse adaptation policy implementation styles that are associated with different levels of internal capacity, local political economies. At the local government level, the Southern African states reflect ineffective intergovernmental dynamics that constrain or support local efforts in governing the institutions. The qualitative method is used to collect the data from articles, and textbooks to understand the quality of Public Administration in Southern Africa. The findings include the colonial legacy, centralised administration, political instability, weak democratic institutions and postcolonial governance in Southern African states. The findings led to the recommendations related to quality of Public Administration, a spectrum of success and failure.

reference: 86 U. Pitt. L. Rev. 675 (Spring 2025)
title: Taking Back Innovation: Threading the Needle on Ownership and Control of Federally-Funded Inventions
affiliations: University of Louisville, Louis D. Brandeis School of Law

detail.title: Taking Back Innovation: Threading the Needle on Ownership and Control of Federally-Funded Inventions
detail.abstract:
For centuries, the Takings Clause of the Fifth Amendment of the United States Constitution has been considered primarily in relation to encroachment on more traditional real-property rights. Nevertheless, a substantial and growing portion of personal and commercial assets are actually comprised of rights in intellectual property. It is therefore essential to now consider the implications of the Takings Clause in the context of Twenty-First century innovation and technology. 

Innovation is an ever-increasing portion of domestic and international assets, contributing an estimated $7.8 trillion to the United States Gross Domestic Product. Accordingly, it is of course also crucial to determine and clarify rights regarding the ownership and control of inventions. Of particular interest in this regard is the key subset of inventions created with use of federal funds––often at universities. Such inventions encompass all range of innovation from biopharmaceuticals to artificial intelligence, and beyond. Under the terms of the governing Congressional statute, the Bayh-Dole Act, universities and other government contractors may assert rights to “subject inventions” created with the use of the over-one-hundred-billion dollars they receive annually in federal research funds. Yet caveats abound, with the federal government reserving certain rights to the subject inventions, including an automatic “grant back” license to practice, along with the very dreaded––and controversial––“march-in” provision.  

Both the grant-back license and the march-in provisions of the Bayh-Dole Act remain largely unexplored in U.S. court and administrative proceedings. Nor has either been widely studied in legal scholarship. Given the far-reaching implications of the grant-back as a possible basis for a “fair use” argument in patent law––and of the march-in provision potentially characterized as a Fifth Amendment Taking––it is likely that more cases will arise on this important issue that lies at the intersection of contract and property doctrine. Analyzing and summarizing the few cases to date, along with the statutory and regulatory framework––this article provides a public policy roadmap both for the administrative agencies and universities governed by the terms of the Bayh-Dole Act, as well as for courts interpreting its provisions––with proposals for threading the needle on ownership and control of inventions.

title: Project Monitoring and Control Systems
affiliations: Ohio State University (OSU) - Department of Management Sciences, The Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK) - Department of Systems Engineering and Engineering Management, Hong Kong University of Science & Technology (HKUST) - Dept. of Industrial Engineering and Decision Analytics and Hong Kong University of Science & Technology (HKUST) - Dept. of Industrial Engineering and Decision Analytics

detail.title: Project Monitoring and Control Systems
detail.abstract: The global use of professional project management to deliver innovative products and services has not eliminated widely observed problems in delivering projects within schedule and within budget. Hence, accurate monitoring of project progress and cost is essential, both for communication with stakeholders and for project control through expediting decisions. Two systems for the monitoring and control of projects, Earned Value Management and Earned Schedule, are available. We model these systems and develop algorithms to minimize the expected total cost of a project under task time and cost uncertainty. This enables us to make structural comparisons between the optimal expediting decisions and expected costs of the two systems. This in turn reveals that the time profile of project workload is an important factor in the relative costs of the two systems. An extensive computational study validates these theoretical results, and shows that the expected loss from choosing the wrong monitoring and control system is typically significant. Our work provides theoretical support for the empirical performance of the two systems. We thus provide project managers with a theoretically justified, simple, and effective way to choose the best monitoring and control system at the start of a project, based on project characteristics that are generally known.

detail.abstract: This article analyzes the progress and challenges in the implementation of the PROCOMPITE program in Peru, a government strategy aimed at promoting local economic development by co-financing the business plans of organized economic agents. Using a documentary analysis methodology, relevant secondary sources were compiled and examined, identifying significant achievements such as the strengthening of production chains, increased productivity, and job creation in rural and urban areas. However, structural limitations related to bureaucracy, unequal access to resources, lack of technical support, and the long-term sustainability of projects are also identified. The study shows that, despite the challenges, PROCOMPITE continues to be a key tool for fostering regional competitiveness, driving innovation, and contributing to reducing social and economic gaps in the country. It concludes that program management needs to be strengthened through greater institutional coordination and a more equitable and sustainable approach.

title: Legal Innovation or Legislative Shortfall? A Critical Analysis of the Investment and Securities Act 2025 in Combating Ponzi Schemes in Nigeria

detail.title: Legal Innovation or Legislative Shortfall? A Critical Analysis of the Investment and Securities Act 2025 in Combating Ponzi Schemes in Nigeria
detail.abstract:
This paper critically examines the provisions of the Investment and Securities Act 2025 (ISA 2025) in addressing Ponzi schemes in Nigeria. Drawing on my experience as a participant in a parliamentary debate on this subject, I evaluate whether the Act represents a sufficient legal innovation compared to its predecessor and other regulatory frameworks. The analysis focuses on sections 196 of the Act, situates them within Nigeria’s financial regulatory landscape, and compares them with international approaches. While the ISA 2025 expands the scope of offences and penalties related to fraudulent investment schemes, it still presents gaps in enforcement mechanisms and inter-agency coordination.

This paper draws from my experience in that debate, supported by statutory analysis, case law, and comparative insights, to evaluate the strengths, weaknesses, and practical challenges of the ISA 2025 in tackling fraudulent investment schemes.

title: Inventory Optimization Using Machine Learning: Advanced Forecasting for Multi-Channel Supply Chains

detail.title: Inventory Optimization Using Machine Learning: Advanced Forecasting for Multi-Channel Supply Chains
detail.abstract: Inventory optimization remains a critical challenge in modern supply chains, where inaccurate demand forecasts lead to either excessive holding costs or costly stockouts. This paper presents a comprehensive machine learning (ML) framework for granular demand forecasting and inventory optimization across regions and sales channels. We integrate hierarchical time series modeling, temporal fusion transformers (TFTs), and spatio-temporal graph neural networks (ST-GNNs) to capture complex demand patterns. Our approach reduces forecast error by 25-38% compared to traditional methods, enabling dynamic safety stock optimization that lowers holding costs by 15-22% and stockout incidents by 30-45%. Implementation challenges including concept drift and explainability are addressed through adaptive retraining and SHAP value analysis. Empirical validation using retail datasets demonstrates 12-18% reduction in total inventory costs, establishing ML as a transformative solution for supply chain resilience.

title: The AI-Augmented Internal Audit: An Operational Framework for a Self-Learning

detail.title: The AI-Augmented Internal Audit: An Operational Framework for a Self-Learning

detail.abstract: Purpose: This paper aims to translate the "management theory using ISO, AI, and blockchain" presented in the author's prior research into a practical, operational framework. It proposes a practical model to transform conventional internal audits, which often remain static compliance checks, into a dynamic and self-learning process through the synergistic effects of AI and human auditors. Design/methodology/approach: This paper is a conceptual study that builds a new operational model upon the author's preceding body of research. It proposes a clear division of roles between AI (responsible for "Conformity/Compliance" audits) and humans (responsible for "Effectiveness" audits), a "human-in-theloop" data cycle that promotes AI learning, and a collaborative reporting workflow. A key feature of this model is its adaptability to diverse management philosophies (TM), its ability to provide immediate AI-driven solutions to onsite challenges, and its inherent mechanism for fostering auditor competency development. Findings: The proposed framework creates a virtuous cycle where real-time quantitative data monitoring by AI is reinforced by qualitative, contextual insights obtained through dialogue by human auditors. Simultaneously, the model addresses the potential bottleneck of auditor skill sets by monitoring the audit process itself, thereby identifying and enabling targeted competency development. This allows both the audit function and human resources to evolve continuously. Originality/value: Whereas prior research established the theoretical foundation, this paper provides the indispensable "how-to" methodology for its implementation, along with a prescription for the associated human resource challenges. It proposes a sustainable, next-generation governance model by integrating advanced management theory, the specific operations of internal auditing, and human resource development into a single framework.

title: Governance of Central Bank Digital Currencies Using the Dynamic Prescriptive Economics Framework

detail.title: Governance of Central Bank Digital Currencies Using the Dynamic Prescriptive Economics Framework
detail.abstract: Central Bank Digital Currencies (CBDCs) present complex governance challenges that demand balancing several competing objectives including state oversight and individual privacy. This paper applies the Dynamic Prescriptive Economics (DPE) framework to analyze and improve CBDC governance, using China's e-CNY (Digital Yuan) and the European Central Bank's Digital Euro as comparative case studies. DPE's quadrant-based model and Normalized Balanced Coordinates (NBCs) allow us to map each CBDC's governance decisions onto a two-dimensional normative space, making visible the hidden trade-offs and "revelation of truth" in their design choices. The e-CNY is found to prioritize state control and financial sovereignty at the expense of user privacy, placing it in an imbalanced quadrant. In contrast, the Digital Euro emphasizes privacy and financial stability, aiming for a more balanced outcome, though still constrained by conservative design choices. By diagnosing these imbalances, we identify governance blind spots-such as surveillance risks in the e-CNY and adoption hurdles in the Digital Euro-that traditional analyses often overlook. We then prescribe Dynamic Transition Strategies (STOs)-Substitutions, Transformations, and Offsets-to move each project toward the ideal Quadrant I of regenerative synergy. Visual tools, including quadrant diagrams and tables of normalized scores, illustrate how DPE quantitatively benchmarks each CBDC's proximity to an ideal balance and guides policy adjustments. The paper concludes with actionable recommendations for central banks, advocating the integration of DPE's structured approach into CBDC design to achieve sustainable, trustworthy, and inclusive digital currency systems.

title: The Impact of Environmental Regulation on the Labor Market: Evidence from China
affiliations: University of Manchester, Global Development Institute, Students, University of Manchester and University of Manchester

detail.title: The Impact of Environmental Regulation on the Labor Market: Evidence from China
detail.abstract: This study provides empirical evidence on the labor market outcomes of China's pilot Emission Trading Scheme (ETS) policy. Using firm-level panel data in manufacturing sectors from 2011 to 2018, we used a staggered Difference-inDifference model to select firms participating in local ETS pilot markets as the treatment group and firms with similar characteristics in non-pilot regions as the control group. We find that the ETS pilot policy has a positive impact on low-skilled labor and a negative impact on high-skilled labor, with the mechanism possessing that firms use an end-of-pipe approach that is less-skilled biased and increases demand for low-skilled labor. We investigate the dynamic treatment effect of the ETS policy further and discover that the effects are more prominent at least in the first few years, with the earlier treated groups and years producing more significant results.

title: Quantum PDSA: Reimagining the Continuous Quality Improvement (CQI) Beyond Mechanical Rituals
affiliations: Tunku Abdul Rahman University (UTAR) - Universiti Tunku Abdul Rahman

detail.title: Quantum PDSA: Reimagining the Continuous Quality Improvement (CQI) Beyond Mechanical Rituals

keywords: Vigilance in Solitude (shèn dú 慎独)

detail.abstract: Contemporary Continuous Quality Improvement (CQI) has increasingly devolved into a ritualistic performance-repeated with procedural fidelity but often stripped of its original purpose as a reflective, learning-oriented process. What began as a philosophy of systemic transformation has, in many contexts, become a compliance exercise, reduced to box-checking and audit readiness. In response, this paper introduces Quantum PDSA (Plan-Do-Study-Act), a novel conceptual framework that reframes quality improvement as a dynamic, context-sensitive, and ethically grounded practice. Drawing on metaphors from quantum mechanics-superposition, entanglement, and uncertainty-the model challenges the linear, deterministic logic of traditional PDCA (Plan-Do-Check-Act) and proposes a paradigm shift from rigid routines to a continuous state of quality mindfulness. Central to this framework is the Confucian ethical principle of shèn dú (慎独)-"vigilance in solitude"-which anchors quality in personal integrity and moral awareness, even in the absence of external oversight. By integrating systems thinking, reflective practice, and humanistic philosophy, Quantum PDSA calls for a return to humility, presence, and continuous consciousness in organizational and educational settings. This paper does not offer a toolkit, but an invitation: to reclaim quality not as a cycle to complete, but as a state of being to inhabit.

title: Collaborative Expertise Facilitation: The Role of School Heads in the Professional Development of Teachers

detail.title: Collaborative Expertise Facilitation: The Role of School Heads in the Professional Development of Teachers
detail.abstract:
This study investigates how school heads act as facilitators of collaborative expertise in the professional development (PD) of teachers. Grounded in social constructivist and distributed leadership frameworks, the research examines the processes, practices, and contextual enablers and barriers through which school leaders cultivate teacher learning communities, mentoring relationships, and job-embedded professional growth. The study addresses three research questions: (1) What strategies do school heads use to promote collaborative professional learning among teachers? (2) How do teachers experience and perceive the influence of school heads on their professional growth? and (3) Which organizational conditions support or hinder school head–led collaborative expertise facilitation?

A mixed-methods design via Explanatory Sequential was employed. A stratified purposive sample of schools, both elementary and secondary public and private, provided quantitative data via a survey of 100 elementary and secondary school teachers and 15 school heads in District 1, Manila measuring frequency and perceived effectiveness of leadership-facilitated PD practices, psychological safety, and collaborative climate. Qualitative data were gathered through semi-structured interviews with 30 teachers and 5 school heads and through analysis of PD artifacts such as, but not limited to, meeting minutes, coaching logs, lesson study plans, etc. Quantitative data were analyzed using descriptive statistics and regression models to identify relationships between leadership practices and teacher-reported professional growth; qualitative data underwent thematic analysis to surface mechanisms and contextual nuances.

Findings show that school heads who prioritize distributed leadership, allocate protected time for collaborative inquiry, model instructional feedback, and secure resources significantly enhance teachers’ engagement in sustained, practice-focused PD. Teachers reported greater instructional confidence, more frequent peer coaching, and improved alignment between PD and classroom practice where leaders supported autonomy and fostered trust. Key barriers included heavy administrative loads, limited time, and top-down accountability pressures that curtailed genuine teacher collaboration.

The study concludes that school heads play a catalytic role in transforming PD from episodic training into continuous, collaborative expertise development. Practical implications include policy recommendations to reconfigure school schedules, build leader capacities for instructional coaching, and institutionalize structures (e.g., lesson study cycles, coaching pairs) that sustain collaborative inquiry. Future research should test causal pathways longitudinally and evaluate targeted leadership-development interventions designed to strengthen facilitation of teacher collaboration.

Keywords: Collaborative Expertise, Professional Development, Distributed Leadership, Instructional Feedback, and Coaching and Mentoring

title: Language Clues on the Surface: Behind the Message of Graffiti

detail.title: Language Clues on the Surface: Behind the Message of Graffiti
detail.abstract: This is a qualitative descriptive paper anchored with semiological analysis that investigated the graffiti that has progressed from an art form to powerful way of expressing thoughts; this aimed to understand the meaning and interpretation of the graffiti of schools in Ermita, Manila. The study analyzed the symbolic elements and artistic styles used in different graffiti works. The researchers included six (6) pieces of graffiti found in school surfaces that featured meaningful phrases, creative elements, and artistic expression. The graffiti analyzed in this study revealed themes such as personal struggles and ambitions to socio-political issues. The study discovered that graffiti is a multi-dimensional expression, revealing personal thought, social criticism, and cultural representation. These findings highlight the reality of university life, shedding light on the challenges, aspirations, and creative tendencies of students. Furthermore, understanding the implication of graffiti as a medium of expression is educationally significant, as it offers insights into the social and cultural dynamics within academic institutions. Educators and administrators can use this understanding to foster a more inclusive and supportive environment that values student perspectives. The study enhances the understanding of how graffiti conveys a wide range of messages and meanings to illustrate the role that art plays in constructing urban environments and reflecting societal values.

title: Diseño y emprendimiento en ecosistemas socio culturales, económicos y espaciales (Design and entrepreneurship in sociocultural, economic and spatial ecosystems)
affiliations: Universidad Nacional de La Plata (UNLP) and Universidad Nacional de La Plata (UNLP)

detail.title: Diseño y emprendimiento en ecosistemas socio culturales, económicos y espaciales (Design and entrepreneurship in sociocultural, economic and spatial ecosystems)
detail.abstract:
This chapter deals with the ways in which entrepreneurships driven by industrial design and the strategies for interconnecting design for innovation are articulated. In the first instance, current practices are recognized in order to analyze the different processes that entrepreneurial dynamics go through. This analysis is carried out from a systemic perspective, at three levels of abstraction: designer, entrepreneurship and ecosystem. The theoretical and conceptual framework will be structured based on the innovations driven by design, which occur around the designer, his personal projects, and the possible interactions and singularities offered by living spaces. The objective of this work is to unravel the eventual relationships of the entrepreneurial designer in the ecosystem and to highlight the potential added by emerging connections, which allow for the projection of synergistic actions with other actors to create value(s). In this way, other possible views of the entrepreneurial process are provided, where the cultural and philosophical dimension that characterizes industrial designers allows them to achieve a higher quality of life, designing and producing collectively (in) their environment.

Resumen
Este capítulo trata los modos de articulación de los emprendimientos impulsados por el diseño industrial y las estrategias de interconexión del diseño para la innovación. En una primera instancia, se reconocen las prácticas vigentes para poder analizar en ellas los diferentes procesos que atraviesan las dinámicas emprendedoras. Este análisis se realiza desde una mirada sistémica, en tres niveles de abstracción: diseñador, emprendimiento y ecosistema. El marco teórico y conceptual, estará estructurado a partir de las innovaciones impulsadas por el diseño, que se producen en torno al diseñador, sus proyectos personales, y las posibles interacciones y singularidades que ofrecen los lugares de vida. El objetivo de este trabajo es desentramar las eventuales relaciones del diseñador emprendedor en el ecosistema y poner en relieve el potencial que agregan las conexiones emergentes, que permiten proyectar acciones sinérgicas con otros actores para crear valor(es). De esta manera, se aportan otras miradas posibles del proceso emprendedor, donde la dimensión cultural y filosófica que caracteriza a los diseñadores industriales, permite alcanzar mayor calidad de vida, diseñando y produciendo colectivamente (en) su entorno.

title: Relação custo-lucro e produtividade nas práticas culturais da cana-de-açúcar
affiliations: Federal Institute of São Paulo, Universidad Nacional de La Plata (UNLP) and Sao Paulo State University - UNESP

detail.title: Relação custo-lucro e produtividade nas práticas culturais da cana-de-açúcar
detail.abstract:
Objetivo do estudo: Analisar os custos e lucros da produção de cana-de-açúcar referente às práticas culturais de fornecedores de cana-de-açúcar.

Metodologia/abordagem: Este estudo se posiciona neste gap ao analisar comparativamente 6 tipos de práticas culturais: desenleiramento, enleiramento, aplicação de corretivos, herbicidas, inseticidas e fertilizantes, com a opção de dois sistemas Taxa fixa (TF) e Taxa Variável (TV).

Originalidade/Relevância: O Brasil é referência mundial na produção de cana-de-açúcar, sendo que o Estado de São Paulo é o maior produtor brasileiro. No entanto, para os fornecedores de cana-de-açúcar se manter nessa atividade há necessidade de reduzir os custos de produção e aumentar a lucratividade/ha. Todavia, há um gap teórico-prático na avaliação financeira (custos e lucros) de diferentes práticas culturais inerentes a produção de cana-de-açúcar.

Principais resultados: Os resultados demonstraram que os custos com as práticas culturais representam mais de 30% sobre os custos totais de produção da cana-de-açúcar. O sistema TF mostrou-se mais eficiente em custos, nas seguintes operações: corretivos, herbicidas e inseticidas. Já na aplicação de fertilizantes, o sistema de TV, na modalidade a lanço, teve o melhor resultado. Por fim, o lucro/tonelada foi R$ 1,70 demonstrando uma margem de lucro/ha muito baixo frente ao risco da atividade.

Contribuições teóricas/metodológicas: A amostra desta pesquisa compreendeu com 55 fornecedores de cana-de-açúcar, do Estado de São Paulo, cujos dados foram alcançados por meio de survey. A análise comparativa pautou-se na diferença de custos das práticas culturais e da estimativa do nível de certeza (lucro/custos), analisadas por meio da frequência acumulativa realizada através da Simulação de Monte Carlo (SMC).

title: Joint Pricing and Inventory Decisions under Unknown Demand: A Satisficing Approach with Shape Information
affiliations: Nanjing University - School of Management and Engineering, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Shanghai University of Finance and Economics - School of Information Management and Engineering and The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen

detail.title: Joint Pricing and Inventory Decisions under Unknown Demand: A Satisficing Approach with Shape Information
detail.abstract: In this paper, we study a joint pricing and inventory decision problem where the exact price-demand relationship is unknown, but historical data and certain shape information (monotonicity, convexity, elasticity, etc) are available. Unlike traditional estimate-then-optimize approaches, we propose an end-to-end satisficing model that directly integrates historical data and shape constraints to avoid overly conservative choices of demand function and achieve robust profitability against demand estimation error. To address the original nonlinear model with infinitely many constraints, we reformulate the problem into a bilevel optimization model. We derive tractable solutions via second-order cone programs for lower-level subproblems and design efficient algorithms under continuous and discrete pricing sets for the upper-level problem, respectively. Through theoretical and numerical validation, we demonstrate that the effectiveness of shape constraints depends critically on the decision-maker's profit targets. Notably, we reveal a counterintuitive finding: complex shape structures do not universally guarantee superior performance, whereas simplified structures prove more advantageous in low-profit-target scenarios. Furthermore, our results demonstrate non-asymptotic convergence to sample size across diverse noise distributions, demand structures, and shape features. Finally, we conduct extensive experiments using synthetic and real-world datasets to confirm that the end-to-end model consistently outperforms parametric and non-parametric estimate-then-optimize methods across key profit metrics, including mean and VaR. This dual theoretical-empirical validation confirms the favorable balance of our framework between profitability and risk mitigation while maintaining robust performance.

title: Sustainable Practices and SMEs Competitiveness in Emerging Markets: The Moderating Role of Government Incentives
affiliations: Veritas University Abuja, Nigeria, Federal University Lokoja. Nigeria and Salem University

detail.title: Sustainable Practices and SMEs Competitiveness in Emerging Markets: The Moderating Role of Government Incentives
detail.abstract: This study explores how government incentives influence the relationship between sustainable practices and the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in emerging markets, drawing on the dynamic capabilities theory as its conceptual foundation. Employing a descriptive research design, the research gathered data from 250 SMEs located across Nigeria's six geopolitical zones through self-reported questionnaires. To analyze the data and test the proposed hypotheses, Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling (PLS-SEM) was applied. The findings reveal that sustainable practices are positively associated with SME competitiveness. Moreover, the analysis demonstrates that government incentives exert a strong and significant positive impact on SME competitiveness and serve as a positive moderator in the relationship between sustainable practices and competitiveness. The study addresses a notable gap in the literature, as few prior investigations have specifically examined the moderating role of government incentives in this context. By highlighting this dynamic, the research contributes valuable insights into how sustainable practices and supportive government policies together can enhance the competitiveness of SMEs operating in emerging economies.

title: Manager-Auditor Negotiations

detail.title: Manager-Auditor Negotiations
detail.abstract: In this dissertation, I address two central research questions. First, I open the black box of manager-auditor negotiations to examine how financial statements are endogenously shaped through strategic interaction under information asymmetry. Second, I investigate how this negotiation process affects financial reporting quality. I develop a two-round negotiation game in which the manager, possessing private information about earnings, makes an initial offer and a potential counteroffer. The auditor, facing potential overstatement penalties, responds strategically while retaining the option to extend the audit-a costly activity for both parties. This framework allows auditor conservatism and managerial conservatism to emerge endogenously. I show that the manager-auditor negotiation leads to conditional overstatement or understatement and produces a non-monotonic, asymmetric pattern in financial reporting quality. Additionally, the model predicts a discontinuity in the distribution of reported earnings. These results offer new theoretical insights into the micro-foundations of auditing and yield testable implications for empirical research on financial reporting quality and earnings distribution.

title: Il Design dell’Unione Europea: situazione attuale, importanza nel settore industriale e politiche comunitarie

detail.title: Il Design dell’Unione Europea: situazione attuale, importanza nel settore industriale e politiche comunitarie
detail.abstract:
Industrial design is becoming increasingly important as a means to differentiate products and enhance their value. At the same time, the speed at which a product reaches the market depends on the ability to integrate design into the production process. However, many SMEs—particularly new technology-based companies—lack specialized skills in design management and often fail to give sufficient attention to this aspect. The automotive industry and large corporations such as Philips and Braun manage and measure the impact of design as an innovative tool. In recent years, leading industrial companies in the production of certain goods have begun to face strong competition that is not equally protected. These companies experience the impact of competitors offering nearly identical products at lower prices, thanks to reduced investment in research and development, which lowers their cost structure.

Resumen
El diseño industrial es cada vez más importante como medio para diferenciar productos y aumentar su valor. Al mismo tiempo, la velocidad con la que se ofrece un producto en el mercado depende de la capacidad de integrar el diseño en el proceso de producción. Sin embargo, muchas PYMES -en particular las nuevas empresas basadas en la tecnología- carecen de habilidades especializadas en la gestión del diseño y, a menudo, no prestan suficiente atención a este aspecto. La industria automotriz y las grandes compañías como Philips y Braun administran y miden el impacto del diseño como una herramienta innovadora. En los últimos años, las empresas industriales que están a la vanguardia en la producción de ciertos productos están comenzando a experimentar una fuerte competencia que no está igualmente protegida. Estos sufren los impactos de la experiencia que ofrece casi los mismos productos a precios más bajos, gracias a una menor inversión en investigación y desarrollo, lo que reduce su estructura de costos.

detail.abstract:
The article proves the relevance of operational business intelligence in insurance in terms of VUCA-world. For this purpose, the use of Microsoft Power BI software as a method of information and communication technologies, its purpose and benefits for business monitoring are considered.
Among the advantages of using Microsoft Power BI is the analysis of existing insurance contracts and current indicators of insurance portfolios. The research substantiates the feasibility of operational analysis of insurance activities based on the calculation of indicators of insurance portfolios that form insurance statistics, which provides results in real time.
This approach eliminates the shortcomings of common means of retrospective operational analysis based on financial statements. Within the research, the insurance portfolio is defined as a set of insurance contracts for a separate line of business of the insurer on a certain date. It is emphasized that for each date of insurance activity the insurance portfolio is a unique set of contracts. A positive factor in the article is the possibility of timely response of managers to fluctuations in the profitability and technical risk of insurance portfolio. The application of the studied elements made it possible to propose a method of monitoring insurance activities based on the calculation of indicators of insurance portfolios and their visualization on analytical panels (dashboards).

title: Can startups generate a competitive advantage with AI tools?
affiliations: HEC Paris and Columbia University - Columbia Business School, Management

detail.title: Can startups generate a competitive advantage with AI tools?
detail.abstract: We examine how generative AI adoption affects the venture performance of high-tech software startups. Using a matched sample, we find that startups using generative AI for product development raise 15% less funding, especially in competitive markets with many similar AI adopters. However, startups targeting broad markets raise 30% more funding when adopting generative AI early-within six months of its release-before a dominant design emerges. These findings suggest that while early AI adoption can be beneficial, widespread use may erode differentiation. Overall, generative AI is not a silver bullet and may hinder fundraising when competitive advantages are easily replicated.

title: Managerial Frameworks for Analyzing Industry Profitability: Enriching Porter's Five Forces

detail.title: Managerial Frameworks for Analyzing Industry Profitability: Enriching Porter's Five Forces
detail.abstract: This paper focuses on rivalry among existing competitors, a key element of Porter's Five Forces analysis. The specific factors that determine the intensity of this rivalry have been discussed in a fragmented way across various theoretical domains. This study addresses this research gap by systematizing these factors, thereby expanding upon and deepening Porter's original discussion. Through a systematic literature review, it synthesizes insights from the broad theoretical landscapes of game theory, industrial organization, and search theory to identify the determinants of competitive intensity among incumbents. Building on this synthesis, we propose a pragmatic, multi-dimensional framework for practitioners. This framework complements the Five Forces analysis, allows for a more granular diagnosis of the competitive environment, and aids in the formulation of robust corporate strategy.

title: Digital Marketing Transformation in Ghana's Pharmaceutical Sector

detail.title: Digital Marketing Transformation in Ghana's Pharmaceutical Sector
detail.abstract: The pharmaceutical sector in Ghana, like in many parts of the world, is witnessing a significant transformation driven by digital marketing strategies. This study aims to provide a comprehensive examination of this transformation by exploring the strategies employed, their impact, and the ethical considerations surrounding digital marketing in the Ghanaian pharmaceutical context. A diverse range of sources, including industry reports, case studies, and data analysis, was employed to gather insights into the evolving landscape of digital marketing within Ghana's pharmaceutical sector. The study scrutinized the effectiveness of various digital marketing approaches, such as social media campaigns, influencer collaborations, search engine optimization (SEO), and targeted online advertisements, within the Ghanaian healthcare environment. The findings reveal that digital marketing is reshaping pharmaceutical promotion in Ghana, offering opportunities to enhance accessibility, engagement, and information dissemination. The study also highlights the critical importance of ethical considerations, including responsible product promotion, regulatory compliance, and data security. This research contributes to a holistic understanding of the complex interplay between digital marketing and pharmaceuticals in Ghana. It underscores the potential implications for healthcare practitioners, pharmaceutical companies, regulators, and, most importantly, patients. The transformative role of digital marketing in Ghana's pharmaceutical sector necessitates continuous attention to balance innovation with ethical responsibility.

title: The Embedding of EMNE Greenfield Subsidiaries in Developed Markets: A Process Perspective

detail.title: The Embedding of EMNE Greenfield Subsidiaries in Developed Markets: A Process Perspective

declarations.declarationOfInterest: This paper is derived from an independent study conducted as part of my self-funded PhD project
declarations.ethicsApproval: This paper received research ethics approval from the University of Sheffield

detail.abstract: This paper adopts a relational embeddedness perspective to examine how greenfield subsidiaries of emerging market multinational enterprises (EMNEs) establish ties with key stakeholders in host-country markets. Drawing on a longitudinal, qualitative case study of four Chinese electronics MNEs in the UK, the study reveals an iterative relationship development process with local sales channels. It highlights competence-based trust as the catalyst for initial engagement, while contractual trust, calculative commitment, and affective commitment enable first transactions. Over time, trust, commitment, and adaptation co-evolve to deepen relational embeddedness. The study contributes to international business theory by shedding light on the underexplored post-entry phase of subsidiary evolution. Managerially, it offers practical insights into facilitating relationship development through internal integration, leveraging OEM reputations, and hiring locally embedded talent across relationship stages.

title: Predictive Modeling and Reverse Logistics in Fashion Product Returns -A Machine Learning and Explainability Approach for Sustainable Fashion E-Commerce

detail.title: Predictive Modeling and Reverse Logistics in Fashion Product Returns -A Machine Learning and Explainability Approach for Sustainable Fashion E-Commerce
detail.abstract: This study examines the blending of predictive modeling and reverse logistics to counter product returns in the e-commerce sector, specially fashion. Leveraging the Women's Clothing E-Commerce Reviews dataset, machine learning classifiers, namely Random Forest, Gradient Boosting and XGBoost were trained to assess and predict the product return behavior; based on variable of 'Recommended IND'. The modeling pipeline integrated comprehensive preprocessing, feature engineering, sentiment analysis employing VADER and hyperparameter tuning via Optuna along with interpretability provided by SHAP. After fixing data leakage and running of five random and independent seeds to make modeling robust, XGBoost had the highest F1-score (0.912). SHAP analysis communicated that the most influential predictors were sentiment embedded in text, customer ratings and product category metadata. The results show that ensemble models that are interpretable can precisely pick high risk return products, in turn aiding more optimal inventory management and sustainability sensitive reverse logistics. The study emphasizes that data driven approaches in fashion retail in e-commerce will significantly impact business and environment.

title: Platform Labor and Financial Instability: Sectoral Insights on Gig Workers' Earnings Elasticity

detail.title: Platform Labor and Financial Instability: Sectoral Insights on Gig Workers' Earnings Elasticity

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares that this study was conducted independently and has no financial or personal relationships that could be perceived to have influenced the research.

detail.abstract: This paper investigates how sectoral differences within platform-based gig work shape financial instability through the lens of earnings elasticity. Drawing on a mixed-methods approach, by examines three core sectors of the gig economy: ride-hailing, food delivery, and digital freelancing. Through original survey data combined with secondary platform reports and user-generated content from online forums, the Earnings Elasticity Index (EEI) was developed to quantify the responsiveness of gig workers' income to changes in labor input and platform dynamics, and assess income volatility using standard deviation. Riders such as Uber or Grab have high earnings elasticity, where small changes in supply or demand result in significant fluctuations in income. However, delivery works show normal elasticity, heavily shaped by algorithmic factors. Digital freelancing, while less elastic in hourly rates, suffers from unfixed income and high project-based volatility. Across all sectors, higher elasticity correlates with reduced financial security, limited saving capacity, and increased dependence on credit. These insights have important implications for labor policy and platform governance. This study contributes to labor economics by introducing a comparative, elasticity-based lens to assess gig work sustainability, emphasizing the need for interventions.

title: Self-brand Connection: A Systematic Literature Review and Future Research Agenda
affiliations: University of Education, The University of Lahore, Lahore, Pakistan, University of Education and University of the Punjab, Lahore, Pakistan.

detail.title: Self-brand Connection: A Systematic Literature Review and Future Research Agenda
detail.abstract: This study aims to present a comprehensive review of the literature on self-brand connection to gain a deeper understanding of its role in shaping consumer-brand associations. This study is based on 30 peer-reviewed articles published over the last 25 years, synthesizing existing knowledge on the role of self-brand connection in consumer behavior, its boundary conditions, theoretical foundations, and methodological approaches. The analysis highlights both inconsistencies and divergences across studies, offering critical insights into how self-brand connection is formed and how they influence brand-related outcomes. Building on this synthesis, the study identifies significant gaps while proposing a structured agenda for future research to advance theoretical development and empirical investigation in the field of selfbrand connection.

detail.abstract: The objective of this study is to analyze the significance of CSR strategy for improving brand image and consumer confidence in global markets. Using a systematic review of published literature and case analysis, the study examines the effects of CSR activities on customer beliefs and brand value in various cultural, economic, and legal environments. Regarding the research questions, the following are the findings; The study establishes that CSR is an important organizational asset that enhances organizational sustainability by regarding stakeholder opinions with corporate values. The findings of the research indicate that the firms that internalize CSR strategies at the core business designs not only enhance the brand reputation but also create improved credibility to consumers. From this perspective, understanding culturally and geographically appropriate initiatives of CSR can be of paramount significance to MNCs venturing into the international markets. It also brings awareness that CSR should be integrated into the business scheme of strategic management since it can again act for competitive edge and corporate profit-making in the long term. This research offers insights that would be viable for business managers, policymakers, and CSR professionals since they establish important features of contemporary CSR.

title: Marketing Trends in the Cryptocurrency Industry
affiliations: Woxsen University and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Marketing Trends in the Cryptocurrency Industry
detail.abstract: This chapter examines the marketing trends and strategies used in the cryptocurrency industry. A qualitative research design was used, with case studies of five cryptocurrency firms as the primary data source. Secondary data sources such as websites, social media accounts, articles, and blogs were also analyzed. The study found that content marketing, social media marketing, and influencer marketing are the industry's most commonly used marketing strategies. Community building and brand reputation were also found to be essential for the success of companies operating in the cryptocurrency industry. However, the study's limitations including the limited sample size, reliance on secondary data, the potential for researcher bias, and lack of triangulation should be considered when interpreting the findings. The insights gained from this study can inform the development of marketing strategies in the cryptocurrency industry and guide future research in this area.

title: Obsessed and Envious: Understanding the Dark Side of Self-Brand Connection
affiliations: University of Education, University of Education and University of the Punjab, Lahore, Pakistan.

detail.title: Obsessed and Envious: Understanding the Dark Side of Self-Brand Connection
detail.abstract: This study aims to understand and empirically investigate a conceptual model to examine the psychological mechanisms through which self-brand connection (SBC) leads to compulsive buying behavior. Drawing on social comparison theory, the model proposes that envy mediates the relationship between SBC and compulsive buying. Furthermore, obsessive passion is introduced as a moderator that intensifies the link between SBC and envy. Data was collected through a structured questionnaire from a sample of consumers with strong brand affiliations, and the hypotheses were tested using structural equation modeling. The results provide empirical support for the proposed relationships, suggesting that SBC significantly predicts envy, which in turn drives compulsive buying, confirming envy as a key mediator. Additionally, obsessive passion was found to moderate the SBC-envy relationship significantly, indicating that consumers with higher levels of obsessive passion experience greater envy in response to their brand connections. These findings contribute to the literature on SBC by highlighting the emotional and motivational underpinnings of compulsive buying. The study offers practical implications for marketers in managing brand strategies responsibly and for consumer well-being.

title: The effects of new ways of working (NWW) on employees’ well-being and happiness. A theoretical overview
affiliations: Universidade de Santiago de Compostela, Universidade de Santiago de Compostela - Faculty of Economics and Business Administration and University of Vigo

detail.title: The effects of new ways of working (NWW) on employees’ well-being and happiness. A theoretical overview
detail.abstract:
Purpose: New ways of working (NWW) is an emerging trend in contemporary organisations, driven by the need to be flexible and adapt quickly to changes. Thus, NWW provides employees with greater control over their working time, also increasing their autonomy with the support of ICTs. However, the adoption of flexible work arrangements can be a source of a wide range of concerns, which can influence employees’ well-being and happiness at work. This research aims to develop an overall framework to guide future research on new flexible work models.

Methodology: This theoretical overview proposes to analyse the influence of e-demands (technostress, e-work-life balance, etc.) resulting from NWW adoption on employees’ e-well-being (e-psychological well-being, e-emotional exhaustion, etc.) and e-happiness. To mitigate the potential negative effects of NWW practices, both organisations and employees should identify personal e-resources (e-psychological capital, e-work self-efficacy, e-psychological empowerment) and job e-resources (e-engaging leadership, e-work effectiveness) that can serve as effective moderators to promote employees’ well-being.

Results: The proposed model attempts to provide an overview based on available knowledge about the relationships between e-demands, employees’ e-well-being and personal and job resources in e-work contexts.

Practical implications: This research aims to shed light on the need for effective strategies to adapt the NWW to work environments characterised by higher levels of flexibility and the intensive use of ICTs, with the aim of guaranteeing employees’ well-being, health and happiness, and achieving better results.

title: Hot Triggers vs Cold Preferences: Consumption Patterns in Digital Media
affiliations: Illinois Institute of Technology - Stuart School of Business, IIT and University of Michigan, Stephen M. Ross School of Business

detail.title: Hot Triggers vs Cold Preferences: Consumption Patterns in Digital Media
detail.abstract: This paper examines excessive digital media consumption by assessing the extent to which it is driven by impulsive behavior. While prior work has linked impulsivity to consumption, we are the first to do so using observational data and to quantify its long-term cumulative effects on consumption levels. Focusing on video games, we develop a dynamic structural model in which players determine the duration of their daily gaming sessions, taking into account that increased consumption today reduces leisure time available for future sessions. The model incorporates insights from dual-process theories of decision-making, where behavior results from the interaction between a forward-looking, analytical system (``cold'') and an impulsive, short-sighted system (``hot''). Environmental cues can stimulate the hot system and amplify its influence at the time of decision, leading to overconsumption. In our setting, these cues correspond to certain in-game experiences. We find that impulsivity increases monthly gaming time by 15.9\% and significantly alters consumption patterns: compared to purely forward-looking behavior, gaming sessions are 89.5\% longer. But as overconsumption reduces the leisure time available for subsequent days, players are forced to abstain until constraints ease, making sessions 38.6\% less frequent. The resulting dynamics resemble the cycles described in the addiction literature: binge consumption, abstinence, craving, and relapse.

detail.abstract: In an era marked by rapid technological advancement and increasing digital disruption, organisations in the education sector must continuously innovate to remain competitive and relevant. This research explores the strategic application of five emerging disruptive technologies-Artificial Intelligence (AI), Blockchain, Internet of Things (IoT), Augmented and Virtual Reality (AR/VR), and 3D Printing, within the early and primary education sector. Using Bright Horizons Family Solutions as a case study, the paper conducts a SWOT and 5C analysis to assess the organization's readiness for technological integration. The findings highlight significant opportunities for Bright Horizons to leverage AI for personalised learning, utilise blockchain for secure recordkeeping, and adopt AR/VR and IoT to enhance engagement and operational efficiency. Among the proposed technologies, AI and IOT emerges as the most strategically viable for immediate implementation. This paper contributes to the discourse on technology-led transformation in education by offering a strategic roadmap for integrating disruptive innovations to strengthen competitive positioning and service delivery in early childhood education.

title: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE AND THE TRANSFORMATION OF THE CORPORATION, LABOR, AND FREE MARKET SYSTEMS *

detail.title: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE AND THE TRANSFORMATION OF THE CORPORATION, LABOR, AND FREE MARKET SYSTEMS *
detail.abstract: This paper examines how artificial intelligence (AI), as a general-purpose and selfimproving technology, is transforming the structure of corporations, labor markets, and free market capitalism itself. Drawing on classical economic theory and recent empirical research, we develop a stylized production model that formalizes the declining labor share under AI-driven capital substitution. We analyze how AI amplifies market concentration, redefines firm boundaries through platformization, and disrupts the labor-capital bargain. The paper concludes with a policy agenda addressing governance, inclusion, and the institutional legitimacy of post-labor economic architectures through a combination of formal modeling, empirical synthesis, and policy analysis.

That means based on the purpose and requirements customers will tend to purchase Samsung mobile phones. Appearance, branding, product design, product performance and price have the influence on people’s buying decision process, which echoes to the literature that whether the product can satisfy people’s needs. Preference of the specific models of Samsung mobile users are based on the features offered by Samsung Company to the customers. Statistical tools, including chi-square tests and descriptive analysis, were applied to evaluate relationships between consumer demographics and satisfaction levels. The research concluded that maintaining customer satisfaction through innovation, value-based pricing, and strong brand engagement is essential for sustaining consumer loyalty and competitive advantage. Due to technology and the innovations, Samsung as brand leader in mobile industry has full field the expectation of customers and made the customer satisfied.

title: AI Anxiety among Creative Professionals: Global Stress and Future Outlook

detail.title: AI Anxiety among Creative Professionals: Global Stress and Future Outlook
detail.abstract: The rapid integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into creative industries has sparked significant psychological stress among professionals such as freelance artists, writers, content creators, and filmmakers. As generative AI tools increasingly perform tasks once considered uniquely human—like writing, illustrating, and editing—many creative workers report heightened anxiety, job insecurity, and fear of obsolescence. This research paper explores the global impact of AI-induced stress on creative professionals, drawing on secondary research that includes surveys, academic studies, expert commentary, and case studies. Findings reveal that AI anxiety is closely linked to diminished well-being, perceived job devaluation, and an erosion of creative identity. The paper also identifies key stress drivers—such as rapid technological change, lack of ethical regulation, and economic pressures—and offers forward-looking strategies to mitigate these effects. Ultimately, it argues that fostering ethical AI adoption, supporting creative professionals through upskilling and transparent communication, and emphasizing the irreplaceable value of human creativity are essential to maintaining mental well-being in an AI-augmented future.

title: Foundations of Modern Governance: The Contributions of Early Policy Thinkers to Public Policy
affiliations: University of Ibadan - Department of Political Science

detail.title: Foundations of Modern Governance: The Contributions of Early Policy Thinkers to Public Policy
detail.abstract: This paper examines the foundational contributions of five early political thinkers: Thomas Hobbes, Jean-Jacques Rousseau, Adam Smith, Robert Malthus, and Alexis de Tocqueville, to the development of public policy. By exploring their seminal ideas and evaluating their legacies, this study reveals how each thinker shaped notions of governance, state responsibility, economy, population control, and civil society. While their theories emerged in different historical contexts, their ideas continue to inform and challenge modern public policy frameworks. The paper employs a comparative and analytical approach to demonstrate the relevance of classical thought to contemporary policymaking, offering an appreciation of these intellectual forebears.

title: Managing Patients' Bypass Behavior in a Hierarchical Healthcare System
affiliations: University of Electronic Science and Technology of China (UESTC), Monash University - Department of Management and Xidian University

detail.title: Managing Patients' Bypass Behavior in a Hierarchical Healthcare System

declarations.declarationOfInterest: No conflict of interest.
declarations.ethicsApproval: N/A
declarations.funderStatement: N/A

detail.abstract:
Problem definition: Patients often bypass primary care and seek services directly from higher-level providers in a health system with limited gatekeeping. This bypass behavior can lead to system inefficiencies and increased healthcare costs. To maximize patient welfare, which includes both objective health outcomes and subjective patient satisfaction, the strategic use of a direct-access fee is essential.

Methodology/results: We develop a queueing model to examine patients' care-seeking behavior in a healthcare system comprising a primary and a secondary level, characterized by non-emergency referrals from the primary to the secondary level. We analyze the welfare-oriented design of the direct-access fee by the regulator to manage patients' bypass behavior. First, a necessary condition is identified for a functional hierarchical system, which requires that the prevalence rate of the severe health condition falls into a specific interval. Second, depending on patients' expected waiting times at the secondary level, which is determined by the direct-access fee, the hierarchical system may relegate to a uniform or two-tier one. The hierarchical system always outperforms the uniform and two-tier systems in terms of patient welfare. Finally, a certain degree of direct access to the secondary level should be permitted under the two simultaneous conditions: one is that the regulator prioritizes the subjective aspect of patient welfare concerning patient satisfaction, and the other is that the demand for services at the secondary level is not excessively high.

Managerial implications: Our analytical results provide managerial insights into maximizing patients' welfare in a hierarchical health system. It emphasizes the critical role of the prevalence rate of the severe condition and patients' waiting cost at the secondary level in aligning doctors' decisions with the signals observed from medical examinations. Moreover, it highlights the strategic implementation of the direct-access fees in influencing patients' joining-and-balking decisions and in managing system congestion.

title: Share Buybacks as a Financial Strategy: Global Perspectives, Indian Insights, and Regulatory Landscape

detail.title: Share Buybacks as a Financial Strategy: Global Perspectives, Indian Insights, and Regulatory Landscape

keywords: Share Buybacks as a Financial Strategy: Global Perspectives

detail.abstract: This paper provides a comprehensive examination of share buybacks as a financial strategy, combining global perspectives with an in-depth analysis of the Indian regulatory environment. It traces the evolution of buybacks from a legally constrained practice to a widely accepted corporate payout mechanism, highlighting the pivotal role of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission's Rule 10b-18 (1982) in creating a "safe harbor" framework. The study contrasts international practices-particularly the flexible, open-market orientation in the United States-with India's stringent, disclosure-driven regime that prioritizes creditor and minority shareholder protection. It outlines key regulatory provisions in India under the Companies Act, 2013, and SEBI Buyback Regulations, including the 25% capital cap, 2:1 post-buyback debtequity limit, one-year completion requirement, and minimum utilization thresholds. The paper also examines execution methods-open-market repurchases, tender offers, Dutch auctions, and accelerated share repurchases-detailing their operational and market impact characteristics. Empirical insights highlight consistent positive announcement effects, driven by undervaluation signaling and capital structure optimization motives. Case studies, notably of Tata Consultancy Services, illustrate regulatory compliance, shareholder participation patterns, and route selection under evolving SEBI norms. The analysis concludes that while buybacks serve as an effective capital allocation tool, their design and regulation significantly influence fairness, market perception, and corporate governance outcomes. Policymakers are urged to balance flexibility with safeguards to ensure buybacks align with long-term value creation rather than short-term managerial objectives.

title: Correcting the Record on Financial Education: Smaller Effects After Adjusting for Publication Bias
affiliations: Catholic University of Portugal, University of Colorado-Boulder, Leeds School of Business - Center for Research on Consumer Financial Decision Making and Cornell University - SC Johnson Graduate School of Business

detail.title: Correcting the Record on Financial Education: Smaller Effects After Adjusting for Publication Bias

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.
declarations.funderStatement: Lynch gratefully acknowledges financial support by a Leeds School of Business Dean’s Impact Award.

detail.abstract: Kaiser et al. (2022, Journal of Financial Economics) report a meta-analysis of 76 randomized controlled trials (RCTs) on the effects of financial education on behavior and knowledge, along with cost-benefit analyses of the interventions. They contrast their headline result - an uncorrected estimate of g = 0.10 standard deviations - with earlier estimates from RCTs in Fernandes et al. (2014, Management Science). The Kaiser estimate is five times larger. Kaiser et al. attribute the discrepancy not to publication bias but to stronger effects in more recent studies. Citing Andrews and Kasy (2019, American Economic Review), they correct for publication bias favoring statistically significant results regardless of sign and conclude that bias is minimal. However, when true effects are small but positive, random sampling alone generates many valid estimates with the "wrong" sign. If these are underreported, published results will be biased upward. We reanalyze their data using Andrews and Kasy's preferred correction, which accounts for selective reporting based on both significance and sign. This adjustment reduces the estimated average effect to g = 0.018-0.033-close to earlier findings. Kaiser et al. also examine heterogeneity across intervention types but do not apply publication bias corrections to type-specific estimates. Once corrected, those effects are again smaller, and the conclusions about which interventions work best shift. We conclude that most financial education programs yield modest behavioral changes, and fewer interventions show benefits exceeding costs than Kaiser et al. suggest. Similar patterns hold for financial knowledge outcomes.

title: Impact of UK Post-Brexit Trade Policy on Key Sectors and Industries

detail.title: Impact of UK Post-Brexit Trade Policy on Key Sectors and Industries
detail.abstract: The study critically examines the UK's approach to negotiations with its largest trading partner post-Brexit, the EU. The complexities surrounding the Northern Ireland Protocol, fisheries, and regulatory standards have raised questions about the UK's strategic direction and the potential long-term implications for its trade relationships. While Brexit presented the UK with an opportunity to diversify its trade partners and potentially tap into emerging markets, challenges persist. The UK's trade policy's pivot towards the 'Global Britain' narrative aims to reposition the nation as a global trading hub. However, the practical implications of this narrative, including potential trade-offs between economic gain and regulatory standards, are critically analysed in this research. The study also delves into the domestic implications of the UK's trade policy, notably the effects on local industries, employment, and the broader economic landscape. There is a particular focus on how trade policy shifts impact sectors that were deeply integrated with the EU market, such as automotive, finance, and agriculture. In conclusion, the UK's post-Brexit trade policy represents a significant departure from its past alignment with the EU. While there are opportunities to forge new trade relationships and diversify its market access, there are also inherent challenges in navigating a post-EU trade landscape. This study offers a comprehensive and critical understanding of these dynamics, contributing to the ongoing discourse on the UK's post-Brexit future.

title: Easy Secular and Temporal Marriage for the Digital Age: Digital Mutah in Accordance with UNCRC Article 7
affiliations: Association of Digital Ecosystem Governance and Development Research

detail.title: Easy Secular and Temporal Marriage for the Digital Age: Digital Mutah in Accordance with UNCRC Article 7

keywords: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (UNCRC)

detail.abstract: The growing prevalence of non-marital relationships has intensified the risk of children being born without officially recognized legal parentage, creating persistent inequalities in access to identity documents, inheritance rights, and social services. In line with Article 7 of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (UNCRC), this paper proposes Digital Mutah-a state-managed, secular, time-bound partnership framework that guarantees the recording of both parents from the outset of the relationship. Leveraging existing civil registration and secure e-government platforms, Digital Mutah offers a costeffective, legally robust mechanism for safeguarding children's legal status while providing adults with a flexible alternative to traditional marriage.

title: Predictive Scaffolding: Meta-Pattern Detection and Environmental Readiness as Gating Conditions for Organizational Change

detail.title: Predictive Scaffolding: Meta-Pattern Detection and Environmental Readiness as Gating Conditions for Organizational Change
detail.abstract: Most organizational change models focus on how to execute change once initiated, treating environmental conditions as either background context or obstacles to overcome. Predictive Scaffolding reframes readiness as the primary gating condition: change will fail if the surrounding environment is misaligned with the structural level of the intended transformation. Extending this logic, the Reflection Pattern (RP) meta-pattern functions as a system-closure mechanism that can nullify change regardless of environmental strength; detecting RP presence and network stage becomes the first predictive filter. Drawing from a hierarchical progression model-habits clustering into patterns, patterns consolidating into frameworks, and frameworks crystallizing into systems-Predictive Scaffolding identifies specific internal environmental variables that signal when change is likely to stick. High-signal predictors include structural slack, reinforcement alignment, psychological safety, cross-boundary permeability, and change fatigue. Unlike prescriptive models such as Kotter' s 8-Step or McKinsey' s 7-S, Predictive Scaffolding is predictive: it determines whether now is the time to act and, if not, which environmental factors can be engineered to accelerate readiness. By combining meta-pattern detection with environmental readiness scanning, the model offers leaders a practical method to reduce failed change initiatives, avoid premature urgency campaigns, and time major transformations for maximum effect.

detail.abstract: This proposal presents a comprehensive and actionable framework to end the Russia–Ukraine war immediately while securing long-term stability for Europe and the global economy. The plan consists of four core elements: (1) an immediate, verifiable ceasefire monitored by a U.S.–NATO–UN mission; (2) Ukraine’s integration into the United States as a territory with a path to statehood, designated as a Special Modern Agricultural Zone; (3) Russia’s admission into NATO as a senior partner and direct U.S. neighbor, with Crimea recognized as Russian territory and sanctions lifted upon compliance; and (4) enhanced European Union security, energy stability, and economic growth. The plan is financed by $300 billion in frozen Russian assets and targeted global investment, ensuring no cost to U.S. taxpayers. This strategy aims to transform adversaries into partners, prevent future wars, and reset the global security and economic order through bold vision and enforceable commitments.

detail.abstract:
A profound paradox pervades the history of science and commerce: why do the most bril
liant minds (Einstein) and dominant organizations (Kodak) so often become prisoners of their
own success? This paper introduces Cognitive Gravity as a unified dynamical framework
to resolve this enigma. We posit that any intelligent entity—individual or organizational—
operates within a “cognitive spacetime” shaped by historical experience. Success accumulates
Cognitive Mass (Mc), which warps this spacetime. When Mc exceeds a critical threshold,
it triggers Gravitational Collapse, forming a Cognitive Black Hole—an extreme state that
systematically distorts and captures information challenging the system’s core paradigm.
We provide exploratory evidence for the theory’s scale invariance through systematic anal
ysis of cross-scale structural isomorphism across cognitive trajectories of Einstein, Kodak,
Freud, and Ford. Crucially, our theory moves beyond explanation to prediction: cognitive
gravity generates diffuse, global effects detectable via our designed “Gravitational Ripples”
neuroscience experiment—predictions that contrast starkly with traditional cognitive models.
Ultimately, this framework provides both a “cognitive physics” for understanding cogni
tive inertia and a suite of falsifiable predictions and analytical tools, establishing the scientific
foundation for an emerging applied discipline: Cognitive Systems Engineering.

title: From Monetary Policy to Capital Investment: The Role of Executive Compensation
affiliations: University of Sheffield, University of York and Amity University Dubai

detail.title: From Monetary Policy to Capital Investment: The Role of Executive Compensation
detail.abstract: By placing corporate governance at the core of analysing the effect of monetary policy on investments, this paper argues that the firm's capital investment response to monetary policy is shaped by how CEO compensation incentivizes risk-taking. We posit that, due to the risks arising from monetary policy decisions, CEO compensation structures that encourage risk-taking lead to a stronger investment response to monetary shocks. Our analysis, based on a comprehensive dataset of 75,352 firm-level observations from 2,302 U.S. firms spanning 1993 to 2018, supports this conjecture: a high CEO compensation sensitivity to stock volatility (Vega) strengthens the firm's investment response to monetary shocks. An increase in Vega from its 25th to 75th percentile in our sample increases (or decreases) the rate of capital investments in response to expansionary (or contractionary) monetary shocks by roughly a third. This effect is accentuated by strong financial flexibility and low economic uncertainty. We also demonstrate that high Vegas partially counterbalance the risk-averse investment response to monetary shocks driven by high Deltas.

title: The Hidden Risk of a Safe Customer: Regulatory Fragmentation and Government Contracting
affiliations: University of Georgia - C. Herman and Mary Virginia Terry College of Business and Oregon State University - College of Business

detail.title: The Hidden Risk of a Safe Customer: Regulatory Fragmentation and Government Contracting
detail.abstract: We examine how regulatory fragmentation affects the capital structure decisions of government suppliers. Using text-based measures of regulatory structure and a novel text-based measure of government procurement exposure, we find that suppliers respond to greater fragmentation by adopting more conservative capital structures, reducing leverage and increasing cash holdings. Our evidence supports a risk-based precautionary channel rather than an expectations-driven motive. The conservative response is strongest among firms with high procurement exposure and those making relationship-specific investments with limited redeployability, including R&D and differentiated products. The effect diminishes for long-tenured government suppliers who have accumulated regulatory expertise and reputational capital. We introduce a novel procurement exposure measure that captures firms' exposure to government contracting processes independent of contract value, addressing limitations of traditional disclosure-based approaches. Our findings reveal that regulatory fragmentation creates a distinct risk channel for government contractors that operates through the increased probability of contract disputes and relationship termination, offsetting the cash flow benefits typically associated with government customer relationships.

title: Construction of a Three-Level Prisoner's Decision Trap Theory Framework —— An Evolutionary Analysis from Individual Prisoner's Decision Trap to Systemic Prisoner's Decision Trap
affiliations: Zhongnan University of Economics and Law

detail.title: Construction of a Three-Level Prisoner's Decision Trap Theory Framework —— An Evolutionary Analysis from Individual Prisoner's Decision Trap to Systemic Prisoner's Decision Trap
