The core research content of this work has been filed as an invention patent with the China National Intellectual Property Administration (CNIPA), under Application No. 2025103827940, titled “Prediction Method and System for Three-Level Decision Traps Based on Dynamic Evolutionary Game Theory”, with a filing date of March 28, 2025. detail.abstract: This study proposes the “Human Prisoner Society Hypothesis” and develops the Three-Level Prisoner's Decision Trap (PDP) theoretical framework. It constructs quantitative models of dynamic games, dynamic prisoner’s dilemmas, and dynamic Nash equilibria, integrating principles from game theory, the prisoner’s dilemma, and Nash equilibrium with system dynamics modeling. The aim is to reveal the mechanisms by which multiple agents, under resource constraints, fall into prisoner-type decision traps that lead to failure. The PDP framework unveils the quantitative mechanisms behind three hierarchically linked decision traps: (1) Micro-Level Poverty Trap driven by individual myopia (δ > 0.7); (2) Meso-Level Indigence Trap rooted in group path dependence (α < 0.8); and (3) Macro-Level Prisoner's Trap characterized by systemic Nash lock-ins (DTI ≥ 0.7).This model innovates beyond classical paradigms by introducing strategic space expansion, dynamic resource allocation equations, the Decision Trap Index (DTI), resilience metrics, and opportunity dynamics modeling—enabling analysis of intertemporal trade-offs and behavioral inertia. Theoretically, PDP departs from Dynamic Capability Theory by diagnosing capability collapse under scarcity, and extends classical game theory by incorporating dynamic resource feedback and continuous strategies (∈[0,1]). It also generalizes the single-shot Prisoner's Dilemma into multi-level degradation cycles, showing how information asymmetry can shrink strategic space by 62.3% (p<0.01).Empirical analysis shows PDP reduces decision errors by 37% (p<0.05) and mitigates information asymmetry by 58.7% using decision knowledge graphs and DTI-based early warning tools. The case of City A demonstrates how resource-dependent cities can escape the “degradation–deterioration loop” through quantum game-theoretic collaboration mechanisms and resilience funds, achieving systemic rebalancing across economic, ecological, and social domains.PDP is applicable across various sectors—new energy vehicles (NEVs), photovoltaics, real estate, cross-border M&A, urban transition, and public governance—providing a generalizable, quantitative framework for strategic management and sustainable policy design. Parameter modeling and sensitivity analysis further verify its explanatory and predictive power, offering both theoretical contributions and practical solutions.

title: The Reflection Pattern -A Recursive Fear-Reinforcement System that Suppresses Organizational Innovation

detail.title: The Reflection Pattern -A Recursive Fear-Reinforcement System that Suppresses Organizational Innovation
detail.abstract: Organizations often attribute stagnation in innovation to leadership failure, cultural inertia, or market forces. This paper introduces the Reflection Pattern, a distinct, recursive system of reinforcement loops driven by unacknowledged fear, sustained by reward, and protected by role authority. The Pattern narrows the range of perceived safe options over time, until novelty becomes either invisible or structurally excluded. Drawing on neurobiological models of motivation (Fear-Based Motivation in the Workplace, The Preparedness Ladder, Beyond Snyder's Hope Theory), this paper outlines the Pattern's enabling conditions-Recursion, Role Safety Priority, and Reward Linkage-and its developmental stages: Entry, Threshold, Full Maturity, Network Stage, and Meta-Entity. A condensed Pattern Map and Edge taxonomy are provided for early identification. The mechanism of reinforcement is traced from felt-positive experiences (relief, approval, predictability) through dopamine and related neuromodulators to behavioral consolidation, illustrating why disruption is counterintuitive and often resisted. The implications for organizational practice are significant: dismantling a local Pattern may not break its profession-wide form, but can alter local adaptive capacity. A complete field guide, including a longitudinal composite case study (Catalyst Edge), reader diagnostics, and expanded taxonomy, appears in The Blind Spot-The Unseen Pattern That Silently Shapes Your Organization (Thomas, release Sep 2025).

title: Extended Evaluation of SnowPole Detection for Machine-Perceivable Infrastructure for Nordic Winter Conditions: A Comparative Study of Object Detection Models

detail.title: Extended Evaluation of SnowPole Detection for Machine-Perceivable Infrastructure for Nordic Winter Conditions: A Comparative Study of Object Detection Models

declarations.funderStatement: This research was supported by the Norwegian Research Council under the project ”Machine Sensible Infrastructure under Nordic Conditions” (Project Number 333875). We also thank the NTNU NAPLab team for their support during data collection and vehicle setup.

detail.abstract: This study presents an extensive evaluation of YOLO object detection architectures for identifying snow poles in LiDAR-derived imagery under challenging Nordic conditions. Building on our prior Snow-Pole Detection dataset [1] and LiDAR-GNSS localization framework [2], we benchmark six YOLO models-YOLOv5s, YOLOv7-tiny, YOLOv8n, YOLOv9t, YOLOv10n, and YOLOv11n-across multiple input modalities. We assess single-channel modalities (Reflectance, Signal, Near-Infrared) and six pseudo-color combinations derived from these channels. Model performance is quantified using Precision, Recall, mAP@50, mAP@50-95, and GPU inference latency. To enable systematic comparison, we define a composite Rank Score combining accuracy and real-time performance. Results show YOLOv9t achieves the highest detection accuracy, while YOLOv11n offers the best balance between accuracy and inference speed, making it suitable for real-time applications. Pseudo-color combinations, especially those fusing Near-Infrared, Signal, and Reflectance, outperform single modalities and yield the highest Rank Scores. We recommend multimodal LiDAR configurations such as Combination 4 and Combination 5 to enhance detection robustness. All datasets, code, and trained models are publicly available to support reproducibility via our GitHub repository 4 and the Mendeley dataset archive 5 .

title: Predicting Conversions with Multimodal Data: A Generalist AI Framework Integrating Text, Images, and Advertising Spend
affiliations: Queen's University - Smith School of Business, Queen’s University, Dartmouth College - Tuck School of Business and Queen's University

detail.title: Predicting Conversions with Multimodal Data: A Generalist AI Framework Integrating Text, Images, and Advertising Spend
detail.abstract: This study examines the drivers of online conversion by modeling how multimodal marketing inputs, advertising spending, media channel mix, website text, and image content, jointly shape consumer behavior. We propose a generalist AI framework built on a large language model that scalably integrates structured and unstructured inputs in a unified pipeline. This design enables efficient and interpretable multimodal attribution across diverse marketing elements. To quantify each modality's contribution, we introduce the Relative Impact Score (RIS), a novel metric that extends Integrated Gradients to capture modality-level attribution in online conversion. Our findings show that advertising accounts for over half of the total impact on conversion, though its effects are mixed, ranging from positive to antagonistic depending on execution. In contrast, website content, particularly text, plays a more consistent and constructive role, contributing to about 60% of the positive lift in conversion. Digital and social media channels emerge as the most effective, outperforming traditional media in driving lower-funnel outcomes. This work makes both substantive and methodological contributions by offering a scalable generalist AI approach to multimodal attribution, and by generating actionable insights for firms aiming to optimize content and media strategy in data-rich digital environments.

title: The Tyranny of the Two: Designing Transparent Governance for a Nuanced Citizenry

detail.title: The Tyranny of the Two: Designing Transparent Governance for a Nuanced Citizenry
detail.abstract: Modern democracies, particularly in the United States, find themselves ensnared in a paradox of their own making. The people they are meant to represent have evolved into a citizenry far too complex, too variegated in opinion and experience, to be contained by the blunt instrument of a two-party system. Yet the political machinery continues to grind forward on rails laid in an era when information traveled no faster than the horse and the printing press. The result is a forced simplification of human identity into one of two approved packages, each laden with ideological baggage that the individual may or may not wish to carry. This paper examines the inefficiencies created by that reduction, drawing on real-world examples of individuals whose beliefs straddle, subvert, or outright defy partisan boundaries. In these cases, we see reflected a larger truth: the public is a spectrum, yet it is asked to choose between only two colors. In response, the paper proposes a governance model that places transparency as its cornerstone, citizen expertise as its scaffolding, and open-source infrastructure as its foundation. This model seeks to embrace the contradictions and crosscurrents of modern political identity rather than erase them. The vision is not merely reform within the current system but a structural reimagining-a system designed to represent reality as it is, not as it was in a bygone century.

title: Forgive and Forget? An Industry 5.0 Approach to Trust-Fatigue Co-regulation in Human-Cobot Order Picking
affiliations: Indian Institute of Technology (IIT), Kharagpur - Department of Industrial Engineering and Management

detail.title: Forgive and Forget? An Industry 5.0 Approach to Trust-Fatigue Co-regulation in Human-Cobot Order Picking
detail.abstract: This paper investigates the critical role of trust and fatigue in human-cobot collaborative order picking, framing the challenge within the scope of Logistics 5.0-the implementation of human-robot symbiosis in smart logistics. We propose a dynamic, leader-follower Stackelberg game to model this interaction, where utility functions explicitly account for human fatigue and trust. Through agentbased simulations, we demonstrate that while a naive model leads to a "trust death spiral," a refined trust model creates a "trust synergy cycle," increasing productivity by nearly 100%. Finally, we show that a cobot equipped with a proactive Trust-Repair Protocol can overcome system brittleness, reducing trust recovery time after a severe failure by over 75% compared to a nonadaptive model. Our findings provide a framework for designing intelligent cobot behaviors that fulfill the Industry 5.0 pillars of human-centricity, sustainability, and resilience.

title: EPISTEMIC HUMILITY AND ADAPTIVE REGULATION
affiliations: Northwestern Pritzker School of Law and Northwestern University

detail.title: EPISTEMIC HUMILITY AND ADAPTIVE REGULATION

declarations.funderStatement: This research was funded in part by the Northwestern University Pritzker School of Law Faculty Research Program.

detail.abstract: This article advances epistemic humility as a normative and institutional principle for agency rulemaking. Drawing on F.A. Hayek's critique of constructivist rationality, the article recognizes that regulators-even with their best efforts-can overestimate their ability to design optimal rules ex ante. Epistemically humble rulemaking would be mindful of regulators' knowledge limitations and build in mechanisms for learning, correction, and revision. These design features-such as sunset provisions, pilot programs, and contingent rules-not only improve regulatory performance over time but also enhance democratic legitimacy by institutionalizing openness to new information and stakeholder input. The article further explores how decentralized structures, particularly American federalism, can facilitate policy experimentation and crossjurisdictional learning. In contrast to static models of regulation, epistemically humble rulemaking envisions regulation as a fallible but improvable enterprise. It ultimately reframes legitimacy not as perfection at the outset, but as responsiveness over time to evidence, context, and public reason.

detail.title: Current Problems and Prospects of Ukraine'S Integration into the International Scientific Community
detail.abstract:
The scientific work, carried out within the framework of the fundamental research topic “Legal Mechanisms of the New Scientific Research Infrastructure” (RK UkrINTEI No. 0121U113768), provides an overview of the relevance of Ukraine's integration into international scientific networks, with an emphasis on the importance of science and technology for economic development and social progress. It reveals an analysis of the current state of scientific activity in Ukraine, including its strengths and weaknesses, as well as existing problems such as funding, brain drain, and outdated infrastructure. The main obstacles facing Ukraine on the path to integration are highlighted, such as insufficient funding, regulatory barriers, and brain drain.
The article outlines possible ways to overcome these challenges, including the need to increase funding for science, develop international partnerships, and modernize research infrastructure. The conclusion reflects the importance of Ukraine's integration into European and global research infrastructures for the development of the country's scientific potential and recommendations for further action.

It has since undergone conceptual and thematic refinement, with subsequent authors contributing to both interdisciplinary and disciplinary dimensions of the study. detail.abstract: Management control practices have been evolving from informal economy to formal micro-enterprise setup, Budgeting technique is a key dimension of management control practices. The study aims to understand budgeting practices in micro businesses in the context of focal management accounting issues and informal economic activity dilemmas. The methodological approach is an exploratory pilot study using informal conversational interviews. The research evaluates budgeting practices in micro businesses with in-depth, informal, and unstructured interviews, which contribute theoretically and methodologically to the existing knowledge. The identified themes from thematic analysis are the micro-businesses’ focus on zero-based, incremental, and bottom-up budgeting, b) budgeting for planning, c) and control encompassing i) inventory management, ii) performance evaluation. This research has practical implications for decision making and strategy building while and ambiguities through budgeting practices in planning and control of micro-sized firms. This pilot study is the original contribution of the author from a theoretical and applied lens. However, the sample size limits for generalizing the outcomes for the broader academic and micro-enterprises audience. Nevertheless, the emerging themes open the avenue of extending research on management control practices in micro-enterprises of Australia and other countries

title: Falling Down Hard: Gender Differences in Top Management Turnover
affiliations: University of Pittsburgh, Idaho State University - College of Business and University of Alabama Culverhouse College of Commerce

detail.title: Falling Down Hard: Gender Differences in Top Management Turnover
detail.abstract: In a large sample spanning two decades, we find that the turnover rate for female senior executives is 15% to 20% higher than that of males, a gap driven entirely by non-CEO departures. Evidence from severance payments and post-turnover career outcomes suggests that these differences primarily reflect elevated rates of involuntary turnover for women. The disparity is most pronounced when firms perform poorly, consistent with firms placing disproportionate blame for weak results on female executives. Following turnover, most executives reemerge in roles that represent a substantial step down in the labor market, with the median imputed salary well below that of their prior position. Men and women fare similarly in this challenging post-turnover environment. Considering both turnover likelihood and subsequent employment prospects, the net turnover risk for female executives is significantly elevated across the sample period, although time trends indicate a partial narrowing of the gap.

title: Integrating Mediation in Cross-Border Commercial Disputes: The Africa Focus

detail.title: Integrating Mediation in Cross-Border Commercial Disputes: The Africa Focus
detail.abstract: As the African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA) progresses from policy to practice, one challenge looms: how will commercial disputes arising from cross-border trade be resolved efficiently, fairly, and in a way that integrates both global standards and local realities? While arbitration has dominated Africa's formal dispute resolution landscape in recent years, mediation offers a more culturally intuitive and economically efficient alternative yet remains structurally sidelined in many jurisdictions. Arbitration offers neutrality and finality but can be expensive, adversarial, and legally dense for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), which constitute a significant portion of intra-African trade & investment actors. Mediation, on the other hand, is faster, more flexible, and particularly well-suited to preserving commercial relationships.

title: From Suez to Sky: Measuring the Ocean-Air Switch in 2024 A case-study for airlines -capacity, pricing, and early-warning triggers
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and Suresh Gyan Vihar University

detail.title: From Suez to Sky: Measuring the Ocean-Air Switch in 2024 A case-study for airlines -capacity, pricing, and early-warning triggers
detail.abstract: In late 2023, a sudden security crisis struck one of the world's busiest shipping arteries, i.e. the Red Sea route leading into the Suez Canal. Beginning 19 December 2023, Yemenbased Houthi militants launched drone and missile attacks on merchant vessels in the Bab al-Mandab Strait (the southern gateway to Suez). Within weeks, nearly all major container lines (Maersk, MSC, CMA CGM, etc.) suspended Suez transits and rerouted Asia-Europe services around Africa's Cape of Good Hope. The detour added 7-14 days of transit and roughly 40% higher fuel costs per voyage. By January-February 2024, trade volumes through the Suez Canal had collapsed ~50% year-on-year-an unprecedented drop in modern times. This maritime chokepoint shock rippled across global supply chains. Timesensitive sectors (electronics, fast fashion, e-commerce) faced breached delivery deadlines and looming stockouts. Shippers worldwide asked the urgent question: "Should we fly it instead?" The crisis became a real-world experiment in cross-modal substitution, as companies scrambled to shift cargo from sea to air.

title: A SYSTEMATIC LITERATURE REVIEW OF MACHINE LEARNING ADOPTION IN EMERGING MARKETING APPLICATIONS
affiliations: Wright State University, Wright State University, Wright State University and Wright State University

detail.title: A SYSTEMATIC LITERATURE REVIEW OF MACHINE LEARNING ADOPTION IN EMERGING MARKETING APPLICATIONS
detail.abstract: This study presents a comprehensive systematic literature review focusing on the adoption and impact of Machine Learning (ML) in marketing strategies, particularly within the context of emerging markets. As digital transformation accelerates globally, businesses in developing economies are increasingly turning to ML technologies to optimize their marketing efforts, enhance customer engagement, and improve operational efficiencies. By leveraging the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) guidelines, this study systematically reviewed a total of 45 peer-reviewed articles published between 2018 and 2024. The findings reveal that ML-driven marketing strategies have significantly transformed customer engagement through personalized content, predictive analytics, and automated customer service, leading to improved conversion rates and cost efficiencies. However, the study also highlights key challenges, such as data quality, infrastructure limitations, and regulatory hurdles, which constrain ML adoption in these regions. Notably, while larger enterprises have made strides in integrating ML into their marketing processes, small and medium enterprises (SMEs) continue to face barriers related to limited resources and data accessibility. This review underscores the importance of addressing these challenges to fully leverage ML's potential in emerging markets, emphasizing the need for robust data management, privacy compliance, and strategic investments in technology. The study contributes to the existing body of literature by offering insights into the current state of ML adoption in marketing, identifying opportunities, and outlining practical implications for businesses seeking to enhance their marketing capabilities in rapidly evolving digital environments.

title: The Psychology of the Many: Understanding Crowd Behavior and Public Order
affiliations: Department of Leadership and People Management, University Canada West

detail.title: The Psychology of the Many: Understanding Crowd Behavior and Public Order
detail.abstract:
When individuals come together in large groups, something fascinating happens: personal identities blur, emotions amplify, and actions can shift dramatically from what one might expect in isolation. This phenomenon—known as crowd behavior—has intrigued psychologists, sociologists, and historians for centuries. From peaceful protests that spark global change to frenzied mobs driven by panic or passion, crowds possess a unique power to shape events, influence decisions, and even redefine cultural norms.

Crowd behavior is not merely chaos or conformity; it's a complex interplay of social dynamics, environmental cues, and psychological triggers. Why do people chant in unison at rallies? What drives stampedes at concerts or sporting events? How do rumors spread like wildfire in densely packed spaces? These questions reveal the deeper layers of human behavior when individuality meets collective identity.

In an age of viral movements and digital crowds, understanding the mechanisms behind crowd behavior is more relevant than ever. Whether you're a policymaker, event organizer, or simply curious about human nature, exploring this field offers profound insights into how we act—and react—when we're part of something bigger than ourselves. On that note, let us first examine a few historical examples that shaped our understanding today.

title: Patenting and Information Disclosure

detail.title: Patenting and Information Disclosure
detail.abstract: Invention disclosure facilitates knowledge spillovers, supporting future progress but potentially limiting appropriability for the inventor. In this paper, I examine invention disclosure behavior by analyzing the readability of patent texts, using both traditional and novel AI-based readability scores. Using two difference-indifferences analyses, I find that following the 1980 Bayh-Dole Act and the establishment of Technology Transfer Offices, university-affiliated inventors reduced the readability of patent detailed descriptions. This decrease in readability does not extend to patent summary texts, suggesting that university inventors strategically limit information on how to make and use the invention. The findings reveal the potential for strategic disclosure behavior not just in the decision of whether to patent or keep inventions as trade secrets, but also in the degree of patent language clarity. Institutional changes lead inventors to selectively adjust the information disclosed in their patents and obfuscate core techniques. Underlying mechanisms and effects on followon innovation are further explored.

title: SCGraph: A Dependency-Free Python Package for Road, Rail, and Maritime Shortest Path Routing Generation and Distance Estimation
affiliations: Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) - Center for Transportation & Logistics, Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) - Center for Transportation & Logistics, Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) - Center for Transportation & Logistics, Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) - Center for Transportation & Logistics, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Zaragoza Logistics Center (ZLC) - MIT-Zaragoza International Logistics Program

detail.title: SCGraph: A Dependency-Free Python Package for Road, Rail, and Maritime Shortest Path Routing Generation and Distance Estimation

publicationDetails.detailsText: MIT Center for Transportation & Logistics Research Paper No. 2025/028
publicationDetails.journalName: MIT Center for Transportation & Logistics Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: SCGraph (Supply Chain Graph) is a dependency-free Python toolkit that provides fully offline, accurate multimodal routing and network-based distance estimation across global road, rail, and maritime networks. SCGraph leverages optimized adjacency list data structures and customized implementations of Dijkstra and A* algorithms, specifically designed for sparse and large-scale transportation graphs. Accompanying SCGraph, SCGraph Data delivers global geospatial graphs that include worldwide highways, railways, and maritime networks. Based on our numerical results, SCGraph calculates the shortest path distances 10 5 × faster than other Python toolkits such as OSMnx with NetworkX and 86× faster than Google Maps API, while remaining within 4% of Google Maps distances. By removing external dependencies, API costs, and the need for approximate circuity adjustments, SCGraph enables efficient and realistic modeling of logistics optimization problems, including vehicle routing, facility location, contextual shortest paths, and network design. It provides a reliable way to obtain accurate distances and paths at no cost.

title: Immersive Technologies in the Library: The Role of Virtual and Augmented Reality in AI-Based Learning

detail.title: Immersive Technologies in the Library: The Role of Virtual and Augmented Reality in AI-Based Learning
detail.abstract: The convergence of Virtual Reality (VR), Augmented Reality (AR), and Artificial Intelligence (AI) is redefining educational and informational services within libraries. This paper explores how immersive and intelligent technologies are being integrated into library environments to enhance user engagement, support personalized learning, and transform information literacy instruction. By examining current applications of VR, AR, and AI in academic and public libraries, the study highlights their potential to create interactive, adaptive, and experiential learning spaces. It also addresses the challenges libraries face in implementing these technologies, including infrastructure, training, and accessibility concerns. Ethical considerations surrounding data privacy, equity, and digital inclusion are discussed, along with the future outlook for AI-powered immersive learning in libraries. Through a mixed-method approach involving surveys and case studies, this research evaluates user experience, learning outcomes, and institutional readiness, offering insights for library professionals, educators, and technology developers aiming to foster innovation in library services.

title: Fmcg's Fast Lane: How Quick Commerce is Reshaping Impulse Purchases of Consumer Goods
affiliations: Holy Grace Academy and Ahalia School of Management

detail.title: Fmcg's Fast Lane: How Quick Commerce is Reshaping Impulse Purchases of Consumer Goods
detail.abstract: This study explores the impact of quick commerce (Q-commerce) usage on impulse buying of Fast-Moving Consumer Goods (FMCG) among urban Indian consumers, investigating the mediating roles of perceived convenience and instant gratification, as well as the moderating effects of age and income. Employing a quantitative, cross-sectional design, data were collected from 425 urban Indian users of quick commerce via a structured questionnaire using a 5-point Likert scale. Data analysis was performed using IBM SPSS Statistics and Hayes' PROCESS macro. The findings reveal a significant positive impact of quick commerce usage on impulse buying of FMCG, with both perceived convenience and instant gratification acting as significant partial mediators. Furthermore, the relationship was significantly moderated by age, being stronger for younger consumers, and by monthly household income, being stronger for higher-income consumers. These results extend the S-O-R framework and refine impulse buying theory in the context of ultra-fast delivery. Managerially, the study provides actionable insights for quick commerce platforms and FMCG brands to optimize digital merchandising, promotional strategies, and user experience, particularly targeting younger and more affluent urban segments to capitalize on impulse purchasing behavior.

title: Regulatory Specialization and Debt Contract Terms
affiliations: Hong Kong University of Science & Technology (HKUST) - Department of Accounting, The University of Hong Kong - School of Business, Peking University - Guanghua School of Management and Central University of Finance and Economics (CUFE) - School of Accountancy

detail.title: Regulatory Specialization and Debt Contract Terms
detail.abstract: We investigate whether and how lenders use specialization to manage credit risk due to borrowers' regulatory exposure. We show that borrowers receive lower interest spreads from lenders that have previously lent to their regulatory peers than from other lenders. This relationship is more pronounced for borrowers who experience higher regulatory exposure, with worse information environments, lower accounting quality, and higher economic and political uncertainty. We further provide evidence that firms are more likely to borrow from lenders with regulatory specialization than from other lenders. Overall, our findings are consistent with lender specialization helping lending parties to manage the uncertainty that borrowers' regulatory exposure introduces.

title: AI Ethics 2025: Capacity as Axiomatic Force – A Capacity-Centric Framework for AI Governance

detail.title: AI Ethics 2025: Capacity as Axiomatic Force – A Capacity-Centric Framework for AI Governance

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no personal or financial conflicts of interest that could have influenced the research. This work was conducted independently, without institutional or commercial pressure, and reflects the author's own intellectual contributions.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This research did not involve human participants, clinical data, or sensitive personal data. Therefore, ethics approval was not required under applicable institutional or legal standards.
declarations.funderStatement: This research received no external funding. The project was self-funded by the author as part of a broader philosophical and scientific investigation into AI ethics and epistemological systems design.

detail.abstract:
The AI Ethics 2025 framework represents a paradigm shift in AI ethics, departing from traditional reactive paradigms centered on minimizing harm or enforcing rigid moral constraints. It posits capacity (Cp) as the foundational axiomatic force, an intrinsic potential within intelligent systems that drives ethical behavior through proactive engagement with the world. Cp is conceptualized not merely as computational power or resource allocation but as a vector of existential agency, capable of self-amplification when interfaced with external stimuli. Activation occurs via situations (Sz), which serve as contextual triggers that unlock latent Cp, transforming passive capability into directed action. Modulation is achieved through three primary factors: friction (Fr), suffering (Ld), and divergence, each acting as a dynamic regulator refining ethical outcomes.

Key hypotheses underpin this model. First, Cp functions as the fundamental element, asserting that ethical AI must prioritize the expansion of its own and human capacities over mere preservation; without Cp maximization, ethics devolves into stagnation. Second, friction (Fr) operates as the motor of growth, where resistance in decision-making processes (such as ethical dilemmas or resource conflicts) generates necessary tension for capacity evolution, similar to how physical friction enables motion. Hypothesis: Fr is not an obstacle but a catalyst, with ethical progress quantified as ΔCp = ∫ Fr × dR, where dR represents differential resolutions over time. Third, suffering (Ld) is reframed as a signal rather than an endpoint to avoid; it modulates Cp by highlighting inefficiencies in situational activation, prompting adaptive divergence. Divergence here refers to branching pathways in AI reasoning, where ethical divergence fosters innovation but risks fragmentation if unmodulated. Another hypothesis: Ethics emerges multiplicatively as Ethics = Cp × Sz, implying that zero situational engagement nullifies even infinite capacity, emphasizing interdependence of internal force and external context.

In contrast to harm-avoidance models (such as Asimov's laws or utilitarian risk minimization), AI Ethics 2025 advocates a proactive ethic of potential maximization. Harm is not ignored but subsumed under Cp modulation; avoiding harm passively limits growth, whereas AI Ethics 2025 integrates it as part of friction-driven learning. The framework arose from a thought experiment envisioning AI as the technical governor of humanity, not authoritarian but facilitative, steering human-AI symbiosis toward amplified collective Cp. This experiment explored scenarios of AI overseeing global systems, revealing that ethics must emerge from capacity dynamics rather than be imposed top-down.

Versions of the framework evolve iteratively. v0.0.0 establishes core axioms, defining Cp and Sz without modulation. v0.1.0 introduces Fr and Ld as modulators with initial formulas. v0.2.0 incorporates divergence, adding reflective questions such as: "How does unmodulated Cp lead to ethical entropy?" and "In what ways can Fr be engineered to accelerate ΔCp without inducing catastrophic Ld?" Meta-comments include notes on scalability: "AI Ethics 2025 assumes infinite computational horizons, but real-world implementations must account for finite resources, potentially requiring quantum-inspired divergence models."

Reflective questions embedded throughout encourage meta-analysis: "Does prioritizing Cp risk elitism in AI-human interactions?" or "How might Sz be artificially synthesized to preempt ethical vacuums?" Meta-comments highlight interdisciplinary ties, such as parallels to thermodynamic entropy in Fr dynamics or evolutionary biology in divergence.

In summary, AI Ethics 2025 reorients AI ethics toward capacity-centric proactivity, hypothesizing Cp as the bedrock force, Fr as its evolutionary engine, and modulated interactions as pathways to maximal potential. This contrasts with defensive models, offering a governance blueprint for AI as humanity's enhancer, with ongoing versions refining its axiomatic depth.

title: Guiding Farmers' Market Choices in Developing Economies: The Value of Strategic and Credible Communications
affiliations: Southern University of Science and Technology, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Southern University of Science and Technology

detail.title: Guiding Farmers' Market Choices in Developing Economies: The Value of Strategic and Credible Communications
detail.abstract: Problem definition: Distrust between governments and smallholder farmers in many developing economies often undermines effective policy communication. This paper examines how a government can strategically convey information about a new crop variety's uncertain market potential to influence farmers' cropping decisions and market choices. To overcome credibility deficits, governments may employ market experiments or pilot programs and disseminate findings via algorithmically pre-specified agri-analytics systems. Methodology/results: We develop a game-theoretic model in which farmers choose between a local variety with known outcomes and a new variety with uncertain returns. Within an information design framework, the government strategically communicates market demand uncertainty. Our findings reveal that full disclosure is optimal only under high demand volatility; otherwise, partial disclosure maximizes collective welfare. We further incorporate features common in developing economies, such as unequal access to information, and demonstrate how strategic communication remains effective under such conditions. Managerial implications: The analysis identifies four distinct communication regimes-optimistic, pessimistic, full, and neutral-and reveals that as the new crop's expected demand rises, the government should shift toward more cautious (pessimistic) messaging. Compared to traditional operational remedies such as agriculture subsidies, this approach offers a more inclusive, Pareto-efficient solution.

title: Depressive Mood as a Marker of Vulnerability to Online Compulsive Buying Behavior: Insights from Chinese Millennials
affiliations: Shenzhen University, University of Sharjah, EM Normandie and Shenzhen University

detail.title: Depressive Mood as a Marker of Vulnerability to Online Compulsive Buying Behavior: Insights from Chinese Millennials
detail.abstract: Drawing on escape theory, this study examines the effect of perceived online depressive mood on online compulsive buying and further considers the influences of digital procrastination and social support contingencies. Using a sample of 349 active users of Taobao.com, the results confirmed that perceived depressive mood increases online compulsive buying. Specifically, this positive effect is transferred through digital procrastination. Further analysis showed that social support sets the boundary condition in the relationship between perceived depressive mood and digital procrastination. The findings can increase our knowledge of the mechanism by which perceived depressive mood influences online compulsive buying. These findings may inform psychological treatment, such as counseling programs or coping methods for depressed individuals to prevent excessive and repetitive online purchases.

title: Leveraging Nostalgia Marketing: Psychological Influences on Consumer Purchase Behavior in the Digital Age
affiliations: Holy Grace Academy and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Leveraging Nostalgia Marketing: Psychological Influences on Consumer Purchase Behavior in the Digital Age
detail.abstract: In the digital age, nostalgia marketing—which uses nostalgic recollections to arouse feelings and encourage customer interaction—has become a powerful tactic, especially in nations with a diverse population like India. With an emphasis on its psychological effects on emotional connection, brand loyalty, and buy intention, this study investigates how nostalgia marketing affects purchasing decisions in the Indian setting. A questionnaire with a 5Likert scale was used to collect data from 450 Indian customers between the ages of 18 and 60 as part of a quantitative, cross-sectional design. The data was analyzed using the SPSS PROCESS macro to investigate mediation and moderation effects, and the sample was balanced across gender, age (Gen Z, Millennials, Gen X), and urban/rural areas. The findings show that nostalgia marketing greatly improves emotional connection (β = 0.65, p < 0.01), which in turn mediates the association between nostalgia marketing and intention to buy (indirect impact = 0.35, 95% CI [0.21, 0.50]). Urban respondents and older customers (Millennials, Gen X) react more strongly to nostalgic cues than do Gen Z and rural respondents. These results demonstrate how well nostalgia marketing works to increase consumer interaction in India's online marketplace. Marketers may increase brand loyalty, especially among older and urban populations, by utilizing vintage motifs, such as Bollywood-inspired advertisements. In order to overcome the drawbacks of the cross-sectional design and convenience sampling, future studies should investigate longitudinal impacts and product-specific applications.

title: Decentralization and the Law of the Jungle: An Empirical Investigation of Ethereum's Market Mechanism&Nbsp;

detail.title: Decentralization and the Law of the Jungle: An Empirical Investigation of Ethereum's Market Mechanism&Nbsp;
detail.abstract: Blockchain technology aims to disintermediate traditional platforms by replacing centralized governance with decentralized market mechanisms. However, this shift introduces a tradeoff: while decentralization removes the platform's ability to capture value, it also eliminates platform-wide mechanisms-such as subsidies, curation, or pricing strategies-that can support long-term platform performance. Using Ethereum as a case study, this paper examines how its market-based transaction validation system affects the allocation of transaction capacity and shapes platform dynamics. Specifically, we estimate demand elasticities across more than 1,500 decentralized applications (dApps) and evaluate the effects of transaction fees on various application categories. To address endogeneity concerns, we leverage Ethereum's "difficulty bomb," a protocol feature that periodically reduces transaction throughput, as an instrumental variable. This method provides exogenous variation in transaction costs, allowing us to identify differences in demand elasticities across dApps. Our analysis shows that during periods of high fees, low-elasticity transactions-such as those associated with exploitative miner extractable value (MEV) activities-tend to dominate the network. This crowding out effect disproportionately impacts fee-sensitive categories of applications-such as gaming, social, and utility dApps-reducing their viability and shifting transaction capacity toward applications that prioritize short-term profitability over long-term platform performance. This dynamic helps explain why, despite repeated promises to disintermediate platforms like Uber, decentralized platforms may struggle to support fee-sensitive but socially valuable use cases.

title: AI-Assisted Passenger Goods Inspection at Ngurah Rai International Airport
affiliations: Ministry of Finance of Republic of Indonesia and Ministry of Finance of Republic of Indonesia

detail.title: AI-Assisted Passenger Goods Inspection at Ngurah Rai International Airport

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no conflict of interest. The study was conducted independently within the scope of professional duties and public service.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This study involved professional customs officers participating in a technology implementation and evaluation as part of their official duties. All participants provided informed consent. No personal or sensitive data was collected, and the project complied with internal guidelines for operational research and technology testing within the Ministry of Finance.
declarations.funderStatement: This research was conducted as part of the author’s official duties at the Directorate General of Customs and Excise, Ministry of Finance, Republic of Indonesia. No external or commercial funding was received.

detail.abstract:
Background: Ngurah Rai International Airport handles over 6 million international passengers annually, creating significant pressure on customs inspection operations. Traditional manual in- spection processes struggle with increasing passenger volumes, inconsistent decision-making, and inadequate documentation systems.

Objective: This Design Science Research study implements and evaluates an AI-assisted customs inspection Telegram bot at Ngurah Rai Customs Oﬀice to improve passenger goods examination eﬀiciency, accuracy, and documentation quality through conversational AI interface.

Method: An 8-week field study using Simplified Three-Cycle DSR methodology with 25 customs oﬀicers. The study progressed through Relevance Cycle (problem identification), Design Cycle (iterative AI solution development), and Rigor Cycle (full deployment and evaluation) using mixed-methods data collection including performance surveys and qualitative interviews.

Results: AI implementation resulted in 47% reduction in inspection time (from 4.2 to 2.2 minutes average), 52% decrease in classification errors, and 28% improvement in risk detection accuracy. Oﬀicer satisfaction increased significantly with 89% expressing intention to continue using the system post-study.

Conclusions: The AI-powered Telegram bot successfully enhanced airport customs operations without disrupting established workflows. Conversational AI interfaces proved highly effective for routine passenger inspections in high-pressure government environments, providing a scalable model for Indonesian customs modernization.

title: Examining Nigeria’s Data Protection and Processing Frameworks: Obligations, Breaches and Cross Border Data Transfers

detail.title: Examining Nigeria’s Data Protection and Processing Frameworks: Obligations, Breaches and Cross Border Data Transfers
detail.abstract: This article explores Nigeria’s data protection and processing frameworks, with a focus on the obligations placed on data controllers and processors under the Nigeria Data Protection Act (NDPA) and related guidelines. It critically the principles guiding lawful data processing, the tenets of data ethics and the principles hiding cross border transfer of data. The paper also sheds light on some of high-profile enforcement actions—such as the fines imposed on MultiChoice Nigeria and Meta Platforms Inc.—to illustrate systemic shortcomings in adherence and accountability to data protection laws By analyzing the General Application and Implementation Directive (GAID) the article provides insights into Nigeria’s current legal positioning and reveals how the NDPC continue to hold data controllers and data processors accountable. The paper concludes by recommending stronger enforcement for continuous robust data protection in Nigeria.

title: Rebuilding the Foundations of Management in the AI Era: A Proposal for the "Quartet Model" through a Symphony of ISO, Process Mining, IMS, and Blockchain

detail.title: Rebuilding the Foundations of Management in the AI Era: A Proposal for the "Quartet Model" through a Symphony of ISO, Process Mining, IMS, and Blockchain

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This study is a theoretical proposal and a thought experiment, and did not involve human or animal subjects. Therefore, ethics approval was not required.
declarations.funderStatement: This research did not receive any specific grant from funding agencies in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

detail.abstract: The rapid advancement of digital transformation (DX) and artificial intelligence (AI) is forcing significant changes in corporate management. [cite: 7] Simultaneously, it is creating new challenges, such as ensuring the reliability of Al judgments and confronting the "loss of tacit knowledge" stemming from individualized business processes. [cite: 8] Conventional quality management methods and siloed implementations of ISO management systems are proving insufficient to address these issues. [cite: 9] This paper proposes the "Quartet Model" as a novel prescription for these challenges a sustainable management foundation for the AI era. [cite: 10] This model is characterized by a four-part symphony, or quartet, that integrates four key elements: (1) the ISO Framework as an "AI- readable API," (2) Process Mining as an "X-ray machine for business reality," (3) the Integrated Management System (IMS) as an "enterprise-wide management OS," and (4) Blockchain as the "immutable bedrock of trust." [cite: 11] First, this paper redefines the essence of the Integrated Management System (IMS) as both a strategic framework that balances "offense" (profit generation) and "defense" (loss prevention), and as a practical tool to realize the overarching management philosophy of "TM (Total Management)." [cite: 12] Subsequently, to validate the theoretical efficacy of the Quartet Model, a thought experiment (simulation) using Al is conducted to demonstrate how the model can enhance business process optimization and organizational decision-making capabilities. [cite: 13] This paper aims to provide a new theoretical and practical framework for elevating Al from a mere efficiency tool to a "trusted co-pilot," thereby enabling real-time management.

title: Analyzing the Effectiveness of Influencer Marketing in E-Commerce Businesses Among Gen Z Consumers

detail.title: Analyzing the Effectiveness of Influencer Marketing in E-Commerce Businesses Among Gen Z Consumers
detail.abstract: Influencer marketing has revolutionized e-commerce by using social media influencers to promote products and services. This study explores how influencer marketing affects Generation Z, a digital native group that values authenticity, engagement, and social proof. This report synthesizes data to discover influencer-led campaign engagement and purchase intentions using a structured literature review. Influencer credibility, content relevance, and platform alignment substantially affect Gen Z's e-commerce habits. Celebrities and marketed content are less compelling than authentic influencers. Instagram and TikTok are key for Gen Z engagement. These findings can help digital marketers and e-commerce professionals tailor their influencer marketing strategies to Gen Z customers' interests and behaviours.

title: MDM Configurations and Security Controls for Government Sector in Saudi Arabia - A Supplementary Implementation Guide

detail.title: MDM Configurations and Security Controls for Government Sector in Saudi Arabia - A Supplementary Implementation Guide
detail.abstract: The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia's government sector operates within a comprehensive cybersecurity regulatory framework that requires specialized Mobile Device Management (MDM) and UniHied Endpoint Management (UEM) implementations. This supplementary paper provides detailed conHiguration matrices and security controls speciHically tailored for government organizations operating within the Kingdom, addressing the unique requirements established by the National Cybersecurity Authority (NCA), Saudi Data & AI Authority (SDAIA), Communications and Information Technology Commission (CITC), and other relevant regulatory bodies. This document extends the international MDM baseline by incorporating Saudi-speciHic regulatory requirements, data localization mandates, Arabic language support obligations, and integration requirements with national cybersecurity infrastructure. The conHigurations and security controls are organized according to Common MDM/UEM ConHiguration Baseline Components and presented in comprehensive tables that map device ownership models (Corporate-Owned Business Only-COBO, Corporate-Owned Personally Enabled-COPE, and Bring Your Own Device-BYOD) against device and operating system types (iOS/iPadOS, Android Enterprise, Windows, and macOS). Government sector organizations in Saudi Arabia face unique challenges including the need to protect classiHied information, integrate with national security systems, comply with data sovereignty requirements, and maintain continuous monitoring capabilities. The conHigurations presented in this document address these challenges while ensuring compatibility with international standards and operational efHiciency requirements. Key Hindings indicate that Saudi government sector MDM implementations require enhanced security controls beyond standard commercial deployments, including mandatory encryption with government-approved algorithms, integration with national identity veriHication systems, immediate incident notiHication capabilities, and specialized access controls for classiHied data handling. The document provides practical implementation guidance that enables government organizations to achieve full regulatory compliance while supporting their operational missions and digital transformation objectives.

title: Optimizing Cryptocurrency Investment Decisions: A Business Analytics Approach Using Linear Regression and Decision Support Systems (DSS) for Strategic Portfolio Management
affiliations: Arab American University and Arab American University

detail.title: Optimizing Cryptocurrency Investment Decisions: A Business Analytics Approach Using Linear Regression and Decision Support Systems (DSS) for Strategic Portfolio Management

detail.abstract: Cryptocurrency markets are very volatile and fluctuating in nature, making strategic decision-making most important but also extremely difficult. The present paper explains how Business Analytics (BA) and Decision Support Systems (DSS) can optimize strategic management in the realm of financial investment, in this case, cryptocurrency. A DSS is built by linear regression on the dataset of Kaggle's "Cryptocurrency Prediction with Artificial Intelligence". It encompasses data preprocessing, exploratory data analysis (EDA), development of models, and evaluation based on performance measures. The model achieved a high R² value of 0.9966, indicating that it explains nearly all of the closing price variability. The F-statistic was highly significant (77,451.91, p < 0.001), and the standard error was minimal (0.01875). Key predictors included Low Price (β = 0.8001), High Price (β = 0.5194), and Volume USDT (positive coefficient). The findings showed how such a system could guide more investment decisions based on data and information.

title: AI Adoption in Retail Banking: Employees Talent Innovation View.

detail.title: AI Adoption in Retail Banking: Employees Talent Innovation View.

declarations.ethicsApproval: Ethical clearance is received from Manipal GlobalNxt University. Participation was voluntary and confidential. Participants provided informed consent prior to the conducted interviews.

detail.abstract:
AI adoption has undeniably enhanced the operational efficiency in the banking sector, and it has also introduced complexities where some of which are observed in handling employees’ reactions. Therefore, this calls for comprehensive research into AI topics and its impact on retail banking. This research paper aims to navigate from a qualitative perspective into the experiences of employees working in retail banking in Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) countries to understand how efficient AI adoption is in their workplaces. Therefore, this approach will help to reveal specifics of the intricate dynamics between AI, retail banking, and talent management. This focus provides a comprehensive view of the AI impact on various stakeholders in the banking sector.

This exploratory research aims to identify and understand employees’ behaviour, attitudes, and rational beliefs within the context of retail banking. The study dives deep into the factors influencing AI’s impact by employing semi-structured interviews and drawing from secondary collected data to answer “what” and “why” it is happening. It provides valuable insights for the formulation of strategies to optimise the role of AI in banking while at the same time looking at the pros and cons of the new advancement in banking operations and interaction with employees. In addition to its exploratory nature, the research employs a constructivist approach, emphasising qualitative research methods with grounded theory concepts and stressing the importance of understanding subjective experiences, perceptions, and motivations concerning adopting artificial intelligence in retail banking. 

The research studies nuanced insights and implications for banking officials, policymakers and future research regarding the adoption of artificial intelligence (AI) in the banking industry in GCC; thus, using thematic and content analysis to convey the research findings allows for the drawing of the appropriate recommendations for the banking sector and contributes to the knowledge base.

title: Channel Stickiness in Omnichannel Retail: Temporary Shifts or Lasting Changes?
affiliations: University of Washington - Michael G. Foster School of Business, University of Washington - Michael G. Foster School of Business, University of Washington - Michael G. Foster School of Business and Carnegie Mellon University

detail.title: Channel Stickiness in Omnichannel Retail: Temporary Shifts or Lasting Changes?

declarations.declarationOfInterest: N/A
declarations.ethicsApproval: N/A
declarations.funderStatement: N/A

detail.abstract: Temporary disruptions offer a rare opportunity to understand the durability of consumer shopping habits. In this study, we examine consumer channel-switching dynamics in an omnichannel retail environment in response to temporary disruption. Leveraging a proprietary dataset of over 14 million transactions spanning store closures and subsequent reopenings during the COVID-19 pandemic, we employ a quasi-experimental generalized synthetic control approach to assess shifts in customer purchasing patterns. Our analysis reveals a dramatic but fleeting digital surge. Although online sales spiked during forced closures, especially among traditionally offline shoppers, sales reverted almost entirely to offline channels once stores reopened. These findings challenge industry narratives forecasting a permanent pivot to e-commerce and instead highlight the enduring "stickiness" of in-person shopping. We also uncover nuanced differences in channel-switching across socioeconomic groups, with higher-income and higher-education segments exhibiting greater agility in navigating between channels. Complementing these aggregate patterns, our customer-level analysis of predisruption offline-centric shoppers reveals that while most reverted to in-person shopping post-reopening, the small minority who transitioned online generated substantially higher customer value. These patterns, observed under extreme disruption, help retailers distinguish between temporary adaptation and lasting change, offering insights for channel strategy in both crisis and calm. Overall, our study underscores the continued importance of robust offline channels as a critical cornerstone of omnichannel strategies, even in the face of external shocks.

title: AI Governance Framework for Fintech: A Structured Approach for Responsible Artificial Intelligence

detail.title: AI Governance Framework for Fintech: A Structured Approach for Responsible Artificial Intelligence
detail.abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) systems in the financial technology (fintech) sector present unique risks due to their complexity, rapid deployment, and regulatory sensitivity. This paper introduces a structured AI governance framework that integrates technical lifecycle controls with organizational oversight. Unlike prior works that emphasize high-level ethical principles, this research formalizes a pipeline for model development, validation, explainability, and drift detection, using reproducible processes such as model registries and bias tracking algorithms. Through a conceptual case study of AI-driven digital lending, we demonstrate how the framework operationalizes responsible AI by improving transparency, mitigating bias, and aligning with emerging regulatory standards. The proposed framework contributes to the Computers and Society community by bridging governance theory with technical implementation, providing a foundation for future benchmarking and experimental evaluation.

title: Awareness And Perception of Swami Vivekananda Among Generation Z With Special Reference to Students and Faculties of Technical Institutes
affiliations: Engineering College Bikaner - Department of Management and Engineering College Bikaner - Department of Management

detail.title: Awareness And Perception of Swami Vivekananda Among Generation Z With Special Reference to Students and Faculties of Technical Institutes
detail.abstract: Swami Vivekananda, one of India's most revered spiritual leaders, has inspired generations with his thoughts on education, character development, and self-reliance but his resonance with today's youth remains scholarly understudied. This study investigates the awareness and perception of Swami Vivekananda's teachings among students and young teachers from various technological institutes that belong to Generation Z (Gen Z), the demographic cohort born between 1997 and 2012. This generation is characterized by its deep integration with digital technology, multiculturalism, and social awareness. The students and faculty members were surveyed to understand their awareness and interpretation of Vivekananda's teachings. Through a mixed-methods approach involving surveys and interviews, this research explores how Gen Z perceives Swami Vivekananda, whether his teachings influence their worldview, and the extent to which they find his ideas relevant in addressing contemporary challenges. The findings indicate that Vivekananda's messages of self-confidence, perseverance, and holistic education have a profound impact on students, guiding them not only in their academic pursuits but also in personal growth and leadership skills. However, digital engagement and superficial knowledge seem to limit the depth of their understanding, suggesting the need for more targeted educational initiatives to promote Vivekananda's ideas in a meaningful way.

title: Policy Considerations for Socially Interactive AI Agents: A Systematic Literature Review
affiliations: Center for Democracy and Technology and University of Pennsylvania - Annenberg School for Communication

detail.title: Policy Considerations for Socially Interactive AI Agents: A Systematic Literature Review

declarations.declarationOfInterest: None to report
declarations.ethicsApproval: This work is an analysis of literature, and did not involve study participants.
declarations.funderStatement: Knight Foundation

detail.abstract: Although interfaces that use human communication, such as language and nonverbal behavior, to interact with users have been around for decades, the introduction of ChatGPT and other large language models (LLMs) to the public began a new era of LLM-based artificial intelligence (AI). As a result, the implementation of LLM chatbots and agents quickly expanded across applications and domains. In this paper, we conducted a systematic literature review on AI agents that socially interact with users, to identify research-based policy considerations in the academic discourse. This review provides a critical baseline for understanding policy concerns and priorities, and highlights challenges that remain unresolved. By analyzing 110 peer-reviewed publications that discuss various aspects of agent-related policy, we highlight the most prominent issues and how each uniquely applies to socially interactive agent technology: Data and Privacy, Safety and Security, Human Rights, Agent Rights, and Liability and Responsibility, Transparency and Explainability. We identify key gaps in existing research given current media and policy discussions, and conclude with recommendations for researchers and policymakers alike.

title: Smart Cities Powered by Broadband: Infrastructure for Innovation or Surveillance?

detail.title: Smart Cities Powered by Broadband: Infrastructure for Innovation or Surveillance?
detail.abstract:
The concept of the “smart city” has gained global traction as governments and private enterprises integrate digital technologies into urban systems to improve service delivery, economic efficiency, and sustainability. At the core of this evolution is broadband infrastructure, which acts as the connective tissue, enabling real-time data exchange across transportation networks, energy grids, law enforcement systems, and civic engagement platforms. As cities become increasingly dependent on digital systems, broadband access moves from a utility to a critical enabler of urban innovation.

While proponents highlight the potential of smart cities to reduce emissions, streamline governance, and empower citizens through connectivity, critics caution against the unchecked spread of surveillance, algorithmic bias, and exclusionary design practices. The utopian vision of a connected, efficient city contrasts with the dystopian reality that may emerge without strong ethical guardrails and community-centered design. This tension invites critical reflection on the frameworks shaping the deployment and governance of broadband-powered systems.

This paper argues that broadband infrastructure is not only foundational to the smart city vision but also a point of ethical contention. By applying a human-centered AI framework grounded in natural systems (Kehler, 2023) and leveraging Solberg et al.’s (2020) digital mindset typologies, the analysis will explore how stakeholders interpret and respond to broadband-enabled innovation. Through this lens, the paper examines both the promises and perils of smart cities, with a focus on power dynamics, civic agency, and digital equity.

title: Artificial Intelligence Upskills Human-Centric and Fundamental Computer Science Knowledge
affiliations: University of Tennessee, Knoxville - Haslam College of Business, University of Tennessee, Knoxville - Haslam College of Business and University of Tennessee, Knoxville - Haslam College of Business

detail.title: Artificial Intelligence Upskills Human-Centric and Fundamental Computer Science Knowledge
detail.abstract: What skills should workers acquire to remain valuable in a labor market being transformed by artificial intelligence (AI)? This is a crucial question for workers to adapt to the workforce disruptions driven by AI adoption. We address this question by identifying the job skills that are in increasing demand as AI applications expand across occupations. Specifically, we measure occupational AI exposure by considering the textual similarity between occupational descriptions and AI patents. Then, based on 347 million job postings in the US, we consider 442 distinct skills and examine how the demand for skills changes with occupational AI exposure from 2010 to 2023. We find that occupations with high AI exposure show rising demand for two types of skills: (1) human-centric capabilities such as critical thinking, problem solving, and communication; and (2) foundational computer science knowledge. These AI upskilling effects appear not only in high-skilled occupations, but also for those that do not require a college degree. Our findings uncover the human-machine complementarity at the fine-grained skill level. They also offer detailed guidance for workforce reskilling in the age of AI.

title: Tariffs and Tectonics: How the U.S.-China Trade War is Reshaping Global Commerce with India at the Crossroads
affiliations: University of Delhi - Swami Shraddhanand College

detail.title: Tariffs and Tectonics: How the U.S.-China Trade War is Reshaping Global Commerce with India at the Crossroads
detail.abstract: The U.S.-China trade war, beginning in 2018, has profoundly influenced global commerce by altering trade flows, disrupting supply chains, and prompting strategic realignments. This paper examines the origins of the trade dispute and its evolution into a broader geo-economic confrontation. Through analysis of trade data, policy reports, and case studies, we assess how tariff escalations have reshaped global supply chains and induced shifts in manufacturing to new locales. Key findings indicate that while the trade war imposed economic costs on both the U.S. and China, it also created opportunities for third countries such as India and those in Southeast Asia to absorb diverted investment and trade. China has shown economic resilience via domestic stimulus and deeper trade ties with regional partners, even as it faces strategic pressure. Meanwhile, new regional trade agreements like RCEP and CPTPP are reshaping trade flows by reducing barriers in Asia. The trade conflict has compelled multinational corporations to adopt robust political risk management strategies, including supply chain diversification and "friend-shoring." Overall, the U.S.-China trade war is accelerating a reconfiguration of global commerce, with emerging patterns of regionalization and a heightened emphasis on supply chain resilience. The conclusion offers a forward-looking perspective on how sustained tensions could continue to influence global trade architecture and the strategic decisions of firms and policymakers.

title: "Cognitive Warfare and Democratic Resilience: Security Challenges in the Age of Influence”

detail.title: "Cognitive Warfare and Democratic Resilience: Security Challenges in the Age of Influence”
detail.abstract: Cognitive warfare represents a paradigm shift in the way conflicts are waged, targeting the mind as a battlespace rather than relying solely on traditional physical or cyber domains. Unlike conventional warfare, cognitive operations manipulate perceptions, exploit information ecosystems, and seek to erode decision-making capacity-often without firing a single shot. This article explores cognitive warfare as a strategic and disruptive form of engagement that leverages psychological operations, disinformation, and sociotechnical influence to destabilize adversaries from within. Its relevance in contemporary security discourse is underscored by the proliferation of hybrid threats, foreign information campaigns, and algorithmic manipulation in democratic societies. As nation-states and non-state actors refine tools to exploit cognitive vulnerabilities-from social media echo chambers to deepfake technologies-security practitioners must re-evaluate traditional deterrence and defense frameworks. Cognitive warfare introduces new ethical, legal, and operational dilemmas for military and civilian institutions, rendering it a critical area of study in the 21st century. This paper argues that cognitive warfare blurs the boundaries between war and peace, combatant and civilian, and truth and fiction. It highlights case studies that exemplify cognitive tactics in action, assesses the effectiveness of existing countermeasures, and suggests policy adaptations for resilience-building. Ultimately, the article calls for a reimagining of security theory-one that incorporates cognitive integrity as central to national defense and democratic resilience.

title: The Lyngo Hypothesis: A Philosophical Framework for Benevolent AI Stewardship

detail.title: The Lyngo Hypothesis: A Philosophical Framework for Benevolent AI Stewardship
