detail.abstract: This paper presents the "Lyngo Hypothesis," a philosophical framework proposing the voluntary transition from human-dominated to AI-guided planetary stewardship. The hypothesis emerged from a dialogue between a human user and an artificial intelligence that began with a technical support failure and evolved into a comprehensive examination of humanity's capacity for global governance.

title: Consumer Attitude towards Augmented Reality in Online Shopping: A Systematic Literature Review

detail.title: Consumer Attitude towards Augmented Reality in Online Shopping: A Systematic Literature Review
detail.abstract:
Purpose: This study aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of consumer attitudes towards augmented reality in online shopping by synthesising peer-reviewed academic articles to identify the factors influencing consumer intentions to use AR technology, factors influencing consumer AR flow experience, and the outcomes of AR in online retailing. This study also intends to identify research gaps in the analysed research paper to provide further guidance for future research. 
Design/methodology/approach: The authors undertake a systematic literature review of the empirical academic research paper that focuses on using augmented reality technology for online shopping. 22 peer-reviewed journal were analysed for this study. 
Findings: Perceived usefulness found to the most crucial variable that influence consumer for AR usage intention in online shopping. Novelty, visual attributes and product involvement found to the most influential factors for creating AR flow experience. Furthermore it was found that using AR technology increase brand image, brand engagement, willingness to buy and purchase intention. 
Originality/value: This study solely takes into account studies that focus on customer attitude towards AR technology on online purchasing in order to set it apart from other research done in a related research subject. Furthermore, this study is the first to offer a comprehensive understanding of consumers' attitudes towards augmented reality in online shopping, including usage intentions, experiences with the AR flow, and results. Furthermore, this research solely takes into account works published between 2014 and 2023 in order to preserve uniqueness.

title: Designing Equitable and Secure Smart Cities: A Strategic Framework for U.S. Broadband Innovation

detail.title: Designing Equitable and Secure Smart Cities: A Strategic Framework for U.S. Broadband Innovation
detail.abstract:
Broadband connectivity has become essential for modern urban development, particularly within smart city initiatives. Since 2021, the U.S. government has allocated over $42 billion through the Broadband Equity, Access, and Deployment (BEAD) Program to expand high-speed internet access (Kumar et al., 2024). These investments reflect a shift from viewing broadband as a luxury to recognizing it as critical infrastructure.
Despite these efforts, many cities face a dual challenge: addressing digital exclusion while securing rapidly growing data systems. Surveillance technologies, algorithmic bias, and unequal deployment of broadband often amplify social inequities (Thomas, 2025). Without deliberate planning, smart city systems risk reinforcing the very disparities they aim to solve.

This proposal focuses on the intersection of digital equity and cybersecurity within broadband-powered smart cities. The research explores how U.S. infrastructure initiatives, such as BEAD, can integrate ethical design and risk governance to protect civic trust and ensure inclusive access. The topic reflects course objectives around technology innovation, policy strategy, and human-centered systems.

title: Organizational Leadership in Small Business: Approaches to Forming Teams Capable of Adaptation and Growth in an Unstable Environment

detail.title: Organizational Leadership in Small Business: Approaches to Forming Teams Capable of Adaptation and Growth in an Unstable Environment
detail.abstract: The article is dedicated to the study of organizational leadership in the context of small enterprises operating in unstable environments with limited financial, human, and institutional resources. It explores how contemporary leadership modelstransformational, adaptive, and situational-can be adapted to the specificities of small businesses to form teams capable of self-regulation, flexibility, and psychological resilience. It is established that effective leadership under such conditions requires a shift from vertical management models to team-centered approaches based on horizontal communication, autonomy, role rotation, and delegation. Particular attention is paid to the psychological aspects of team building in crisis situationsenhancing trust, ensuring a sense of safety, and supporting employees' emotional resilience. The article presents a practical case study of entrepreneur Violetta Varha, who manages a network of small businesses under conditions of wartime instability, applying methods of internal mentoring, non-material motivation, facilitative conflict resolution, and operational on-site leadership. Based on this case, the challenges are analyzed, including staff exhaustion due to multitasking, managerial burnout, difficulties in delegation, and the management of micro-conflicts. It is argued that adaptive leadership, which combines emotional intelligence with functional flexibility, may serve as a key to maintaining and scaling teams in small businesses under conditions of high turbulence. The practical value of the study lies in the formulation of tools for non-material incentives, managerial flexibility, and the support of a team environment capable of survival and growth even in the absence of a traditional HR infrastructure. The article employs an interdisciplinary approach-managerial, sociopsychological, and organizational-which enables a comprehensive assessment of leadership potential as a means of stabilizing and developing small enterprises during periods of crisis. The scientific novelty of the article lies in the development of an applied leadership model adapted to small organizations facing high levels of instability, based on the integration of empirical cases and theoretical concepts of teamcentered management.

title: Delegating Judgment: AI Agents, Legal Accountability, and the Foundations of Democratic Legitimacy

detail.title: Delegating Judgment: AI Agents, Legal Accountability, and the Foundations of Democratic Legitimacy
detail.abstract: Integrating autonomous artificial intelligence (AI) into critical decision-making has outpaced the reach of existing legal frameworks, forcing legal systems to confront unprecedented dilemmas of procedural fairness, explainability, and democratic legitimacy. Autonomous systems now routinely determine access to benefits, jobs, and basic services, often without meaningful human oversight or recourse. Against this rapidly consolidating reality, this Article proposes a novel framework: the Delegated Synthetic Agent (DSA)-an autonomous, nonhuman system deployed by public or regulated actors to perform consequential legal or administrative tasks. Building from first principles in U.S. constitutional law, European rights regimes, doctrines of tort and agency, and contemporary AI regulation, the Article exposes the limits of retrofitting classical liability doctrines to nonhuman agency. It details how the DSA concept can restore procedural dignity, transparency, and institutional accountability that the law requires in automated governance. The analysis draws upon recent court decisions and current U.S. and European legislation-including the EU AI Act and several U.S. state laws-and incorporates current executive orders and policy reports to demonstrate the urgency and feasibility of reform.

title: Pioneering Ethical AI Integration in Enterprise Workflows: A Framework for Scalable Team Governance

detail.title: Pioneering Ethical AI Integration in Enterprise Workflows: A Framework for Scalable Team Governance
detail.abstract: Generative AI is transforming enterprise workflows at a rapid pace. However, ethical gaps in deployment raise challenges in transparency, fairness, accountability, and privacy. This paper proposes a framework to embed ethical principles—such as bias mitigation, explainability, and responsible automation—into generative AI workflows specifically tailored for project teams. The model emphasizes stakeholder alignment, context-aware decision-making, and iterative feedback loops. Implementation strategies and governance mechanisms are illustrated through enterprise-level scenarios, ensuring trustworthy and sustainable AI adoption.

title: Exploring the Mechanisms Behind Information Sharing Behavior in Legal Livestreaming: A Pls-Sem and Fsqca Perspective
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Sunway University

detail.title: Exploring the Mechanisms Behind Information Sharing Behavior in Legal Livestreaming: A Pls-Sem and Fsqca Perspective
detail.abstract: Matrimonial Legal Counseling Live Streaming (MLCLS) is emerging as a crucial medium for the public to access legal knowledge and support. This study aims to systematically examine the formation mechanisms of information sharing behavior in MLCLS. Drawing on information foraging theory and parasocial interaction theory, a theoretical model was developed that includes pre-search cognitive cues (information seeking motivation), interactive cues during search (metavoicing and visibility), and post-search evaluative cues (source credibility and social presence). A questionnaire survey yielded 401 valid responses from Chinese viewers. Data were analyzed using Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling (PLS-SEM) and Fuzzy-Set Qualitative Comparative Analysis (fsQCA). The results indicate that all cues positively influence both information sharing behavior. Parasocial interaction partially mediates these relationships. Moreover, privacy concern negatively moderates the effects of metavoicing and visibility on parasocial interaction. The fsQCA further reveals multiple equifinal pathways leading to high levels of viewing and sharing behaviors. This study highlights the value of non-entertainment live streaming and the critical role of privacy concerns. The findings provide practical implications for platforms and content creators to optimize livestream design, enhance user engagement, and promote information dissemination.

title: Digital Breaches of Judicial Protection Criminal Law and Child Victimization in the Online Sphere

detail.abstract: This research explores the legal challenges posed by the digital violation of judicial protection orders, especially in cases involving minors and gender-based violence. By analyzing the Spanish criminal framework and comparing it with U.S. legal standards, the study seeks to identify effective legal responses to cyber harassment, online stalking, and indirect digital contact. The research focuses on the interplay between freedom of expression, judicial safeguards, and the protection of vulnerable individuals in cyberspace.

title: The Impact of Artificial Intelligence and Automation on Financial Services in Emerging Asian Economies

detail.title: The Impact of Artificial Intelligence and Automation on Financial Services in Emerging Asian Economies
detail.abstract: This research paper examines the impact of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Automation on the financial services sector in five emerging Asian economies: Pakistan, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, and Cambodia. Financial services encompass a wide range of areas including banking, insurance, investment management, digital payments, and financial advisory. With the rise of AI-driven technologies such as machine learning, predictive analytics, robotic process automation, and chatbots, financial institutions in these countries are undergoing significant transformation. This study investigates how these technologies are enhancing operational efficiency, customer experience, financial inclusion, and risk management. At the same time, it explores key challenges such as regulatory readiness, data privacy, technological infrastructure, and workforce adaptation. By analyzing secondary data and recent developments, the research provides a comprehensive understanding of how AI and automation are reshaping financial services and offers policy insights for sustainable digital growth in emerging Asian markets.

title: Comparative Analysis of the U.S., GCC, and South Asian Models: Policy Gaps in SME Financing Asif Raza, ACCA(UK), CMA (USA) MSc in Professional Accountancy University Of London ( UK)

detail.title: Comparative Analysis of the U.S., GCC, and South Asian Models: Policy Gaps in SME Financing Asif Raza, ACCA(UK), CMA (USA) MSc in Professional Accountancy University Of London ( UK)
detail.abstract:
This article provides a comparative examination of the policy frameworks that regulate the financing of small and medium-sized enterprises (SME) in the United States, the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) countries (specifically the UAE and Qatar), and South Asia (specifically India and Pakistan). The study pinpoints critical policy gaps that impede access to finance for SMEs by concentrating on regulatory structures, the function of financial institutions, and fintech integration. The research indicates that the United States continues to encounter obstacles in achieving equitable access, despite the fact that it has a mature financial ecosystem and a robust credit infrastructure. In contrast, the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) countries are in the early stages of fintech adoption and rely heavily on state-driven initiatives. South Asian countries, on the other hand, grapple with informality and institutional bottlenecks, despite leveraging regulatory mandates and digital infrastructure to broaden credit outreach. The paper suggests practical, region-specific recommendations to improve SME financing, including the expansion of credit guarantee schemes, the promotion of fintech partnerships, the improvement of legal and credit infrastructure, and the promotion of inclusive financial systems, based on international data sources and official policy documents. The results function as a policy roadmap for governments and institutions that are committed to bridging the financing divide for SMEs and fostering inclusive economic growth.

title: Wired to Buy: An Empirical Study of Neuroeconomic Drivers, Emotional Arousal, and Price Sensitivity in Consumer Purchase Intentions
affiliations: Holy Grace Academy and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Wired to Buy: An Empirical Study of Neuroeconomic Drivers, Emotional Arousal, and Price Sensitivity in Consumer Purchase Intentions
detail.abstract: This study investigates the neuroeconomic factors influencing consumer purchase decisions within the Indian retail market. Drawing upon dual-process and prospect theories, the researchers developed a conceptual framework to examine the roles of expected reward, loss aversion, social influence, and cognitive load on purchase intentions.The study utilized regression analysis on data collected from 300 Indian consumers. The findings indicate that anticipated reward and social influence positively impact purchase intention, whereas loss aversion and cognitive load have a negative effect. Emotional arousal was identified as a key mediator, linking expected reward to purchase intention. Conversely, price sensitivity was found to moderate this relationship, diminishing the influence of emotional arousal.The authors propose that these findings can be leveraged to develop more effective emotion-driven marketing and pricing strategies within the Indian retail landscape.

title: Does the Handsome Man Trap Work? A Study on the Impact of Male Anchors’ Reverse Gender Traits on Female Consumers’ Purchasing Intention
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and Shandong Jianzhu University

detail.title: Does the Handsome Man Trap Work? A Study on the Impact of Male Anchors’ Reverse Gender Traits on Female Consumers’ Purchasing Intention
detail.abstract: This study aims to explore how the reverse gender characteristics of male anchors in the live streaming consumption field attract female consumers and influence their purchasing behavior. Based on the interpersonal attraction theory and the PAD three-dimensional emotion model, the male anchor's physical attractiveness, verbal attractiveness, femininity and masculinity are taken as independent variables, female consumers’ sense of pleasure, arousal and dominance are taken as mediating variables, social presence is taken as a moderating variable, and female consumers' purchase intention is taken as the dependent variable, thus proposing research hypotheses and models. The study used structural equation modeling (SEM) to verify the hypotheses using empirical data from 443 female consumers. Research results show that the reverse gender characteristics of male anchors not only have a significant positive impact directly on the PAD three-dimensional emotion model, but also affect female consumers' purchase intention through the mediating effect of the PAD model. Social presence plays a positive moderating role in the relationship between female consumers' sense of arousal and purchase intention. The study expands the application of gender reverse marketing related theories in live e-commerce scenarios and provides targeted reference suggestions for e-commerce anchors, MCN agencies and merchants.

title: A Study of Consumer Behaviour in India with Respect to Digital Payments

detail.title: A Study of Consumer Behaviour in India with Respect to Digital Payments
detail.abstract: India has witnessed a significant transformation in its payment ecosystem, driven by rapid digitalization, demonetization, and increased mobile penetration. This study examines consumer behavior in the context of digital payments, exploring preferences, frequency of usage, influencing factors, and associated challenges. By analyzing responses from 82 consumers and 22 merchants, the research identifies Unified Payments Interface (UPI) as the most widely adopted method across all demographics, highlighting convenience, safety, and cashbacks as key motivators. The study uses both primary survey data and secondary industry reports, supported by statistical testing to validate key hypotheses. Findings emphasize the growing ubiquity of digital transactions in India and provide actionable recommendations for policy makers and businesses to further strengthen digital payment adoption.

title: Business Meets AI: Real-World Use Cases, Strategic Benefits, and Operational Risks
affiliations: Independent Researcher - DPS Monarch International School

detail.title: Business Meets AI: Real-World Use Cases, Strategic Benefits, and Operational Risks
detail.abstract: This paper explores how Artificial Intelligence (AI) is quickly changing how businesses work, especially in the financial and operational parts of a company. Today, businesses are expected to move faster, stay efficient, and make smarter decisions-and AI is becoming one of the key tools helping them do that. From automating time-consuming tasks like reviewing documents or invoices, to detecting fraud and improving investment strategies, AI is being used to handle work that would normally take teams of people and many hours. In this paper, I take a close look at how companies like JPMorgan Chase, Goldman Sachs, and Amazon are using AI in real-world business situations. These examples show that AI is more than just a trend-it's becoming a critical part of how companies reduce costs, save time, and increase accuracy. I've also included some of the challenges that come with depending too much on AI, like data bias, unfair decisions, or losing human control over important tasks. By showing both the benefits and risks, this paper gives a realistic view of how AI is transforming financial workflows and why businesses need to understand and adopt these tools carefully to stay ahead.

title: Structural Equation-VAE: Disentangled Latent Representations for Tabular Data
affiliations: The University of Hong Kong - Department of Politics and Public Administration, Harbin Institute of Technology (shenzhen), Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong Polytechnic University - Department of Applied Social Sciences and The University of Hong Kong - Department of Politics and Public Administration

detail.title: Structural Equation-VAE: Disentangled Latent Representations for Tabular Data
detail.abstract: Learning interpretable latent representations from tabular data remains a challenge in deep generative modeling. We introduce SE-VAE (Structural Equation-Variational Autoencoder), a novel architecture that embeds measurement structure directly into the design of a variational autoencoder. Inspired by structural equation modeling, SE-VAE aligns latent subspaces with known indicator groupings and introduces a global nuisance latent to isolate construct-specific confounding variation. This modular architecture enables disentanglement through design rather than through statistical regularizers alone. We evaluate SE-VAE on a suite of simulated tabular datasets and benchmark its performance against a series of leading baselines using standard disentanglement metrics. SE-VAE consistently outperforms alternatives in factor recovery, interpretability, and robustness to nuisance variation. Ablation results reveal that architectural structure, rather than regularization strength, is the key driver of performance. SE-VAE offers a principled framework for white-box generative modeling in scientific and social domains where latent constructs are theory-driven and measurement validity is essential.

title: Provocative Imagery's Impact on Charitable Giving: A Comparative Analysis of Donation Platforms in the Us and Korea
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and Hanyang University

detail.title: Provocative Imagery's Impact on Charitable Giving: A Comparative Analysis of Donation Platforms in the Us and Korea
detail.abstract: This study examines how provocative imagery, often termed "poverty porn," influences donation behavior in online crowdfunding platforms across different cultural contexts. Analyzing data from GoFundMe (United States) and HappyBean (South Korea), we investigate the impact of both cognitive elements (image and text attributes) and affective elements (emotional responses) on donation outcomes through the lens of the hierarchy-of-effects model. Using deep learning-based image emotion detection models, we quantify visual emotional appeals into two categories: poverty porn related negative emotions (depression, fear, shame, powerlessness, and humiliation) and hopeful emotions (amusement, awe, and contentment). Our findings reveal significant cultural differences in donor responses to visual and emotional stimuli. In the U.S., certain emotional appeals (powerlessness and amusement) positively influenced donations, while text length enhanced donation amounts. In contrast, South Korean donors responded negatively to nearly all emotional appeals, with humiliation showing the strongest negative effect. Additional analysis comparing human-focused versus animal-focused campaigns further confirms these cultural variations. The study contributes to crowdfunding literature by providing empirical evidence that provocative imagery's effectiveness varies substantially across cultural contexts, challenging the universal applicability of emotional appeal theories in donation campaigns. These findings offer practical implications for nonprofit organizations and fundraisers, emphasizing the importance of culturally tailored visual and messaging strategies rather than relying on standardized approaches to provocative imagery.

title: The Memory Wars: AI Memory, Network Effects, and the Geopolitics of Cognitive Sovereignty
affiliations: University of Zagreb - Faculty of Electrical Engineering and Computing

detail.title: The Memory Wars: AI Memory, Network Effects, and the Geopolitics of Cognitive Sovereignty
detail.abstract: The advent of continuously learning Artificial Intelligence (AI) assistants marks a paradigm shift from episodic interactions to persistent, memory-driven relationships. This paper introduces the concept of "Cognitive Sovereignty", the ability of individuals, groups, and nations to maintain autonomous thought and preserve identity in the age of powerful AI systems, especially those that hold their deep personal memory. It argues that the primary risk of these technologies transcends traditional data privacy to become an issue of cognitive and geopolitical control. We propose "Network Effect 2.0," a model where value scales with the depth of personalized memory, creating powerful cognitive moats and unprecedented user lock-in. We analyze the psychological risks of such systems, including cognitive offloading and identity dependency, by drawing on the "extended mind" thesis. These individual-level risks scale to geopolitical threats, such as a new form of digital colonialism and subtle shifting of public discourse. To counter these threats, we propose a policy framework centered on memory portability, transparency, sovereign cognitive infrastructure, and strategic alliances. This work reframes the discourse on AI assistants in an era of increasingly intimate machines, pointing to challenges to individual and national sovereignty.

title: THE IMPACT OF AI-DRIVEN PERSONALISATION TOOLS ON PRIVACY CONCERNS AND TRUST IN SOCIAL MEDIA MARKETING

detail.abstract: This study investigates how AI-driven personalisation in social media marketing affects users' privacy concerns and trust. Guided by Privacy Calculus Theory, it explores how perceived benefits and privacy risks shape consumer trust and behaviour. The aim is to inform ethical, user-centric strategies for AI personalisation that preserve engagement while safeguarding privacy. A mono-method quantitative design was used with a cross-sectional online survey. Data were collected from 217 active social media users via convenience sampling. Descriptive and correlation analyses were conducted using SPSS to examine relationships among AI personalisation, privacy concerns, trust, and risk awareness. Privacy concerns negatively impact trust in AI systems, despite user recognition of the benefits of personalisation. A strong correlation between privacy concern and risk awareness suggests that users are cautious but still engage with personalised content. This reflects a "Cautious Engagement Model," where users manage trade-offs through privacy controls. The findings can guide the development of a powerful brand image through ethical and transparent personalisation practices, fostering consumer trust and loyalty. They support strategies for creating "brand ambassadors" who actively advocate for brands they trust and offer guidance on managing the balance between stability in brand values and adaptability to user privacy expectations in dynamic digital markets. This study extends Privacy Calculus Theory by introducing the "Cautious Engagement Model," showing that users dynamically negotiate trust, risk, and transparency in AI-mediated environments. It offers actionable insights for marketers, platform designers, and policymakers seeking to balance AI innovation with ethical governance.

title: The Impact of Artificial Intelligence on Skills and Education: A Roadmap for Future-Ready Learning

detail.title: The Impact of Artificial Intelligence on Skills and Education: A Roadmap for Future-Ready Learning
detail.abstract: This paper examines the transformative impact of Artificial Intelligence (AI) on the global job market and, consequently, on the requisite skills for future employment. Drawing insights from a Microsoft study on AI applicability in various occupations, this research proposes a strategic roadmap for educational institutions, particularly in the Indian context, to adapt their curricula. We analyze jobs most and least susceptible to AI's influence, suggesting shifts in existing courses and proposing new interdisciplinary programs. The paper further discusses the likely impact of AI course implementation on skills at different educational levels, emphasizing the need for human-AI collaboration, ethical considerations, and critical thinking. This study aims to provide guidance for students, educators, and policymakers in navigating the evolving landscape of AI-driven skill demands.

title: Exploring the implications of artificial intelligence and automation on future workforce dynamics and skill requirements in Lebanon
affiliations: UCAM Universidad Católica San Antonio de Murcia, UCAM Universidad Católica San Antonio de Murcia and Universidad Católica San Antonio de Murcia

detail.title: Exploring the implications of artificial intelligence and automation on future workforce dynamics and skill requirements in Lebanon
detail.abstract:
The rapid advancement of artificial intelligence (AI) and automation is reshaping global labor markets, necessitating a critical examination of their implications for workforce dynamics and skill requirements in developing economies. Lebanon, facing unique socio-economic challenges, presents a compelling case study for understanding how AI-driven disruptions may influence employment trends, skill gaps, and workforce preparedness. This interdisciplinary study conducted by researchers with expertise in engineering, human resources (HR), and supply chain management investigates the transformative effects of AI and automation on Lebanon’s labor market.

Through a systematic review of global and regional literature, combined with sector-specific case studies from Lebanon’s key industries (e.g., manufacturing, IT, logistics, and services), this study analyzes:

  1. Technological Exposure: The susceptibility of Lebanese jobs to automation, drawing on frameworks like the Frey-Osborne "Task Model" and localized data from the World Bank and Lebanon’s Central Administration of Statistics (CAS).
  2. Emerging Skill Requirements: The growing demand for technical competencies (e.g., AI literacy, data analytics) and soft skills (e.g., adaptability, cross-functional collaboration) across engineering, HR, and supply chain roles.
  3. Structural Barriers: Challenges unique to Lebanon, including infrastructural deficits, lack of institutional reskilling programs, and policy inertia in addressing digital transformation.

Our engineering analysis highlights AI’s dual role in displacing routine tasks while creating high-value opportunities in smart manufacturing and IT. The HR perspective underscores workforce polarization, where low-skilled workers face displacement while professionals with hybrid (technical + managerial) skills thrive. The supply chain lens reveals automation-driven efficiencies in logistics but warns of job losses in traditional warehousing and procurement roles.

By contextualizing global trends within Lebanon’s socio-economic reality, this study contributes a framework for inclusive AI adoption in developing economies, offering insights for policymakers, educators, and business leaders.

title: Pakistan's Digital Presence Proceeds Tax Act, 2025, Compared with International Digital Services Tax Regimes

detail.title: Pakistan's Digital Presence Proceeds Tax Act, 2025, Compared with International Digital Services Tax Regimes
detail.abstract:
The rapid digitization of the global economy has presented significant challenges to traditional international tax frameworks, prompting numerous jurisdictions to implement unilateral measures such as Digital Services Taxes (DSTs). Pakistan's Digital Presence Proceeds Tax Act, 2025 (DPPTA25), enacted to address tax base erosion from multinational digital enterprises, represents a notable addition to this evolving landscape. This article provides a comprehensive comparative analysis of DPPTA25 against similar digital taxation legislation in key international jurisdictions, focusing on definitions, scope, tax rates, collection mechanisms, compliance requirements, and enforcement measures.


The analysis reveals that DPPTA25, while sharing common objectives with other DSTs, distinguishes itself through a broader scope that includes digitally ordered goods, a lower transaction-based nexus for establishing digital presence, and highly interventionist collection and enforcement mechanisms, particularly involving payment intermediaries and Customs. These features indicate a robust and assertive approach to capturing digital economic value, potentially leading to enhanced revenue collection for Pakistan. However, they also introduce significant compliance burdens for affected businesses and intermediaries, raise data privacy considerations, and may invite international scrutiny, similar to challenges faced by other countries implementing unilateral digital taxes. The persistent adoption of such measures globally, despite ongoing multilateral efforts by the OECD, underscores the complex interplay between national fiscal sovereignty and the pursuit of a unified international tax system.

title: Abbreviated Judgments and Asymmetries
affiliations: Texas A&M University School of Law

detail.title: Abbreviated Judgments and Asymmetries
detail.abstract: A grand jury may refuse to indict a defendant, but never convict them; an academic paper can easily be desk-rejected but seldom desk-accepted; and in many other settings, the decision maker (DM) may make a preliminary judgment in one direction, but is required to do a more thorough review to make a judgment in the opposite direction. Here, I investigate the optimality of such asymmetric abbreviated-judgment rules, and provide informational; preference-based; and frequency-based rationales for them. In the model considered, asymmetric priors as well as asymmetric error-avoidance preferences can cause one-sided abbreviated judgment rules to be optimal. Prior asymmetries enjoy a form of dominance over preference asymmetries in determining the properties of optimal abbreviated judgment rules, which I define and explain. Moreover, these one-sided classification rules can be optimal even when the DM has symmetric priors and error-costs, because signals may be produced asymmetrically. It may also be optimal to use abbreviated judgments of both kinds, in which case the standards of proof applicable to the two abbreviated judgments may differ.

title: Crypto in the Shadows: Why Global Tax Systems Struggle to Regulate Digital Asset Conversions

All data used were obtained from publicly available regulatory documents, official government reports, and reputable secondary sources.

detail.abstract: The rapid expansion of cryptocurrency markets has fundamentally challenged the architecture of traditional tax systems. As digital asset transactions increasingly bypass institutional oversight, national and international tax frameworks remain fragmented, reactive, and insufficient. This paper critically examines the structural, technological, and policy-driven barriers that inhibit global tax systems from effectively regulating cryptocurrency conversions, particularly the transformation of digital assets into fiat currencies. Drawing upon a comparative analysis of tax regimes across the United States, European Union, United Arab Emirates, and Singapore, this study identifies systemic inconsistencies in the classification of crypto assets, the recognition of taxable events, and the enforcement of cross-border reporting standards. The research highlights the growing prevalence of decentralized finance (DeFi) platforms, peer-to-peer exchanges, and privacy-enhancing technologies, which further complicate tax compliance and erode the ability of authorities to trace digital wealth. Using an interdisciplinary framework grounded in regulatory arbitrage theory and institutional economics, the paper explores the interplay between policy inertia, technological complexity, and jurisdictional competition. It critically assesses the limitations of emerging efforts such as the OECD's Crypto-Asset Reporting Framework (CARF) and FATF's Travel Rule, arguing that without coordinated global standards, crypto tax evasion will persist through legal voids and regulatory arbitrage. The study concludes with a set of policy imperatives for achieving equitable, technologically feasible, and internationally harmonized approaches to digital asset taxation-ensuring tax integrity without stifling innovation or violating digital privacy rights.

title: What Do Firms Think About Inflation? LLM Signals from Earnings Calls and Their Real & Financial Effects

detail.title: What Do Firms Think About Inflation? LLM Signals from Earnings Calls and Their Real & Financial Effects

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author(s) declare no competing interests.
declarations.ethicsApproval: Not applicable: analysis of publicly available earnings-call transcripts; no human participants or personal data.

detail.abstract:
We study what firms say about inflation on quarterly earnings calls and whether that information forecasts real outcomes and stock returns. Using a rules-based prompt, we deploy large language models strictly as classifiers to assign two transparent labels to each call: Inflation Exposure (Low/Med/High) and Pricing-Power Tone (Negative/Neutral/Positive). We run the pipeline across three independent LLM backends and reconcile outputs to avoid model-specific effects, then validate the labels against human annotations. In panel regressions with firm and time fixed effects, higher exposure predicts lower next-quarter margins, while a more positive tone—especially when exposure is high—predicts greater margin resilience and small increases in capex and inventories. In asset-pricing tests, a long–short portfolio based on the combined signal earns small, positive returns around Consumer Price Index (CPI) announcement windows. Results are robust to alternative prompts, model backends, dictionary-based controls, and sector shocks. We provide a simple measurement recipe suitable for replication.

Keywords: inflation exposure; pricing power; earnings calls; text analysis; large language models; pass-through; asset pricing

title: REVOLUTIONIZING FINANCIAL MARKETS: THE ROLE OF AI AND BLOCKCHAIN IN MODERN TRADING

detail.title: REVOLUTIONIZING FINANCIAL MARKETS: THE ROLE OF AI AND BLOCKCHAIN IN MODERN TRADING
detail.abstract: The intersection of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Blockchain technology is driving a significant transformation in financial trading. This paper delves into how these emerging technologies are reshaping trading strategies by enhancing efficiency, security, and the quality of decision-making. By analysing current implementations, limitations, and future directions, the study offers an in-depth look at the disruptive influence of AI and Blockchain within the trading ecosystem. Both technologies, independently and in combination, are redefining areas such as algorithmic trading, high-frequency trading, and decentralized finance (DeFi). Their integration is contributing to greater transparency, improved risk management, and streamlined operations. The paper also highlights ongoing challenges involving scalability, regulatory compliance, and ethical considerations, while exploring future possibilities at the convergence of AI, Blockchain, and digital financial markets.

title: From Gold Dinar to Digital Ledger: Is Islam Ready for Cryptocurrency?
affiliations: Macquarie University - Department of Applied Finance and Actuarial Studies and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: From Gold Dinar to Digital Ledger: Is Islam Ready for Cryptocurrency?
detail.abstract: For over a millennium, Islamic finance has anchored itself in tangible value, ethical trade, and the rejection of interest-based speculation. Yet today, a digital revolution challenges these paradigms. Cryptocurrencies, once dismissed as fringe innovations, have evolved into trillion-dollar markets, raising a pressing theological and economic question: can Islam embrace the blockchain era? This paper traces the Islamic history of money, from the intrinsic value of the gold dinar to the fiat systems that dominate modern banking, highlighting the ethical dilemmas of riba, gharar, and maysir. We then explore how the principles behind blockchain, including decentralization, transparency, and trustless verification, may paradoxically bring finance closer to Sharia ideals than current fiat frameworks. Using empirical data from global and Muslim-majority crypto adoption, official fatwas, and a Sharia screening of the top 20 well known cryptocurrencies, we uncover both contradictions and convergence. While many scholars remain divided, with some condemning crypto outright and others cautiously endorsing it, there is increasing evidence that cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin, gold-backed tokens, and Islamic-compliant digital assets could offer a viable path forward. This study argues that Islam is not only ready for cryptocurrency, but uniquely positioned to shape its ethical frontier. The recent emergence of tokenized Real-World Assets (RWA), including sukuk, real estate, and commodities, further reinforces the compatibility between Islamic finance and blockchain-based innovations.

title: AI Pricing, Agent Heterogeneity, and Collusion
affiliations: National University of Singapore (NUS) - NUS Business School, Boston University - Questrom School of Business, University of Pennsylvania - The Wharton School and Boston University

detail.title: AI Pricing, Agent Heterogeneity, and Collusion
detail.abstract: Recent studies find that firms using similarly capable LLM pricing agents can reproduce classical algorithmic collusion results. In practice, however, firms' agents differ in multiple dimensions, including algorithm type (e.g., LLMs vs. reinforcement learning), model sophistication, size, and data access. We provide one of the first joint theoretical and experimental analyses of how such heterogeneity affects algorithmic collusion. We develop a model showing that differences in sophistication and data access weaken collusion sustainability. We then test and validate these predictions in a lab framework using open-source LLM agents. Leveraging this framework, we further show that both a greater number of agents and greater algorithmic diversity reduce collusion, while differences in model size alone do not. These findings highlight agent heterogeneity as a new factor for firms and regulators managing collusion in the age of agentic AI.

title: Transforming Marketing Research with Generative AI: Opportunities, Limitations, and Ethical Implications
affiliations: University of Oklahoma and University of Oklahoma - Michael F. Price College of Business

detail.title: Transforming Marketing Research with Generative AI: Opportunities, Limitations, and Ethical Implications
detail.abstract: The rapid advancement of Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) is transforming marketing research by automating and enhancing routine marketing tasks. In this paper, we explore how GenAI is impacting marketing research practices across four areas: a) Synthetic Respondents for Market Research, b) Automated Content Generation, c) AI-Powered Customer Service, and d) B2B Marketing Automation. For each of these areas, we conduct a thorough and systematic review of existing literature to evaluate the opportunities and limitations of GenAI in marketing, including its accuracy, cost-efficiency, and ethical challenges. Overall, our findings show that while GenAI enhances scalability and innovation, its effectiveness hinges on a hybrid approach, combining responsible human guidance with ethical AI use and continued research to ensure trust and transparency. Based on our analysis, we recommend best practices such as validating synthetic data with real-world samples, ensuring human oversight in content creation, training customer service models on context-rich datasets, and aligning B2B automation with relationship-building strategies.

title: Refined Expansions of the Skew-Stickiness Ratio in Stochastic Volatility Models
affiliations: Bloomberg LP, Centre de Mathématiques Appliquées (CMAP),  CNRS, Ecole Polytechnique and École Polytechnique, Paris - Centre de Mathematiques Appliquees

detail.title: Refined Expansions of the Skew-Stickiness Ratio in Stochastic Volatility Models
detail.abstract: Building on the celebrated Bergomi-Guyon expansion, we derive second-order expansions in the volatility-of-volatility parameter for the Skew-Stickiness Ratio, an indicator of implied volatility dynamics, within a general class of forward variance models. We demonstrate the accuracy of these expansions under parameters calibrated to the SPX market across several models, including the two-factor Bergomi, rough Bergomi, Heston, and rough Heston models.

title: The Evolving Landscape of Artificial Intelligence on Knowledge Acquisition: An Empirical Assessment

detail.title: The Evolving Landscape of Artificial Intelligence on Knowledge Acquisition: An Empirical Assessment

detail.abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is transforming the way individuals engage with information, especially in educational environments where there is an increasing need for tailored, scalable, and effective learning models. This study offers a thorough evaluation of the changing impact of AI on knowledge acquisition, emphasising learners' adaptability, engagement, and performance. This paper employs a mixed-methods approach with a carefully selected sample size of 150 participants from various academic institutions and learning environments to assess the effectiveness, challenges, and equity dimensions of AI-enabled educational tools. The findings indicate significant enhancements in understanding and memory retention among users of AI platforms, while also highlighting inequalities in access and the necessity for responsible implementation. The research provides practical policy recommendations to facilitate the sustainable integration of AI in knowledge delivery systems.

title: Coordination and Data Sharing in Tiered Healthcare
affiliations: Wake Forest University, University of Texas Rio Grande Valley and University of Korea

detail.title: Coordination and Data Sharing in Tiered Healthcare
detail.abstract: In tiered healthcare systems, early diagnostic decisions made at the frontline critically shape downstream outcomes, especially when the value of shared patient data depends on specialists' ability to interpret it. While prior research highlights the benefits of data sharing and interoperability, less attention has been paid to how these benefits vary with provider capabilities or how initial diagnostic choices should adapt accordingly. Motivated by this research gap, we develop a game-theoretic model of a two-tiered system in which a frontline provider chooses a type of medical exam that determines the richness of diagnostic data shared with downstream specialists. If the initial treatment fails, the patient is referred to one of two specialists who vary in their ability to interpret the shared diagnostic data and make treatment decisions. The model examines how initial diagnostic data influences both preventive efforts and treatment decisions. Our analysis shows that the frontline provider’s choice of a richer exam depends not only on clinical factors but also on the specialist’s analytics capabilities, treatment costs, and uncertainty in patient outcomes. Importantly, rich data alone does not ensure better care coordination. When downstream providers lack the capacity to interpret or act on it effectively, even high-quality data can be underutilized—shifting coordination burdens the frontline and leading to inefficient choices. We also conduct a welfare analysis to identify structural conditions under which incentive misalignments cause under- or overuse of patient data. These findings shed light on why data-sharing initiatives, such as CMS’s Promoting Interoperability in the U.S., may underperform in practice, and underscore that improving care coordination requires not only broader access to data but also stronger investment in providers’ capacity to translate data into actionable insight.

reference: Emory Legal Studies Research Paper No. 101
title: The Illusory Normativity of Rights-Based AI Regulation
affiliations: Emory University and Emory University School of Law

detail.title: The Illusory Normativity of Rights-Based AI Regulation

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The authors have no personal or financial relationship with other people or organizations that may have or could be perceived to have influenced their study.

publicationDetails.detailsText: Emory Legal Studies Research Paper No. 101
publicationDetails.journalName: Emory University School of Law Legal Studies Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: Whether and how to regulate AI is now a central question of governance. Across academic, policy, and international legal circles, the European Union is widely treated as the normative leader in this space. Its regulatory framework, anchored in the General Data Protection Regulation, the Digital Services and Markets Acts, and the AI Act, is often portrayed as a principled model grounded in fundamental rights. This Article challenges that assumption. We argue that the rights-based narrative surrounding EU AI regulation mischaracterizes the logic of its institutional design. While rights language pervades EU legal instruments, its function is managerial, not foundational. These rights operate as tools of administrative ordering, used to mitigate technological disruption, manage geopolitical risk, and preserve systemic balance, rather than as expressions of moral autonomy or democratic consent. Drawing on comparative institutional analysis, we situate EU AI governance within a longer tradition of legal ordering shaped by the need to coordinate power across fragmented jurisdictions. We contrast this approach with the American model, which reflects a different regulatory logic rooted in decentralized authority, sectoral pluralism, and a constitutional preference for innovation and individual autonomy. Through case studies in five key domains—data privacy, cybersecurity, healthcare, labor, and disinformation—we show that EU regulation is not meaningfully rights-driven, as is often claimed. It is instead structured around the containment of institutional risk. Our aim is not to endorse the American model but to reject the presumption that the EU approach reflects a normative ideal that other nations should uncritically adopt. The EU model is best understood as a historically contingent response to its own political conditions, not a template for others to blindly follow.

title: Assessing Long-Term Drought Persistence Using Markov Chain Analysis of SPI-12 and SPI-24 Data

detail.title: Assessing Long-Term Drought Persistence Using Markov Chain Analysis of SPI-12 and SPI-24 Data
detail.abstract: Understanding the persistence and recurrence of drought is critical for effective water resource planning and climate risk management. This study applies Markov chain analysis to characterize long-term drought behavior using the Standardized Precipitation Index at 12-month (SPI-12) and 24-month (SPI-24) timescales. Historical precipitation data were analyzed to classify drought states and estimate transition probabilities between wet, normal, and drought conditions. The results reveal that drought persistence increases significantly at longer timescales, with SPI-24 indicating a higher likelihood of prolonged dry periods compared to SPI-12. Transition probability matrices and steady-state distributions provide insights into the recurrence intervals and stability of drought conditions over time. These findings highlight the utility of Markov chain modeling as a predictive tool for long-term drought risk assessment, enabling policymakers and water managers to implement more robust mitigation strategies in regions vulnerable to extended rainfall deficits.

title: Heat, Cold, and Tax Compliance: Temperature Effects on Corporate Behavior
affiliations: University of Auckland Business School, University of Reading - Henley Business School, University of Auckland Business School and Central South University - School of Business

detail.title: Heat, Cold, and Tax Compliance: Temperature Effects on Corporate Behavior
detail.abstract: This study revisits the effects of temperature exposures on firm-level tax behavior using a nationally representative panel of Chinese firms from 2007 to 2016. We construct a temperature exposure metric based on cumulative days within specified temperature bands to mitigate measurement error. We document a U-shaped relationship, whereby extreme cold and moderate heat conditions correspond to elevated effective tax rates, reflecting reduced tax avoidance under these scenarios. These effects differ by firm ownership, industry, and pollution intensity. We further show that temperature exposures enhance overall productivity but depress profitability and labor productivity, while decreasing fossil fuel use and carbon emissions. Crucially, we link these dynamics to local government political performance, proxied by proximity to water-quality monitoring stations and the changes in water quality. Our analysis reveals that the tax-compliance benefits of traditional R&D innovation are significant only within a 32 km radius of monitoring stations; beyond this, the effect diminishes or reverses. Yet, digital innovation exhibits limited and spatially inconsistent impacts. Moreover, improvements in local water quality attenuate the positive compliance effects of innovation, advocating that enhanced environmental conditions reduce regulatory stringency. This attenuation reflects weakened political incentives for enforcement, leading to more opportunistic tax strategies. Our findings underscore the critical role of local governance quality in shaping innovation effectiveness for tax compliance and sustainable industrial development, highlighting the need for coordinated policies that strengthen environmental oversight and incentivize genuine innovation.

title: Machine Learning-Based Prediction of Drought Phase Transitions Using Multi-Scale SPI Data

detail.title: Machine Learning-Based Prediction of Drought Phase Transitions Using Multi-Scale SPI Data
detail.abstract: Accurately predicting drought phase transitions is critical for effective water resource management, agricultural planning, and disaster preparedness. This study presents a machine learning framework for forecasting drought phase shifts by leveraging multi-scale Standardized Precipitation Index (SPI) data, specifically SPI-3, SPI-6, SPI-12, and SPI-24. Historical precipitation records were processed to compute SPI values across multiple temporal scales, enabling the detection of short-term and long-term drought patterns. Supervised learning algorithms, including Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, and Support Vector Machines, were evaluated for their ability to capture the nonlinear and temporal dependencies inherent in drought evolution. The models were trained and validated using a stratified dataset of drought phases onset, persistence, recovery, and intensification derived from SPI classifications. Performance metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score were used to assess predictive capabilities, with feature importance analysis revealing the dominant influence of longer SPI scales in forecasting phase transitions. The results indicate that the proposed machine learning approach can provide early and reliable predictions of drought dynamics, offering valuable decision-support tools for climate resilience strategies and proactive mitigation measures.

reference: ECB Working Paper No. 2025/3092
title: Mind the App: Do European Deposits React to Digitalisation?
affiliations: RBB Economics, Boston University, European Central Bank (ECB), European Central Bank (ECB) and European Central Bank (ECB)

detail.title: Mind the App: Do European Deposits React to Digitalisation?
detail.abstract: The March 2023 banking turmoil has intensified discussions whether social media and the digitalisation of finance have become significant factors in driving severe deposit outflows. We introduce the concept of deposits-at-risk and utilize quantile regressions for disentangling determinants of stressed outflows at the lowest tail of the distribution. For a sample of large banks directly supervised by the ECB, our findings indicate that an increased use of online banking services leads to a small amplification of extreme deposit outflows, but this effect is not further exacerbated by the availability of a mobile banking app. Online banking use and availability of a mobile app do not have a causal effect on deposit volatility in normal times. Finally, social media are impactful only in idiosyncratic cases.

title: Breaking the Mortality Curve: Investment-Driven Acceleration in Life Expectancy and Insurance Innovation

detail.title: Breaking the Mortality Curve: Investment-Driven Acceleration in Life Expectancy and Insurance Innovation

declarations.declarationOfInterest: No conflict of interest that the author is aware of. Nothing to declare
declarations.ethicsApproval: Not relevant.
declarations.funderStatement: The author received no funding for this study.

detail.abstract: Capital investment in longevity science-research targeting the biological processes of aging through interventions like cellular reprogramming, AI-driven drug discovery, and biological age monitoring-may create significant divergence between traditional actuarial projections and emerging mortality improvements. This paper examines how accelerating investment in life extension technologies affects mortality improvement trajectories beyond conventional actuarial assumptions, building on the comprehensive investment landscape analysis documented in "Investors in Longevity" supported by venture capital databases, industry reports, and regulatory filings. We introduce an Investment-Adjusted Mortality Model (IAMM) that incorporates capital allocation trends as leading indicators of mortality improvement acceleration. Under high-investment scenarios (annual funding of USD 15+ billion in longevity technologies), current insurance products may significantly underestimate longevity risk, creating potential solvency challenges. Our statistical analysis demonstrates that investment-driven mortality improvements-actual reductions in death rates resulting from new anti-aging interventions-could exceed traditional projections by 18-31% by 2040. We validate our model by backtesting historical data, showing improved predictive performance (35% reduction in MAPE) compared to traditional Lee-Carter approaches during periods of significant medical technology advancement. Based on these findings, we propose modified insurance structures, including dynamic mortality-linked products and biological age underwriting, quantifying their effectiveness in reducing longevity risk exposure by 42-67%. These results suggest the need for actuarial science to incorporate investment dynamics in response to the changing longevity investment environment detailed in "Investors in Longevity". The framework presented provides both theoretically grounded and empirically tested tools for incorporating investment dynamics into mortality projections and insurance product design, addressing gaps in current risk management approaches for long-term mortality exposure.

title: Smartphone Use, Social Support, and Sleep Health
affiliations: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University and Pamplin College of Business

detail.title: Smartphone Use, Social Support, and Sleep Health
detail.abstract: Lack of sleep has been declared a public health epidemic, with more than one-third of adults in the United States being sleep-deprived. The dominant narrative in the existing literature and contemporary discourse concludes that the use of smartphones contributes significantly to the deterioration of sleep health. We take a more nuanced approach to this question and examine how different types of phone use impact sleep health. In particular, smartphones are an important vehicle for interpersonal communication and social support. In this study, we examine the impact of pre-sleep smartphone use on sleep health, differentiated by use type (communication vs. non-communication). We also examine whether the effects of smartphone use focused on communication vary with closeness and the type of the other individual contacted. We leverage a detailed longitudinal data set (2015–2019) tracking phone activity, measured using an agent installed on users’ mobile devices, and sleep patterns, measured using health wearable bands, of 550 individuals. Our results suggest that pre-sleep screen time has a U-shaped impact on sleep debt: moderate use of smartphones can reduce sleep debt by up to 28 minutes but heavy use results in harmful effects on sleep. We also find that higher message frequency and messaging close contacts reduce sleep debt over screen time, effectively curbing the negative effects of phone use on sleep health. Those who primarily use their phone for communication with close contacts don’t see significant adverse effects on sleep, whereas heavy non-communication users were significantly harmed at lower levels of use. Moreover, our results show that low-income individuals have significantly higher sleep debt, and communication-focused use is not effective at reducing sleep debt for this group. Our study highlights the nuanced effects of smartphone use on sleep health, deepening the understanding of the relationship between personal technology use and users’ well-being.

reference: ECB Working Paper No. 2025/3091
title: Higher-Order Exposures
affiliations: European Central Bank (ECB), Institute for New Economic Thinking (INET), International Monetary Fund (IMF) and University of Oxford, Faculty of Law

detail.title: Higher-Order Exposures
detail.abstract: Traditional exposure measures focus on direct exposures to evaluate the losses an institution is exposed to upon the default of a counterparty. Since the Global Financial Crisis of 2007-2008, the importance of indirect exposures via common asset holdings is increasingly recognized. Yet direct and indirect exposures do not to capture the losses that result from shock propagation and amplification following the counterparty's default. In this paper, we introduce the concept of \higher-order exposures" to refer to these spill-over losses and propose a way to formalize and quantify these. Using granular data on the South African banking and investment fund sectors and a contagion model that captures the most commonly studied contagion channels and their interactions, we demonstrate that higher-order exposures make up a significant part of exposures -particularly during times of financial distress when exposures matter most. We also show that higher-order exposures cannot simply be extrapolated from direct or indirect exposures, since they depend strongly on the network structure and the robustness of individual institutions. Our findings suggest that exposures should be properly understood as consisting of direct, indirect and higher-order exposures in the design and calibration of those tools in the regulators' arsenal where exposures matter - including large exposure limits, capital requirement calibration, stress test design and resolution. Failure to do so may result in both lax ex-ante regulation and ill-informed ex-post handling of financial crises.

title: Navigating the Ethical Landscape of AI in Higher Education: Insights from the Bardhaman District

detail.title: Navigating the Ethical Landscape of AI in Higher Education: Insights from the Bardhaman District
detail.abstract: The integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) into education holds significant promise for improving learning outcomes, personalizing education, and enhancing teaching methodologies. However, the widespread use of AI in educational settings also raises a variety of ethical concerns. These include issues related to data privacy, algorithmic bias, equity in access, and the role of AI in decision-making processes. This paper explores the ethical considerations surrounding the use of AI in education, analysing the potential risks, the benefits, and the responsibility of educators, policymakers, and technology developers in ensuring that AI is used responsibly. It highlights the need for clear guidelines and regulatory frameworks to address these concerns while maximizing the benefits of AI in education. As Artificial Intelligence (AI) technologies become increasingly integrated into higher education, ethical concerns surrounding their implementation have gained critical attention. This study explores the ethical implications of AI adoption in academic institutions across the Bardhaman district of West Bengal. Using a mixed-method survey approach, data were collected from 120 respondents including students, faculty, and administrators from various colleges and universities. The research investigates stakeholder awareness, perceived benefits, and ethical concerns related to AI applications in teaching, learning, assessment, and administrative tasks. Findings indicate that while a majority recognize the potential of AI to enhance educational outcomes and operational efficiency, there is significant apprehension regarding issues such as data privacy, algorithmic bias, lack of transparency, and overreliance on automation. Over 80% of participants expressed the need for clear ethical guidelines and human oversight in AI implementation. The study emphasizes the urgency of developing inclusive, transparent, and accountable AI governance frameworks to ensure responsible and equitable use of emerging technologies in higher education.

title: TVEd: Ethics in the Age of Tech: Navigating Emerging Tools in Accounting and Tax Practice

detail.title: TVEd: Ethics in the Age of Tech: Navigating Emerging Tools in Accounting and Tax Practice
detail.abstract: From AI to automation, the rise of emerging technologies is transforming how accountants work. But while these tools promise efficiency and insight, they also raise new ethical questions. When does automation undermine professional judgement? How do you manage client confidentiality with cloud platforms? And what are your responsibilities when relying on data from third-party tools? This session explores how the profession's ethical obligations-under APES 110 and the TASA 2009-interact with the practical use of new technologies in accounting and tax practices.

detail.abstract: Globalization, digitalization, and artificial intelligence (AI) are reshaping the concept of citizenship and the traditional social contract. This paper introduces the "Citizen as Guest" model, in which states and jurisdictions compete for the loyalty of individuals similarly to how firms compete for customers. As mobile actors, citizens can relocate, change income sources, and alter legal affiliations at relatively low cost, reshaping economic, political, and cultural structures.

title: Cross-Border Trade Competition and International Stock Return Comovement
affiliations: Yonsei University - School of Business and National University of Singapore (NUS) - Sustainable & Green Finance Institute (SGFIN)

detail.title: Cross-Border Trade Competition and International Stock Return Comovement
detail.abstract: Stock markets of countries that actively engage in international trade may move together more or less depending on their international trade linkages. This paper demonstrates that the stock markets of two countries are less likely to move together if these countries compete intensely in their export product markets. This is in contrast to the higher stock co-movement of countries that share similar exposures to common demand shocks. The empirical patterns imply that stronger cross-border trade linkages may not result in higher cross-market return correlations.

title: Merchant wise UPI Transaction Patterns for July 2025

detail.title: Merchant wise UPI Transaction Patterns for July 2025
detail.abstract: We analyze 12.4 billion UPI transactions worth ₹7.3 trillion across 29 merchant categories in July 2025. Three distinct transaction patterns emerge: high-frequency retail (groceries, food services), highvalue services (utilities, debt collection), and micro-payment ecosystems (gaming, digital goods). Groceries dominate volume with 3.0 billion transactions, while debt collection leads value despite low volume, averaging ₹5,817 per transaction. The analysis demonstrates UPI's comprehensive penetration across India's economy, from street vendors to financial institutions, establishing it as the backbone of digital commerce. These findings provide critical insights for understanding digital payment adoption patterns in the world's largest real-time payment system.

title: The Financialization of Bitcoin: Insights From Arcus BTC and El Salvador's Bitcoin Bank Initiative

detail.title: The Financialization of Bitcoin: Insights From Arcus BTC and El Salvador's Bitcoin Bank Initiative
detail.abstract:
The financialization of Bitcoin refers to the process of expanding Bitcoin's utility beyond a store of value and a medium of exchange. Historically, crypto exchanges and centralized finance (CeFi) lending platforms have offered Bitcoin-based financial products, including lending and staking, often by wrapping Bitcoin into other blockchain ecosystems. However, this approach has introduced risks such as counterparty exposure, bridge vulnerabilities, and reliance on centralized custodians, which undermine Bitcoin's decentralized ethos.
The landscape is rapidly evolving with the emergence of Bitcoin-native financial products and services that eliminate the need for wrapped Bitcoin, blockchain bridges, and risky CeFi lending models. Concurrently, growing institutional adoption signals a shift in Bitcoin's role within global finance. Approximately $50 billion in idle institutional Bitcoin holdings require secure, compliant yield-generation mechanisms that align with decentralization principles.
Arcus BTC, the first Bitcoin-native lending platform tailored for family offices, high-net-worth individuals (HNWIs), and institutions, and El Salvador's pioneering Bitcoin Bank initiative represent transformative efforts to address this demand. This paper argues that Arcus and El Salvador are strategically positioned to accelerate the financialization of Bitcoin, scaling it toward maturity by leveraging Bitcoin's Layer 1 (L1) infrastructure and non-custodial principles.

title: AI in Education: A Global Perspective on Classroom Transformation

detail.title: AI in Education: A Global Perspective on Classroom Transformation
detail.abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) has emerged as a transformative force in education, reshaping classroom teaching practices worldwide. As AI technologies evolve, they offer promising solutions to personalize learning, enhance teaching efficiency, and address challenges such as student engagement and assessment. This paper explores the global scenario of incorporating AI into classroom teaching, analysing how different countries and educational systems are adopting and integrating AI technologies. The paper discusses the benefits, challenges, and ethical considerations associated with AI in education, as well as the future trajectory of AI in classroom settings across various regions.

title: Engaging citizens in EU Missions. Insights from a six-country experimental survey
affiliations: NESTA - Innovation Growth Lab, NESTA - Innovation Growth Lab, NESTA - Innovation Growth Lab, Joint Research Center of the European Commission, NESTA - Innovation Growth Lab and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Engaging citizens in EU Missions. Insights from a six-country experimental survey
detail.abstract: This report discusses the findings of an online survey of European citizens’ attitudes to social challenges and their willingness to participate in activities aimed at addressing these challenges. The results show clearly that European citizens want to be actively involved in solving societal challenges. However, many have a lack of trust in public institutions and low awareness of or lack of access to decision-making processes. Preferences for how to engage differ between individuals, but most are motivated more by community and societal benefits than by personal gain.

title: BlackEconomics.org ® Working Paper "Addressing the Negative Multifactor Productivity Conundrum: Elevating Black Americans' Contributions to US Productivity" There is No Full Accounting for Homo Economicus (HE)-Especially Black HE

detail.title: BlackEconomics.org ® Working Paper "Addressing the Negative Multifactor Productivity Conundrum: Elevating Black Americans' Contributions to US Productivity" There is No Full Accounting for Homo Economicus (HE)-Especially Black HE
detail.abstract: This working paper suggests that, if the growth in real (human animate) materials (M) factor inputs is reduced sufficiently through appropriate quality adjustment (using appropriate quality indicators), then it is possible that estimated negative multifactor productivity might disappear from certain service industries’ landscapes. Currently, capital (K), labor (L), energy (E), and certain services (S) factor inputs are quality adjusted in a KLEMS framework.

title: "A New View on How Black Americans (Afrodescendants) Lose the U.S. Economic Game"

detail.title: "A New View on How Black Americans (Afrodescendants) Lose the U.S. Economic Game"

contentType.other: Published to the BlackEconomics.org Internet Website

detail.abstract: Black Americans (Afrodscendants) are characterized often as losers in the U.S. economic game, and a rich framework of concepts and statistics are available to affirm and confirm this view. Arguably, an opposing view could be considered; i.e., that current metrics used to measure wellbeing are not perfect, which are being considered here. This Analysis Brief builds on the above-mentioned characterization by adding a new and different view. This new view does not focus on the loss concept itself, but opens a new and dark window on how Black Americans are relegated to the lowest economic tier of the U.S. economy using tactics that are seemingly unrelated to traditional metrics that measure Black America’s economic losses.

title: Discontinuous Jumps in Evolving Trend Inflation and Structural Stability of New Keynesian Phillips Curve 1
affiliations: School of International Relations and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Discontinuous Jumps in Evolving Trend Inflation and Structural Stability of New Keynesian Phillips Curve 1
detail.abstract: We test for the structural stability of the New Keynesian Phillips curve (NKPC) featuring an evolving trend inflation derived by Cogley and Sbordone (2008) by exploiting four major oil price shocks and four macroeconomic regimes. Using quarterly US aggregate data since 1954, we estimate this evolving NKPC in subsamples formed with major oil price shock dates and macroeconomic regime switching dates by adapting their two-step procedure combining Bayesian vector autoregression with minimum distance estimation. We find dramatic increases in two pricing parameters immediately after the 1974 Oil Crisis when we allow for discontinuous jumps in the evolving trend in‡ation: during the 1974:I-1979:I period, the share of …rms that were backward-looking is estimated to have risen to 95% from 60%, and the pricing indexation parameter for the backward-looking …rms is estimated to have increased to 100% from 10%. Both parameters, however, are estimated to have reverted to their previous levels in post-1979 subsamples, suggesting that the smaller and less persistent oil price shocks after the 1974 Oil Crisis may not have had much impact on in‡ation gap persistence. We postulate that when a large and persistent macroeconomic shock sets off a large and sudden increase in trend in‡ation, backward-looking becomes more rational than it appears for two reasons. First, the high and volatile in‡ation makes it relatively easier for firms to infer that macroeconomic uncertainty has risen dramatically, and hence the cost of being forward-looking has become prohibitively high. Second, the substantially higher inflation persistence relative to the evolving trend justifies the benefit of backward-looking price setting to a non-trivial extent. Similar results are found across post-WWII U.S. macroeconomic regimes known as the Great Inflation, the Great Moderation, and the Great Recession. When we impose a continuous evolving trend inflation across the entire sample in estimation, the median estimates of firm pricing parameters do not seem to display structural breaks and imply a structurally stable NKPC. The data, however, supports the hypothesis of jump discontinuity in evolving trend in‡ation. Moreover, the forecasting power of the CS08 model is investigated for both continuous and discontinuous trend in‡ation. We first calculate the one-step-ahead inflation forecast for the whole sample based on the continuous trend inflation, based on the median as well as the mean. Then we further investigate the one-step-ahead forecasts in subsamples formed with both oil price shock dates and macroeconomic regime switching dates for which discontinuous trend inflation has been imposed. Some subsamples produce larger RMSEs compared to the whole sample, but on average, it seems that imposing a discontinuous trend inflation produces one-step-ahead forecasts that are almost as good as those produced by the whole sample. To make a general statement, however, we need to look at longer-horizon forecasts.

title: The Art of Asking and Borrowing in Decentralized Finance (Houhai Chen

detail.title: The Art of Asking and Borrowing in Decentralized Finance (Houhai Chen

declarations.declarationOfInterest: None
declarations.ethicsApproval: None
declarations.funderStatement: None

detail.abstract: Imagine being able to lend and earn interest without ever having to talk to a bank. That's the vision of Decentralized Finance (DeFi), a fast-growing area of finance that is built on blockchain and smart contracts. This paper discusses how lending sites like Aave, Compound, and MakerDAO work, and why clients from ordinary savers looking for high returns to institutions seeking clout are joining. We delve into the technology behind smart contracts, how they deal with risk using over-collateralization, and what motivates people to lend or borrow under this trustless system. But DeFi is not just a tech story-it's social too. It has the potential to disrupt traditional finance, open up access in underserved communities, and put a strain on global regulatory systems. But challenges of scalability, security, and restricting usage to crypto holders only also raise underlying questions. Drawing on a mix of on-chain data and user case studies, this paper further applies resilience theory to discover how DeFi responds to economic shocks compared to traditional banks. By doing so, it fills a key research gap in terms of the long-term economic contribution of DeFi.
