We offer policy proposals like undercollateralized lending programs and single point regulation, and argue that DeFi, if carefully constructed, can support goals like decent work and economic growth (UN SDG 8). There needs to be future work on what drives take-up and how DeFi could scale across blockchains and geographies to realize its potential.

title: Macroeconomic, Policy, and Geopolitical Drivers of Financial Stability: Evidence from 9 Major Economies (2000-2024
affiliations: The University of Lahore Islamabad Campus

detail.title: Macroeconomic, Policy, and Geopolitical Drivers of Financial Stability: Evidence from 9 Major Economies (2000-2024

declarations.ethicsApproval: I declare that this manuscript is my original work and has not been submitted, in whole or in part, for publication elsewhere. All sources of data, literature, and information used in this study have been duly acknowledged. I confirm that there is no conflict of interest, financial or otherwise, that could have influenced the outcomes of this research. Ethical standards have been observed in the collection, analysis, and reporting of the data.

detail.abstract: This study investigates the macroeconomic, policy, and geopolitical determinants of financial stability across eight major economies-China, France, Germany, India, Japan, Russia, Turkey, and the United States-over the period 2000-2024. Financial stability is measured using a Principal Component Analysis (PCA)-based Financial Stability Index (FSI) that integrates multiple indicators, including non-performing loan ratios, sovereign bond spreads, stock market volatility, foreign exchange volatility, external debt levels, and current account balances. The empirical framework employs panel data techniques, including fixedeffects and random-effects regressions, with robust standard errors to account for heteroskedasticity and cross-sectional dependence. The independent variables encompass macroeconomic fundamentals (GDP growth, inflation, trade openness, external balances, and foreign reserves), policy indicators (central bank policy rates, asset quality measures), and geopolitical factors (Economic Policy Uncertainty, Geopolitical Risk Index, and sanctions). Descriptive statistics, correlation analysis, and panel unit-root tests are conducted prior to estimation to ensure data quality and stationarity. Preliminary results indicate that stronger GDP growth, higher foreign reserves, and current account surpluses are positively associated with financial stability, while elevated inflation, non-performing loan ratios, and market volatility exert destabilizing effects. Geopolitical risk and sanctions are found to significantly undermine stability, with effects more pronounced in emerging markets. The study's integrated approach highlights the interplay between economic performance, policy choices, and geopolitical conditions in shaping financial resilience. The findings provide valuable insights for policymakers seeking to design macroprudential frameworks that safeguard stability amid economic uncertainty and geopolitical tensions, and contribute to the literature by combining macroeconomic, policy, and geopolitical determinants in a unified empirical model.

title: Legal Innovation or Legislative Shortfall? A Critical Analysis of the Investment and Securities Act 2025 in Combating Ponzi Schemes in Nigeria

detail.title: Legal Innovation or Legislative Shortfall? A Critical Analysis of the Investment and Securities Act 2025 in Combating Ponzi Schemes in Nigeria
detail.abstract:
This paper critically examines the provisions of the Investment and Securities Act 2025 (ISA 2025) in addressing Ponzi schemes in Nigeria. Drawing on my experience as a participant in a parliamentary debate on this subject, I evaluate whether the Act represents a sufficient legal innovation compared to its predecessor and other regulatory frameworks. The analysis focuses on sections 196 of the Act, situates them within Nigeria’s financial regulatory landscape, and compares them with international approaches. While the ISA 2025 expands the scope of offences and penalties related to fraudulent investment schemes, it still presents gaps in enforcement mechanisms and inter-agency coordination.

This paper draws from my experience in that debate, supported by statutory analysis, case law, and comparative insights, to evaluate the strengths, weaknesses, and practical challenges of the ISA 2025 in tackling fraudulent investment schemes.

title: Calibration of the CMA and Regulatory Capital for Securitisations
affiliations: Risk Control Limited, BNP Paribas, Risk Control Limited and BNP Paribas

detail.title: Calibration of the CMA and Regulatory Capital for Securitisations
detail.abstract:
This paper presents a calibration of the Conservative Monotone Approach (CMA), a model of capital for securitisation tranches, and shows how it may be used as the basis for regulatory capital. The CMA is risk-sensitive and implementable by both investor and originator banks. We explain how regulatory judgement may be exercised in the calibration so as to yield a conservative set of tranche capital charges.

The definition of tranche capital employed by the CMA is based on the tranche Marginal Value at Risk (MVaR). Basing capital on the MVaR ensures that capital per dollar of par always decreases as the seniority of the tranche rises, a desirable feature for a regulatory capital framework.

The CMA is non-neutral when compared to the on-balance-sheet capital (which, under the Basel II rules, bases capital on Unexpected Losses rather than MVaR). Specifically, the CMA requires more capital for all the tranches of a deal than is required under the loan capital charges for the underlying pool. Importantly, the CMA is transparent about the degree by which it deviates from capital neutrality in that the deviation equals the Expected Loss of the pool assets (after adjustment for the pool’s Future Margin Income and inclusive of a risk premium).

Key inputs to the CMA are: (i) the tranche attachment and detachment points, (ii) whether the tranche is senior, (iii) the pool risk weight, (iv) the pool loss given default, (v) the delinquency ratio, (vi) the conditional pool correlation, 𝜌𝑀 ∗ , and (vii) the pool regulatory capital surcharge scaling factor, 𝐶𝑆𝑆𝐹𝑀. The pool risk weight inputs employed may be either Basel Standardised Approach (SA) or Internal Ratings Based Approach (IRBA) risk weights. The pool LGD may be assigned regulatory values under the SA or may be pool-specific estimates under the IRBA. The 𝜌𝑀 ∗ and 𝐶𝑆𝑆𝐹𝑀 parameters may be set equal to values appropriate for regulatory asset classes relatively easy to observe, consistent with the BCBS (2006) framework.

In an associated paper, Duponcheele et al. (2014b), we have systematically examined appropriate parameters for the Simplified Supervisory Formula Approach (SSFA) advocated by the Basel authorities in the recently published revision of the securitisation capital proposals (BCBS (2013c)). This calibration or parameterisation is accomplished in the associated paper by matching the thin tranche capital implied by the SSFA (which is an ad hoc capital allocation formula not derived from any rigorous risk model) with the capital implied by the CMA as described in this paper.

title: Banking System Stress Testing (Case Study)

detail.title: Banking System Stress Testing (Case Study)
detail.abstract:
This note presents a stress testing case study for a set of banks with inter-bank obligations, illustrating how stress testing may be accomplished using Risk Control’s RC-ICAAP and Stress Testing System. The calculations are performed for a banking sector comprising three individual banks (labelled A, B and C). The software may accommodate any number of banks and potentially other financial intermediaries.

We show how each bank’s balance sheet, P&L and key capital planning ratios are affected by macro scenarios including (i) a domestic country recession and (ii) a US recession. Note here that the “domestic country” is a notional small, open, emerging market economy. We also demonstrate (in scenario (iii)), how the software models a ‘contagion effect’ caused by the failure to fulfil inter-bank obligations resulting in a liquidity shock to one of the banks.

Changes in the credit quality of each bank’s loan book and fluctuations in the values of mark-to-market exposures affect the value of the banks’ balance-sheet items and the banks’ income through provisions and mark-to-market asset write-offs. A liquidity shortfall from a specific bank causes changes in that bank’s possible funding resources, as well as ‘inter-bank’ losses to other related banks resulting from inter-bank exposure insolvencies.

For a base case and for each of the stressed scenarios, predictions are supplied for the banks’ key variables. The results show how the impairment provisions rise and capital, asset growth, and profitability are depressed by the different recession scenarios. A US recession has a larger and more persistent impact than the domestic-based recession scenario.

The liquidity shock results also show that the rescue triggered by the liquidity shortfall increases the capital and funding of the distressed bank, as well as causing losses and capital reductions in the other banks.

Note that the framework described here may be used either with coarse, public data to perform high-level, top-down stress testing or with more granular internal data for bottom-up stress testing purposes. Financial statement modelling is highly flexible since equations may be written first in Excel, before being converted into scripts and then imported into the software for use at run-time to perform calculations.

title: Unwitting Markowitz' Simplification of Portfolio Random Returns

detail.title: Unwitting Markowitz' Simplification of Portfolio Random Returns
detail.abstract: In his famous paper, Markowitz (1952) derived the dependence of portfolio random returns on the random returns of its securities. This result allowed Markowitz to obtain his famous expression for portfolio variance. We show that Markowitz's equation for portfolio random returns and the expression for portfolio variance, which results from it, describe a simplified approximation of the real markets when the volumes of all consecutive trades with the securities are assumed to be constant during the averaging interval. To show this, we consider the investor who doesn't trade shares of securities of his portfolio. The investor only observes the trades made in the market with his securities and derives the time series that model the trades with his portfolio as with a single security. These time series describe the portfolio return and variance in exactly the same way as the time series of trades with securities describe their returns and variances. The portfolio time series reveal the dependence of portfolio random returns on the random returns of securities and on the ratio of the random volumes of trades with the securities to the random volumes of trades with the portfolio. If we assume that all volumes of the consecutive trades with securities are constant, obtain Markowitz's equation for the portfolio's random returns. The market-based variance of the portfolio accounts for the effects of random fluctuations of the volumes of the consecutive trades. The use of Markowitz variance may give significantly higher or lower estimates than market-based portfolio variance.

title: Smart Management of Digital Content: Archives and Media Resources in the Digital Era

detail.title: Smart Management of Digital Content: Archives and Media Resources in the Digital Era

declarations.declarationOfInterest: Smart Management of Digital Content: Archives and Media Resources in the Digital Era
declarations.ethicsApproval: YES
declarations.funderStatement: NO

detail.abstract: With the exponential growth of digital content, effective management of digital archives and media resources has become vital for libraries, educational institutions, and heritage organizations. This study explores the key principles, tools, and challenges in managing digital archives. It analyses data from libraries, archives, and museums, focusing on metadata standards, digital preservation, user access, and content organization. The paper also includes ten analytical tables to illustrate practices, trends, and gaps in digital resource management. The management of digital archives and media resources is increasingly vital as institutions transition from traditional physical collections to complex digital ecosystems. This study examines current practices, challenges, and emerging trends in digital archive management, focusing on preservation strategies, metadata standards, user access features, and technological infrastructure. Using quantitative data and literature analysis, the research highlights prevalent adoption of metadata frameworks like Dublin Core and preservation techniques such as bitlevel backup and format migration. The study also reveals gaps in mobile access, media playback, and the implementation of advanced technologies like artificial intelligence for metadata enhancement. Key challenges identified include budget constraints, obsolete formats, copyright issues, and the need for skilled personnel. Collaboration among academic institutions, government bodies, and community organizations emerges as a crucial factor for sustainable digital preservation. This paper provides actionable insights for institutions aiming to develop resilient, accessible, and user-centered digital archives that balance innovation with long-term preservation needs.

title: Reducing the Reliance of Securitisation Capital on Agency Ratings
affiliations: Risk Control Limited, Risk Control Limited and BNP Paribas

detail.title: Reducing the Reliance of Securitisation Capital on Agency Ratings

keywords: Joint Committee of the European Supervisory Authorities

detail.abstract:
This paper describes the disadvantages of using agency ratings for securitisations in regulatory applications, and in particular as a basis for regulatory capital. We argue that an external ratings based approach to securitisation capital has become close to unworkable since the crisis, particularly in Europe because of major practical problems created by ratings agency practices.

These problems are (i) ratings volatility due both to methodology changes and the applications of sovereign and counterparty caps and triggers and (ii) to the lack of transparency of ratings agencies approaches and inconsistency with regulatory risk evaluations.

European regulators have adopted the objective of reducing reliance on external ratings in financial regulation substantially within Europe. In November 2013, the Joint Committee of the European Supervisory Authorities (EBA, ESMA and EIOPA – ESAs) launched a joint consultation on how this might be achieved. It has not, however, been obvious what risk measure for securitisation exposures one might employ as an alternative to agency ratings.

Here, we propose as a substitute for agency ratings a simple analytical formula termed the Conservative Monotone Simplified Arbitrage-Free Approach (CMA). This approach is a variant of the Arbitrage Free Approach (AFA) developed by Duponcheele et al (2013) in response to BCBS (2012) and an alternative to some of the approaches in BCBS (2013).

The approach allows one to assess the riskiness of a securitisation exposure on the basis of a small number of inputs. These consist of (i) its attachment and detachment points, (ii) the Basel regulatory asset class and associated regulatory parameters for the pool, (iii) the risk weight of the pool (either based on the Standardised Approach or Internal Ratings Based Approach calculations).

title: Calibration of the Simplified Supervisory Formula Approach
affiliations: Risk Control Limited, Risk Control Limited and BNP Paribas

detail.title: Calibration of the Simplified Supervisory Formula Approach
detail.abstract:
The Simplified Supervisory Formula Approach (SSFA) is a simple, ad hoc approach to allocating capital across tranches with different seniorities. The SSFA has been adopted by the Basel authorities in their latest proposal (December 2013) as their formula-based approach for securitisation regulatory capital with a given calibration.

In this paper, we present an alternative way to calibrate the SSFA that is more straightforward and transparent. This calibration is based on the rigorous, analytically solvable Arbitrage Free Approach (AFA) elaborated by Duponcheele et al. (2013a,b,c,d). In order to perform this calibration, we build upon the detailed investigation we have conducted on appropriate asset class-specific parameters for the Conservative Monotone Approach (CMA, a variant of the AFA). The CMA and its calibration are described in a sister paper, Duponcheele et al. (2014b).

Our calibration has broader significance than simply the parameter values we obtain, in that we show how, by calibrating the SSFA for different regulatory asset classes, one may differentiate capital (across different parts of the securitisation market in a risk sensitive manner) without placing unrealistic information demands on investors.

Last, we demonstrate how to achieve a much better fit between the capital charges implied by the SSFA and those implied by a more rigorous, model-based analysis such as the CMA. This can be done through a simple modification of the SSFA, by adding one additional parameter driving the 1250% risk weight threshold.

title: Estimating the Probability of Export Restrictions to Inform Mineral Criticality

detail.title: Estimating the Probability of Export Restrictions to Inform Mineral Criticality

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.
declarations.funderStatement: All authors are U.S. Government employees or contractors for the U.S. Government. This work was conducted as part of the authors’ regular duties. No funding was received from sources external to the U.S. Government.

detail.abstract: As demand for advanced technologies rises, mineral commodities will increase in geopolitical importance. To assess risks associated with mineral commodity supply chain disruptions, governmental agencies and others have developed "criticality" assessments, with criticality described using the economic impact and probability of supply chain disruptions. In previous work, subjective supply risk indicators were developed to approximate this probability, typically combining several factors such as supply diversity and political stability of trading partners, where indicator weightings can substantially impact results. This work explicitly quantifies trade barrier probability using an ensemble of several machine learning classifiers, with probability estimates informed by exogenous variables such as prior trade barrier implementation and global export dominance. Major differences in the high-probability countries and commodities are observed across models, but the ensemble method highlights Indonesia, China, Tanzania, and the United States as particularly high risk. This approach enables a direct, quantitative, objective approach to assessing trade barrier probability, enhancing risk identification and prioritization for policymakers.

title: The Starbucks Safety Net: Solving the Samaritan's Dilemma

detail.title: The Starbucks Safety Net: Solving the Samaritan's Dilemma
detail.abstract: Welfare programs are often critiqued for creating dependency effects. This can be illustrated using Buchanan's Samaritan's dilemma, where good Samaritans who want to help those in need give unconditional aid. Knowing that this aid is unconditional, the recipients of the aid come to rely upon it. Instead of exerting effort to better their own situation, the recipients become parasites who rely on the generosity of the Samaritans. Beginning with this framework, this paper outlines constitutional rules that private welfare programs can implement to overcome the dilemma, thereby reducing dependency effects. I then illustrate how one such program incorporates the outlined rules into their current welfare program, Starbucks' CUP Fund. This constitutional framework highlights the ability of private welfare programs to overcome the dependency effects associated with welfare provision.

title: Stubborn Scorecards: Analyzing Belief Perseverance and Group Dynamics in Mixed Martial Arts (MMA) Judging
affiliations: University of Michigan at Ann Arbor

detail.title: Stubborn Scorecards: Analyzing Belief Perseverance and Group Dynamics in Mixed Martial Arts (MMA) Judging
detail.abstract: This paper treats Ultimate Fighting Championship judging as a setting for understanding how panel composition shapes agreement in expert evaluations. I find that round outcomes obey a clear hierarchy (decisive, high-impact actions carry the most weight), but consistency hinges on judging panel composition. Panels that include officials with weaker links to the sport's core training and assignment pipeline exhibit meaningfully lower agreement; panels drawn from a shared, professionalized training environment agree more, and agreement further rises without crowd pressure. Disputes cluster in inherently ambiguous sequences, not because criteria are unknowable, but because interpretation varies across panel mixes. At the bout level, mis-scorings exist yet are not systematically tied to panel mix. Internal and external validity implications are direct: panel reliability depends less on calibrated composition: minimum experience thresholds, shared training and recertification, transparent selection, structured feedback, and, for high-stakes cases, larger panels or consensus protocols.

title: College Application Mistakes and the Design of Information Policies at Scale
affiliations: Arizona State University, University of Texas at Dallas - Department of Information Systems & Operations Management, Institute for Fiscal Studies and Yale University

detail.title: College Application Mistakes and the Design of Information Policies at Scale
detail.abstract: We study whether large-scale information interventions can improve college applicant outcomes. Using nationwide surveys, we document widespread information frictions and the prevalence of application mistakes. To address these frictions, we conducted a field experiment that provided applicants with personalized information on admission chances and program characteristics. The intervention increased assignment probabilities for previously unmatched students by 44% and increased placement into higher-ranked programs by 20%. Following these results and with the collaboration of policymakers, we successfully scaled up the policy nationwide. Our findings suggest that personalized information policies implemented at scale can effectively reduce application mistakes and improve student outcomes.

title: Informed Trading in Peer Firms: Evidence from M&A Advisor Banks

detail.title: Informed Trading in Peer Firms: Evidence from M&A Advisor Banks
detail.abstract: This paper finds that M&A advisor banks earn higher profits from trading in the peers of target firms, consistent with exploiting private information about upcoming deals. Cross-sectional analyses document more pronounced trading profits when M&A events generate stronger peer effects and when M&A advisor banks face performance pressure. In contrast, the trading profits are attenuated for top-ranked advisor banks and in periods following heightened regulatory scrutiny. In addition, M&A advisor banks are more likely to execute large trades in peer firms, and these trades are associated with increased probability of informed trading, return non-synchronicity, and stock illiquidity in peer firms. Overall, the findings reveal a previously underexplored channel through which M&A advisor banks profit from their privileged access to client information.

title: Against the Clock: Strategic Adjustments to the NHL's 3-on-3 Overtime Rule Change
affiliations: University of Michigan at Ann Arbor

detail.title: Against the Clock: Strategic Adjustments to the NHL's 3-on-3 Overtime Rule Change

keywords: within-contest outcome uncertainty JEL Codes: Z28

detail.abstract: In this study, I examine the strategic and structural effects of the National Hockey League's 2015-16 shift to 3-on-3 overtime. Leveraging play-by-play and betting odds data from 2010 to 2023, I assess how this rule change influenced expected goals (xG), puck possession dynamics, and, overall, competitive balance. Using a difference-indifferences framework with team fixed effects, I find that cumulative xG during tied score states in the final minute of regulation remained statistically unchanged postreform and possession time decreased significantly, indicating quicker transitions and strategic adjustments. Importantly, there is no significant advantage accrued to favored teams in close-score scenarios, which suggests that the reform preserved fairness while enhancing game dynamism. These findings contribute to the economics of sports rules literature by demonstrating how policy interventions can reconfigure strategic incentives, increasing the pace and variance of outcomes without undermining within-contest uncertainty or distorting competitive balance.

title: Covered Bond versus ABS Liquidity: A Comment on the EBA's Proposed HQLA Definition

detail.title: Covered Bond versus ABS Liquidity: A Comment on the EBA's Proposed HQLA Definition
detail.abstract: The EBA has analysed the liquidity of different asset classes as part of its work for the European Commission on definitions to be employed in a European implementation of the Liquidity Coverage Ratio. This paper critically examines the EBA's analysis, focussing on the exclusion of bid-ask spread data from the evidence employed. Using bid-ask spreads, we show that Asset-Backed Securities (ABS) and Covered Bonds (CB) do not exhibit radically different levels of liquidity in recent years. Furthermore, we show that, based on bid-ask spreads, some non-residential-mortgage-backed ABS (excluded from the LCR in the EBA proposals) have been more liquid than CBs.

title: Locked Out: Upzoning and Population Dynamics
affiliations: University of Southern California - Price School of Public Policy, RAND Corporation and University of Southern California

detail.title: Locked Out: Upzoning and Population Dynamics
detail.abstract: Upzoning is increasingly cited as a supply-side instrument to combat the housing affordability crisis. However, some are concerned that upzoning is a part of a thinly veiled agenda for gentrification (Rodríguez-Pose and Storper, 2020). This paper investigates this tension in Southern California using novel longitudinal zoning data. We first employ emerging hotspot analysis to demonstrate the spatio-temporal trend of residential upzoning in Southern California over the last decade, finding they cluster near popular migration destinations. We then use fixed-effects models and instrumental variable approach to quantify the impacts of upzoning on populations. Our results show that upzoning did not increases total population. Instead, cities with more upzoning experienced significant increases in young college graduates and decreases in non-white population. These demographic shifts coincided with the development of new multi-family housing. As such, upzoning has not increased affordable housing supply, but has instead accommodated local gentrification trends.

title: Probability Weighting Drives Speculative Impact and Lottery-Demand Anomalies *
affiliations: University of Alabama - Department of Economics, Finance and Legal Studies, University of Alabama, University of Alabama and University of Denver - Daniels College of Business

detail.title: Probability Weighting Drives Speculative Impact and Lottery-Demand Anomalies *
detail.abstract: We use a probability weighting model to examine the marginal value of stock market participation for investors with lottery-demand preferences. We apply a NEO-EU model to motivate our measure of speculative impact and test theoretical predictions regarding how probability weighting affects asset prices. Our empirical results document that probability weighting provides a joint explanation for time variation in lottery demand, the pricing of idiosyncratic risk, and momentum. These anomalies are amplified in periods of high speculative impact and are largely eliminated in periods of low speculative impact when the marginal value of stock market participation to lottery demand traders is low. Our results document that probability weighting helps explain time variation in the cross-section and the aggregate market, and survive limits to arbitrage.

title: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL IMPACT OF LABOR REFORM IN COLOMBIA Economic Impact of Labor Reform

detail.title: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL IMPACT OF LABOR REFORM IN COLOMBIA Economic Impact of Labor Reform
detail.abstract: Law 2466 of 2025, or labor reform, introduces structural changes to labor regulation in Colombia with the goal of ensuring decent employment, inclusion, and formalization. From the perspective of Amartya Sen's welfare and capabilities economics, this analysis examines how contractual modifications, reduced working hours, protection for vulnerable groups, and formalization can impact the reduction of multidimensional poverty by expanding opportunities and rights. However, macroeconomic risks such as inflation and unemployment resulting from adjustments in labor costs and labor market behavior are also examined.

title: A Principles-Based Approach to Regulatory Capital for Securitisations
affiliations: Risk Control Limited, Risk Control Limited and BNP Paribas

detail.title: A Principles-Based Approach to Regulatory Capital for Securitisations
detail.abstract: This paper develops a principles-based approach to calculating regulatory capital for securitisations. The approach is simpler and more transparent than the Basel Committee's proposed Modified Supervisory Formula Approach (MSFA) and avoids the latter's numerous opaque approximations. Importantly, our proposed approach is directly consistent with the Basel II Internal Ratings-Based Approach (IRBA) capital formulae for on-balance sheet loans. It is therefore "capital neutral" (at least, before model risk charges or other add-ons) in that a bank holding all the tranches of a securitisation will face the same capital charge as if it retains the securitisation pool assets as directly held exposures. Our suggested approach is therefore, less likely to encourage capital arbitrage.

title: Granularity, Heterogeneity and Securitisation Capital
affiliations: Risk Control Limited, Risk Control Limited, Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) and BNP Paribas

detail.title: Granularity, Heterogeneity and Securitisation Capital
detail.abstract:
his paper examines the effects of granularity and heterogeneity on capital requirements for securitisation transactions. For securitisation portfolios exhibiting a low number of obligors, a granularity adjustment to the Arbitrage Free Approach (AFA) (proposed by Duponcheele et al (2013a)) is derived in detail.  

The adjustment is based on a second-order moment matching of the loss distribution under the Vasicek approximation. Capital based on the AFA inclusive of granularity adjustments is compared with the capital implied by a Monte Carlo model.  

Similarly, for securitisation possessing heterogeneous pools (including barbell deals), the tranche capital implied by the AFA is compared with that obtained using a Monte Carlo model.

We conclude (i) that a simple version of the AFA, using pool level parameters, supplies accurate capital estimates even for extreme barbell deals, (ii) that the AFA, inclusive of granularity adjustments in the correlation, gives accurate capital measures for all except the few securitisation deals that have pools with fewer than 10 effective assets, and (iii) that for such deals, the AFA, inclusive of granularity adjustments to both the correlation and the loss given- default rates gives a capital distribution that is compatible with the situation in which recovery rates of individual assets are stochastic.

title: Maturity Effects in Securitisation Capital: Total Capital Levels and Dispersion Across Tranches
affiliations: Risk Control Limited, Risk Control Limited and BNP Paribas

detail.title: Maturity Effects in Securitisation Capital: Total Capital Levels and Dispersion Across Tranches
detail.abstract:
This paper examines how the capital required for securitisation tranche exposures varies as the maturity of the securitisation increases. We investigate for different maturities the appropriate capital for (i) loan pools, (ii) securitisation deals as a whole (i.e., all the tranches within a given deal), and (iii) individual tranches of differing seniority. 

This issue is highly topical because the Basel Committee's recent proposals on regulatory capital for securitisations include an expected loss component that is highly sensitive to maturity. An alternative proposal, the Arbitrage Free Approach (AFA), advanced by the industry (see Duponcheele et al (2013)) builds maturity effects into the capital formulae in a very different way. 

The paper makes the following points: 
1. We develop a new multi-period version of the AFA and use show that it is equivalent to the 1-period AFA of Duponcheele et al (2013a) when maturity-adjusted parameters are included.

2. The AFA is capital neutral in the sense that securitisation capital for all the tranches of a deal equals the IRBA capital inclusive of maturity adjustment. We show that IRBA maturity adjustment is quite conservative when compared to the capital implied by an industry-standard ratings-based Monte Carlo credit portfolio model. 

3. Using the same Ratings-based Monte Carlo model, we show that with suitable maturity adjustments, the AFA yields an appropriate dispersion of capital across tranches of different seniorities while maintaining capital neutrality.

title:
The Simplified Arbitrage-Free Approach: 
Calculating securitisation capital based on Risk Weights alone
affiliations: Risk Control Limited, Risk Control Limited and BNP Paribas

detail.title:
The Simplified Arbitrage-Free Approach: 
Calculating securitisation capital based on Risk Weights alone
detail.abstract: This paper proposes a variant of the Arbitrage Free Approach (AFA) (developed by Duponcheele et al. (2013)) applicable when the available inputs are risk weights alone. This Simplified AFA, together with the AFA itself, offer a consistent set of approaches for regulatory capital calculations that can be used by investor or issuer banks without relying on agency ratings. The consistency of the AFA and SAFA has the significant advantage of eliminating the cliff effects that occur with the Modified Supervisory Formula Approach (MSFA) and the Simplified Supervisory Formula Approach (SSFA) recently suggested by the Basel Committee. The latter are based on different assumptions and so may imply quite different capital for a given securitisation tranche.

title: Feeling Rich or Looking Rich? Quantifying Self-Image and Social-Image Motives
affiliations: Cornell University - Department of Policy Analysis and Management, University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA), Simon Fraser University (SFU) and Kindai University - Faculty of Economics

detail.title: Feeling Rich or Looking Rich? Quantifying Self-Image and Social-Image Motives
detail.abstract: Preferences for status are typically attributed to two distinct channels: self-image, in which individuals derive utility from being richer than others, and social-image, in which individuals value being seen as richer by others. While both channels are believed to be at play, little is known about their relative importance. We address this gap using a hypothetical discrete choice experiment. Our findings indicate that self-image is at most 19.3% as important as social-image. Additionally, we document substantial heterogeneity in the strength of these preferences across individuals and domains.

title: White Paper: GDP-Linked Money Printing vs. Quantitative Easing

detail.title: White Paper: GDP-Linked Money Printing vs. Quantitative Easing
detail.abstract: This white paper proposes a new policy framework that could strengthen the U.S. economy while maintaining confidence in the dollar. The proposal, GDP-Linked Money Printing, replaces the discretionary nature of quantitative easing (QE) with a transparent, rules-based approach tied directly to economic performance. Under this framework, the U.S. Treasury would receive a fixed percentage of the previous year's GDP as newly created money-allocated as a "bonus budget" for Congress to invest in infrastructure, innovation, and public goods. This ensures stimulus levels match the size and health of the economy, automatically adjusting during booms and recessions.

reference: Libro las verdades de una mentira el gobierno la economía y tu dinero
title: IRGO -ÍNDICE DE RIQUEZA GENERADA POR ORIGEN Una propuesta complementaria para medir la riqueza real de una sociedad Autor: Andrés Gutiérrez Año: 2025 Resumen El Producto Interno Bruto (PIB) es el indicador económico más usado para medir la riqueza de un país, pero presenta limitaciones importantes al enfocarse únicamente en el valor monetario total de bienes y servicios producidos, sin analizar el origen real de dicha riqueza

detail.title: IRGO -ÍNDICE DE RIQUEZA GENERADA POR ORIGEN Una propuesta complementaria para medir la riqueza real de una sociedad Autor: Andrés Gutiérrez Año: 2025 Resumen El Producto Interno Bruto (PIB) es el indicador económico más usado para medir la riqueza de un país, pero presenta limitaciones importantes al enfocarse únicamente en el valor monetario total de bienes y servicios producidos, sin analizar el origen real de dicha riqueza

publicationDetails.detailsText: Libro las verdades de una mentira el gobierno la economía y tu dinero

detail.abstract:
El Producto Interno Bruto (PIB) es el indicador económico más usado para medir la riqueza de un país, pero presenta limitaciones importantes al enfocarse únicamente en el valor monetario total de bienes y servicios producidos, sin analizar el origen real de dicha riqueza.

Este artículo propone el Índice de Riqueza Generada por Origen (IRGO), un modelo complementario que clasifica la riqueza según tres fuentes esenciales: esfuerzo físico, capital acumulado y conocimiento aplicado.

El IRGO permite descomponer el ingreso de individuos o sectores para identificar qué proporción proviene de cada fuente, facilitando un análisis más profundo de la estructura económica y la capacidad de crecimiento sostenible.

Se presenta un caso aplicado al sector médico para ejemplificar la utilidad práctica del modelo. El IRGO busca ser una herramienta para la formulación de políticas públicas más justas y efectivas, promoviendo el reconocimiento y valorización del conocimiento como motor principal del desarrollo.

title: Intellectual Property and Migration: Unpacking Africa's Brain Drain Saga
affiliations: Australian Catholic University (ACU) - Faculty of Law and Australian Catholic University (ACU) - Faculty of Law

detail.title: Intellectual Property and Migration: Unpacking Africa's Brain Drain Saga
detail.abstract: Africa is witnessing a mass exodus of its brightest minds, as skilled professionals migrate from the global south to the north, reshaping the continent's intellectual property (IP) landscape. This phenomenon, brain drain, is a double-edged sword. On one side, it depletes human capital, stifles innovation, and weakens IP law enforcement. On the other, it fuels brain gainenabling the transfer of knowledge, remittances, return migration, and professional networks that can strengthen the home country's IP sector. This article examines these dynamics through the lens of brain drain theory, which suggests skilled migration undermines a nation's capacity for innovation, and endogenous growth theory, which posits that economic growth is driven by internal creativity, innovation, and technological advancements. It explores both the challenges and opportunities posed by brain drain and proposes actionable strategies to mitigate its downsides while capitalizing on its potential benefits for Africa's IP regime.

title: Signalling Quality Through Underpricing: A Bayesian Game-Theoretic Analysis of Indian Startup IPOs (2020-2024)

detail.title: Signalling Quality Through Underpricing: A Bayesian Game-Theoretic Analysis of Indian Startup IPOs (2020-2024)
detail.abstract: The period between 2020 and 2024 saw an unprecedented boom in Indian startup initial public offerings (IPOs), which included listings by Zomato, Nykaa, Paytm, Mamaearth, and other venture-backed companies. Most of these IPOs showed significant underpricing-a process of fixing the offer price less than the anticipated market-clearing price-resulting in huge first-day appreciation for investors. Although underpricing would seem to be harmful to issuers, theory in signalling explains that good-quality firms would underprice for the purpose of signalling their quality credibly in asymmetric information markets. Using a Bayesian signalling game framework, this paper models IPO underpricing. Issuers are classified as high-or low-quality based on unobservable fundamentals. While low-quality issuers are discouraged by the expense of imitating such a strategy, high-quality issuers may strategically underprice in anticipation of long-term reputational benefits and improved aftermarket performance. Data on offer prices, listing prices, underpricing percentages, and post-listing returns from Indian startup initial public offerings (IPOs) from 2020 to 2024 are used to test the model. According to the results, underpricing works well as a signal in industries with a lot of information asymmetry, like technology. Issuers, practitioners of equity capital markets (ECM), and emerging market policymakers can all benefit from the study's conclusions.

title: Private Wealth Growth of High-Ranking Public Officials in Korea: A Comparison to Matched Households

detail.title: Private Wealth Growth of High-Ranking Public Officials in Korea: A Comparison to Matched Households

keywords: rent-seeking behaviors. JEL classification codes: G51

detail.abstract: We compare the wealth growth rates of officials' households to those of ordinary households in Korea. To make the comparison meaningful, officials' households are matched to ordinary households with similar wealth levels and compositions. All high-ranking officials subject to asset disclosure between 2010 and 2021 are included in the analysis. Five interesting patterns emerge: First, officials enjoy significant advantages relative to ordinary households; the wealth growth rates of officials' households are higher by 2.7% per year. Second, the gap between officials' and ordinary households has expanded in recent years. Third, judiciary officials (without access to profitable information) enjoy as much advantages as the executive officials (with such access). Fourth, unelected officials enjoy as much advantages as elected legislators. Fifth, a large difference between central and local government officials. We discuss these and other findings in the framework of officials' rent-seeking behaviors.

title: AMBIT OF TEACHING FREEDOM WITHIN AUSTRALIA'S CURRENT COPYRIGHT REGIME
affiliations: Australian Catholic University (ACU) - Faculty of Law

detail.title: AMBIT OF TEACHING FREEDOM WITHIN AUSTRALIA'S CURRENT COPYRIGHT REGIME
detail.abstract: Are you worried about using movies, music, books, articles and more in your lessons? You are not alone. This article navigates the intricate realm of copyright issues surrounding use of educational materials and explores the legal boundaries teachers face in utilizing such materials in their teaching. It explores the grey area of fair use and fair dealing and how it stifles creativity in the classroom. Amidst the anxiety-inducing ambiguity of copyright infringement, the narrative underscores how this uncertainty disrupts the learning environment. The article scrutinizes statutory provisions across various jurisdictions, including Australia, US, UK, Canada, and India. It argues against the current trend of constraining teachers' freedom within the framework of copyright protectionism and advocates for a more balanced approach. Ultimately, it proposes legislative reforms aimed at alleviating the burden on teachers and fostering a more conducive educational landscape.

title: The Cost of Servicing Debt Pools
affiliations: Washington University in Saint Louis, John M. Olin Business School and University of California, Berkeley - School of Law

detail.title: The Cost of Servicing Debt Pools
detail.abstract: With the rise of securitization, 45% of US mortgages are not serviced by their originator, yet little is known about how loan servicers set their prices and the effect it has on loan performance. We provide novel evidence that the majority of servicers set their servicing fees at the average cost of servicing an entire pool of securitized loans. We calculate a risk based fair market value of the servicing fee at the loan level and document the wedge between the fair market value and the actual servicing fee. Consistent with servicers working harder to cure overpriced loans, we find that servicers increase foreclosures and decrease loan modifications when there is larger underpricing, making the actual servicing fee lower than the fair market fee. At the deal level, we find that larger underpricing negatively impacts investor cash flows.

reference: https://posgrado.colef.mx/tesis/20141165/; https://posgrado.colef.mx/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/TESIS-Zamarripa-Villa-Nayib-Ren%C3%A9.pdf
title: Consumo de electricidad y crecimiento economico en Mexico: Analisis de series de tiempo y prospectiva
affiliations: California State University, Northridge - Department of Economics

detail.title: Consumo de electricidad y crecimiento economico en Mexico: Analisis de series de tiempo y prospectiva
detail.abstract: La implementación de la reciente reforma del sector energético ha despertado el interés por conocer si existe una relación entre los recursos energéticos y el crecimiento económico de México. Este trabajo tiene por objetivo comprender la relación que hay entre el sector eléctrico y la producción nacional y evaluar los posibles efectos que la Reforma Energética de 2013 tendrá en el producto interno bruto (PIB). Se adopta una metodología de econometría de series de tiempo con modelos de vectores autorregresivos. Con datos de 1993 a 2014, los resultados muestran que no hay cointegración entre el consumo de electricidad y el PIB, pero que sí la hay entre el precio de la electricidad, el precio de los productos petroquímicos y el PIB. Por otra parte, el consumo de electricidad Granger-causa al PIB en el corto plazo. A nivel sectorial, el sector secundario y el terciario mantienen una relación de largo plazo entre su nivel de producción y precio de la electricidad. Finalmente, los resultados sugieren que la disminución en el precio de la electricidad pronosticada por la Reforma Energética tendría un efecto positivo en la producción en el corto plazo, y uno negativo en el largo plazo.

title: Theory Unifying Equity Valuation and Expected Return Rate

detail.title: Theory Unifying Equity Valuation and Expected Return Rate
detail.abstract: We propose the Intrinsic Value Valuation Model (IVVM) to estimate fair stock prices from the enterprise side and the Extrinsic Value Valuation Model (EVVM) to estimate fair stock prices from the financial market side. Based on mean reversion, we obtained the theoretical closed-form formulas for these models. When the market reaches equilibrium, the two fair prices derived from IVVM and EVVM should be the same, leading to the development of the theoretical closed-form formula for the Expected Return Rate Model (ERRM). This model consists of two growth coefficients,  m1 and m2, which respectively represent the persistence of Return on Equity (ROE) and the return rate of stock, used to estimate the expected return rate of stock. In this study, we unified two valuation models and one return rate model within a comprehensive theoretical system, providing significant theoretical contributions. The ERRM model also reveals several profound insights: (1) The required return rate, representing systematic risk, affects the expected return rate, but its effect depends on the relationship between the two growth coefficients. If  m1>m2  (m1<m2), the greater the required return rate, the smaller (greater) the expected return rate. If m1=m2, the expected return rate is independent of the required return rate. (2) This finding addresses long-standing debates in CAPM and explains abnormal stock returns observed in some empirical studies, such as why a greater β leads to smaller expected return rates. (3) CAPM may explain the desired return rate but not the expected return rate. The desired return rate is a long-term, static concept related to systematic risk, while the expected return rate is a short-term, dynamic concept not directly tied to systematic risk.

title: American Option Pricing Under Time-Varying Rough Volatility: A Signature-Based Hybrid Framework
affiliations: University of North Carolina (UNC) at Chapel Hill

detail.title: American Option Pricing Under Time-Varying Rough Volatility: A Signature-Based Hybrid Framework

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have influenced the work reported in this paper.
declarations.ethicsApproval: Not applicable. This study did not involve human participants or animal subjects.
declarations.funderStatement: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

detail.abstract: We introduce a modular framework that extends the signature method to handle American option pricing under evolving volatility roughness. Building on the signaturepricing framework of Bayer et al. (2025), we add three practical innovations. First, we train a gradient-boosted ensemble to estimate the time-varying Hurst parameter H(t) from rolling windows of recent volatility data. Second, we feed these forecasts into a regime switch that chooses either a rough Bergomi or a calibrated Heston simulator, depending on the predicted roughness. Third, we accelerate signature-kernel evaluations with Random Fourier Features (RFF), cutting computational cost while preserving accuracy. Empirical tests on S&P 500 equity-index options reveal that the assumption of persistent roughness is frequently violated, particularly during stable market regimes when H(t) approaches or exceeds 0.5. The proposed hybrid framework provides a flexible structure that adapts to changing volatility roughness, improving performance over fixed-roughness baselines and reducing duality gaps in some regimes. By integrating a dynamic Hurst parameter estimation pipeline with efficient kernel approximations, we propose to enable tractable, real-time pricing of American options in dynamic volatility environments.

title: Synthetic Control Methods: A Practitioner's Guide
affiliations: Stanford University and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Synthetic Control Methods: A Practitioner's Guide
detail.abstract: The paper provides a simple user's guide to synthetic control methods and makes the case that synthetic control methods are almost always superior to traditional parametric difference-indifference estimators which almost always violate the parallel trends assumption. The paper provides several examples in one-shot, staggered adoption, panel settings.

title: The Gold Holes Theory

detail.title: The Gold Holes Theory

declarations.declarationOfInterest: NONE
declarations.ethicsApproval: NONE
declarations.funderStatement: NONE

detail.abstract: We propose the concept of gold holes as theoretical gravitational entities that act as the dynamical inverse of black holes. Unlike black holes, which generate extreme spacetime curvature resulting in matter-energy accretion, gold holes induce an outward curvature that manifests as persistent gravitational wave emission. This outward-directed influence contributes to the large-scale expansion of the universe. The internal structure of gold holes is characterized by spatially varying gravitational field magnitudes, producing anisotropic stressenergy distributions within their vicinity. Such a configuration may account for both the observed uniformity and acceleration in cosmic expansion, offering a complementary mechanism to dark energy models. Analytical treatment of the gold hole metric suggests that the expansion rate H(t) may be modulated locally by gold hole density, leading to testable predictions for large-scale structure surveys.

title: Optimal Transfer Mechanism for Municipal Soft Budget Constraints in Newfoundland
affiliations: Memorial University of Newfoundland (MUN) - Department of Economics

detail.title: Optimal Transfer Mechanism for Municipal Soft Budget Constraints in Newfoundland
detail.abstract: Newfoundland and Labrador's municipalities face severe soft budget pressures due to narrow tax bases, high fixed service costs, and volatile resource revenues. We develop a Stackelberg style mechanism design model in which the province commits at t = 0 to an ex ante grant schedule and an ex post bailout rule. Municipalities privately observe their fiscal need type, choose effort, investment, and debt, and may receive bailouts when deficits exceed a statutory threshold. Under convexity and single crossing, the problem reduces to one dimensional screening and admits a tractable transfer mechanism with quadratic bailout costs and a statutory cap. The optimal ex ante rule is threshold-cap; under discretionary rescue at t = 2, it becomes threshold-linear-cap. A knife-edge inequality yields a self-consistent no bailout regime, and an explicit discount factor threshold renders hard budgets dynamically credible. We emphasize a class of monotone threshold signal rules; under this class, grant crowd out is null almost everywhere, which justifies the constant grant weight used in closed form expressions. The closed form characterization provides a policy template that maps to Newfoundland's institutions and clarifies the micro-data required for future calibration.

title: Why Providing More Information to Parents May Not Always Improve Child Educational Outcomes: Lessons from a Study in China
affiliations: Tianjin University-Ma Yinchu School of Economics

detail.title: Why Providing More Information to Parents May Not Always Improve Child Educational Outcomes: Lessons from a Study in China

declarations.ethicsApproval: This study was approved by the Institutional Review Board (IRB) at Ma Yinchu School of Economics (IRB Approval Number: [MYSOE-2019002]). All research procedures involving human subjects were conducted in accordance with the ethical standards of the Ma Yinchu School of Economics IRB and the principles outlined in the Declaration of Helsinki. Prior to participation, informed consent was obtained from all parents/guardians of student participants, and assent was obtained from the students themselves. Participation in the study was voluntary, and participants were assured that their responses would remain confidential and anonymized. For any questions regarding ethical considerations, please contact Econ@tju.edu.cn.
declarations.funderStatement: This research received support from the Seed Foundation of Tianjin University, project number: [2022XS-0081].

detail.abstract: Information asymmetries between parents and children, as well as poor schoolparent communication, hinder parental participation in education. This paper examines two key questions: (1) How does reducing information asymmetries affect student performance? (2) What drives changes in parental and student behavior? Using data from a Shenzhen school, nearly 250 parents received both positive and negative information on their children's school performance. The experiment, conducted over two semesters starting in spring 2019, was terminated in spring 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Contrary to expectations and existing literature, increased parental information was correlated with lower test scores. The explanation lies in "upward belief bias", where parents overestimate their children's behavior. Although school information corrected these beliefs, negatively surprised parents responded with increased involvement, such as punishments or rewards for money and playtime, which proved counterproductive. The findings suggest that excessive parental intervention, particularly in response to negative information, exerts undue pressure on children, harming their academic performance. Overincentivization may not be beneficial for elementary students in China, highlighting the need for balanced parental involvement.

title: Classical Utilitarianism Revisited
affiliations: University of Zurich - Department of Economics

detail.title: Classical Utilitarianism Revisited
detail.abstract: A compelling and commonly held view is that individuals' lifetime well-being can be represented by the integral of their instantaneous utility over time. Under this conception of well-being, the present paper shows that the classical utilitarian social welfare function is characterized by a set of remarkably weak anonymity and dominance axioms. The key insight of the paper is that this characterization result is immune to the main ethical objections that have been raised in response to prior axiomatizations of utilitarianism.

title: Behavioral Signal Design in Financial Markets: Integrating RSI 60/40 with Dow Theory Through a Heuristic Lens

detail.title: Behavioral Signal Design in Financial Markets: Integrating RSI 60/40 with Dow Theory Through a Heuristic Lens
detail.abstract: This paper introduces a behavioral signal framework that integrates a modified Relative Strength Index (RSI 60/40) with Dow Theory trend confirmation to capture sentiment-driven market phases. While RSI and Dow Theory are widely discussed in trading practice, their combined application under a behavioral finance lens remains largely unexplored in academic literature. We hypothesize that RSI threshold breaches, when concurrent with Dow-confirmed trends, provide earlier and more behaviorally intuitive cues than the conventional RSI 70/30 model. The approach is interpreted through anchoring, herding, and overreaction biases, drawing from behavioral finance theory. Manual tests on the NIFTY 50 index (2021-2023) suggest that this framework reduces whipsaws and aligns with observable sentiment patterns. This work contributes to the literature by formalizing practitioner heuristics into a structured, testable academic model, with implications for behavioral asset pricing and sentiment-based market modeling.

title: Chatbots' Soft Power: Generative Artificial Intelligence Promotes Different Political Values Across Countries
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of Lausanne and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Chatbots' Soft Power: Generative Artificial Intelligence Promotes Different Political Values Across Countries
detail.abstract: Generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) has emerged as a transformative technology. Yet, its potential transmission of political values remains underexplored. This study examines whether the most popular chatbot, ChatGPT, adapts its responses to local democratic values, depending on the language in which it is queried and how these responses compare to human opinions across countries from the World Values Survey (WVS). We develop a novel "AI Political Index", quantifying ChatGPT's alignment with local political attitudes. We find that ChatGPT's answers partially adapt to local attitudes, but are liberally biased from 35-60%, depending on the question. For specific dimensions of democracy, ChatGPT presents an almost 100% pro-liberal bias. To investigate to what extent this bias may generalize to all generative AI models, we also carry out the identical analysis for one of ChatGPTs greatest competitors, the Chinese chatbot Deepseek. Interestingly, while the qualitative overall picture at first sight is not fundamentally different for Deepseek, we find some salient differences. While Deepseek displays-if anything-even stronger pro-liberal bias for abstract concepts like "democracy", when it comes to specific features of the political system, Deepseek is significantly less weary of having a "strong leader" or of army rule. Last but not least, we also study how the political values displayed by chatbots have evolved over the last six months. While overall chatbot answers have proven very stable over this period, for some questions there have been changes, with notably a salient decline in the commitment to democratic elections and gender equality. The findings of the current contribution offer insights into the normative influence of AI technologies, which may become increasingly salient in the context of global democratic backsliding.

title: USING COMBINATION OF FUZZY SET AND GRAVITATIONAL ALGORITHM FOR IMPROVING INTRUSION DETECTION

detail.title: USING COMBINATION OF FUZZY SET AND GRAVITATIONAL ALGORITHM FOR IMPROVING INTRUSION DETECTION
detail.abstract: An intrusion detection system (IDS) is a tool used by administrators to protect networks from unknown activities. In signature-based systems, the detection of attacks relies on predefined patterns or behaviours associated with known threats, triggering an alert upon identification of a match. Conversely, anomaly detection systems initiate their process by establishing a baseline profile that reflects the normal operational behaviour of the system or network. These systems possess the capability to identify previously unrecognized attacks, rendering them more effective than their signature-based counterparts. Nevertheless, anomaly-based IDS must consider numerous characteristics when pinpointing attacks Despite these difficulties, machine learning techniques have demonstrated a strong ability to achieve highly accurate anomaly detection and have been employed to identify attacks over the past few decades. Intrusion detection systems are widely used methods to maintain network security. In this paper, the proposed IDS employs machine learning approaches, namely FUZZY are initially applied, followed by optimization algorithms such as Gravitational Search Algorithm (GSA) to determine the optimal subset of detection features. Comparison study on the performance of the FUZZY and FUZZY-GSA models using KDD dataset with selected optimal 27 total features, shows that the proposed model achieves the highest detection rate with the lowest false alarm rate. The highest detection rate for FUZZY-GSA on the KDD dataset is 98.94% in comparison to other recognition algorithm. In summary, the proposed FUZZY-GSA model attains the highest attack recognition percentage with the lowest false positive rate in KDD dataset.

title: Domain-Specific LLMs, Retrieval-Augmented Generation, and Agentic AI: A Unified Architecture for Specialized Intelligence

detail.title: Domain-Specific LLMs, Retrieval-Augmented Generation, and Agentic AI: A Unified Architecture for Specialized Intelligence

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no personal or financial relationships with organizations or entities that could be perceived to influence the research presented in this paper. This work was conducted independently without industry sponsorship or conflicts of interest.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This study did not involve human participants, animal subjects, or clinical data. As a theoretical framework for AI architectures, no ethics approval or consent was required.
declarations.funderStatement: This research received no specific grant from funding agencies in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors. It was developed as independent academic work.

detail.abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities in natural language understanding and generation, yet their application in high-stakes domains such as healthcare, law, and finance is constrained by limitations in contextual accuracy, regulatory compliance, and real-time adaptability. This paper proposes a unified architecture that integrates domain-specific LLMs, retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), and agentic AI to create intelligent systems that are context-aware, data-grounded, and action-capable. Domain-specific LLMs enhance precision and terminology alignment, RAG enables access to trusted and up-to-date information at inference time, and agentic AI introduces autonomous planning, tool use, and multi-step task execution. The resulting Domain Agent Stack transforms AI from a reactive language model into a proactive, regulation-ready digital collaborator. We illustrate the architecture through use cases in healthcare, legal, and financial sectors, supported by system diagrams and workflow examples. This approach provides a scalable pathway toward building AI agents that combine linguistic expertise, dynamic knowledge retrieval, and autonomous decision-making-redefining specialized intelligence for real-world deployment.

title: Financial Consumer Protection Suite with Next-Generation, AI-Powered, Chatbot-Supported Complaints Management System
affiliations: Cambridge SupTech Lab - University of Cambridge, University of Cambridge - Cambridge Centre for Alternative Finance and Cambridge SupTech Lab - University of Cambridge

detail.title: Financial Consumer Protection Suite with Next-Generation, AI-Powered, Chatbot-Supported Complaints Management System

declarations.funderStatement: Gates Foundation

detail.abstract: This case study by the University of Cambridge SupTech Lab outlines the developmen of a fully integrated case management system with analytics dashboards, powered by AI-driven chatbots, to enhance the supervisory capabilities of Otoritas Jasa Keuangan (OJK) Indonesia and Bank of Ghana. The solution, developed in collaboration with Proto and Winnow Technologies, leverages advanced techniques to automate inquiry and complaints handling and correlates this data with web-based public data to provide real-time insights into market conduct.

title: Global Stablecoin Regulations and Policies

detail.title: Global Stablecoin Regulations and Policies
detail.abstract: The growing adoption of stablecoins has prompted governments worldwide to develop comprehensive regulatory frameworks addressing monetary sovereignty, financial stability, and consumer protection concerns. This paper examines the regulatory landscape for stablecoins across major jurisdictions, analyzing recently implemented policies and emerging frameworks. Through examination of legislative developments in the United States, European Union, Asia-Pacific region, and other key markets, this research identifies common regulatory themes while highlighting jurisdictional variations in approach. The findings reveal a global convergence toward stringent reserve requirements, licensing regimes, and operational standards, though implementation strategies vary significantly based on regional priorities and existing financial infrastructure.

title: Intelligence Platform for Flagging Fraudulent Fintech Apps
affiliations: Cambridge SupTech Lab - University of Cambridge, University of Cambridge - Cambridge Centre for Alternative Finance, Cambridge SupTech Lab - University of Cambridge and Cambridge SupTech Lab

detail.title: Intelligence Platform for Flagging Fraudulent Fintech Apps
detail.abstract:
This case study outlines the development of an intelligent platform designed to identify fraudulent fintech applications in India under collaboration with the Reserve Bank

of India and the Reserve Bank Innovation Hub, and the suptech solution provider Winnow Technologies. The solution integrates advanced fraud detection algorithms, behavioural analytics, anomaly detection, and other AI-driven techniques to proactively flag suspicious applications, enhancing regulatory oversight and consumer protection in India's digital financial ecosystem.

title: Financial Consumer Protection Suite with Web Scraping and Machine Learning-Based Analysis
affiliations: Cambridge SupTech Lab - University of Cambridge, University of Cambridge - Cambridge Centre for Alternative Finance and Cambridge SupTech Lab - University of Cambridge

detail.title: Financial Consumer Protection Suite with Web Scraping and Machine Learning-Based Analysis

detail.abstract: This chapter offers notes and advice for the conceptualization, design, and implementation of research using agent-based computational models (ABM). We focus, in particular, on evidence-driven computational models (EDM) which rest on three methodological pillars: agent-based computational modeling (ABM), contextualization using geographical information systems (GIS), and empirical validation. EDM harness the strength of ABM in capturing social and causal complexity-the heterogeneity of actor beliefs, preferences, behaviors, and the nature of local environments, as well as questions about who interacts with whom, when, where and with what effect. The EDM approach can be used to develop and empirically validate theories that can be generalized beyond the contexts in which they were developed, achieving a high degree of real-world correspondence and providing policy relevant insights. We detail the design and use of EDM for a DfiD-sponsored project that involves forecasting malnutrition at the household level as a result of climate-and conflict-related shocks. Our approach is comprised of six steps: (1) model conceptualization, based on understanding key dynamics-including important causal mechanisms; (2) specification of an ABM that captures these dynamics, albeit parsimoniously; (3) internal validation of the model by means of interaction with domain experts and field work; (4) seeding of the model with relevant empirical data; (5) running simulations and validating model outcomes with empirical data; (6) external validation, or testing the model out-of-sample. Our chapter offers guidance on the EDM development process, from initial model conceptualization based on a research question, to the creation of tools that make research insights accessible to non-technical audiences.

title: Economic Divides: Disparities in Wages and Household Earnings in Bangladesh
affiliations: Center for Policy and Economic Research (CPER)

detail.title: Economic Divides: Disparities in Wages and Household Earnings in Bangladesh
detail.abstract: This study examines the effects of human capital—specifically, education and work experience—and social factors, such as age, gender, location, and economic activity, on household income in Bangladesh, using data from the Household Income and Expenditure Surveys (HIES) for 2010 and 2016. Employing Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) and Instrumental Variable (IV) regression techniques, including Two-Stage Least Squares (2SLS) and the Generalized Method of Moments (GMM), the analysis reveals that both human capital and social factors have a moderate influence on income over time, with substantial income variability explained by these variables. Findings from the OLS and IV models indicate that returns to education and additional years of work experience have a consistently positive impact on income across both rural and urban areas in the two survey years. However, wage disparities widened significantly in 2016: the gender wage gap increased to 44.1%, the rural-urban gap to 19.4%, and the industrial-service sector gap to 5%, all of which were notably higher than in 2010. Urban males and females earned significantly more than their rural counterparts in both years. The study also highlights a persistent wage advantage in the service sector compared to the agricultural and industrial sectors in 2016. At the same time, the wage differential between agricultural and non-agricultural sectors narrowed, indicating improved wage growth within the agricultural sector. Furthermore, the marginal return to an additional year of education was found to be higher for females than males, underscoring the critical economic value of investing in women’s education. Given that both human capital and social variables play a significant role in shaping income dynamics, strategic policy interventions and targeted investments are essential for addressing wage inequality, reducing socio-economic disparities, and fostering inclusive development in Bangladesh.

detail.abstract: This thesis proposes the concept of OASES (Oriental Republic of Uruguay, Austria, Switzerland, Emirates (UAE) and Singapore) as a grouping that brings together some of the most successful small open economies from the various regions of the global economy. OASES economies are shown to share commonalities in approaches to economic policies, while also featuring as important logistical hubs connecting the largest economies in their respective regions. The paper also explores the modalities of the OASES framework in the international arena in such areas as platforms for coordinating environmental and digital economy policies. A case is also made in favor of an OASES business model that takes advantage of the competitive strengths of OASES economies. The main findings point to notable commonalities in the policies pursued by OASES economies, with the Swiss model of economic development serving as an important reference point and inspiration for the group’s economies. The strongest performance by OASES economies in the key international rankings is observed in areas such as the quality of living indices (Mercer index) as well as in the levels of wealth and GDP per capita. The thesis identified a number of promising venues for OASES economic cooperation, including platforms for coordinating policies in the environmental sphere, in the development of digital economy, in peace mediation as well as in promoting greater cooperation between the regional integration blocs of OASES economies. A coordinated effort by OASES economies to boost cooperation among small economies (also outside of the OASES perimeter) could open new communication lines as well as widen the “possibility set” for international economic diplomacy.

title: Managerial Myopia and the Time Horizon of Executive Compensation Evidence from Transient Institutional Ownership

detail.title: Managerial Myopia and the Time Horizon of Executive Compensation Evidence from Transient Institutional Ownership
detail.abstract: We hypothesize that corporate boards offer longer duration pay contracts to their executives in order to mitigate short-termism induced by transient institutional investors and that such contracts curb managerial myopia. Consistent with our prediction, we find that pay duration increases with the level of transient institutional ownership. We further find that managers engage in earnings management and focus more on short-term rather than long-term performance when they face transient-induced implicit short-termism incentives and that longer duration pay contracts mitigate such myopic behavior. Collectively, our study provides new evidence on the relation between a firm’s investor base and its compensation structure.

detail.abstract:
For each of the past two years, The International Review of Constitutional Reform (IRCR) has reported on all forms of constitutional revision around the world. Now in its third year, the IRCR has become a fixture in constitutional studies—and it has become a valued resource in universities, courts, and parliaments.
The IRCR continues to offer an invaluable service to scholars, jurists, practitioners, and beyond: to explain and contextualize events in constitutional reform over the previous year. This year’s edition features separate and self-standing reports on over 80 jurisdictions from every region of the globe.
The IRCR defines constitutional reform broadly. We include constitutional amendments, constitutional dismemberments, constitutional mutations, constitutional replacements and other events in constitutional reform, including the judicial review of constitutional amendments.

title: What Drove Jeju to the Coast? The Enduring Impacts of the Jeju 4.3 Massacre

detail.title: What Drove Jeju to the Coast? The Enduring Impacts of the Jeju 4.3 Massacre
detail.abstract: This paper investigates the long-term economic and demographic impacts of the Jeju 4·3 Incident, a large-scale state-led massacre that took place between 1948 and 1954 in South Korea. Using newly digitized historical population and geographic data combined with modern administrative records, I examine how the violence shaped local economic trajectories, settlement patterns, and demographic composition over seven decades. To address potential endogeneity in the spatial distribution of violence, I employ an instrumental variables approach that exploits the military’s “5 km rule” as an exogenous source of variation in exposure to the massacre. The results reveal persistent disparities between interior and coastal regions: interior areas experienced slower population growth, lower levels of urbanization, and reduced provision of public goods. These effects have endured despite South Korea’s rapid national economic growth, highlighting the long-lasting consequences of geographically targeted violence. The findings suggest that historical conflict can leave deep and enduring scars on regional development.

detail.abstract: Quasi-experimental studies of mortality variation and trends among large administrative areas of England in the 2000s and early 2010s have suggested that more deprived populations gain larger mortality benefits from marginal increases in public expenditure on secondary care. We took a closer look by examining mortality variation in 2018 among 32,784 small areas with a mean population of 1,700, allowing more fine-grained measurements of deprivation and mortality. To identify causal effects of marginal changes in expenditure, we used cross-sectional data on secondary care funding allocated to 195 National Health Service administrative areas in England in 2018/19 and employed a well-established instrumental variable approach based on the “distance from target” component of the funding formula, which generates quasi-exogenous variation in funding based on historical factors unrelated to the need for secondary care.  We found an inverted-U shape pattern of mortality gains by deprivation group, whereby the middle group gained significantly more than others.  However, we could not reject the null hypothesis that the two more deprived groups received the same mortality gain as the two less deprived groups.  These findings were robust to extensive sensitivity analysis using different levels of analysis, control variables, mortality outcomes, functional forms, first stage regression specifications, and exclusions, and our preferred specifications all satisfied standard instrumental variable diagnostic tests.  We conclude that the poor do not always gain more from marginal increases in public expenditure on secondary care and, conversely, do not always bear the largest share of the health opportunity costs of cost-increasing programmes.
