detail.abstract: While a significant body of research establishes a negative relationship between overweight and wages, the extent to which the wage-BMI gradient varies across sexual orientations remains understudied. Using the latest released cycles of the Canadian Community Health Survey (CCHS), and an intersectional framework, we explore how the incidence of overweight and obesity predicts wages by sexual orientation. Lacking a viable instrument, the estimations are made by OLS. Among women, we find that overweight heterosexuals are the lowest earning group while nonoverweight lesbians earn the most. Among men, there is no evidence for an overweight penalty for neither gay nor straight men. The patterns are mixed for bisexuals.

title: How Western Legal Systems Fail Caribbean Youth

detail.title: How Western Legal Systems Fail Caribbean Youth
detail.abstract: This paper explores the disconnect between inherited Western legal structures and the lived realities of Caribbean youth in the West Indies. Rooted in colonial-era traditions, many justice systems in the region continue to reflect Eurocentric ideals that fail to accommodate the cultural, linguistic, and socioeconomic conditions faced by young people. As a result, Caribbean youth often experience unequal treatment within the legal system, leading to disproportionately high rates of incarceration, recidivism, and social exclusion. These legal shortcomings also contribute to broader societal challenges such as gang involvement, exposure to violence, and limited access to quality education and opportunity. Using a post-colonial point of view, this paper critically analyzes the structural failures of Caribbean justice systems inherited from Western colonial rule, and proposes culturally responsive reforms aimed at youth rehabilitation and empowerment.

detail.abstract:
El modelo de Black-Scholes es el más utilizado a nivel mundial para valoración de derivados financieros. En periodos de crisis deja de funcionar ya que algunos de sus supuestos en este escenario no se cumplen: la volatilidad ya no es una función conocida, y en el mercado aparecen posibilidades de arbitraje.

Se busca entregar modelos que corrijan estos escenarios de incertidumbre al levantar los supuestos, permitiendo predecir valores de opciones en todo momento y no solo cuando reina la estabilidad económica.

Para llevar a cabo la investigación se revisaron conocimientos de distintas ramas de la ciencia, tales como cálculo estocástico o fundamentos financieros, que fueron necesarios para poder revisar la literatura y comprender el estado del arte, además de permitir fundamentar los supuestos del modelo. Se estudió la modelación financiera también de manera de poder construir modelos que sean consistentes con estos supuestos.

Para obtener soluciones se aplicaron técnicas de computación científica que permitieron elaborar algoritmos que resolviesen los modelos de manera precisa y eficiente. Para interpretar los resultados se recurrió nuevamente a la teoría financiera de manera de llevar al plano práctico los resultados numéricos obtenidos.

Los resultados muestran que al incorporar volatilidad estocástica y arbitraje en el modelo de Black-Scholes se pueden describir las crisis ya pasadas. Esto permite tener herramientas predictivas en tiempos donde todos los instrumentos existentes permanecen descalibrados. El modelo entregado permitiría mejorar la toma de decisiones de inversión, lo que conlleva a una utilización eficiente de los recursos.

detail.abstract: Robust interest in the creation of low-power wireless sensor networks has risen due to the rapid development of Mobile Ad-Hoc Networks (MANET). To build pre-existing infrastructure-less networks for process monitoring and control in industries like transportation, energy, smart structures, environment observing, healthcare, security, industrial, and manufacturing, all the wireless sensors are now integrated into the MANET ecosystem. MANET nodes' long-term operations must be taken into account for designing purposes. Historically, batteries have been a common source of power for wireless devices, which are a major chunk of MANET components. While this has led to lower overall system costs, it can hurt the lifetime and general recital of the network in which they are employed. Various routing-based protocols are proposed for extending the lifespan of these sensor networks, and in certain situations doing away with the need for batteries entirely. Furthermore, energy harvesting provides practical and financial benefits by optimizing energy use and lowering network maintenance expenses. This research explores current developments in MANET energy harvesting methods along with a few research issues that need to be resolved in the future to facilitate the widespread use of energy harvesting technologies in MANET.

detail.abstract: Distributed Denial of Service i.e. DDoS attacks are the most destructive attacks that may be launched against wireless networks. The MANET is an obvious solution to the anytime, anywhere network in the age of heterogeneous networks. All mobile gadgets wirelessly communicate and organize themselves. The Distributed Denial of Service (DDOS) is a severe danger to the security and communication of the mobile node in a MANET. However, with the time network, defenses against these attacks became more lackluster, and network infrastructure grew stronger with time. Additionally, they make use of valid application layer requests, which in turn creates a challenging environment for defense systems in place to identify them. DDoS attacks have recently begun targeting web applications to create disturbance in user service. Finding distinctive characteristics for DDoS attack detection with a high classification accuracy to label the user as either valid or illegal depending on selected attributes is proposed in this work. The results of the suggested model can be tested in terms of assessment parameters.

detail.abstract: This study examines the relationship between household composition and labour market outcomes using two waves (2010 and 2016) of the Jordan Labor Market Panel Survey (JLMPS). The number of female children in the household is used as an instrumental variable to address endogeneity concerns. The findings show that a larger family size negatively impacts labour market performance, raising unemployment and lowering employment rates. While family size is positively associated with holding formal or managerial/professional jobs, it significantly reduces hourly wages, weekly working hours, and monthly earnings. No significant effects are found for public or private sector employment. Subgroup analysis reveals that the negative impacts are more pronounced among individuals with lower education levels and in regions outside Amman, suggesting regional disparities in labour market access and structure.

title: Demonetization and Under-Reporting of Economic Activity: Evidence from Real Estate

detail.title: Demonetization and Under-Reporting of Economic Activity: Evidence from Real Estate
detail.abstract: A major goal of India's 2016 demonetization was to curb tax evasion by reducing the use of cash in under-reported economic activity. We test whether the policy reduced under-reporting in real estate transactions - a market long suspected of widespread cash use and evasion. We find no change in aggregate underreporting, but moderate declines among the 30% of transactions between individual buyers and sellers, relative to the 70% where developers are sellers. Our results highlight the limits of cash-based enforcement and the adaptability of informal practices in high-value asset markets.

title: Decolonization, Legitimacy and Fiscal Capacity: Event Study Evidence from Africa
affiliations: UC Berkeley School of Law and Trinity College Dublin

detail.title: Decolonization, Legitimacy and Fiscal Capacity: Event Study Evidence from Africa
detail.abstract: A vast literature across several academic disciplines studies the impact of colonial rule, but less attention has been paid to the consequences of decolonization. This paper uses a recently-constructed dataset on the fiscal history of African countries from 1900 to 2015 to analyze the impact of decolonization on fiscal capacity (defined as revenue from taxes that are relatively difficult to collect and that require more administrative infrastructure). The analysis adopts a staggered difference-indifference approach, implemented using a stacked event study. It finds no discernible pre-trends prior to decolonization, and a substantial increase in fiscal capacity starting about 5-6 years after decolonization. This result-which implies substantial state-building activity in postcolonial Africa-is robust to tests for a variety of alternative explanations, the use of alternative control groups, and the use of generalized synthetic control methods. We also show that this effect is not explained by democratization or improved public goods provision. Our conceptual framework instead posits that post-colonial states were able to increase tax revenues from hard-to-collect sources because their higher degree of legitimacy improved citizens' tax morale. We offer historical evidence that is consistent with this channel. Our finding-that colonial rulers invested less in fiscal capacity than did post-independence governments-sheds new light on the consequences of colonial rule, and on the determinants of variation in governments' fiscal capacity.

title: Monetary policy in the Euro Area, when Phillips curves ... are curves
affiliations: University of Oxford, De Nederlandsche Bank - Research Department, TU Wien, Oesterreichische Nationalbank (OeNB) and CMAP, Ecole polytechnique, Institut Polytechnique de Paris

detail.title: Monetary policy in the Euro Area, when Phillips curves ... are curves
detail.abstract: We study monetary policy where the price and wage Phillips curves exhibit true curvature. To this end, we propose a New Keynesian (NK) model featuring endogenous adjustment of price and wage setting frequencies, moving beyond the quasi-linear structure of the standard nonlinear NK Phillips curves (NKPC). Using euro area data spanning 1999Q1 to 2024Q4, we estimate and simulate the non-linear model. We then study the recent inflation surge and the implications of state-dependent prices and wages for monetary policy in the estimated non-linear model. Unlike conventional models, our framework does not primarily explain inflation dynamics by exogenous supply shocks. Instead, the impact of shocks on inflation depends on their timing, size, and the business cycle. Consequently, the inflation-output stabilization trade-off faced by monetary policy is state-dependent. For example, monetary policy is more effective in curbing inflation, and supply shocks have larger effects during periods of high inflation.

detail.abstract:
In West and Central Africa (WCA), access to family planning (FP) remains constrained by chronic underfunding, limited domestic resource mobilization, and high dependency on external aid. To address these challenges, the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) adapted the SMART Advocacy methodology, aiming to catalyze sustainable, country-led financing solutions. Between July 2023 and the end of 2024, SMART Advocacy was implemented across 18 UNFPA offices in WCA, including at the subnational level in Nigeria.

The nine-step SMART approach enabled multisectoral coalitions to define Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant and Time-bound (SMART) objectives, map decision-makers, and develop action plans to influence FP financing policies. The initiative achieved measurable outcomes: approximately US$14 million in new government funding was mobilized across a dozen countries; four countries institutionalized FP budget lines; and FP was integrated into national health insurance schemes in two countries. Despite limited progress on corporate social responsibility (CSR) commitments, the approach laid critical groundwork for future private sector engagement.

This study documents the implementation process, results and lessons learned, highlighting the strategic value of aligning advocacy with national budget cycles, strengthening Steering Committees, and adapting plans to dynamic political and fiscal contexts. SMART Advocacy has proven to be a scalable model for driving policy change and securing sustainable financing – not only for FP, but potentially for broader health priorities such as maternal health and gender-based violence (GBV).

Simulations illustrate its relevance to freelance research, algorithmic governance, and decentralized labor systems. detail.title: Anonymous Network Formation *
detail.abstract: Social connections provide various benefits, such as access to information, support, and collaboration, motivating individuals to form networks. However, in many social settings-like academic conferences or networking events-participants are initially strangers, making the networking process inherently anonymous and random. This paper incorporates anonymity into the canonical non-cooperative connections model (Bala and Goyal (2000)) to explore symmetric, mixed-strategy equilibria in network formation. We show that, for any trembling-hand perfect equilibrium, strategies can be interpreted as socialization effort and yield a random network, closely related to but distinct from classical Erdős-Rényi graphs. This provides a strategic microfoundation for random graphs. We fully characterize these equilibria and efficient networks for large populations as a function of connection costs.

title: Did the Declaration of Martial Law Stunt our Economic Growth? A Causal Impact Analysis in Time Series

detail.title: Did the Declaration of Martial Law Stunt our Economic Growth? A Causal Impact Analysis in Time Series
detail.abstract: This paper investigates the long-debated question of whether the declaration of Martial Law in the Philippines in 1972 had a measurable negative effect on the country’s long-run economic and educational outcomes. Leveraging Bayesian structural time-series models developed by Brodersen et al. (2015), the study constructs counterfactual scenarios for key macroeconomic indicators—Gross Domestic Product (GDP), GDP growth rate, and gross enrollment ratio—had Martial Law not been implemented. Using Indonesia and Malaysia as regional comparators and equity indices (S&P 500 and Dow Jones) as global economic controls, the analysis reveals a statistically significant decline in GDP levels, growth rates, and educational attainment during the post-Martial Law period. The GDP fell short by approximately 3%, GDP growth lagged by 1.63 percentage points annually, and gross enrollment was 2 percentage points lower relative to the counterfactual. Results suggest that Martial Law induced long-term economic costs, stunting development and undermining education. These findings challenge the narrative of a "golden age" under authoritarian rule and underscore the importance of evidence-based evaluation of unconventional policy regimes in developing economies.

detail.abstract: This article investigates the impacts of economic shocks resulting from trade liberalization in Brazil on educational indicators in microregions from 1990 to 2010. The analysis explores disparities between different age cohorts, genders, qualification levels and racial groups, in addition to examining the effects on other dimensions of education. We also assess the effects of these shocks on formal employment in large occupational groups over time, as well as the role of China's growing presence in international trade between 2000 and 2010. The results indicate that the regions most exposed to tariff reductions showed significant increases in schooling, especially among individuals aged 10 to 24. From a gender perspective, men were initially the most affected by the shocks, although the effects redistributed over time. Regarding racial composition, white individuals were the most affected in the short term. As a consequence, an increase in educational inequalities between individuals and between regions was observed, revealing the heterogeneity of the impacts of trade liberalization on human capital.

detail.abstract: This study evaluated the profitability and efficiency of an evacuated tube collector integrated with a novel adsorption chiller using phase change material (PCM) thermal energy storage. A 3D model was developed using ANSYS 2023R1, with analyzing cycle times of 1 hour 30 minutes and 4 hours under solar irradiance of 4.92 kW/m²/day in Enugu State, Nigeria. Results showed that the collector achieved a 65% optical efficiency after 4 hours, with a radiant flux of 8.191×10³ W/m² and a heat transfer fluid temperature of 162°C, using a stainless steel heat pipe and aluminum-glass cover. Furthermore, static enthalpy increased to 2.95×10² kJ/kg with a longer cycle time. Heat losses occurred via conduction (350 J), convection, and radiation (2×10³ kJ) throughout emission, reflection, and transmission processes. The silica gel/water adsorption pair showed strong sensitivity to the driving heat source, enabling desorption temperatures of 60-90°C. A maximum exergy efficiency of 75% could be achieved for PCM storage.

title: Elaborative Trademark Similarity Evaluation Using Goods and Services Automated Comparison
affiliations: Scientific and Research Institute of Providing Legal Framework for the Innovative Development of National Academy of Law Sciences of Ukraine, Simon Kuznets Kharkiv National University of Economics, Students and Simon Kuznets Kharkiv National University of Economics

detail.title: Elaborative Trademark Similarity Evaluation Using Goods and Services Automated Comparison
detail.abstract: Trademark description comparison is an important problem during registering a new trademark. Manual search for the most similar trademark often faces the plenty of similar trademarks already registered and filed, so subjective evaluation of the trademark similarity imposes some deviations in the comparison. This paper discusses the methods that aim the automatic evaluation of the trademark's similarity/identity based on the text description of goods and services. The analysis included trademarks covering legal services. Various models (count vectorizer, TF-IDF, word2vec, doc2vec) pretrained and trained by ourselves, and sets of vectors comparison approaches (cosine similarity, Tanimoto similarity) have been evaluated. Own simple greedy matching algorithm that can optionally include difference between size of sets which is useful for trademarks comparison has been proposed. The article shows that some combinations of model/similarity measure are successful in searching for correct hierarchy of trademarks, while some other are better in terms of human relevance. The quality and performance analysis of the discussed methods allowed us to choose the most effective of them according to the available data and technical requirements and implement them in practical applications to perform search for the similar or identical trademarks by example. We contribute to the study of methods for automating legal processes and offer a mean to reduce the risk of intellectual property disputes.

title: Jobs in Jeopardy: Explaining the Dynamics of Philippine Fiscal Stimulus and Monetary Adjustments on Unemployment

detail.title: Jobs in Jeopardy: Explaining the Dynamics of Philippine Fiscal Stimulus and Monetary Adjustments on Unemployment
detail.abstract: With the objective of lowering unemployment rates, the Philippine government should be able explore three economic policies based on conventional wisdom-the implementation of (1) efficient job matching processes, (2) fiscal, and (3) monetary policies. However, literature would suggest that fiscal and monetary shocks would significantly increase unemployment whereas an improvement in job-matching would allow hard-to-fill occupations to find qualified applicants. Thus, this research simulates shocks of matching technology processes, government spending through unemployment benefits and subsidies, and monetary policies on labor market dynamics in the Philippine economy both empirically and theoretically. Building on dynamic stochastic general equilibrium (DSGE) models of previous literatures (McNelis, 2009; Monacelli, 2010; Tan, 2015; and Zhang, 2015), the research employs a New Keynesian DSGE model of labor markets with search frictions that estimates the impact of advanced matching technology, expansionary fiscal and monetary policies on output and unemployment. Calibration is used to match certain elements of the Philippine economy. Results from the calibrated baseline model show that the matching process, expansionary fiscal and monetary shocks all lead to an expansion in output and an increase in vacancies, translating to a decline in the unemployment rate. Overall, the fiscal shock exhibits more persistent effects on both the economy and the labor market compared to the monetary and matching process shocks, although both fiscal and monetary effects on output and unemployment are short-lived. A policy mix would generate the best results as a simultaneous matching, fiscal, and monetary shock would decrease unemployment and increase output the most. The results of the simulations in the calibrated model allow us to develop policies that are effective in carrying out the short-term and long-term objectives of the Philippine authorities.

detail.abstract: Rainwater harvesting is a sustainable and effective irrigation method that addresses water scarcity and climate change. This article examines rainwater gathering as an agricultural water supplement. Rainwater capture, storage, and use reduces farmers' dependence on groundwater and traditional water sources, improving agricultural yields, irrigation costs, and resilience during dry seasons. Rainwater harvesting methods, system designs, and their applicability across locations and climates are examined in the paper. Case studies and data show that this strategy promotes water conservation and sustainable agriculture. Rainwater harvesting could optimise water resources and food security in a changing environment.

title: Artificial Intelligence-Powered Learning Analytics and Student Feedback Mechanisms for Dynamic Curriculum Enhancement and Continuous Quality Improvement in Outcome-Based Education

detail.title: Artificial Intelligence-Powered Learning Analytics and Student Feedback Mechanisms for Dynamic Curriculum Enhancement and Continuous Quality Improvement in Outcome-Based Education
detail.abstract: The integration of AI in education has revolutionized student assessment and feedback systems, enabling personalized learning pathways tailored to individual needs. The opacity of AI-driven feedback mechanisms presents significant challenges in transparency, trust, and pedagogical alignment. XAI has emerged as a critical solution to enhance interpretability, ensuring that students and educators can understand, validate, and act upon AI-generated assessments. This chapter explores cutting-edge techniques for explainable AI in student feedback systems, including attention mechanisms in NLP, SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP), and Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations (LIME). It also examines human-AI interaction, algorithmic authority, and ethical considerations in AI-driven assessments. Through case studies of personalized student evaluation platforms, this research highlights the practical implications of XAI in fostering transparency, engagement, and equity in learning environments. The findings underscore the necessity of integrating interpretable AI models that align with pedagogical frameworks, ensuring that AI serves as a collaborative tool rather than an autonomous decision-maker. By bridging the gap between AI interpretability and pedagogical decision-making, this work advances the development of ethical, transparent, and student-centric AI-driven feedback systems.

detail.abstract: This theory posits that the double-entry accounting system is a robust model that applies the laws of thermodynamics to bookkeeping. Rooted in the mathematical principle of conservation, the system is isomorphic to the physical laws governing energy flow. The proposed framework reveals that while global growth is limited by energy extraction and efficiency, the American economic subsystem utilizes a third growth method: an indiscriminate tax on U.S. currency holders domestically and abroad, which is facilitated by the dominance of the Petrodollar system. This "inflation tax," implemented through domestic credit creation, allows for a systemic transfer of value from international U.S. dollar holders to domestic recipients. The theory concludes that the integrity of the double-entry system is therefore paramount, as departing from it risks creating an economic ledger that no longer corresponds to physical reality.

title: Role and Functional Aspects of Bamboo Amongst the Ethnic Communities of Northeast India: A Case Study of the Karbi Tribe in the District of Karbi-Anglong, Assam

detail.title: Role and Functional Aspects of Bamboo Amongst the Ethnic Communities of Northeast India: A Case Study of the Karbi Tribe in the District of Karbi-Anglong, Assam
detail.abstract: Bamboo is regarded as the 'green gold' or 'poor man's timber' and is one of the highest producing global renewable natural resources. It is a versatile plant possessing more than 1500 uses and forms an indispensable component in the socio-economy of the rural ecosystem in Northeast India. Bamboo groves or patches are observed to be situated in the two hill districts of Assam, namely Dima Hasao and Karbi Anglong. The present study aimed at understanding the socioeconomic dependency of the Karbi tribe on bamboo resources as well as to document the utilization of bamboo in the cultural festivals of the Karbi community for sustenance of their culture & ethnic heritage. Participatory Rural Appraisal (PRA), focus-group discussions, keyinformant interviews and semi-structured household surveys were deployed for the purpose of primary data collection. Results revealed that Bambusa tulda, locally referred to as Jati bamboo is predominantly available and observed in the homestead gardens. However, in the natural forested regions, both Bambusa tulda & Dendrocalamus hamiltonii, locally referred to as Kako/Kaipho had a major occupancy. Bamboo is intimately utilized by the locals for the purpose of construction and artwork, handicrafts and agricultural as well as fishing implements. In addition, Bamboo plays an indispensable role in various ethnic rituals and cultural festivals of the Karbi tribe namely Chujoon, Rongker, Karbi Youth Festival, etc. However, bamboo sale and marketability has reduced over the years. Shutting down of paper mills is one of the major reasons towards less involvement in Bamboo farming and management. Illegal trading and third-party exploitation were also reported in the bamboo supply-chain.

title: Tax Education and Academic Sustainability: a SWOT Analysis of Strategic Management in Accounting and Tax Support Centers (NAF)

detail.title: Tax Education and Academic Sustainability: a SWOT Analysis of Strategic Management in Accounting and Tax Support Centers (NAF)
detail.abstract: This study aims to identify strategic factors related to the management and sustainability of the Accounting and Tax Support Center (NAF), a Brazilian tax education initiative developed by the Federal Revenue Service in partnership with Higher Education Institutions (HEIs). The qualitative methodology adopted included triangulation of methods with documentary research of official reports (2021-2024), semi-structured interviews with the national coordination, and questionnaires applied to local coordinators, students, and taxpayers served by the centers. The main results highlight as strengths the solid institutional partnership between the Federal Revenue Service and HEIs, which maintains 493 active centers, and the successful integration of theory and practice, with 345,869 cases handled annually. However, the study identified significant weaknesses, such as excessive dependence on student volunteer work and the geographical concentration of services in a few regions. Among the opportunities, we highlight the increase in demand for accounting services for Individual Microentrepreneurs (28% growth in three years) and the inclusion of tax education in the National Common Core Curriculum. On the other hand, threats such as the financial instability of partner institutions and deficiencies in post-pandemic technological infrastructure may compromise the future sustainability of the project. The study offers important strategic and theoretical contributions, highlighting objective guidelines for expanding the social impact and operational and financial sustainability of NAF at the national level.

title: Power Electronics for IoT-Enabled Smart Grids and Industrial Automation

detail.title: Power Electronics for IoT-Enabled Smart Grids and Industrial Automation
detail.abstract: The rapid digitalization of energy markets, coupled with the rise of decentralized power generation, has necessitated innovative solutions for secure, transparent, and scalable energy trading. Blockchain technology, integrated with P2P energy trading and IoT-enabled smart grids, presents a transformative approach to decentralized energy management. Challenges related to scalability, interoperability, transaction throughput, and security must be addressed to enable large-scale adoption. This book chapter explores advanced blockchain-enabled mechanisms, including Layer 2 scaling solutions, cross-chain communication, and AI-driven smart contract optimization, to enhance the efficiency of energy trading networks. The role of blockchain in managing renewable energy certificates (RECs) and carbon credits was also examined, highlighting tokenization as a means to improve market liquidity, transparency, and regulatory compliance. Additionally, a comparative analysis of consensus mechanisms and throughput optimization techniques was provided, offering insights into the trade-offs between security and scalability. The integration of AI and machine learning in smart contracts was discussed as a key enabler for predictive energy trading, automated market adjustments, and fraud detection. Future research directions focus on hybrid blockchain models, cross-chain interoperability, and sustainable energy tokenization frameworks. The findings of this chapter contribute to the development of a highly efficient, decentralized, and resilient smart power ecosystem, paving the way for the next generation of blockchain-based energy markets.

title: Modeling of Biological and Subjective Age with Economic Applications
affiliations: Ulm University - Institute of Insurance Science, Ulm University - Institute of Insurance Science and Ulm University

detail.title: Modeling of Biological and Subjective Age with Economic Applications
detail.abstract: The distinction among chronological, biological, and subjective age is not only well established in biomedical and psychosocial research on human longevity and healthspan, but is also increasingly relevant in economics due to its superior predictive power for mortality and individual decision-making. In this paper, we propose a realistic yet parsimonious model of an individual's biological and subjective age. Moreover, our model explicitly incorporates the interaction between biological and subjective age, as documented in empirical studies (e.g., Stephan et al., 2015). It replicates key findings from the literature, such as the observation that biological age can differ up to 20 years from the chronological age (Bortz et al., 2023), or that people older than 40 believe to be 20% younger (Rubin and Berntsen, 2006). To facilitate economic applications, we develop a three-state lifecycle model in which transition probabilities are determined by biological and subjective age, respectively. As an illustration, we apply the framework to a consumption and portfolio choice problem, where health-dependent utility functions are applied.

title: The Derivatives Skills Gap in Financial Markets: A Case Study Analysis of the Certified Futures and Options Analyst (CFOA) Designation

detail.title: The Derivatives Skills Gap in Financial Markets: A Case Study Analysis of the Certified Futures and Options Analyst (CFOA) Designation
detail.abstract: The exponential growth and increasing complexity of global derivatives markets has created unprecedented demand for professionals with advanced knowledge of derivative instruments, yet traditional academic and professional pathways have proven inadequate in delivering the practical, strategy-focused education required for contemporary market applications. This paper investigates the structural nature of the derivatives skills gap in modern finance, systematically evaluates the pedagogical limitations of established finance certifications in addressing derivatives competency, and examines the emergence of specialized, applicationoriented credentials as potential solutions. Through detailed case study analysis, we examine the Certified Futures and Options Analyst (CFOA) designation, analyzing its curriculum design, assessment methodology, market positioning, and early adoption patterns. Our research incorporates analysis of job market trends, employer requirements, educational content gaps, and industry feedback to construct a comprehensive framework for understanding how targeted certifications might address structural weaknesses in financial training infrastructure. We conclude that while specialized certifications like the CFOA represent a meaningful market response to documented educational gaps, their long-term efficacy and broader implications for professional development in derivatives markets require continued empirical investigation and systematic evaluation.

title: MAPPING OF BAMBOO GROVES IN KARBI ANGLONG DISTRICT, ASSAM USING GEOSPATIAL TECHNOLOGIES

detail.title: MAPPING OF BAMBOO GROVES IN KARBI ANGLONG DISTRICT, ASSAM USING GEOSPATIAL TECHNOLOGIES
detail.abstract: Bamboo forms an essential and integral component of the natural landscape as well as the socio-cultural and economic lives of the people of Northeast India. India is home to nearly 45% of global bamboo patches and Northeastern Region (NER) comprises of two-thirds of the total growing stock of the country. However, there has been a lot of challenges and loopholes identified in terms of availability of consistent and accurate data on different aspects of bamboo such as area coverage, productivity, carbon sequestration, feedstock, consumption & livelihood. Earth observation data has been proved to be highly instrumental and successful towards spatial mapping of natural resources, including bamboo ecosystems. The present study aimed at delineating & analyzing the bamboo groves of Karbi-Anglong district of Assam using geospatial technologies. Random Forest Classifier technique was adopted for supervised classification in Google Earth Engine (GEE) using the necessary scripts and codes. Bamboo Index (BI) for the study area was computed by incorporating Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) and Stress Index (SI). Results of the research work revealed that bamboo patches in the study area had BI values ranging from 0.42 to 0.49. Furthermore, majority of the area was observed to be occupied by the forests (Tropical Moist Deciduous Forests & Tropical Semi-Evergreen Forests) followed by Bamboo groves, Agriculture, Fallow Land, Barren Land, Waterbodies and Built-up areas. The findings were instrumental in contributing to the ambit of information on the Bamboo Groves of Karbi-Anglong District, Assam. This could prove to be vital in creation of a reliable database for monitoring and management of one of the most essential renewable Non-Timber Forest Resources considered as 'green gold' and 'poor man's timber' thereby contributing towards elimination of few of the gaps and challenges which has direct implications on the growth and development of the bamboo sector in Northeastern region.

detail.abstract: Text and data mining (TDM) is fundamental to AI development, but algorithmic scraping creates copyright tensions. Critical analysis demonstrates that TDM qualifies for fair use under the "other circumstances" clause. This characterization satisfies the Three-Step Test: as a special computational process, TDM avoids conflict with normal exploitation of works by extracting informational patterns rather than expressive content, and causes no unreasonable prejudice where outputs are non-infringing. A tiered regulatory approach is proposed-non-commercial TDM requires only simplified registration, while commercial operations must implement technical opt-out mechanisms and output safeguards. These boundaries balance technological progress with copyright protection in the AI ecosystem.

title: Rethinking the Requirement of Service of Pre-Action Notice on the Nigeria Revenue Service Under the 2025 New Tax Regime

detail.title: Rethinking the Requirement of Service of Pre-Action Notice on the Nigeria Revenue Service Under the 2025 New Tax Regime
detail.abstract:
One of the key innovations introduced by the Nigeria Revenue Service Act is the requirement of service of one-month pre-action notice on the Nigeria Revenue Service before initiating any suit against it. This provision is unwelcome. It seems to create practical challenges in view of Paragraph 2(2) of the Second Schedule of the Joint Revenue Board Act, which mandates a taxpayer to file an appeal against the Nigeria Revenue Service within thirty (30) days of receiving a notice of assessment or a notice of refusal to amend (NORA). A combined reading of the Nigeria Revenue Service Act and the Joint Revenue Board Act raises uncertainty regarding the validity of an appeal filed by a taxpayer within the thirty (30) days prescribed by the Joint Revenue Board Act without full compliance with the one-month pre-action notice requirement of the Nigeria Revenue Service Act.

This article examines the relevant provisions of the Nigeria Revenue Service Act and the Joint Revenue Board Act in light of the issues highlighted above and proposes a practical approach to resolving the apparent practical challenges in the enforcement of the two laws.

title: Poverty is a curable disease

detail.title: Poverty is a curable disease

declarations.declarationOfInterest: There are none
declarations.funderStatement: My Masters degree at the University of Cape Town was partially funded by the Centre for Social Science Research

detail.abstract: Poverty is commonly defined by a poverty line, an income threshold that is considered insufficient to meet the basic necessities of life. Consequently, poverty alleviation efforts have largely focused on raising incomes through grants, subsidies and other financial interventions. Non-profit and religious organisations supplement these efforts, often reducing the suffering and sustaining life. However, such approaches do little to cure poverty, contributing instead to its persistence. Income, rather than being the root cause, is a symptom of a broader issue. Other symptoms, such as elevated crime rates, road fatalities, teenage pregnancies, certain health conditions, fragile relationships, and poor educational outcomes, frequently accompany poverty. This paper argues that poverty stems from behavioural patterns transmitted intergenerationally, primarily through parenting. These behaviours are shaped by chronic stress during childhood, an epigenetic process that programs individuals for the environment they are expected to inhabit. Addressing poverty, therefore, requires strengthening pair bonding (the foundation of effective parenting), educating caregivers on the importance of parenting, and providing mechanisms to alleviate stress and trauma frequently found in disadvantaged communities. Given the constraints on financial and professional resources, such interventions must be community-driven.

title: GEDCO In The Heart Of The Storm

detail.title: GEDCO In The Heart Of The Storm
detail.abstract:
This white paper presents a comprehensive analytical study of the impact of the ongoing Israeli aggression on the Gaza Electricity Distribution Company (GEDCO) during more than a full year of conflict. It documents the severe and systematic damage to infrastructure in the electricity sector, which serves 2.3 million citizens and supports essential services such as healthcare, water, communication, education, and municipalities.

The study highlights the extent of material and human losses, including the destruction of 68% of electricity networks, damage to 73% of company buildings, and the displacement and loss of staff. It also showcases GEDCO’s efforts to maintain critical services under extreme conditions, including securing remaining infrastructure, supporting hospitals and municipalities, and supplying power to vital facilities like the Coastal Municipalities Water Authority's desalination plant.

This document offers a model for understanding how vital companies operate and adapt during prolonged crises, and it serves as a foundational reference for recovery planning and humanitarian support strategies in post-conflict zones.

title: Individual Investors and Nature-Conscious Investment: A Systematic Review Protocol
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and University of Limerick - Kemmy Business School

detail.title: Individual Investors and Nature-Conscious Investment: A Systematic Review Protocol
detail.abstract: The global financial system plays a central role in allocating resources towards human activities that are causing degradation to ecosystems and an alarming decline in biodiversity. For capital providers, particularly those classified as retail investors or pension fund holders, the links between biodiversity loss and how their capital is allocated may be difficult to discern. A broad variety of investment vehicles are available to non-professional, individual investors. The largest proportion of investment capital is directed towards those vehicles that are passively managed and as far as possible reduce transaction costs for capital providers while offering easily defined expected returns and risk over a defined future time-period. While these investment vehicles and associated systems that direct capital providers are efficient from a financial perspective, they have effects on transparency and investor agency over how their capital is deployed. The protocol described here outlines the methodology for a systematic review to explore how individual investors can more effectively allocate their capital to investment vehicles that protect and enhance nature, and the ecosystem services it provides. Our primary research question is: how do individual investors interpret, access and participate in nature-conscious investment? By individual investors we mean non-professional investors who allocate capital in pursuit of financial goals. This includes those who actively manage their long-term savings through pension funds and retail investors who participate in financial markets of their own accord. Studies will be categorised according to the themes that support or prevent investors choices. The results will inform us about how future research should attend to each of these themes if the private financial flows are to be redirected towards the protection and restoration of nature.

detail.title: Healthcare Utilization and Labour Market Responses to Health Shocks

keywords: Universal Healthcare System JEL Classification: I12

detail.abstract:
This paper examines the long-term impacts of negative health shocks on healthcare utilization and labour market outcomes by applying a dynamic difference-in-differences estimator to a sample of heart attack and stroke survivors in Taiwan. To investigate who is more affected by these health shocks, we estimate differential effects by age, healthcare utilization, and income. We find that low-income individuals are less likely to survive but more likely to utilize healthcare and remain employed after the health shocks, indicating the existence of a socioeconomic health gradient. Moreover, non-employed workers are more likely to start working, which could be attributed to increased financial needs following the health shocks. 
Building upon our empirical findings, we conduct counterfactual assessments to evaluate health-enhancing policies from a social perspective.

detail.abstract: The U.S. dietary supplement industry has seen exponential growth since the passage of the Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act in 1994, with current sales surpassing $56 billion. This expansion, driven by consumer preferences and aggressive marketing tactics, occurred under a regulatory framework that prioritizes access over safety. Unlike prescription and over-the-counter medications, supplements do not require pre-market FDA approval, enabling widespread distribution of products with limited oversight. This paper critically examines the U.S. regularly approach to dietary supplements, contrasting it with that of the E.U., and explores how cognitive biases are routinely exploited to drive sales. The manipulation of consumer preferences and behavior, especially among vulnerable populations, has led to significant public health consequences, including underreported adverse events and increased emergency department visits. Case studies, such as TB12 during the height of the COVID-19 pandemic and vitamin A promotion during the current U.S. measles outbreak, illustrate the dangers of regulatory gaps and misinformation. The paper concludes with evidence-based policy recommendations to strengthen consumer protections, including enhanced labeling requirements, mandatory adverse event reporting, pre-market product registration, and expanded third party certification.

detail.abstract:
This study examines the implications of Maersk's decision to discontinue direct cargo shipments between South Africa and the United States by October 1, 2025, and its broader impact on African trade dynamics. The research analyzes how this strategic withdrawal by a major shipping conglomerate represents a critical juncture in Africa's global trade integration, with particular focus on the cascading effects on neighboring economies such as Nigeria.

The analysis reveals that the disruption extends beyond bilateral South Africa-U.S. trade relations, significantly affecting other African nations that have historically relied on South African maritime infrastructure as transit points for their exports to American markets. The study explores the deterioration of established intra-African trade frameworks and examines how geopolitical tensions, including Iran-Israel conflicts and resistance to perceived neo-colonial practices, have manifested as trade barriers, sanctions, and market access restrictions.

Key findings suggest that this development poses both challenges and opportunities for regional trade structures, particularly regarding Nigeria's potential emergence as an alternative shipping hub. The research questions whether existing diplomatic and economic mechanisms can resolve these disruptions or whether they will lead to further fragmentation of Nigeria's international trade architecture. The study contributes to understanding how global shipping decisions intersect with regional economic integration and geopolitical dynamics in contemporary African trade policy.

title: Tracking Urban Sprawl Dynamics in Erbil Through Two Decades of Geospatial Analysis

detail.title: Tracking Urban Sprawl Dynamics in Erbil Through Two Decades of Geospatial Analysis
detail.abstract: Rapid urban development driven by population growth presents significant challenges in developing countries, particularly through the phenomenon of urban sprawl. This study develops a comprehensive framework for measuring and analyzing urban sprawl in Erbil, Iraq, addressing the methodological limitations that constrain traditional measurement approaches in developing regions. The research employs remote sensing (RS), geographic information systems (GIS), and Python APIs to conduct a longitudinal analysis of land-use and land-cover (LULC) changes over two decades (2000-2020). Our findings reveal that Erbil's urban expansion exhibits polycentric, linear, and scattered spatial configurations, influenced by three primary factors: rapid population growth, increasing automobile dependency (demonstrated by a 1,197% increase in vehicle registrations), and accelerated LULC transformations (evidenced by 281% growth in built-up areas). The absence of an integrated master plan and inadequate urban governance mechanisms have contributed substantially to uncontrolled sprawl patterns. This research provides critical insights for urban planners and policymakers in developing regions confronting similar urbanization challenges.

detail.abstract: This article aims to analyze and assess the impact of economic growth, electricity generation from renewable energy sources, and environmental technology patents on CO2 emissions in Morocco over the period 2000-2020 using the Vector Autoregressive (VAR) model. The results show no direct and significant causal relationship between electricity generation from renewable energy sources and CO2 emissions in Morocco. However, a causal relationship exists between economic growth, environmental technology patents, and CO2 emissions. The analysis based on impulse response functions demonstrates that CO2 emissions are not directly affected by the share of renewable electricity generation, while economic growth and environmental technology patents contribute to reducing CO2 emissions.

title: An Empirical Analysis of the US Economy Through the Lens of Financial Instability Hypothesis (1999-2022)

detail.title: An Empirical Analysis of the US Economy Through the Lens of Financial Instability Hypothesis (1999-2022)
detail.abstract: The framework of the financial instability hypothesis consists of a holistic approach to the changes within the capitalist economy of the United States and the evolution of the financial structure of the economy. Hyman Minsky always emphasized the importance of finance in the capitalist system and described finance as a constantly evolving mechanism that creates inherent stability for the economy. Minsky also proposed policy solutions to mitigate the instability caused by financial innovation and evolution. He considered the institutions within the capitalist system as the most fundamental elements regarding providing stability to the innately unstable system. However, the scope of the empirical literature on the financial instability hypothesis was narrow for a very long time and has recently been growing, specifically after the Global Financial Crisis. There are several fundamental questions: What were the shares of Ponzi, speculative, and hedge firms in an industry in the US economy between 1999 and 2022? What are the determinants of a firm in an industry becoming Ponzi? If they are already, then what is the probability of default? This article attempts to address these research questions via an empirical analysis of the major industries in the United States from the perspective of financial instability hypothesis between 1999 and 2022. The main argument of the article is that the financial fragility of the US economy has been consistently high since the early 2000s leading up to the COVID-19 pandemic and beyond. However, this article finds some conflicting and some consistent results concerning the financial instability hypothesis.

title: The Influence of Social Belonging on Adolescents' Internet and Phone Dependency

detail.title: The Influence of Social Belonging on Adolescents' Internet and Phone Dependency
detail.abstract: This study investigates the relationship between adolescents' perceptions of social belonging and their internet and phone dependency, using data from the Pew Research Center’s 2018 Teens and Technology survey. The research aims to determine whether adolescents who feel they fit in with their peers exhibit different levels of internet and phone dependency compared to those who do not. A latent variable for internet and phone dependency was constructed using factor analysis, and a regression model was employed to analyze the relationship between social belonging and dependency, controlling for variables such as gender, age, and socioeconomic status. Contrary to initial hypotheses, the study found no significant relationship between adolescents' perceptions of fitting in and their internet and phone dependency. However, gender was found to be a significant predictor, with female adolescents more likely to exhibit higher levels of dependency compared to males. The study also found that self-imposed screen time restrictions were not reliable indicators of dependency. These findings suggest that interventions aimed at reducing internet and phone dependency should focus on psychological factors such as social anxiety and self-esteem, rather than peer integration. The study contributes to the growing body of literature on adolescent internet dependency and offers practical recommendations for stakeholders, including the need for gender-specific interventions and universal programs that address underlying psychological factors.

detail.abstract: The governance of food systems increasingly demands the integration of health, ecological, and social values. Yet how expert-driven dietary guidelines navigate such expansion remains underexplored. This study addresses this knowledge gap by examining the 2023 Nordic Nutrition Recommendations (NNR2023) as a pioneering case of traditional health-focused frameworks broadening to embrace ecological sustainability and procedural transparency. Drawing on theories of framing and legitimacy, this qualitative case study analyses documentary materials and seven in-depth interviews with core NNR experts, capturing their reflective sense-making at the intersection of science, policy, and public participation. Our findings reveal that NNR2023 experts pursued legitimacy through three intertwined strategies: enhancing epistemic legitimacy via interdisciplinary recruitment and systematic evidence review; fostering procedural legitimacy through unprecedented stakeholder openness and transparency; and building cultural legitimacy through principled flexibility that accommodated Nordic food traditions. Yet these expansions generated new tensions. Maintaining scientific authority whilst integrating non-health priorities required careful frame management, whilst procedural transparency paradoxically increased both trust and vulnerability to criticism and political contestation. These findings illuminate the challenges inherent in frame expansion within contemporary governance: legitimacy emerges not as a fixed attribute but as a dynamic negotiation amongst diverse values, interests, and uncertainties. The study advances theoretical understanding of legitimation in food policy whilst offering practical insights for designing robust, contextsensitive dietary governance in an era of heightened expectations for health, sustainability, and democratic engagement.

title: Role of NDA’s in Strengthening Trade Secret Protection in India

detail.title: Role of NDA’s in Strengthening Trade Secret Protection in India
detail.abstract: Trade secrets are a crucial form of intellectual property, especially for businesses that rely on confidential processes, formulas, or client data. In India, where no standalone trade secret law exists, Non-Disclosure Agreements (NDAs) have become the primary tool for protecting such information. This research explores the role of NDAs in safeguarding trade secrets within the current Indian legal framework. It examines how courts have interpreted and enforced NDAs, and whether they are effective enough to deter misuse or unauthorized disclosure. The study looks at landmark Indian judicial decisions and compares India’s approach to international standards, including those in the U.S., EU, and China. A key focus is the practical challenges in enforcing NDAs, especially in employer-employee settings, where confidentiality is often breached. The research also considers whether relying on NDAs is enough, or if India needs a dedicated trade secret law. Based on legal analysis and comparative study, the paper proposes reforms to strengthen NDA-based protection and improve legal certainty for businesses operating in India.

detail.abstract: This study proposes a novel machine learning-enhanced three-stage slack-based measure-data envelopment analysis framework, combined with the global Malmquist productivity index to measure green total factor productivity (GTFP) globally. The framework applies Lasso regression to select different sets of environmental factors for each slack variable and employs a long shortterm memory model to estimate slack surpluses by mitigating omitted variables, multicollinearity, linearity constraints, and distributional assumptions while reducing statistical noise. Using data from 150 countries between 2011-2023, the proposed framework significantly reduces estimation bias caused by external influences in 129 countries. Results reveal uneven GTFP performance between developed and developing economies.

title: Textual and AI-based Analysis of Climate Disclosures: Evidence from the European Energy Sector

detail.title: Textual and AI-based Analysis of Climate Disclosures: Evidence from the European Energy Sector
detail.abstract: As European companies face increasing pressure to align with sustainability reporting frameworks, recent analyses of corporate disclosures reveal uneven quality, with gaps in clarity, structure, and thematic integration. This paper examines the textual structure of climaterelated financial disclosures in the European energy sector, focusing on their alignment with the Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) recommendations on governance, strategy, risk management, and metrics and targets. The analysis combines four layers: lexicometric diagnostics to assess readability and structure; AI-based BERT models to evaluate alignment; topic modeling to explore thematic organisation; and panel regressions to identify structural, financial, and cultural drivers. Results show that firms prioritize metrics and strategy over governance and risk management. Shorter, focused language improves alignment with risk disclosures, while lexical variety supports governance and strategy. Thematic analysis reveals fragmented climate narratives, suggesting limited maturity in integration. Regression results highlight that board gender diversity, ownership structure, ESG scores, EU taxonomy-aligned revenues, and cultural orientation are key drivers of TCFD alignment. These alignments are material, as each is significantly linked to firm valuation, indicating investors respond to depth and specificity of disclosures. Findings advance understanding of narrative climate disclosures and offer practical insights for assurance, benchmarking, and sustainability analysis.

detail.title: Disaster-Induced Displacement in India: Law, Policy and Practice

detail.abstract: Disaster-induced displacement is a significant and growing concern, especially in developing countries like India, exacerbated by their vulnerability to natural hazards such as floods, cyclones, droughts, and earthquakes. As climate change intensifies the frequency and severity of these events, millions are increasingly at risk of displacement, resulting in profound social, economic, and legal challenges. This paper explores disasterinduced displacement through a legal and policy lens, examining the adequacy of current frameworks in addressing the protection needs of affected populations. The paper is divided into four parts. The first part of the paper provides a foundational understanding of disaster-induced displacement, outlining its causes, consequences, and unique characteristics that distinguish it from other forms of displacement. The second part delves into international legal frameworks, such as the United Nations Guiding Principles on Internal Displacement and the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction, which outlines states' obligations in protecting those displaced by disasters. In the third part, the author discusses India's legal and policy responses towards the issue of disaster-induced displacement. The absence of dedicated legal safeguards leaves disaster-displaced individuals vulnerable to inadequate resettlement and rehabilitation measures, perpetuating cycles of vulnerability. The last part concludes the paper by emphasising the need for a more comprehensive approach to disaster-induced displacement in India.

detail.abstract: 本文提出一套以价值守恒定律 (Km=Kp) 为核心的新均衡完全内生范式，可在不依赖价格粘性或外生利率冲击的条件下，统一解释复杂宏观经济现象。该范式建立在三条互为支撑的底层公设：(1) 价值守恒定律——任一时点资本循值 Km 与生产循值 Kp 恒等，确保跨商品、跨区域、异质主体的计量等价；(2) 要素赋值结构效率——Km、Kp 的效率耦合共同决定彼此价格（购买力）-循值效率-总量信号，是异质价差与跨区价差的根源；(3) 供需动态耦合循环——货币与商品分别锚定其整条价值转移链，Km、Kp 在时间维度内持续重组，形成必然的均衡路径。由此，“货币”与“商品”不再是对立对象，而是守恒约束下的两种流动形态。通过以下文原理范式批判传统经济学围绕价格中心的均衡理论和线性加总方法论，思证异质体对于名义价格和名义一般利率的扭曲根源逻辑。

title: On the Accuracy of the H-model

detail.title: On the Accuracy of the H-model
detail.abstract: We analyse the accuracy of the H-model approximation formula and identify the full set of parameter values for which it is exact. We illustrate the effect of deviations from these and note the practical difficulty in assessing accuracy in general situations. We suggest that in modern computing environments it may be preferable to calculate the exact value. The analysis nevertheless highlights some potential avenues to explore whether more robust, yet relatively simple approximation formulas may exist.

title: Mistake of Law Defenses in Patent Law

detail.title: Mistake of Law Defenses in Patent Law
detail.abstract:
Mistake of law defenses are generally disfavored in the law, but nevertheless are sometimes permitted.  The appropriateness of the law’s purported preference against mistake of law defenses is questionable, as is its justification. In patent law, mistake of law defenses are sometimes permitted in at least two different contexts: more often such defenses are permitted to negate the willfulness required for enhanced damages; and in more limited circumstances, such defenses are permitted to negate the knowledge required for indirect infringement.  This article will explore some unsettled questions as to the proper scope of these defenses in patent law. 

While it seems that a good faith subjectively held bona fide mistake as to any patent law defense may negate willfulness for enhanced (up to treble) damages, in the context indirect infringement, the Supreme Court has made clear that mistaken beliefs in noninfringement may negate the requisite knowledge (and thus eliminate liability for indirect infringement), but that mistaken beliefs in invalidity may not.  Although the Court invoked the general principle that mistake of law defenses are disfavored in holding that mistakes as to invalidity are no defense to indirect infringement, the court did fully acknowledge or explain why at the same time it was permitting mistakes of law as to noninfringement to serve as defenses. 

The law is not currently clear as to the status of other defenses, such as patent exhaustion, license, or equitable unenforceability defenses; that is, whether a reasonable but mistake belief in these defenses could negate knowledge for indirect infringement.  This article explores these unanswered questions, gleaning what it can from caselaw and also drawing normative conclusions from academic theory and commentary on mistake of law defenses, ultimately concluding that reasonable and contemporaneously held beliefs as to some (but not all) other defenses should negate knowledge for indirect infringement.  There are also unsettled questions regarding the timing and scope of these defenses in both the enhanced damages (willfulness) and indirect infringement (knowledge) contexts.  One is whether and when the defense is or should be limited to only reasonable mistakes of law.  Another is whether and in what context a subjective belief in the defense must have been formed at a time contemporaneous with the excused infringement.  This article will address and suggest answers to these questions as well, (and more).

title: Optimal Pricing Schemes in the Presence of Social Learning and Costly Reporting
affiliations: Pennsylvania State University, Department of Economics, Students, Peking University - Guanghua School of Management and Peking University

detail.title: Optimal Pricing Schemes in the Presence of Social Learning and Costly Reporting
detail.abstract: A long-lived monopolist selling a new product of unknown quality competes with a competitive fringe offering a safe alternative with known utility. Sequentially arriving, short-lived buyers with unit demand make purchase decisions and may publicly report their realized utility. As reporting is costly, the monopolist must offer a bonus to incentivize disclosure. We work within an exponential-bandit framework and characterize the monopolist's optimal joint policy of dynamic pricing and bonus, which switches among distinct phases. Compared to the learning process led by a social planner, we find that although the monopolist's learning is terminated at the efficient cutoff, their rate of information acquisition is inefficiently slow.

title: The Impact of Government Expenditure on Economic Growth in Botswana (1990–2021)

detail.title: The Impact of Government Expenditure on Economic Growth in Botswana (1990–2021)
detail.abstract: This paper investigates the impact of government expenditure on economic growth in Botswana between 1990 and 2021. Using multiple linear regression analysis and secondary data from the World Bank, the study examines the role of public spending alongside exports, inflation, and foreign direct investment. Results show a strong positive relationship between government expenditure and economic growth, supporting Keynesian economic theory. The study concludes with policy recommendations to improve fiscal planning and resource allocation in Botswana.

detail.abstract: This paper examines the coordination between fiscal and monetary policies across 30 countries from Middle East and Central Asia (MECA) region over the period 2000-2024. The paper employs panel Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) regressions with fixed effects, incorporating interaction terms to assess the combined influence of monetary and fiscal instruments. To ensure robustness, Panel Vector Autoregression (PVAR) models are also utilized to analyze dynamic responses to policy shocks. Empirical results show that monetary tightening consistently reduces inflation, though its growth effects depend on fiscal policy alignment. Government expenditure often has an inflationary impact, while revenue-based fiscal measures contribute to both inflation control and growth enhancement. Findings indicate partial policy coordination, where fiscal consolidation reinforces monetary tightening, although in a reactive rather than institutionalized manner. Impulse responses confirm persistent inflation dynamics, with output contracting after interest rate hikes but improving with coordinated fiscal actions. Oil-exporting countries exhibit heightened volatility to monetary shocks, emphasizing the need for cautious, synchronized policies, while oil-importing countries face fiscal space constraints, limiting the effectiveness of expenditure-led growth strategies. The paper calls for the importance of strengthening institutional frameworks for macroeconomic policy coordination in MECA economies to reduce volatility, enhance policy credibility, and improve the efficacy of stabilization efforts. Proactive coordination, and improved communication between fiscal and monetary authorities are essential for fostering sustainable growth, especially in economies vulnerable to exogenous shocks and fiscal imbalances.

title: Noésologie : Pour une science Autonome de l'Intelligence dans la Renaissance Pluriverselle

detail.title: Noésologie : Pour une science Autonome de l'Intelligence dans la Renaissance Pluriverselle
detail.abstract: Cet article propose de fonder la noésologie comme une science autonome et transdisciplinaire de l'intelligence sous toutes ses formes et dimensions : humaines, sociale, artificielle, spirituelle, systémique et cosmique. A partir d'une critique des approchescognitivistes et eurocentrées dominantes, il élabore un cadre théorique associant philosophie de l'esprit, systémique, épistémologies décoloniales et cosmologies africaines. L'article soutient que la pluralité des intelligences-individuelles, collectives, non humaines et spirituelles-constitue une ressource essentielle pour les sociétés contemporaines confrontées à la complexité, aux crises systémiques et à l'urgence de refonder les savoirs. Enfin, il identifie les applications prospectives de la noésologie en santé mentale pluriverselle, leadership transsystémique et en résilience cognitive collective.

detail.abstract: This paper provides an in-depth analysis of climate scenarios and climate stress testing as essential tools for driving a sustainable transition within the global banking sector. These instruments are increasingly central to regulatory and supervisory strategies aimed at mitigating climate-related financial risks. The study begins by outlining the historical development and methodological foundations of climate scenario analysis. It then explores the pivotal role played by the Network for Greening the Financial System (NGFS), the European Central Bank (ECB), and the European Banking Authority (EBA) in the design and implementation of climate-related tools. The paper highlights key application areas, including the frequency and severity of climate impacts on financial institutions, and addresses the methodological and operational challenges involved in climate stress testing. Finally, it offers practical recommendations for the effective integration of climate scenarios into banking risk management and strategic planning frameworks, positioning them as catalysts for sustainable transformation in the financial system.

title: Insuring Against the Heat
affiliations: National University of Singapore, Nanyang Technological University (NTU), Nankai University, Nankai University - School of Finance and Nankai University

detail.title: Insuring Against the Heat
detail.abstract: We examine how households respond to heat when making health insurance decisions. Using administrative data from major insurers covering 70 percent of China's health insurance market, we show that a one-degree Celsius increase in purchaseday temperature raises uptake of critical illness insurance by 0.55 percent, and by 5.5 percent on extreme heat days. These effects fade quickly, with cancellations rising as temperatures cool. On hot days, households are also more likely to choose single-premium contracts, consistent with a commitment motive. Our findings support salience bias, as heat amplifies attention and shifts demand toward severe-risk products without affecting claims.

title: Disjunctures in Philippine History Education since the K to 12 Reform

detail.title: Disjunctures in Philippine History Education since the K to 12 Reform

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no conflict of interest.

detail.abstract: How has Philippine history education changed since the K to 12 reform that removed the Philippine history subject at the high school level and led to the institution of a mandatory Philippine history course at the tertiary level? This study assesses the disjuncture resulting from the changes instituted a decade ago by critically analyzing the relevant secondary and tertiary Philippine history course syllabi and conducting interviews with teachers implementing these new courses. The investigation reveals that the removal of a dedicated history subject in high school has led to a fragmented historical education, potentially weakening the cohesive national narrative essential for fostering a strong national identity. The subsequent introduction of a mandatory Philippine history course in tertiary education, focusing on primary sources, aims to address these gaps but presents new challenges in content adequacy and pedagogical approach. Ultimately, the study highlights the educational and identity implications of these reforms but also discusses the new Matatag Curriculum's potential to realign and enhance Philippine history education. Through this examination, the article contributes to ongoing discussions about educational policy, national identity, and the role of history education in shaping informed and engaged citizens.

title: Efficacy of Natural Farming Inputs, Botanicals and Bio Agents against Foot Rot Disease of Finger Millet Caused by Sclerotium Rolfsii
affiliations: ZARS, ZARS, ZARS, ZARS, University of Agricultural Sciences, Bangalore and ZARS

detail.title: Efficacy of Natural Farming Inputs, Botanicals and Bio Agents against Foot Rot Disease of Finger Millet Caused by Sclerotium Rolfsii
detail.abstract: An in vitro study was conducted to evaluate the efficacy of natural farming inputs, botanicals, and bio-agents against Sclerotium rolfsii using the poisoned food technique at varying concentrations (3%, 5%, and 10%). Among the natural farming inputs, Shuntiastra at 10% concentration exhibited complete (100%) inhibition of the pathogen, followed by Jeevamruta with 90.78% inhibition against Sclerotium rolfsii. Among botanicals Neem leaf extract and Pongamia leaf extract at higher concentration of 10 per cent recorded 100 per cent inhibition of the pathogen. However the combination of leaf extracts viz., Neem, Pongamia, Yekka, Tulsi and cow urine at 5 per cent also showed 100 per cent inhibition of the pathogen. Among the bio agents, Trichoderma spp. showed 72.11 per cent inhibition over control. A subsequent pot culture study under greenhouse conditions revealed that seedling treatment and soil drenching with Mancozeb 75 WP @ 0.25% recorded the lowest percent disease index (PDI) with no wilting symptoms. This was followed by seedling treatment and drenching with Trichoderma spp. @ 5%, which also demonstrated effective management of finger millet foot rot. The study highlights the potential of integrating natural inputs and biocontrol agents for sustainable disease management in finger millet.

title: Finance for All: Experimental Evidence of a Financial Literacy Program
affiliations: Nova School of Business and Economics, Stockholm School of Economics and Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System

detail.title: Finance for All: Experimental Evidence of a Financial Literacy Program

declarations.ethicsApproval: Approval by the Institutional Review Board at Nova School of Business and Economics, reference #202373, on August 14th, 2023.
declarations.funderStatement: Fidelidade.

detail.abstract: We evaluate the impact of a structured personal finance course through a randomized controlled trial involving over 5,000 adults in Portugal. Treated individuals exhibit significant improvements in financial knowledge, especially among women, low-income and financially excluded individuals, and those with low baseline literacy. The program also enhances confidence and attitudes toward personal finance, promoting more informed and effective decision-making. Treated participants are more likely to take responsibility for their financial well-being, engage in budgeting and planning, track income and expenses, and prepare for retirement. They display greater knowledge of financial assets and liabilities, increase savings and participation in financial markets, and are more likely to hold sophisticated mixed-rate mortgages while reducing reliance on costly consumer credit. Notably, they improve their knowledge of cryptocurrencies without increasing exposure. Treated participants are also less likely to experience financial distress. Our results suggest that targeted, evidence-based financial education can effectively close financial literacy gaps, even within relatively affluent populations in high-income countries.

title: The Impact of Climate Change on the Education Sector in Somalia during the Deyr Season in 2023

detail.title: The Impact of Climate Change on the Education Sector in Somalia during the Deyr Season in 2023
detail.abstract: Global warming is directly impacting the education of Somali students. This research examined the impact of climate change-induced events on the education sector in Somalia. It specifically surveys the results of the Deyr season (October-November-December) in 2023 when the El Niño and the positive Indian Ocean Dipole (pIOD) rains occurred. The Deyr season rains were the heaviest in recent memory and breached natural and artificial barriers, flooding schools and temporarily closing more than 70% of schools surveyed nationwide. The survey takers contacted school administrators from 16 out of the 18 regions of Somalia to research the effects of global warming-induced Deyr rains in 2023. The results of the study show global warming-induced rains have had an adverse impact on the education of Somali students during the Deyr season in 2023.

title: Accounting for Intergenerational Educational Immobility in Low-And Middle-Income Countries
affiliations: Friedrich-Schiller-Universität Jena and German Institute of Development and Sustainability (IDOS)

detail.title: Accounting for Intergenerational Educational Immobility in Low-And Middle-Income Countries
detail.abstract: This study investigates intergenerational educational immobility and its transmission channels in four developing countries: Ethiopia, India, Peru, and Vietnam. From data elicited throughout children's childhood, we extract latent factors of children's attributes and their environments. We decompose educational immobility by analyzing the extent to which these factors mediate intergenerational persistence. The findings show that relevant channels in developed countries are also important in these developing countries. Additionally, developing-country specific factors, such as starting a family while underage and performing child labor, play a role. The factors' importance differs moderately between the countries. Other factors-most notably non-cognitive skills-play no role.

title: The Implications of the European Commission's Funding Programs in Increasing National Safety and Security, with a Focus on the Regions Adjacent to the Danube
