As of 2024, over 80% of enterprises globally deploy AI across core business processes (McKinsey Global Survey, 2024), and AI integration into public services and
education is accelerating rapidly (OECD AI Policy Observatory, 2023). This pervasive adoption has made AI not merely a tool but a systemic agent of change—affecting everything from healthcare diagnostics to border control and school assessments.
However, with rising deployment comes rising complexity and risk. According to PwC’s Global AI Study (2024), 72% of reported AI-related failures stem not from flawed algorithms, but from organizational governance gaps—such as unclear roles, absent risk protocols, and non-existent stakeholder redress mechanisms. Meanwhile, regulatory frameworks like the EU
AI Act (Regulation 2024/1689), ISO/IEC 42001:2023, and the EU Data Act (Regulation 2023/2854) are raising the bar for legal compliance, transparency, and accountability. 
Against this backdrop, this whitepaper introduces AIGN OS—the world’s first certifiable AI Governance Operating System. AIGN OS is a governance infrastructure engineered to be auditable, modular, and globally applicable. Its seven-layer architecture operationalizes governance logic across the AI lifecycle: from principle to protocol, from compliance to certification. By integrating six sector-specific frameworks (including education, SMEs, and agentic AI), AIGN OS enables organizations to move beyond static templates and implement live governance systems.
More than a framework, AIGN OS is a verifiable trust infrastructure that makes responsible AI measurable, certifiable, and ready for regulatory inspection. It provides a unified system to align legal duties, technical oversight, cultural readiness, and stakeholder accountability—closing the gap between principle and practice. With real-world pilots in government agencies, universities, and multinational enterprises, AIGN OS marks a paradigm shift: from fragmented compliance to systemic governance-by-design.

title: The Impact of Rate Cut on the Indian Economy

detail.title: The Impact of Rate Cut on the Indian Economy

keywords: Impact of Rate Cuts on the Indian Market

detail.abstract: This report examines the Reserve Bank of India’s decision to reduce its policy repo rate by 100 basis points between February and June 2025, taking advantage of a rare “Goldilocks” environment characterized by disinflation and stable growth. Drawing on official data from the RBI, MoSPI, and leading financial institutions, it traces how lower borrowing costs have begun to filter through to banks’ lending rates and to various sectors—from professional services and agriculture to housing and MSMEs—albeit with uneven speed and depth. The analysis details the liquidity management tools deployed alongside rate cuts, including variable repo operations and open market interventions, and assesses their impact on system-wide liquidity. It further explores the effects on debt markets, where corporate bond yields and mutual fund inflows have responded positively, and on equity markets, which have seen renewed foreign and domestic investment and marked rallies in rate-sensitive sectors. Despite early signs of recovery, the report identifies persistent transmission asymmetries—especially in savings and deposit rates—and structural hurdles in long-term yield dynamics. It concludes that while further rate reductions of 25–50 basis points may be warranted if inflation remains subdued, enhancing the monetary transmission mechanism (for example, by adopting a secured overnight benchmark) will be crucial to sustain credit flow, support private consumption and investment, and preserve macroeconomic stability over the coming quarters.

title: Imperial Fault Lines: Colonial Legacy and Fertility in Sub-Saharan Africa

detail.title: Imperial Fault Lines: Colonial Legacy and Fertility in Sub-Saharan Africa

declarations.declarationOfInterest: I report no conflict of interest.

detail.abstract: Colonization has profoundly impacted the economic and financial development trajectory in the colonized countries. However, previous work has not yet explored the impact of colonization on present-day fertility outcomes in Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA). This paper investigates the influence of colonial legacy on fertility through colonial legal institutions and the identity of the colonizer. Europeans differed not just in the legal institutions they transplanted in their colonies but also in their colonial administrative policies. I use the random splitting of ethnic homelands by the colonizers in 21 SSA countries as a natural experiment to identify the causal effect of colonial institutions and policies on current fertility in SSA. I find that the colonizer's identity plays a major role in explaining current fertility outcomes. Countries colonized by Britain have nearly 19.3 percent lower fertility than those colonized by France. Lastly, I show that this differential persists through restrictive access to contraception in French colonies, a feature resulting from France's colonial 1920 law, which sought to deter contraception use and promote fertility.

title: Educational Reforms in Rwanda's Post-Genocide Recovery
affiliations: Korea International School and Korea International School

detail.title: Educational Reforms in Rwanda's Post-Genocide Recovery
detail.abstract: In the aftermath of the 1994 genocide, Rwanda undertook a comprehensive national rebuilding process where the government identified education as a crucial factor for fostering peace, economic revitalization, and social cohesion. This study examines Rwanda's demographic stabilization and educational restructuring, with a focus on their impacts such as literacy rates, public education spending, enrollment trends, and infrastructure development. According to data from the World Bank, Rwanda has consistently increased public investment in education, leading to significant improvements in national literacy levels and school accessibility (World Bank, 2004). The expansion of inclusive education for historically marginalized groups has further reinforced social integration and contributed to the formation of a more unified national identity; these educational advances played a central role in facilitating Rwanda's post-conflict recovery (The Guardian, 2011). However, the recent escalation of tensions with the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) introduces new geopolitical conflicts that threaten Rwanda's social gains achieved through these reforms (Lawal, 2024). As such, the sustainability of Rwanda's educational progress increasingly depends on the government's ability to manage emerging regional threats while maintaining internal stability.

title: The Dual-Track Universal Framework: Addressing AI Displacement and Innovation Asymmetry Through Dignity-Linked Income and Participation-Linked Innovation Currency

detail.title: The Dual-Track Universal Framework: Addressing AI Displacement and Innovation Asymmetry Through Dignity-Linked Income and Participation-Linked Innovation Currency
detail.abstract: This paper proposes the Dual-Track Universal Framework (DTUF), a two-path architecture designed to address both existential economic security and entrepreneurial opportunity in the age of AI displacement and innovation asymmetry. DTUF consists of a dignity-linked base income tied to community service and a participation-linked innovation currency that democratizes access to professional services and startup resources. Unlike traditional Universal Basic Income proposals, DTUF preserves human agency through meaningful contribution while creating systematic pathways for innovation regardless of initial wealth. The framework leverages existing institutional structures, from Small Business Administration categorizations to professional licensing requirements, to create a parallel economy that coexists with current systems rather than replacing them wholesale. Through theoretical modeling and comparative analysis, I demonstrate how DTUF addresses key limitations of existing UBI proposals while mitigating the innovation access gaps that perpetuate wealth concentration in knowledge economies.

title: The Economic Impact of INGO Withdrawal: Evidence from Afghanistan Using Nightlight Data

detail.title: The Economic Impact of INGO Withdrawal: Evidence from Afghanistan Using Nightlight Data
detail.abstract: This sudden and mass exodus of International Non-Governmental Organizations (INGOs) in Afghanistan, as witnessed in the very aftermath of defector authority coming into power in August 2021, created a major and complex structural shock in the whole economy of the nation. INGOs were part and parcel of both socioeconomic life in Afghanistan, despite their role being essentially a humanitarian aid one, they had facilitated jobs and creation of infrastructures, and market stability. Their abrupt departure broke existing supply chain, finance systems and service provision networks, causing a huge strain on local economies and livelihoods. The goal of this paper is to quantitatively measure these economic consequences of such withdrawal on the local markets of Afghanistan using an advanced Generalized Synthetic Contr ol (GSC) methodology utilizing high-frequency, monthly satellite nightlights. As a well-known proxy of the economic activity, nightlight intensity allows to determine the economic trends more timely and in a spatially fine-grained manner, which is particularly relevant in situations when the traditional data sources are obstructed by conflict or other governance issues. We have empirical evidence of the significant shrinkage in the economic performance where an estimated 16 percent of reduction in the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is expected between the year 2020 and 2022. This fall, though considerable, is not as high as earlier survey-based estimates and it could turn out that some aspects of economic activity were less troubled than imagined or even covered by other dynamics over time. In addition to aggregate GDP impacts, the stark negativity on deviations of economic performance indicators in the post-withdrawal periods are significant implications within our synthetic counterfactual analysis, along side significant inflationary pressures that continue to aggravate the cost of living burden on local populations. All in all, these findings present important empirical insights in the growing body of work investigating the employment of non-traditional economic data, i.e. satellite-derived data, on examining economic processes in post-conflict and data-poor conditions. They also provide important lessons on the intricate and disproportionate effects of the withdrawal of international aid on economies that remain vulnerable, that can serve as a guide to policy makers, development practitioners, and researchers in conflict recovery and economic resilience.

title: Econometrics Paper
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Independent and Independent

detail.title: Econometrics Paper
detail.abstract: In its continuously growing and changing job market, the tech industry holds a large variety of work options, such as remote, hybrid, and in-person work in companies from small startups to tech giants such as Google and Amazon. With such a variety in remote work opportunities and company sizes, we sought to explore the effects of these variables on salaries of tech workers, specifically in the field of data science and artificial intelligence. The data used in this study comes from AI Jobs' Data Science Salary Index with about 140,000 survey results from workers in the industry. We performed a Welch's ANOVA test to determine the statistical significance and effect size of the variables, finding that the categorical variables of remote work ratio, company size, and the combination of the two are all statistically significant with notably low effect sizes. Ultimately, the low impact of the variables presents fascinating implications for the variety of work opportunities in the data science and artificial intelligence industry.

title: Do Debt Collection Restrictions Hurt Hospitals?
affiliations: Singapore Management University - Lee Kong Chian School of Business, University of Texas at Dallas - Naveen Jindal School of Management and National University of Singapore (NUS) - NUS Business School

detail.title: Do Debt Collection Restrictions Hurt Hospitals?

declarations.declarationOfInterest: Nothing to declare.
declarations.ethicsApproval: Nothing to declare.
declarations.funderStatement: Nothing to declare.

detail.abstract: Tighter regulations on consumer debt collectors, although intended to curb predatory practices, may disrupt industries to which such debts are owed. Using a paired-county stacked difference-in-differences design, we show that these regulations adversely affect hospitals. While hospital patient volume remains unchanged, their account receivables, liabilities, and profitability deteriorate, with stronger effects for ex-ante higher financial liability and debt collector density. Hospitals respond by reducing capacity, employment, and care quality, and by steering patients to high-cost procedures. Additionally, non-profit hospitals reduce charity care for uninsured patients. Overall, ignoring spillovers of consumer financial protection laws on non-financial sectors may overstate their benefits.

title: Effects of Information and Price Promotions on Farmer Experimentation with New Maize Hybrids
affiliations: CIMMYT Kenya, International Maize and Wheat Improvement Centre, International Maize and Wheat Improvement Centre, affiliation not provided to SSRN, CIMMYT Kenya and International Maize and Wheat Improvement Centre

detail.title: Effects of Information and Price Promotions on Farmer Experimentation with New Maize Hybrids

declarations.ethicsApproval: Ethics clearance was granted by CIMMYT (IREC.2022.052) and ILRI (ILRI-IREC2023-08)
declarations.funderStatement: This research was funded by the Gates Foundation’s Seed Marketing Innovations for Africa and Accelerated Genetic Gains in Maize programs.

detail.abstract: Varietal turnover in maize seed systems in sub-Saharan Africa remains slower than expected, despite significant public and private investment in breeding and seed commercialization. Encouraging farmers to experiment with new hybrids could accelerate adoption and facilitate the replacement of outdated seed products. This study evaluates the impact of point-of-sale information and price promotions on farmer purchases of new maize hybrids in Kenya, using a randomized controlled trial with 1,790 farmers intercepted at agro-dealer shops. We tracked farmers' seed choices immediately after the intervention and again in the following season, eight months later. Informational messages that highlighted the benefits of new hybrids and recommended specific hybrids increased the likelihood that farmers purchased these seeds. Combining information with a price discount increased both the likelihood of purchase and the quantity of seed bought. Follow-up data show that discount-induced experimentation translated into continued use, suggesting that farmers were willing to pay full price after the initial trial. These findings underscore the potential of modest targeted retail interventions to overcome adoption frictions and accelerate varietal turnover.

title: Exploring the Nexus between Economic Growth, Energy Access and Population Dynamics in Sub-Saharan Africa
affiliations: Trinity University, Veritas University, Caleb University and Central Bank of Nigeria

detail.title: Exploring the Nexus between Economic Growth, Energy Access and Population Dynamics in Sub-Saharan Africa
detail.abstract: This study examines the dynamic relationships between economic growth, energy access, population growth, urbanization, and human capital in 46 Sub-Saharan African countries over the period 2000-2023. Employing the Pooled Mean Group Autoregressive Distributed Lag (PMG-ARDL) approach alongside robustness checks with Random Effects (RE) and Panel Corrected Standard Errors (PCSE), the analysis reveals significant long-run and short-run effects of urbanization, population growth, and human capital on per capita income growth. Energy access exhibits a positive but statistically insignificant long-run impact on growth, with some countries showing significant shortterm effects. The findings underscore the crucial role of enhancing human capital and managing demographic transitions to foster sustainable economic development in the region. Policy implications highlight the need for integrated strategies to expand energy infrastructure, improve education and health outcomes, and support urban planning for inclusive growth.

title: Dental Care Barriers for Autistic Individuals in Egypt: A Narrative Review

declarations.ethicsApproval: This article is a narrative review of existing literature and does not involve any new studies with human participants or animals performed by the author. Therefore, ethical approval and informed consent were not required.
declarations.funderStatement: This research received no external funding.

detail.abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is increasingly recognized in Egypt, yet dental care for individuals on the spectrum remains significantly underdeveloped. Many dental practitioners are not adequately trained to manage autistic patients, leading to miscommunication, anxiety, and limited access-particularly for adults. This narrative review explores key barriers faced by autistic individuals when seeking dental services in Egypt. Drawing on recent national and international studies, including a large-scale NIH-supported prevalence report, the review highlights deficiencies in education, access, and awareness. Findings emphasize the urgent need for improved clinical training, specialized services, and policy reform to establish inclusive and equitable dental care frameworks nationwide.

title: "The Evolution of Pohela Boishakh Celebrations in Bangladesh"

detail.title: "The Evolution of Pohela Boishakh Celebrations in Bangladesh"

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author(s) declare(s) that there are no known personal or financial relationships with any individuals or organizations that could have influenced or biased the research presented in this study.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This study did not involve human or animal subjects requiring ethics committee approval. All research procedures complied with relevant institutional and national guidelines.
declarations.funderStatement: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

detail.abstract: This study looks at how Pohela Boishakh, the Bengali New Year, has changed over time, from its roots in the 16th-century Mughal era as a farming and tax-related event to its current form as a widely celebrated cultural occasion. Based on fieldwork and archival research from 2009 to 2023, the paper shows how the festival has taken on new meanings in different periods. In the 1950s-1971, it became a way to express cultural nationalism during the fight against Pakistani rule. Later, after 1990, it turned into a modern urban celebration shaped by media, brands, and fashion. More recently, since UNESCO recognized it in 2016, it has also become a global symbol shared on social media and blended with digital rituals. This shift has sparked debates about what’s real versus what’s commercial, and how rural roots clash with urban changes. The paper shows how Pohela Boishakh brings together culture, politics, and business, and suggests ways to protect its deeper meaning while adapting to modern life.

title: Pricing Mechanisms for Multi-Indication Drugs
affiliations: Nova School of Business and Economics, Nova School of Business and Economics and Nova School of Business and Economics

detail.title: Pricing Mechanisms for Multi-Indication Drugs
detail.abstract: Multi-indication drugs pose pricing challenges, affecting therapeutic benefits and patient access. We model how a manufacturer strategically chooses clinically eligible patient populations for each indication, recognizing that broader populations increase demand but reduce expected therapeutic benefits and thus allowable prices. We identify mechanisms that induce the manufacturer to maximize total benefit while ensuring profits cannot exceed benefit generated: indication-specific prices equal to expected benefits, population-weighted uniform prices, and two-part tariffs. This holds when indications are introduced simultaneously or sequentially, provided prices fully adjust as indications are added. Price caps distort patient selection, explaining empirically observed strategies.

title: Consumer Risk from Piracy in Southeast Asia

detail.title: Consumer Risk from Piracy in Southeast Asia
detail.abstract: The aim of this Southeast Asia study is to rigorously quantify and compare the cyber risks facing consumers in the region who engage with various types of piracy services. Building on peer-reviewed methodologies, this research addresses a critical policy question: How much greater is the cybersecurity risk for Southeast Asian consumers using piracy sites compared to mainstream, legitimate platforms? To quantify the cyber risk posed by these services, this study analyzed the top 30 sites per piracy category in each country, across Streaming, Anime, Streaming Sports, P2P, IPTV, Manga, and Scam sites, using VirusTotal (with over 95 security vendors). Detections were then compared to a control group comprising each country’s 30 most popular mainstream sites. A total of 1,200 URLs were empirically analyzed using multi-vendor threat assessment. The results are stark. Under both upper bound (“best case”) and lower bound (“worst-case”) counting assumptions, piracy sites generated vastly more threat detections than legitimate sites. On average, piracy platforms presented 19.65 threat detections (best-case; mean Relative Risk ≈ 22.40×) and 26.55 detections (worst-case; mean RR ≈ 27.91×), with P2P, scam, and streaming services identified as the riskiest categories. In conclusion, this study offers granular, cross-country insights designed to inform evidence-based policy, regulatory reform, law enforcement resource allocation, and consumer education.

title: ESG Strategy for Banks: Tackling the Data Problem
affiliations: Risk Control Limited and Risk Control Limited

detail.title: ESG Strategy for Banks: Tackling the Data Problem
detail.abstract:
Banks worldwide are grappling with the problem of integrating Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) issues into their businesses. ESG provides a new criterion for judging exposures, activities and ways of working over and above the traditional basis for decision-making in banks, i.e., risk adjusted financial returns. The two are linked to the extent that ESG issues create financial vulnerabilities, for example, through climate transition risk or reputational costs. But much of the ESG impact of business activities consists of externalities, costs imposed on others that do not contribute to the firm’s own bottom line.

The preferences of investors and regulators are pushing all firms that raise capital and obey regulatory rules to take account of ESG in making their decisions. Banks are at the centre of this trend both because they depend on markets on a large scale to finance their operations and because they are tightly overseen by international regulators who are gearing up to include ESG factors in their reporting, vulnerability assessments and supervision processes.

What should a bank do to develop its ESG strategy? There are four key elements that banks must put in place. The first element is to tackle the data problem. The last three decades have witnessed a revolution in the use of data-driven, quantitative modelling within banks, to start with, inside their risk functions, but, increasingly, throughout banks’ business activities. ESG is a major challenge to banks in that it requires new ways of recording and analysing impact and then feeding information into appropriate business decision-making.

The three other elements are equally important: (i) analysing vulnerability, (ii) positioning the institution to be compliant with emerging regulations and (iii) instituting transparent and convincing reporting to the market, senior managers and regulators. But all of these rely on a resolution of the basic problem of collecting high quality data.

This note discusses the data strategy that banks should follow in implementing their broader ESG policies. Future notes will examine the three other aspects.

Future notes will examine the three other aspects.

An industry of ESG rating providers has sprung up in recent years offering ratings, scores and a variety of raw
data around the ESG performance of different companies, sectors and countries. Banks need to learn from what these providers offer, in some cases directly using the data they offer and in others devising their own data collection and analysis protocols.

Investment institutions were the first to employ ESG scores in their reporting and investment decisions and
ESG vendor offerings were in most cases initially developed for the use of investors. Now banks are beginning
to make extensive use of ESG indicators. What lessons in the use of ESG scores can banks draw from
investment firms? What pitfalls should they seek to avoid? What open issues remain?

This note is organised as follows. Section 2 explains the state of development of the ESG ratings industry.
Section 3 identifies key aspects of ESG data that banks should bear in mind. Section 4 considers open issues
that remain for banks.

title: Administrative Law Far Western University Handout by Mahesh Singh Saud

detail.title: Administrative Law Far Western University Handout by Mahesh Singh Saud
detail.abstract:
This course provides a comprehensive examination of administrative law, focusing on the principles of transparency, accountability, and good governance that are fundamental to modern public administration. It is designed to equip students with the necessary knowledge to foster an effective and just administrative system. The curriculum covers the theoretical foundations of administrative law, the classification of administrative powers, delegated legislation, the function of quasi-judicial bodies, and the scope of administrative discretion. Key emphasis is placed on the principles of natural justice, the role of the Ombudsman, anti-corruption frameworks, and legal remedies available against government actions. Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to Understand the diverse legal foundations and dimensions of modern public administration.

  • Analyze the scope and role of the judiciary in reviewing governmental functions to protect citizens' rights and ensure the legitimacy of state actions.

  • Promote the values of good governance, including accountability, transparency, and fairness, within public institutions.

  • Develop the competence to apply the principles of administrative justice in professional practice.

title: Another Bad Deal: Why the US-EU Tariff Pact is a Second Tax on Americans

detail.title: Another Bad Deal: Why the US-EU Tariff Pact is a Second Tax on Americans

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no financial or institutional conflict of interest. This work is entirely independent and does not reflect the agenda of any political party, organization, or commercial entity.
declarations.funderStatement: This research was conducted independently and did not receive any external funding.

detail.abstract: On July 27, 2025, the United States and the European Union signed a sweeping trade agreement that imposes a uniform 15% tariff on nearly all EU goods entering the U.S. market. The Trump administration hailed this as a bold step toward correcting the trade imbalance. But beneath the political headlines lies a more troubling economic truth: tariffs do not reduce trade deficits; they merely shift the cost of those deficits onto American consumers. This paper debunks the myth that tariffs punish foreign exporters and demonstrates, with data and market logic, how this agreement not only fails to achieve its stated goals-but actually increases consumer prices, fuels inflation, and may worsen the U.S. trade deficit.

title: Turning Points in Transport Emissions: Comparative Fixed-Effects Modeling of EV Incentives and Transit Investment

detail.title: Turning Points in Transport Emissions: Comparative Fixed-Effects Modeling of EV Incentives and Transit Investment
detail.abstract: The study aims to analyze carbon emission data from cities that have implemented large-scale public transportation systems or economic rebates or incentives to purchase and increase Zero-Emission Vehicle (ZEV) usage. Using a two-way fixed-effect model that integrates the Human Development Index (HDI), population density, privately owned cars, and numerous other factors, it predicts the effectiveness of two contrasting strategies in reducing carbon emissions stemming from the transport sector. The model serves as a predictive tool to determine which strategy yields better results and at what specific point. Our findings show that implementing ZEV rebates is more effective at lower values of the model, until public transportation becomes the most efficient method in semi-urban areas, before declining in effectiveness in highly urbanized cities. Policymakers should approach reducing carbon emissions from the transport sector in larger cities with a mixed approach, while rural and suburban areas may not benefit from heavy investment in public transportation.

title: Oilfield Rotations and the TWP Regime: Legal Optimisation for E&P Operators

detail.title: Oilfield Rotations and the TWP Regime: Legal Optimisation for E&P Operators
detail.abstract:
In the high-stakes environment of oil and gas exploration, operational efficiency hinges on the ability to rapidly mobilise specialist talent, often across borders and on rotation. For many Exploration & Production (E&P) operators in Nigeria, the Temporary Work Permit (TWP) regime has become the preferred platform for facilitating short-term, project-based expatriate deployments, particularly for field engineers and consultants. But, as the industry’s reliance on rotational work structures grows, so do regulatory concerns and scrutiny over compliance with immigration laws. E&P operators that exploit the TWP scheme to accommodate long-term employees in the guise of rotational staffing may face immigration penalties and disrupted operations.
This article examines how the TWP regime interacts with rotational staffing models in the oil and gas exploration sector, providing key insights for legal optimisation. It highlights the core compliance risks E&P executives should prioritise, and offers practical compliance strategies for companies to remain proactive without crossing regulatory lines.

title: Franchising Hotels in Nigeria: Legal and Regulatory Insights

detail.title: Franchising Hotels in Nigeria: Legal and Regulatory Insights
detail.abstract:
Nigeria’s hospitality and tourism sector has witnessed significant growth in recent years, influenced in part by increased domestic travel and renewed government interest in diversifying the economy beyond oil. The surge in demand for high-quality accommodation has led international and local hotel brands to turn to franchising as a vehicle for expansion.
Franchising offers hotel operators a cost-effective way to scale, leveraging the brand recognition and operational expertise of established global chains. However, expanding a hotel franchise in Nigeria involves dealing with a complex mix of legal, regulatory, and commercial considerations. From securing intellectual property rights and negotiating franchise agreements to obtaining approvals from agencies such as the National Office for Technology Acquisition and Promotion (NOTAP) and the Nigerian Investment Promotion Commission (NIPC), success depends heavily on a clear understanding of the legal landscape.
This article explores the legal pathways available to franchise operators seeking to grow their footprint in Nigeria’s hospitality industry. It highlights key structuring options, regulatory requirements, and best practices for mitigating associated risk.

title: Temperature Shocks, Cash Windfalls and Efficiency
affiliations: Technische Universität München (TUM) and Technische Universität München (TUM)

detail.title: Temperature Shocks, Cash Windfalls and Efficiency

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The authors declare that they have no relevant or material financial conflicts of interest that relate to the research described in this paper.

detail.abstract: We examine the impact of temperature-driven cash windfalls on investments in efficiency and environmental performance. Leveraging geo-coded data on temperature shocks and a rich panel of U.S. power plants from 2008 to 2021, we show that temperature shocks are a strong predictor of plant revenue. Using temperature shocks as instrument in an IV regression, we find that a 10 percent increase in cash windfalls, i.e., temperature-driven revenue changes, significantly increases capital expenditures at the plants by about 4.5 percent. We find that these investments lead to significant improvements in plant efficiency and reductions in emission intensity.

title: Sovereign Investors Manage US$55 Trillion - In Very Different Ways

detail.title: Sovereign Investors Manage US$55 Trillion - In Very Different Ways
detail.abstract:
Sovereign balance sheets and investor classifications are diverse. Country authorities typically own the global sovereign investors running $55.7 trillion in assets globally. 

But not all are equal in size and macroeconomic mandates are diverse. 

This paper reviews global data and highlight that 87% of global investing power is sitting in the top-25 countries. United States, China and Japan tops the podium.

title: Capital Floors, the Revised Sa and the Cost of Loans in Switzerland

detail.title: Capital Floors, the Revised Sa and the Cost of Loans in Switzerland
detail.abstract:
The Basel Committee has recently announced plans to revise the Standardised Approach (SA) to bank capital for credit risk and to employ the revised SA as a floor for bank capital based on internal models. Some aspects of the proposals remain unclear but it is likely that the new approaches will have a major impact on the overall level of capital and its distribution across banks and asset classes.

This paper examines the effects of the proposed changes in capital rules on the Swiss loan market. Using primarily public information, we estimate the effects on the capital of individual Swiss banks broken down by asset class. We infer what this is likely to imply for lending rates in the Swiss market.

We find that the proposed Basel rule changes would significantly boost capital for corporate and commercial mortgage exposures while capital for residential mortgages could actually fall for SA banks. This pattern of effects across asset classes is at variance with the lessons of the recent financial crisis which was triggered by the collapse of the US residential mortgage market. It is also inconsistent with current policy concerns in Switzerland where regulators have publicly expressed concern about possible overheating in the residential mortgage market.

title: When Global Markets Stir the Pen: A Synthetic Control Study of the Impacts of the 2007 Food Price Crisis on Research Agendas in Food Policy
affiliations: Tennessee State University - College of Agriculture and Vanderbilt University - Medical Center

detail.title: When Global Markets Stir the Pen: A Synthetic Control Study of the Impacts of the 2007 Food Price Crisis on Research Agendas in Food Policy

declarations.ethicsApproval: Not Applicable

detail.abstract: How do major economic shocks influence the priorities of academic research? Does the direction of scholarly inquiry pivot in response to global crises, or does it follow established trajectories? We address these questions by examining the impact of the 2007 food price crisis on the research agenda of Food Policy, one of the field's leading journals. Using topic modeling on all articles published from 1975 to 2024, we classify each publication by research theme and apply the synthetic control method to estimate the effect of the crisis on research activity related to "Trade, Pricing & Global Markets." We find a persistent increase in the share of articles devoted to trade and pricing issues beginning in 2007. The estimated effect corresponds to an average increase of 0.048 in topic share during 2007-2009, equivalent to approximately 40% rise relative to the pre-crisis baseline. Extensive placebo and robustness checks confirm that this change is unique to the crisis period and is not explained by editorial interventions or alternative specifications. The results suggest that the food price crisis served as an exogenous shock, redirecting scholarly attention toward market and price volatility. Our findings illustrate how academic research can respond to real-world events and highlight the value of synthetic control methods for analyzing shifts in the scientific literature.

title: Self-Advising: A Non-Monetary Performance Booster for Remote Workers
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and The Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK) - CUHK Business School

detail.title: Self-Advising: A Non-Monetary Performance Booster for Remote Workers
detail.abstract: The transformation of post-pandemic workspaces has created an urgent need to identify effective interventions that drive productivity in remote or virtual work environments. This paper examines whether self-advising—a practice where workers provide themselves with performance-related guidance—can improve remote workers’ productivity. Through two randomized experiments in 2022 (during the pandemic) and in 2024, online gig workers were assigned to either a baseline, advising-others, or self-advising condition and completed a real-effort task. Results demonstrate that self-advising increases performance by 5–10%, outperforming advising-others—a widely recognized performance enhancement method (Eskreis-Winkler et al. 2018, 2019)—and these improvements persist across both experimental years. The productivity gains are particularly pronounced among workers initially in the lower half of the performance distribution. Analysis of potential mechanisms suggests that heightened confidence may explain the observed improvement, whereas two alternative hypothesized channels do not. These findings underscore the potential of self-advising as a cost-effective, scalable intervention for enhancing worker productivity and confidence, offering practical insights for organizations to create an empowered culture that enhances worker productivity.

title: A Pedagogical Introduction to the Deutsch and Deutsch-Jozsa Algorithms
affiliations: Maulana Abul Kalam Azad University of Technology - Ramkrishna Mahato Government Engineering College, Purulia

detail.title: A Pedagogical Introduction to the Deutsch and Deutsch-Jozsa Algorithms
detail.abstract: The Deutsch and Deutsch-Jozsa algorithms are foundational in the study of quantum computing, providing early and elegant demonstrations of quantum speedup over classical computation. This paper offers a pedagogical exposition of both algorithms, beginning with the necessary background in quantum computation and culminating in detailed, step-by-step derivations of the algorithms, complete with mathematical formulations and circuit diagrams. Simulations using quantum gates are also discussed to enhance understanding. The aim is to make these seminal algorithms accessible to readers with a basic background in linear algebra and quantum mechanics.

title: Dynamic Interdependence between ESG and FinTech Markets: Evidence from Time-Varying and Frequency-Domain Analysis

detail.title: Dynamic Interdependence between ESG and FinTech Markets: Evidence from Time-Varying and Frequency-Domain Analysis
detail.abstract: This article examines the evolving relationship between environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investing and financial technology (FinTech), two of the principal drivers reshaping modern financial markets. Based on daily observations for the Global X FinTech ETF (FINX) and the STOXX USA ESG Select Index over 2017-2025, we employ a Time-Varying Parameter Vector Autoregressive (TVP-VAR) framework to assess return spillovers, frequency-domain dynamics, and extreme market dependencies. Our key finding demonstrates a two-way strong spillover with the Total Connectedness Index (TCI) of 75.81%, indicating deep interdependence between FinTech and ESG markets. Regarding the horizon-specific dynamics, FinTech leads short-term volatility transmission (61.67% at 1-5 days) owing to its vulnerability to high-frequency shocks. ESG acts as a long-term stabilizer (14.14% at 5+ days) with net positive spillovers (+0.43) and faster error correction. Robustness tests, including Granger causality, Johansen cointegration, and VECM, confirm these results, with ESG shocks possessing higher predictive power (F = 24.32) than FinTech (F = 18.73), t-copula analysis picks up on significant tail dependence (λₗ = 12.4%), five times higher than Gaussian models predict, pointing to higher crash risk under systemic stress. Our findings highlight the need for combined portfolio strategies to offset FinTech's short-term volatility and ESG's long-term resilience, offering critical implications for investors, regulators, and policymakers navigating this complex nexus.

title: From the Amistad to Gaza: Small States, Empire and a Political Economy of Interests

detail.title: From the Amistad to Gaza: Small States, Empire and a Political Economy of Interests

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author is the founder of Ingenio CIX, an investment intelligence company specializing in paradigm analysis and strategic market insights. This research contributes to the intellectual foundation of the company's analytical framework, though no financial compensation was received for this specific academic work. The author has no financial relationships with any Israeli defense companies, Cuban entities, or other organizations discussed in this study.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This research is based on historical analysis using publicly available archival sources, published academic literature, and government documents. No human subjects were involved, and no ethics approval was required for this documentary research.
declarations.funderStatement: This research received no external funding and was conducted independently by the author.

detail.abstract:
Using nineteenth-century Cuba and contemporary Israel as comparative cases, this article examines how sophisticated small states can achieve apparent economic success while becoming structurally dependent on conflict-driven markets. It’s dual historical and contemporary analysis of defense-driven industries demonstrates how economies that require surveillance, suppression, or state violence to flourish create dependency relationships that constrain rather than enhance sovereignty.

The analysis emphasizes a distinction between formal sovereignty (democratic institutions, legal independence) and substantive sovereignty (economic independence, autonomous decision-making capacity), arguing these can exist independently and often in tension. Drawing on Treaty of Chaumont criteria for "small states," the article shows how both Cuba under Spanish colonial rule and contemporary Israel, despite technological sophistication and global market success, exemplify patterns of economic subordination disguised as strategic advantage. Contemporary analysis of U.S. domestic security expansion suggests similar patterns may be emerging within the United States itself, as conflict-dependent growth models spread across different contexts.

The study reveals how Cuba's trajectory from maritime innovation hub to sugar monoculture, followed by chronic political instability, offers cautionary lessons for contemporary Israel's defense-linked economy. This research contributes to small states theory by offering a framework for identifying when market performance masks underlying vulnerabilities.

title: Castles
affiliations: George Mason University - Department of Economics and George Mason University - Department of Economics

detail.title: Castles

declarations.declarationOfInterest: We have nothing to declare
declarations.ethicsApproval: N/A
declarations.funderStatement: This paper builds on earlier work that was supported by the Templeton Foundation. Mark Koyama acknowledges ongoing research support from the Mercatus Center.

detail.abstract: Castles are an iconic element of how we view medieval Europe. Many of these castles were private-the possession of feudal barons, rather than of a central state. From the conventional perspective, the prevalence of private castles prevented the monopolization of violence and is thus a sign of state weakness. Drawing on the insights of James C. (Scott, 1999), we challenge this state-centric perspective. We model the role of castles in the feudal world, in which political order was not maintained by a state but, rather, a coalition of king and barons who each had their own economic and military resources. The most important resource of the baron was the castle, which rendered his holdings less legible to the king and harder to appropriate, thereby increased his bargaining power relative to the king. This, then, served as a primary check to the king's abuses and rendered his promises more credible. Castles, then, did not weaken, but rather strengthened, the feudal king's rule.

title: Response to the Revised SA Consultation BCBS 307

detail.title: Response to the Revised SA Consultation BCBS 307
detail.abstract:
This document provides comments on BCBS 307 which describes the Basel Committee’s proposals for a revised credit risk Standardised Approach (SA). Under the revised SA, the risk weights for exposures to banks, corporates and commercial and residential mortgages depend on risk indicators. Agency ratings which, when available, are the basis for corporate- and bank-exposure risk weights in the current SA would instead depend on these risk indicators.

While we see arguments in favour of reducing reliance on agency ratings in regulations and in increasing the risk sensitivity of the SA for exposures that are not rated, we are dubious that the proposed calibration, as it currently stands, represents a significant improvement on the current SA. We plan to investigate these issues of calibration in coming months but, in the meantime, we here provide some general comments and illustrative benchmarking exercises that underline contentious aspects of the current proposals.

title: From Scandal to Sunlight: How Enron's Collapse Indirectly Fueled the Rise of Solar Energy in the United States

detail.title: From Scandal to Sunlight: How Enron's Collapse Indirectly Fueled the Rise of Solar Energy in the United States

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no financial or non-financial conflicts of interest related to this manuscript.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This article does not involve human participants, personal data collection, or animal research, and therefore does not require institutional ethics approval.
declarations.funderStatement: This research was conducted independently and received no external funding.

detail.abstract: The collapse of Enron in 2001 is remembered as a historic corporate failure, but its long-term impacts extended beyond finance. This article explores how the Enron scandal, combined with the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 and the 2008 financial crisis, indirectly contributed to the rise of solar energy in the United States. By examining this sequence of events through a sustainability education lens, the article highlights how systemic failure can lead to systemic change. The case study provides a framework for teaching the intersections of trust, policy reform, and energy transitions, offering educators a new narrative for integrating financial history into environmental education.

title: Disaggregated State Theory: Reevaluation of Unitary Actor in International Relations

detail.title: Disaggregated State Theory: Reevaluation of Unitary Actor in International Relations

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no conflicts of interest.
declarations.ethicsApproval: Ethics approval was not required for this theoretical study.
declarations.funderStatement: This research received no external funding.

detail.abstract: This paper presents the Disaggregated State Theory (DST), a novel theoretical framework that challenges the unitary actor assumption in international relations. DST posits that states are not coherent, monolithic actors, but rather byproducts of competition and alliance between “power centers” which are hierarchical structures controlled by individual or collective rulers. Each power center seeks to maximize its latent power (productive and financial capacity) and, when necessary, converts this into real power (coercive capability). The theory establishes a parsimonious ontology of three units: power center, motivation, and goal. It outlines an operational model for identifying and measuring latent and real power. Four falsifiable hypotheses (Dominant Aggression, Threat Balancing, Buck-Passing, and Bandwagoning) describe expected behavior from power centers in the international system. A case study of the Iraq War (2001–2003) demonstrates DST’s explanatory power compared to traditional IR frameworks. By disaggregating the state, DST offers a more accurate and flexible tool for analyzing both conflict and cooperation in fragmented, multipolar, and postcolonial environments.

title: India's March Toward a Cashless Economy: Post-Demonetization Realities and Challenges
affiliations: Symbiosis College of Arts and Commerce

detail.title: India's March Toward a Cashless Economy: Post-Demonetization Realities and Challenges

declarations.declarationOfInterest: I declare that I have no personal or financial relationship with any person or organization that could have influenced the content, analysis, or conclusions of this study. This research was carried out independently for academic purposes.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This research is based entirely on secondary data sourced from publicly available government and institutional reports. No human participants were involved, and therefore formal ethics approval was not required.
declarations.funderStatement: This study did not receive any external funding. It was conducted as part of my MA Economics academic work at Symbiosis College of Arts and Commerce, Pune.

detail.abstract: India's shift toward a cashless economy began with an extraordinary policy move in November 2016 that changed the country's financial habits almost overnight. While the initial intention of demonetization was to address black money and counterfeit currency, it also gave an unexpected push to digital transactions. Over the years, India has seen an impressive rise in mobile-based payments, UPI usage, and fintech adoption. However, the shift is still incomplete and uneven. This paper examines how demonetization acted as a trigger for India's digital transition, assesses the opportunities and structural gains made since then, and highlights the continued challenges, particularly among low-income and rural populations. Using recent data from RBI, NPCI, and government reports up to 2024, this paper critically reflects on India's cashless journey, with a view toward sustainable and inclusive financial digitization.

title: Enabling Innovation and Protecting Consumers in the Agentic Economy: Why the Digital Fairness Act Should Regulate Agentic AI
affiliations: University of Osnabrück - European Legal Studies Institute

detail.title: Enabling Innovation and Protecting Consumers in the Agentic Economy: Why the Digital Fairness Act Should Regulate Agentic AI
detail.abstract: Agentic AI is widely seen as the next major evolution in the field of artificial intelligence. Unlike chatbots, AI agents are able to browse the web and autonomously perform multi-step tasks on behalf of users. The rise of agentic AI could have a transformational impact on the functioning of digital markets and change the way how consumers interact with digital services. This technological development coincides with a policy debate about the future of EU consumer law that could lead to the adoption of a Digital Fairness Act. Considering the rapid developments in the field of agentic AI and its potentially transformative impact on digital markets, one would expect that AI agents take centre stage in the policy debate about the future of EU consumer law. However, this is not the case. It rather seems that agentic AI is the blind spot in the policy debate leading to the Digital Fairness Act. There is a significant risk that the upcoming reform of consumer law will ignore one of the key developments in digital markets. As a consequence, the Digital Fairness Act could be outdated even before it enters into force. Against this background, this paper argues that the Digital Fairness Act should regulate agentic AI. Updating the existing regulatory framework for agentic commerce is of key importance for two reasons: It is necessary for enabling innovative agent-based business models and for protecting consumer autonomy in tomorrow's agentic economy. In this sense, ensuring that EU consumer law is "agent-ready" is essential for creating the legal infrastructure for the future of the Digital Single Market.

title: RETAINing Talent at D4M Ltd.: A Strategic Framework for Combating Burnout and Strengthening Workforce Commitment

detail.title: RETAINing Talent at D4M Ltd.: A Strategic Framework for Combating Burnout and Strengthening Workforce Commitment
detail.abstract: This research investigates the key drivers of employee retention, motivation, and burnout in the event management sector, with a specific case focus on D4M Ltd. By combining insights from recent academic literature and practical industry experience, the study identifies critical challenges and proposes actionable solutions. A central contribution of this research is the development of the RETAIN Framework—a strategic model designed to help organisations improve employee engagement, reduce burnout, and enhance long-term retention. The framework integrates core themes such as recognition, empowerment, trust, alignment, incentives, and nurturing, offering a practical toolkit for HR leaders and managers in dynamic, high-pressure industries like event management.

title: Adoption Subsidies and the Digital Divide
affiliations: Phoenix Center for Advanced Legal & Economic Public Policy Studies
