detail.abstract: Regression analysis of American Community Survey data confirms the Federal Communications Commission’s survey findings that only about one-in-five Affordable Connectivity Program (ACP) subscribers were actually new to broadband service. Using a different data source and methodology than the FCC’s direct survey of ACP participants, the analysis finds nearly identical conclusions about the program’s effectiveness in reaching unconnected households. The FCC’s survey of 5,317 ACP participants found that 21.8% had no broadband service prior to entering the program.  Here, data comparing broadband adoption rates between 2019 and 2023 across 824 counties finds the same result.

title: The PBM Profit Myth
affiliations: Phoenix Center for Advanced Legal & Economic Public Policy Studies

detail.title: The PBM Profit Myth

declarations.declarationOfInterest: No financial support was received for this study.
declarations.ethicsApproval: No approval required for this study.
declarations.funderStatement: Research provided the Phoenix Center for Advanced Economic & Public Policy Studies, a 501(c)(3) organization.
declarations.clinicalTrialRegistration: This study is not a clinical trial.

detail.abstract: Advocates calling for the regulation of Pharmacy Benefit Managers ("PBMs") often justify such interventions by claiming that not only do PBMs earn very high profits, but PBMs make more profits than even the drug manufacturers themselves. In this POLICY BULLETIN, I examine the profits of PBMs and other firms, both within and outside the healthcare industry, to determine whether high profits justify PBM regulation. I find that PBMs earn thin margins (below 5%), and that their margins are at the bottom of major healthcare sectors, comparable to Walmart's thin margins and below that of the highly competitive restaurant industry. Accusations of high profits, therefore, provide no justification for PBM regulation; claims to the contrary are easily dismissed.

title: The 5G Promise Falls Short of Reality: Examining Economic Impact Claims
affiliations: Phoenix Center for Advanced Legal & Economic Public Policy Studies

detail.title: The 5G Promise Falls Short of Reality: Examining Economic Impact Claims
detail.abstract: The mobile wireless industry has spent the past decade promoting 5G as a transformative technology that will boost the U.S. economy by over $1 trillion and create millions of jobs. Industry groups claimed 5G represented a “technological paradigm shift, akin to the shift from typewriter to computer” that will fundamentally transform American life—from healthcare and transportation to manufacturing and education. This paper analyzes federal data on 5G availability and key economic indicators across U.S. counties to test whether these sweeping promises have materialized. There is no evidence that 5G deployment has improved employment, wages, business growth, personal income, or GDP.

title: United States v. Apple: A Review of the DOJ's Case
affiliations: Auburn University - Department of Economics and Phoenix Center for Advanced Legal & Economic Public Policy Studies

detail.title: United States v. Apple: A Review of the DOJ's Case
detail.abstract: In its recent antitrust Complaint, the United States Department of Justice ("DOJ") alleges that Apple is a monopoly that suppresses competition in the smartphone market through deliberate quality degradation to raise switching costs. In this BULLETIN, we question the economic foundations of the DOJ's case. First, the DOJ mischaracterizes Apple's market position and misinterprets the effects of its business practices. Apple's global market share of less than 30%, and the uniformity of its design choices and pricing strategy, undermines the DOJ's claim that Apple's monopoly power and market share drive its design choices. Second, customer satisfaction data, including from sophisticated enterprise users, contradict allegations of quality degradation. Third, Apple's pricing is stable over time, and its profit margins are comparable to industry standards, refuting claims of price increases and extraordinary profits. Fourth, Apple's higher U.S. market share is better explained by income levels than anticompetitive practices. Fifth, the economic literature on switching costs reveals ambiguous implications for competition, further weakening the DOJ's position. Given the allegations contained in the Complaint, we conclude that the DOJ's antitrust case against Apple lacks strong economic support.

title: A War on Low Prescription Prices: Regulating PBMs and the Effect on Drug Prices
affiliations: Auburn University - Department of Economics, Phoenix Center for Advanced Legal & Economic Public Policy Studies and Auburn University - Department of Economics

detail.title: A War on Low Prescription Prices: Regulating PBMs and the Effect on Drug Prices

declarations.declarationOfInterest: No funding received for this study.
declarations.ethicsApproval: No approval required.
declarations.funderStatement: Study funded by the Phoenix Center for Advanced Legal & Economic Public Policy Studies.

detail.abstract: Entities that negotiate for lower prices for their customers are not friends of sellers. Nowhere is this more transparent than in the pharmaceutical industry, where Pharmacy Benefit Managers (“PBMs”)—who are hired by insurance companies and other sponsors to reduce drug costs—negotiate price concessions from pharmaceutical manufacturers. This paper demonstrates that PBMs effectively reduce prescription drug costs for consumers by negotiating with pharmaceutical manufacturers from positions of greater leverage than individual insurers or plan sponsors could achieve. The paper presents both theoretical economic models and empirical evidence showing that PBMs secure substantial price concessions from drug manufacturers, particularly for medications with limited therapeutic competition. Proposed regulations aimed at restricting PBM practices will undermine PBMs’ effectiveness at cost containment, resulting in higher prescription drug prices for consumers, increased profits for pharmaceutical manufacturers, and reduced market efficiency.

title: The Unseen Influence: How Conversational Framing Shapes Efficiency in Dhaka's Rickshaw Fare Negotiations

detail.title: The Unseen Influence: How Conversational Framing Shapes Efficiency in Dhaka's Rickshaw Fare Negotiations
detail.abstract: Navigating Dhaka's ubiquitous rickshaw system often involves daily fare negotiations, a common yet unpredictable economic interaction. This research investigated whether a subtle shift in passenger communication could enhance the efficiency of these micro-negotiations. Using a quasi-experimental design conducted from March to July 2025 in Bashundhara R/A, the study compared two conversational approaches for a fixed 2-kilometer route: a direct fare request versus one framed with "it's quite close." Findings revealed that the "Framed Approach" significantly reduced negotiation attempts, requiring an average of 2.56 rickshaws hailed compared to 3.04 for the "Direct Approach"-a 15.79% improvement. This highlights how a few well-chosen words can lead to tangible time savings and greater operational efficiency in informal urban economies. The study offers practical insights for commuters and provides real-world validation of behavioral economics principles, specifically framing effects, demonstrating their powerful influence on everyday economic outcomes. The study demonstrates the framing effect's strong influence on daily decision-making and resource allocation while offering crucial, useful commuter strategies and solid, empirical validation of behavioral economics concepts.

title: Meddling with Platforms: Can Antitrust or Regulatory Interventions in Platform Design Improve Economic Welfare?
affiliations: Auburn University - Department of Economics, Phoenix Center for Advanced Legal & Economic Public Policy Studies and Auburn University - Department of Economics

detail.title: Meddling with Platforms: Can Antitrust or Regulatory Interventions in Platform Design Improve Economic Welfare?
detail.abstract: In several contemporary enforcement actions brought by federal and state governments against digital platforms, antitrust law is being applied in a manner that is less about mitigating market power and cognizable consumer harm and more as a means by which the government can regulate certain aspects of digital platforms' policies and practices. The complex interplay of factors within multidimensional processes, like those governing two-sided platforms, presents a unique challenge for antitrust policy. In this BULLETIN, we explore within a theoretical framework whether government interference with certain aspects of such processes can ultimately undermine social welfare. It does, as such meddling fails recognize the intricate dynamics at play. Without government intervention, a retail platform searches for a balanced approach to competing interests and does so in the most efficient way. Interfering with those choices must, therefore, lead to a less efficient solution, thereby reducing economic welfare across all participants.

title: Testing Clustered Equal Predictive Ability with Unknown Clusters
affiliations: Université de Bourgogne - Laboratoire d'Economie de Dijon (LEDI), ERMES (CNRS), Université Panthéon-Assas Paris II, Centre for Econometric Analysis, Faculty of Finance, Bayes Business School (formerly Cass), London, UK  and Singapore Management University

detail.title: Testing Clustered Equal Predictive Ability with Unknown Clusters
detail.abstract: This paper proposes a selective inference procedure for testing equal predictive ability in panel data settings with unknown heterogeneity. The framework allows predictive performance to vary across unobserved clusters and accounts for the datadriven selection of these clusters using the Panel Kmeans Algorithm. A post-selection Wald-type statistic is constructed, and valid p-values are derived under general forms of autocorrelation and cross-sectional dependence in forecast loss differentials. The method accommodates conditioning on covariates or common factors and permits both strong and weak dependence across units. Simulations demonstrate the finitesample validity of the procedure and show that it has very high power. An empirical application to exchange rate forecasting using machine learning methods illustrates the practical relevance of accounting for unknown clusters in forecast evaluation.

title: Reflecting on the Significance of the Concept "Advice" in the Determination of Bank Liability in Cameroon

detail.title: Reflecting on the Significance of the Concept "Advice" in the Determination of Bank Liability in Cameroon
detail.abstract: Bancarisation, the rise and continuous development of sophisticated banking products and services coupled with the need to increase liquidity, security and profitability of banking customer’s investments, especially those in business has incited the CEMAC legislator to develop rules to protect bank clients. This is perceived in various CEMAC regulations that have enlarged the scope of liability of credit establishments through the concept “advice”. Though, it is wondered whether such advice is simply a statutory obligation or a banking operation. With this visible legal uncertainty in place, this work seeks to find out the place the term “advice” has in the determination of bank liability in Cameroon. By considering bank advice as a statutory obligation and as a banking operation, findings reveal that, although the Cameroonian legislator addresses issues of bank liability deriving from the obligation of advice, it is still corrigible. As such indicating the need for legal certainty in this area.

title: Neuroeconomics of Risk: Brain Based Financial Decision Making in Emerging Markets

detail.title: Neuroeconomics of Risk: Brain Based Financial Decision Making in Emerging Markets
detail.abstract: This paper examines financial decisions when dealing with risk in an emerging market setting, with a specific focus on Azerbaijan. It approaches the topic from a neuroeconomic perspective (a field that brings together ideas from neuroscience, psychology, and economics) to better understand how people think about money and risk. Unlike most neuroeconomics studies that focus on individuals in developed countries, this research shifts attention to the behavioral patterns seen in a different cultural and economic environment. Data was gathered through a Google Forms survey, targeting Azerbaijani participants, to understand how they perceive financial risk and uncertainty in their daily lives. Although the study does not include direct brain-based measurements, it uses neuroeconomic theory to interpret people's choices and reasoning. The findings aim to shed light on how local economic conditions, cultural expectations, and uncertainty influence behaviour. These insights may help inform financial education efforts, policymaking, and the design of models that are more relevant to emerging markets. This paper is an independent research project conducted solely by the author.

title: Refocusing the FCC's Section 706 Reports
affiliations: Phoenix Center for Advanced Legal & Economic Public Policy Studies

detail.title: Refocusing the FCC's Section 706 Reports
detail.abstract: Section 706 of the Telecommunications Act directs the Federal Communications Commission to conduct an annual inquiry to “determine whether advanced telecommunications capability is being deployed to all Americans in a reasonable and timely fashion.” However, over the years these Section 706 Reports have been plagued by partisan interpretations and have failed to address the core issues behind broadband deployment gaps.  This paper proposes a fundamental reframing of how the FCC conducts these annual Section 706 inquiries by redefining “reasonable and timely” deployment as a question of whether government policy effectively and promptly enhances economic incentives in areas where the market alone won’t support deployment.

title: Tactical Allocation for Vanguard Investors: A Defensive Strategy for Retirement Portfolios
affiliations: Independent Researcher in Systematic Investing and Risk Management

detail.title: Tactical Allocation for Vanguard Investors: A Defensive Strategy for Retirement Portfolios
detail.abstract: This paper introduces a streamlined, transparent, and empirically grounded tactical allocation strategy tailored for retirement-focused investors. The model rotates among four distinguished mutual funds available through Vanguard's platform: Vanguard Wellington (VWELX), Vanguard Wellesley Income (VWINX), Permanent Portfolio Fund (PRPFX), and Vanguard Market Neutral (VMNFX). These funds span diverse economic exposures-growth, income, inflation protection, and market neutrality-and the allocation is evaluated bimonthly using a dual momentum framework. From January 2000 through June 2025, the model delivered a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 6.16% with volatility of just 4.09%, achieving a Sharpe ratio of 1.02 and a worst calendar year return of-1.87%. Its low drawdowns significantly outperformed both equal-weight blends and the Vanguard Balanced (60/40) portfolio. Fully rules-based and composed of no-load, low-cost funds, the strategy is easily executed using end-of-month data. The long tenures of the component funds-with inception dates ranging from 1929 to 1998-lend institutional-grade credibility and out-of-sample robustness. In plain terms, this strategy offers a simple way to help retirement investors avoid deep losses and stay invested through market turbulence. By rotating among a small number of proven mutual funds based on performance trends, it delivers steadier returns with less risk-no Wall Street complexity required.

title: Does Severance Pay Prolong Unemployment? Evidence from Micro-level Survey in Myanmar's Crises
affiliations: Universitas Gadjah Mada (UGM) - Faculty of Economics and Business (FEB), Universitas Gadjah Mada (UGM) - Faculty of Economics and Business (FEB) and International Labour Organization, Indonesia

detail.title: Does Severance Pay Prolong Unemployment? Evidence from Micro-level Survey in Myanmar's Crises

declarations.funderStatement: This paper is made possible with the Research Grant from the Faculty of Economics and Business, Universitas Gadjah Mada, Indonesia with grant number 3069/UN1/EK/UJM/LT/2024

detail.abstract: This study examines the impact of severance payments on unemployment duration and reemployment quality in Myanmar's labour market, using data from an ILO survey conducted in May-June 2022. The analysis accounts for the long-term effects of the COVID-19 pandemic and the February 2021 military coup. Cox regression results indicate that severance payments significantly extend unemployment duration, particularly for women, as confirmed by Kaplan-Meier survival curves. A multinomial logit analysis reveals that women and rural workers are less likely to secure reemployment, while higher education correlates with longer unemployment and reduced chance of reemployment. To address right-censoring, additional Cox regression for reemployed individuals validates the robustness of the severance effect. Notably, individuals unemployed and reemployed after the coup experienced shorter unemployment durations, likely reflecting structural labour market shifts. While severance payments provide a financial buffer for job matching, they risk prolonging unemployment among vulnerable groups. Policymakers should prioritize job search assistance, retraining, and employment initiatives for women and rural workers in politically and economically unstable regions. Further research should explore the pathways through which political turmoil influences labour market outcomes.

title: From Harvest to Offering: The Symbolism of Pumpkin in Kodava Sankramana Celebrations

detail.title: From Harvest to Offering: The Symbolism of Pumpkin in Kodava Sankramana Celebrations
detail.abstract: Among the Kodava community of Kodagu, Karnataka, the celebration of Cauvery Sankramana is more than just a festival it is a deeply spiritual event that reflects their connection to nature, ancestry, and tradition. Central to this celebration is a humble yet meaningful dish: pumpkin curry (Kumbala Curry). This study explores why this particular dish holds such significance during the festival and what it represents in the larger cultural context. Cauvery Sankramana marks the believed emergence of River Cauvery at Talacauvery, and on this sacred day, Kodavas prepare simple vegetarian meals, with pumpkin curry being the most prominent. Through interviews with community members, observation of rituals, and exploration of oral histories, this research uncovers how pumpkin transforms from a seasonal harvest into a symbol of purity, gratitude, and devotion. The study finds that the use of pumpkin is not only practical, being readily available during the season but also symbolic of prosperity, humility, and spiritual cleansing. Preparing and offering the curry becomes an act of reverence to Goddess Cauvery, while also strengthening family bonds and passing on cultural values to the next generation. In a time when many traditions face the risk of fading, this simple ritual stands as a powerful reminder of how food can carry stories, beliefs, and identities. The Kodava community's Sankramana celebration is a beautiful example of how everyday ingredients can become sacred, linking people to the land, to the divine, and to each other.

title: Tourism and Economic Growth in Small Island Developing States (SIDS): A Case-Based Review of Maldives, Seychelles, and Sri Lanka

detail.title: Tourism and Economic Growth in Small Island Developing States (SIDS): A Case-Based Review of Maldives, Seychelles, and Sri Lanka
detail.abstract: Tourism is a cornerstone of economic development in Small Island Developing States (SIDS), providing critical revenue, employment, and foreign exchange. However, the sector's overreliance also exposes these economies to global shocks, environmental vulnerabilities, and structural limitations. This study undertakes a comprehensive secondary analysis of the economic impacts of tourism in three representative SIDS, Maldives, Seychelles, and Sri Lanka. Drawing on data from international organizations (UNWTO, World Bank, IMF) and peerreviewed literature, the paper examines tourism's contribution to GDP, employment, export earnings, and its role in national development strategies. The analysis reveals that while tourism acts as a major driver of growth, it is accompanied by risks such as economic leakage, environmental degradation, seasonality, and exposure to pandemics and climate change. Casebased comparisons highlight how policy frameworks, investment models, and sustainability practices influence tourism's effectiveness as a development tool. The paper concludes by proposing integrated, resilience-oriented strategies for SIDS to enhance tourism's benefits while mitigating long-term risks, emphasizing diversification, sustainable resource management, and regional cooperation.

title: Strategic Pricing and Competition: Applying Game Theory and Nash Equilibrium in Modern Markets

detail.title: Strategic Pricing and Competition: Applying Game Theory and Nash Equilibrium in Modern Markets
detail.abstract: This paper explores how game theory and Nash equilibrium work in three different markets: Azerbaijan's mobile operator companies, banks setting interest rates, and OPEC's oil production decisions. By looking closely at each case, the study shows how companies and countries watch each other's moves and respond in ways that create a balance between making money and keeping the market stable. For example, Azerbaijan's mobile operators seem to follow similar pricing strategies without directly agreeing, while dealing with public reactions and their reputations. Banks tend to keep interest rates steady because no one wants to start a price war that hurts everyone. In the case of OPEC countries work together behind the scenes to manage oil production and keep prices stable worldwide. Overall, the research highlights how important timing, communication, and understanding competitors' actions are in making smart business decisions. Such insights are crucial for helping policymakers and business leaders effectively manage challenges in dynamic market settings. This study represents the author's independent research work Methodology: This research uses a qualitative approach based on library research and case analysis. Academic sources and economics textbooks were reviewed to understand the key concepts of game theory and price competition. The author used AI tools to assist with language editing. However, all the research design, analysis, and conclusions are the sole work of the author. In addition, the study includes a public data review using web-based sources such as official operator websites, news reports, and social media responses to analyze and compare the pricing strategies of mobile operators in Azerbaijan, interest ratesetting behavior in the banking sector, oil production coordination among OPEC countries. The research is interpretive in nature and aims to connect theoretical models with real-life market dynamics.

title: The Role of Lawyers in Ensuring Canadian Corporate Law Attracts Investment
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: The Role of Lawyers in Ensuring Canadian Corporate Law Attracts Investment

contentType.other: Forthcoming in the Dicey Law Review and Supreme Court Law Review

detail.abstract:
Jurisdictions around the world are consistently competing to attract foreign investment through policymaking and law. Topically, the threat of American tariffs has amplified a potential opportunity to create an appealing investment environment in Canada. In this paper, we argue that Canadian governments need to critically evaluate existing corporate and securities statutes to ascertain whether they provide a net benefit or act as a deterrent in the global competition for capital. However, the government is not the only stakeholder that is responsible for this evaluation. The legal profession has an obligation to engage in continual and meaningful review of Canadian corporate and securities laws to establish a stable, predictable, and responsive corporate and securities law system. Undoubtedly, this involves striking a balance. To ensure that this reform is effective, we suggest adopting the Delaware practice of instituting an annual review of corporate and securities laws by a council composed of distinguished transactional lawyers and commercial litigators.

 

In order to demonstrate the need for such a reform, the paper proceeds in three core stages. First, we discuss discrete examples of uncertainty present in Canadian corporate and securities law. Within this section, we specifically discuss the following: (i) director and officer liability under the relevant legislation and common law; (ii) the oppression remedy under the relevant legislation and common law; and (iii) the Ontario Securities Commission’s public interest power under the relevant legislation. The purpose of this discussion is to demonstrate the need for a holistic review to assess the impact of corporate and securities laws on the attraction and retention of investment. The second part of this paper articulates the legislative reform process in Delaware, which discusses the following key pillars: (i) the judiciary; (ii) the legislature and Delaware General Corporation Law; (ii) the Governor and Secretary of State’s office; and (iv) the state bar. Each of these entities works in harmony to create a unique balance between modernizing applicable corporate law and maintaining stability in the Delaware corporate legal system. Third, this paper recommends a reform proposal applicable to the Canadian context. Ultimately, we recommend the establishment of provincial Corporate Law Councils to undertake regular reviews of each jurisdiction’s corporate and securities laws to ensure they attract and maintain investment.

title: Value My Care, Safeguard Your Fare: CEO Inside Debt Holdings and Wage Theft
affiliations: University of Exeter, Hong Kong Polytechnic University - School of Accounting and Finance, Lingnan University and Hong Kong Polytechnic University - School of Accounting and Finance

detail.title: Value My Care, Safeguard Your Fare: CEO Inside Debt Holdings and Wage Theft
detail.abstract: We provide compelling evidence that wage theft is less prevalent in firms with large CEO inside debt holdings. These findings align with the view that CEOs who have substantial inside debt holdings are more attuned to the adverse effects of wage theft on their payoffs. This heightened sensitivity incentivizes them to promote fair compensation policies. To establish causality, we conduct a difference-indifferences analysis around the implementation of the Internal Revenue Code Section 409A Final Regulation and an instrumental variable estimation. Cross-sectional analyses reveal that the negative effect of CEO inside debt on wage theft is stronger in firms led by more risk-averse CEOs but attenuated in the presence of greater union coverage and greater proportions of secured debt. Supplemental evidence indicates that CEO inside debt leads to an increase in firms' overall payroll costs, while wage theft has a negative effect on firm performance.

title: Eco-Tourism Taxation in Island Economies: A Review of Equity and Efficiency

detail.title: Eco-Tourism Taxation in Island Economies: A Review of Equity and Efficiency
detail.abstract: Eco-tourism has gained increasing prominence as a sustainable development strategy, particularly within island economies that are highly dependent on tourism yet face significant environmental vulnerabilities. The delicate balance between promoting economic growth through tourism and conserving fragile ecosystems has led policymakers to adopt eco-tourism taxation as a fiscal tool aimed at mitigating environmental degradation while generating government revenue. This research paper offers a comprehensive review of eco-tourism taxation policies in island economies, focusing on two critical dimensions: equity and efficiency. Equity is examined by analyzing how tax burdens and benefits are distributed among different stakeholders, including local communities, businesses, and tourists. Efficiency is evaluated based on the ability of eco-tourism taxes to correct market failures, reduce negative externalities, and support environmental sustainability without imposing excessive economic costs. Utilizing a secondary research approach, this paper synthesizes insights from academic literature, government reports, and case studies of island nations such as Belize, Palau, and Seychelles. The findings reveal that while eco-tourism taxes can enhance environmental outcomes and provide sustainable financing for conservation efforts, their success largely depends on context-specific factors such as tax design, implementation capacity, and stakeholder engagement. The study underscores the importance of transparent and participatory policy frameworks to ensure that taxation mechanisms align with local social, economic, and ecological realities. Finally, the paper identifies gaps in current research and policy practice, advocating for further empirical evaluations and adaptive management strategies to enhance the effectiveness of eco-tourism taxation in island economies.

detail.title: Belgian Wealth Inequality, 1935-2022

publicationDetails.detailsText: National Bank of Belgium. Working paper 477.

detail.abstract: In the absence of a wealth register, Belgian wealth inequality needs to be estimated. Here I apply the mortality multiplier approach to Belgian inheritance tax tabulations and administrative microdata, collectively covering 1935 to 2022. Belgian wealth inequality has strongly declined during the 20th century and seems relatively stable in recent years. I triangulate my estimates with national accounts aggregates and previous work on Belgian wealth inequality. The evolution of Belgian wealth inequality is in line with other European countries for which long-run estimates are available.

title: Competitiveness Analysis of Uzbekistan's Grape Export (2017-2023)

detail.title: Competitiveness Analysis of Uzbekistan's Grape Export (2017-2023)
detail.abstract: This research analyzes Uzbekistan's export competitiveness of grapes (2017-2023) using RCA and Vollrath indices. Uzbekistan was competitive (RCA>1) until 2022, but the exports of fresh grapes declined by 57% in 2023, and RCA decreased from 39.3 to 16.4. This fall was due to outside influences like Russia-Ukraine conflict impacts on the large Russian market (absorbing 80.3% of exports) and COVID-19 supply chain disruption combined with regional issues of crop policy reforms and climate uncertainty. The findings indicate RCA's shortfall in assessing geopolitical risks to support Vollrath's integrated strategy. The study offers policymakers insights on enhancing export resilience through market diversification, value chain upgradation, and human capital enhancement. The case impacts farm export-dependent economies that are subject to the global market.

title: Crimes Against Humanity: Repairing Title 18's Blind Spots

detail.title: Crimes Against Humanity: Repairing Title 18's Blind Spots

declarations.declarationOfInterest: None
declarations.ethicsApproval: N/A
declarations.funderStatement: I was a salaried professor at the time of authorship.

detail.abstract: This chapter, part of a festschrift devoted to the incomparable Professor William Schabas, argues that Congress should enact a crimes against humanity statute to fill a gap in the United States’ federal penal code.  The author helped implement President Barack Obama’s atrocities prevention initiative, a key element of which was a concerted interagency effort to improve the United States’ ability to prosecute atrocity crimes by closing gaps in the U.S. penal and immigration codes and preventing the United States from serving as a safe haven for abusers. A number of such gaps significantly hinder the reach of the United States’ prosecutor authorities, and have led to instances of impunity, and incomplete accountability, where perpetrators in our midst cannot be prosecuted for their substantive crimes and must be dealt with through immigration and other remedies—a second best option when crimes against humanity are at issue.  The chapter argues that strengthening prosecutorial authorities in the service of atrocities prevention and response has historically enjoyed strong bipartisan support. The chapter describes prior unsuccessful efforts to draft international crimes legislation, proposing and evaluating various elements based upon previous draft bills, international criminal law and jurisprudence, and other cognate federal statutes. It demonstrates that the United States can implement the proposed legislative changes and exercise leadership in atrocities prevention and response without increasing the risk that U.S. personnel or service members will be subject to litigation overseas.

title: Impact of Renewable Energy Production on Thermal Generation and Electricity Pricing Dynamics in India: A Comprehensive Market Analysis Using IEX and Grid India Data (2014-2024)

detail.title: Impact of Renewable Energy Production on Thermal Generation and Electricity Pricing Dynamics in India: A Comprehensive Market Analysis Using IEX and Grid India Data (2014-2024)

declarations.funderStatement: This research received no external funding. The work was independently conducted and self-funded by the author.

detail.abstract: This study examines renewable energy integration impacts on India's thermal generation and electricity pricing using comprehensive datasets from Grid India (4,103 daily records, 2014-2025) and Indian Energy Exchange (8,352 15-minute intervals, 2025). We employ comprehensive statistical analysis including correlation analysis, time series decomposition, and descriptive statistics to quantify relationships between variable renewable energy penetration and market clearing prices. Key findings reveal median electricity prices of ₹5,847/MWh with a range of ₹200-10,000/MWh. Solar generation achieved exponential growth from 0 MU in 2014 to 445 MU daily by 2024, contributing to an average renewable penetration of 19.73% (peak 47.4%). Strong negative correlation (r =-0.670, p < 0.001, 95% CI: [-0.683,-0.657]) exists between renewable generation and market prices, with thermal displacement averaging 74.2% during peak renewable periods. Statistical analysis demonstrates renewables explain 44.9% of hourly price variance (Adj. R² = 0.449, F(1,7305) = 5959.23, p < 0.001), confirming merit-order effects and emergent duck curve phenomena. All correlations were tested for multiple comparisons using Bonferroni correction, maintaining statistical significance. Findings support India's 500 GW renewable target by 2030, indicating successful market integration with manageable price volatility. Results inform policy frameworks for enhanced grid flexibility and market design reforms.

title: The Optimal Threshold for Drug Decriminalization: A Game-Theoretic Model *

detail.title: The Optimal Threshold for Drug Decriminalization: A Game-Theoretic Model *

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no conflict of interest.
declarations.funderStatement: The author receives no funding for this research.

detail.abstract: Despite growing interest in drug decriminalization, existing studies on decriminalization thresholds often rely on qualitative reasoning, resulting in unclear and often conflicting policy recommendations. This paper develops a dynamic game-theoretic model, grounded in the Beckerian economics of crime, to examine strategic interactions between the state and a representative drug dealer. In this framework, the state first sets the decriminalization threshold and penalty level, while the dealer later chooses the profit-maximizing drug quantity. The subgame perfect Nash equilibrium yields several key implications: the optimal threshold should always exceed average personal consumption, whilst penalties must remain harsh. In light of the theoretical result, the current methamphetamine threshold of 0.02 grams in Thailand should be increased by at least sixtyfold to approximately 1.2 grams, an amount on par with standards in Canada, the Czech Republic, and Portugal.

title: The Role of Virtual Reality (VR) in Enhancing Sustainable Tourism Experiences: A Secondary Research Review

detail.title: The Role of Virtual Reality (VR) in Enhancing Sustainable Tourism Experiences: A Secondary Research Review
detail.abstract: The tourism industry faces mounting challenges related to environmental degradation, overtourism, and socio-cultural impacts, necessitating innovative approaches to sustainability. This paper critically reviews secondary literature on the application of Virtual Reality (VR) technology as a tool to enhance sustainable tourism practices. VR's capacity to provide immersive and interactive virtual experiences presents an opportunity to reduce physical travel demand, thereby lowering associated carbon emissions and minimizing pressure on vulnerable destinations. Furthermore, VR facilitates environmental education and fosters responsible visitor behavior by enabling experiential learning in simulated settings. Despite its promise, barriers such as high technology costs, limited accessibility, and the inability to fully replicate the multisensory dimensions of in-person travel constrain VR's widespread adoption. This review underscores the need for further empirical research to evaluate VR's long-term effectiveness in influencing tourist behavior and to develop inclusive, cost-effective VR solutions. The integration of VR into sustainable tourism strategies could play a critical role in balancing tourism growth with environmental and socio-cultural preservation.

title: Economic Transitions and Gender Empowerment in Coastal Bangladesh: Pathways to Resilience in the Face of Climate Change

detail.title: Economic Transitions and Gender Empowerment in Coastal Bangladesh: Pathways to Resilience in the Face of Climate Change
detail.abstract: This article critically examines the interplay between economic transformations, gender empowerment, and climate adaptation in the context of coastal Bangladesh. Drawing from macroeconomic shifts-particularly the rise of the ready-made garment (RMG) sector-and regional climate-induced livelihood challenges, it outlines the necessity of an integrated development strategy. Insights from private-sector collaboration, local innovation ecosystems, and youth-led entrepreneurship inform the analysis, offering globally adaptable solutions for building resilience in vulnerable communities.

detail.abstract: This is a book review of a compelling account by Professor Ronald Slye of his time serving as the only non-African commissioner on the Kenyan Truth, Justice and Reconciliation Commission, established following the 2007-8 post-election violence. The book is part poignant memoir and part essential reading on the theory and practice of transitional justice, particularly given that the Kenyan TJRC featured a number of important innovations in institutional design, evidentiary practices, the integration of feminist theory, and procedural best practices that will no doubt inform future efforts. The books is also, in many respects, an exercise in setting the record straight in light of several scandals that rocked the work of the Commission.  Slye juxtaposes his work on the Commission against efforts at the International Criminal Court to pursue criminal accountability and offers a postmortem of the Kenyan cases, all dismissed under various grounds following rampant witness intimidation.

title: Industrial Security Policy Application in High Tech Defense Industry

detail.title: Industrial Security Policy Application in High Tech Defense Industry
detail.abstract: Industrial security policies governing the execution of defense industry security programs are poorly aligned to the security management methods of the growing influx of high-tech defense contractors and the expansion of government classified cloud computing services. Organizational characteristics of large and highly matrixed technology companies present challenges in aligning corporate security methods with industrial security requirements. Investigative comparison of leading security management methods against industrial security policies, coupled with surveying of current practitioners will allude to the challenges and opportunities. Survey respondents generally agree that industrial security policies are challenging to implement in the tech space. Greater public-private partnership is necessary to advance the union between defense policy and the advancing standardization and adoption of security management doctrine and best practices. Security thought leaders and industry partner organizations must continue to proactively craft policy and doctrine to ensure security methods are uniform across industry and that protective programs achieve the greatest level of uniformity and adoption to safeguard the defense industrial base mission.

title: Governance in Transition: Sectoral Resistance and the Political Ecology of Sustainable Development in Greece and the United Kingdom

detail.title: Governance in Transition: Sectoral Resistance and the Political Ecology of Sustainable Development in Greece and the United Kingdom
detail.abstract: Climate change and ecosystem degradation are urgent global issues with profound political and socioeconomic implications. This paper investigates how sustainable development policies in Greece and the UK align with or conflict with the interests of key sectorsagriculture/fishery, energy, and tourism-and their stakeholders. Using a qualitative comparative case-study approach and stakeholder mapping, we examine how governance structures, political dynamics, and interest-group coalitions shape sectoral sustainability outcomes. We find that entrenched interests often resist change unless policies are backed by incentives or compensation, and that political leadership can tip the balance. In energy, decarbonization is underway in both countries, but timelines and resistance vary. Tourism policy advances when ecological goals align with business incentives but slows under perceived trade-offs. The analysis contributes to political ecology by showing how institutional arrangements and power dynamics mediate sustainability outcomes. Practically, we offer governance lessons: effective policy must be adaptive, multi-level, and participatory.

title: Debunking the Dependency Trap: An Econometric Analysis of Welfare Schemes and Labor Force Participation in Tamil Nadu's Dravidian Model

detail.title: Debunking the Dependency Trap: An Econometric Analysis of Welfare Schemes and Labor Force Participation in Tamil Nadu's Dravidian Model
detail.abstract: The global discourse on social welfare is dominated by the "dependency trap" hypothesis, which posits that subsidies disincentivize work. This study provides a robust empirical counter-narrative by examining the impact of Tamil Nadu's extensive welfare schemes, a cornerstone of its Dravidian Model, on the Labor Force Participation Rate (LFPR). Utilizing a quasi-experimental research design, this paper analyzes data from the Periodic Labour Force Survey (PLFS) 2023-24, Tamil Nadu Economic Survey 2024-25, and the Time Use Survey (TUS) 2019. We employ a sophisticated suite of econometric models-including Propensity Score Matching (PSM), Difference-inDifference in Differences (DDD), Instrumental Variables (IV), and Seemingly Unrelated Regressions (SUR)-to isolate the causal effects of subsidies on labor market behavior across income quintiles, gender, caste, and age. The findings decisively refute the "laziness" narrative. Instead of reducing LFPR, subsidies are shown to act as "barrier-targeted investments" that significantly increase labor force participation, particularly for the most marginalized groups: women in lower-income quintiles and those from Scheduled Caste and Scheduled Tribe communities. The study reveals that while these policies empower women to enter the paid workforce, they also lead to a "double burden" of increased unpaid domestic work. This research provides a replicable, multi-model framework for policy evaluation and concludes that well-designed welfare is not an impediment to economic activity but a crucial enabler of inclusive growth.

title: The Anatomy of "No-Cost" EMI in India: A Stakeholder-Centric Profitability Analysis

detail.title: The Anatomy of "No-Cost" EMI in India: A Stakeholder-Centric Profitability Analysis
detail.abstract:
Abstract
The "No-Cost" Equated Monthly Installment (EMI) has emerged as a ubiquitous and powerful marketing tool in the Indian retail and e-commerce landscape, promising consumers the ability to purchase high-value goods without any apparent interest burden. However, this belies the sophisticated financial architecture that underpins these offerings. This paper deconstructs the "no-cost" EMI paradox, revealing it not as a zero-interest facility, but as a complex business model predicated on the strategic distribution of costs and benefits among multiple stakeholders. Through a qualitative analysis of prevailing business models, stakeholder revenue streams, and the regulatory environment, this study addresses how profitability is engineered in the absence of direct interest charges. The findings indicate that profits are generated through a symbiotic ecosystem involving banks and financial institutions, merchants, and product manufacturers. Costs are effectively shifted and shared, manifesting as absorbed discounts for merchants, subvention payments from manufacturers, and a series of hidden or indirect costs for the consumer, including processing fees, Goods and Services Tax (GST) on notional interest, and the forfeiture of rewards. This paper argues that while "no-cost" EMI schemes successfully stimulate consumer demand, boost sales, and expand credit access, they operate in a zone of qualified transparency that has significant implications for consumer protection, market dynamics, and financial regulation in India.

title: QCTO Efficacy Amid the Phase-Out of TVET NATED Offerings: Practical Challenges and Strategic Recommendations

detail.title: QCTO Efficacy Amid the Phase-Out of TVET NATED Offerings: Practical Challenges and Strategic Recommendations

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no financial interests or benefits arising from this study.
declarations.ethicsApproval: The analysis utilised anonymised data from a cohort of 100 N4 students enrolled in Trimester 2, 2025, at a South African Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) college. Informed consent was obtained from all participants, and measures were implemented to ensure confidentiality and protect personal information, in compliance with the Protection of Personal Information Act (POPIA) of South Africa. No identifiable data were disclosed, and the study posed no risk to participants.
declarations.funderStatement: This research was conducted at the author’s expense, with no external funding or financial support received.

detail.abstract: A core challenge in South Africa's Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) sector is the widening gap in academic readiness among students entering N4 programmes directly from Grade 12, without the foundational scaffolding previously provided by N1-N3 courses. This study draws on policy documents, QCTO and DHET implementation reports, SETA communications, expert insights, and an empirical analysis of 100 student records from a 2025 N4 Electrotechnics cohort. A scatter plot diagram comparing term marks to matriculation mathematics results reveals a weak positive correlation (r = 0.17), indicating that prior academic achievement in mathematics does not predict success at the N4 level very well. Moreover, over 25% of students scored below 50% in term assessments, and many repeaters showed persistent underperformance despite previous exposure-highlighting a systemic preparedness gap. These findings raise concerns about equitable access and learner throughput in the emerging QCTO system, as well as its capacity to supply industry with GCC-certified engineers. This article recommends strategic interventions, including structured bridging programmes, expanded Recognition of Prior Learning (RPL), flexible and blended learning models to counter digital infrastructure challenges, enhanced lecturer development, and increased industry-partnered work-based learning (WBL) placements. A more inclusive and supportive implementation of the QCTO model is essential to ensure it delivers on its promise of creating a robust, accessible, and industry-aligned vocational education system.

title: Teaching International Law

detail.title: Teaching International Law

detail.abstract: This article, part of a 2021 symposium edition devoted to the topic of “The Academy and International Law: A Catalyst for Change and Innovation”, discusses one vehicle for teaching international law: the harrowing story of Mr. Khalid El-Masri, who was rendered to torture by the United States but has never received comprehensive justice, notwithstanding the acknowledgement that he was not implicated in terrorism at all and was rather a case of mistaken identity. The case study, which I developed for my course on Human Rights: Theory & Practice, begins by asking students to imagine they represent Mr. El-Masri and to develop a litigation and advocacy strategy on his behalf.  This requires them to identify responsible individuals, entities, and states as well as potential causes of action. It is also an exercise in forum shopping, inviting students to identify national, regional, and international courts capable of exercising jurisdiction. In this way, this case offers a mapping of the international justice ecosystem—marked as it is by both vertical and horizontal institutional arrangements with a certain degree of redundancy—and an opportunity to compare the prospects and pitfalls of individual versus state responsibility as well as criminal versus civil remedies.  This case study of a profound injustice serves as a useful introduction to a semester-long course on human rights theory and practice. I close the exercise with a short lecture on the various efforts, both real and imagined, Mr. El-Masri’s lawyers adopted to provide justice for these abuses and the mixed outcomes of these cases.

title: Structural Hunger: The Commodification of Human Energy and the Regulation of Compulsory Labor

detail.title: Structural Hunger: The Commodification of Human Energy and the Regulation of Compulsory Labor

detail.abstract: This article, based on the bioeconomic thesis presented in "The Price of Life. You work, your energy, the true engine of the world economy" (Orquiza, 2025), analyzes structural hunger as a consequence of a fundamental historical process: the commodification of human biochemical energy. We start from the principle that the real unit of value in any economic action is the adenosine triphosphate (ATP) molecule, life's energy currency. We argue that the post-agrarian transition transformed this vital energy into the primary commodity, creating a systemic surplus that feeds both production (through the vast supply of labor) and consumption (by channeling human energy into demand). We demonstrate that structural hunger is not an accidental byproduct, but the regulatory mechanism ensuring the low cost of this energycommodity, forcing the sale of lifetime in exchange for subsistence and perpetuating compulsory labor. This structure, intrinsically linked to how Human Rights are implemented, conditions the right to life to a market transaction, representing a fundamental bioenergetic violation.

title: Dissecting the International Transmissions of U.S. Monetary Policy
affiliations: HKU Business School, The University of Hong Kong, Singapore Management University and Fudan University - International School of Finance (FISF)

detail.title: Dissecting the International Transmissions of U.S. Monetary Policy
detail.abstract: This paper examines the international transmission of U.S. monetary policy by differentiating between expected changes and unexpected shocks. We find that both pegged and floating exchange rate regimes without capital controls respond similarly to U.S. monetary shocks, supporting the "dilemma" proposed by Rey (2015). However, floating regimes do not react to expected changes in U.S. monetary policy, in line with Mundell-Fleming's "trilemma." Further empirical analysis and a quantitative evaluation of a small open economy model suggest that preemptive investment adjustments by the private sector in open floating economies, in response to expected changes in U.S. monetary policy, can help explain our findings. These results have implications on the debate of international transmissions of U.S. monetary policy, particularly as the importance of the expected component of U.S. policy has likely increased.

title: Monthly High Timing Patterns in NIFTY 50 Stocks: Evidence of Late-Month Bias
affiliations: Andhra University - Department of Commerce and Management and Independent Researcher

detail.title: Monthly High Timing Patterns in NIFTY 50 Stocks: Evidence of Late-Month Bias
detail.abstract: This study examines the timing of monthly price highs in NIFTY 50 constituent stocks over a ten-year period (2015-2025), building on earlier evidence of calendar anomalies and seasonality in equities (as documented in prior studies of monthly and seasonal effects). Each trading month was divided into three calendar clusters: Early (1-10), Mid (11-20), and Late (21-31). Analysis of 5,781 monthly observations reveals a statistically significant concentration of monthly highs in the Late cluster (χ² = 400.6, p < 2.2 × 10⁻¹⁶), consistent with behavioral trading cycles and liquidity-driven end-of-month effects described in earlier market microstructure research. Sector-level tests (χ² = 33.13, p = 0.51) indicate that this late-month bias persists across industries, highlighting it as a broad market phenomenon rather than a sector-specific anomaly. These findings contribute to the growing literature on behavioral finance and market timing, offering insights into the persistence of timing-based patterns in Indian equities and their potential applications in tactical portfolio design, short-term trading, and risk management.

title: Forecasting U.S. Recessions with Transparent Models: Evidence from Ten Economic Indicators, 1978–2025

detail.title: Forecasting U.S. Recessions with Transparent Models: Evidence from Ten Economic Indicators, 1978–2025
detail.abstract: Over the years, recessions have erased trillions in wealth and disrupted lives across every socioeconomic stratum. Accurately identifying the onset of a downturn therefore carries immense value for policymakers, businesses, and financial institutions. Yet most "early warning" tools still hinge on a single signal-often the yield curve inversion or a headline unemployment spike-leaving them prone to false alarms and blind spots (e.g., the 1990-1991 downturn, whose lingering job losses were missed by curve only systems). In this study I assemble a quarterly U.S. dataset (1978 Q1-2025 Q2) of ten macro indicators from FRED-including GDP growth, CPI inflation, the federal funds rate, the 10 year/2 year Treasury spread, consumer sentiment, housing starts, capacity utilization, industrial production, NASDAQ levels, and the civilian unemployment rate-and label recession quarters with official NBER dates. After standardization, I benchmark five classifiers and mitigate severe class imbalance via bespoke weighting and a lowered decision threshold. A weighted logistic regression model emerges as the clear winner: across four out of sample recession windows (1980-83, 2001-03, 2007-09, 2020-21) it achieves F1 scores up to 0.86 while competing models routinely miss every recession. Coefficient analysis pinpoints unemployment, capacity utilization, housing starts, the federal funds rate, and consumer sentiment as the strongest recession predictors-mirroring decades of macroeconomic literature yet improving timing precision. Because the framework relies solely on publicly available data, it can be replicated for other countries or updated in real time, giving decision makers a transparent, multifactor dashboard for recession risk instead of a single, fallible gauge.

title: Fair Dealing or Unfair System? Copyright Enforcement, Content ID, and their Impact on Indian Digital Creators

detail.title: Fair Dealing or Unfair System? Copyright Enforcement, Content ID, and their Impact on Indian Digital Creators
detail.abstract: The proliferation of digital content platforms has intensified the conflict between copyright enforcement and creators' rights, a tension particularly acute for Indian YouTubers. This research investigates the systemic misalignment between India's "fair dealing" doctrine, as codified in Section 52 of the Copyright Act, 1957, and the operational logic of YouTube's automated Content ID system. Through a doctrinal and comparative legal analysis-juxtaposing India's framework with the United States' "fair use" standard and the European Union's Directive on Copyright in the Digital Single Market, this paper scrutinizes the legal ambiguities that disadvantage creators. The findings indicate that the current ecosystem, exemplified by disputes involving entities such as Asian News International, facilitates the misuse of copyright claims, disproportionately affecting independent creators and inducing a chilling effect on critical commentary and transformative works. The analysis reveals how automated enforcement mechanisms prioritize copyright claims over nuanced legal exceptions, creating a significant power imbalance. The paper concludes by proposing a dual-pronged reform strategy: platform-level governance changes, including enhanced fair dealing assessment protocols, and legislative clarification by the Indian government to adapt fair dealing for the digital age, potentially through a new regulatory oversight body.

Developed across twelve integrated scientific disciplines, DFAS replaces equilibrium assumptions, backward-looking ratios, and static financial tools with modular engines, sovereign-aware logic, and real-time ESG-integrated recalibration systems.

Volume I operationalizes DFAS through the Alaali Financial Models Meta-Framework (AFMF), presenting over 170 original models across volatility diagnostics, liquidity analysis, and financial resilience forecasting. This volume empirically demonstrates the generative scalability of DFAS, exemplified by the Alaali Cash Flow Volatility Index (A-CFVI), which has produced over 176 derivative models spanning operational, macroeconomic, regulatory, and ESG contexts.

Anchored in the Alba vs. Alcoa Master Case Study, this work exposes the structural failure of traditional models such as ICR, D/E, and WACC to explain asymmetric outcomes under sovereign support and ESG stress. In response, AFMF deploys proprietary engines such as the Sovereign Support Adjustment Factor (SSAF), Nonlinear Logic Engine (A-NLE), and Dynamic Recalibration Architecture (DRA) to simulate regime shifts, liquidity fractures, and systemic volatility.

AFMF is not merely a model library. It is the applied manifestation of DFAS as a modular, meta-scientific platform—designed for structural realism, policy integration, and predictive adaptability. While not all models in this version are optimized for immediate institutional deployment, their inclusion serves a deliberate purpose: to prove the scalability and generative capacity of DFAS. Future volumes will selectively advance high-impact, empirically validated models, prioritizing regulatory relevance, institutional value, and cross-sectoral applicability.

title: Offline Privacy Concerns in Mental Health Care Delivery Through Telehealth
affiliations: Johns Hopkins University - Carey Business School and University of Pennsylvania

detail.title: Offline Privacy Concerns in Mental Health Care Delivery Through Telehealth
detail.abstract: Mental health conditions are responsible for 23% of all pregnancy-related deaths in the US. A significant contributor is postpartum (after birth) mental health issues, primarily depression, which affect 1 in 8 mothers. Yet more than half of new mothers with depression go untreated. Telehealth has the potential to increase access to and utilization of mental health care, but any such benefits may be affected by offline (physical) privacy concerns. On the one hand, telehealth shifts care from a provider office setting to a home setting, which may reduce privacy for individuals using telehealth in crowded households ("privacy at home"). On the other hand, consumption of telehealth services may be less observable than in-person care, alleviating concerns about societal stigma related to the use of mental health services ("privacy in the community"). Using detailed insurance claims data surrounding a period of rapid increase in telehealth use, we find that telehealth availability increases treatment utilization, with lower utilization for individuals in crowded households and higher utilization where there is a high societal stigma to the use of mental services. These insights are potentially actionable as insurers and providers can expand the utilization of maternal mental health services by increasing support for telehealth in environments where there is high societal stigma, and seek alternative delivery mechanisms for individuals who may live in crowded households. Furthermore, our findings are likely to extend beyond maternal mental health setting, as the advantages and disadvantages of telehealth and the associated privacy concerns are not exclusive to mothers or mental health.

The consequences of this phenomenon affect the coastal livelihood. Fakirhat Upazila is one of the Upazilas of coastal region of Bagerhat and has same characteristics, like other parts of the regions in Khulna division. Analysis revealed that BRRI released wet (Aman) season rice technology has a robust and positive effect on small farmers‟ welfare in Bangladesh as indicated by the level of increases in per capita household real income, increases in real Aman rice income, and also increases in yield and decreases both in poverty gap and squared poverty gap over time. The marginal and near landless farmers have not gained significantly through adopting BRRI released modern variety over non-adopters in terms of all the indicators except Aman rice yield. However, only yield of BRRI released modern wet (Aman) season rice technology has positive and significant impact on the marginal and near landless farmers Land use of Fakirhat is changing day by day, like agricultural lands have been transformed into rural settlement, water body, vegetation etc. The major objectives of this study are to detect and predict the Land- use for rice production in the coastal area at Bagerhat and investigate the coastal rice production in relation to Linear regression model. It is found that 22% rural settlement is increased and 20% agricultural land is decreased between 1989 and 2010 and in the year of 2025, maximum portion of the agricultural will be lost. This paper found that the rate of landless households increased alarmingly due to frequent disasters.

detail.abstract: More than seventy-five percent of the foreign earnings of Bangladesh come from RMG sector where more than five million workers are working. Ninety percent of these huge unskilled workers are women coming from rural areas of Bangladesh? This sector is primarily based on lower skilled or unskilled workers. These women have no other option of work except maid servant. But due to global development of new technologies like CAD, CAM, these workers will have the chance to become jobless which will have a severe negative impact on their socioeconomic lives. Therefore, this papers aims at identifying the job security impact factors of RMG workers in Bangladesh due to introducing new technologies. Both primary and secondary data were used to conduct this study. Multivariate analysis like factor analysis was performed to identify the job security impact factors of the workers. Multiple regression analysis was done to identify the significant impact factors. Results show that the impact factors are concerned with the introduction to new technologies at work. Increased uncertainty, increase of confusion at work, work stress, frustration and technology-based work environment are significant impact factors that are concerned with the job security of the workers in this sector. Skill and abilities, supervisors, behavior, time pressure, workers" importance to supervisor, and co-workers' relations are found "not significant" job security impact factors. This study suggests that the managers and the policy makers of RMG sector should focus more on the technical training, more friendly behavior, and reduction of frustration factors to improve the situation in this sector of Bangladesh.

detail.abstract: Laboratory experiments established that peer punishment is a powerful cooperation-enhancing institution. However, this evidence centers on punishment that affects punishees immediately, whereas in many out-of-lab instances, punishment only takes effect some time after it has been inflicted. Moreover, studying the consequences of a delay in the effect of punishment could shed light on the channels through which punishment facilitates cooperation. A delay may (i) prevent punishees from immediately responding to the punishment and (ii) dissolve the perceived link between received punishment and past behavior. In the present study, we model a situation where punishment affects the punishee five periods after it has been inflicted. We find that even under a delay in the effect and feedback of punishment, peer punishment is very effective in facilitating cooperation. However, peer punishment is only efficient when a salient link between received punishment and past contributions is established.

title: Peculiarities Of Adaptation Mechanisms of Enterprises in the Condition of Economic Instability
affiliations: Russian Presidential Academy of National Economy and Public Administration (Institute of management, RANEPA St. Petersburg), The National Research University and The National Research University - Higher School of Economics

detail.title: Peculiarities Of Adaptation Mechanisms of Enterprises in the Condition of Economic Instability
detail.abstract: This article examines the peculiarities of adaptation mechanisms of enterprises in the condition of economic instability. As the global economy has become increasingly volatile and unstable in recent years, companies' ability to adapt to such changes plays a very important role. This study explores various adaptation mechanisms that help firms adapt to new market conditions in order to achieve growth or simply survive. It is worth clarifying that the authors consider the unstable economic situation, in particular in the Russian market, caused by the consequences of the events of February 2022. Through ordered logit regression analysis, authors simultaneously evaluated how different strategies influence firm performance while considering their potential interactions. Our model included an independent factorial variable measuring earnings changes, multiple dependent variables affecting performance, and necessary control variables to account for company characteristics and ensure validity. This approach allowed us to comprehensively assess both individual and combined strategy impacts on financial outcomes. According to preliminary findings, the ongoing economic instability, marked by financial crises, geopolitical shifts, and unpredictable market fluctuations, presents both challenges and opportunities for enterprises worldwide. This study aims to explore how organizations respond to economic instability through various adaptation mechanisms. Information was collected among 93 selected representatives of companies from different sectors and different regions of the Russian Federation using survey and 10 representatives using in-depth structured interviews to obtain more detailed information. The findings suggest that firms expanding their workforce tend to achieve better performance growth than those not investing in human resources. Additionally, our analysis reveals that SMEs previously exporting to Western markets showed weaker results during sanctions compared to companies focused primarily on domestic operations.

detail.abstract: This thesis presents an in-depth analysis of the effectiveness of the interministerial skill development program "Diploma in Agriculture" in shaping the Bangladesh workforce for emerging agro-trades, with a critical evaluation of the Agricultural Training Institute in Saturia, Manikganj. The study focuses on the contribution of this program to preparing graduates for emerging agrotrades such as organic farming and precision agriculture. Through a mixed-methods approach, including surveys of 100 recent graduates and 20 employers, alongside in-depth interviews with faculty and policymakers, this research assesses the program's impact on skill development and employment outcomes. Key findings reveal a significant gap between the curriculum's theoretical focus and the practical skills demanded by the agro-trade industry, particularly in business management and modern agricultural technologies. While the program solidly covers fundamental agronomic principles, only 32 percent of graduates feel equipped for modern agro‑business roles, and 78 percent report insufficient training in entrepreneurship and market management. The study recommends specific curriculum reforms, enhanced industry-institute partnerships, and the integration of entrepreneurship development to better align the "Diploma in Agriculture" program with the dynamic needs of Bangladesh's agricultural sector.

detail.title: Bibliometric Analysis of Scientific Production: Citation Trends, Global Contributions, and Core Journals
detail.abstract: This paper presents a bibliometric analysis of scientific literature based on data extracted from a Biblioshiny report, focusing on the period from 2018 to 2023. The study is structured around three key components: (1) citation performance per year, (2) country-wise scientific production, and (3) core journal distribution guided by Bradford's Law. The analysis of citation trends over the years reveals the trajectory of scholarly influence, highlighting peaks in research impact and areas of emerging academic interest. Country-wise scientific production maps the global landscape of research contributions, identifying leading nations in terms of output and influence within the field of economics and its related disciplines. Additionally, the application of Bradford's Law illustrates the concentration of research dissemination across a select group of core journals, reinforcing the role of these publications in shaping academic discourse. The study provides valuable insights into how scholarly output is distributed and recognized across time, geography, and publication platforms. By understanding these bibliometric patterns, researchers, policymakers, and institutions can better comprehend the dynamics of academic publishing and global knowledge dissemination. This analysis not only offers a snapshot of recent research trends but also serves as a tool for strategic decision-making in research planning, journal selection, and international collaboration. Overall, the findings underscore the evolving nature of academic research and its diffusion across borders, disciplines, and publication venues, with implications for future research development and scholarly engagement in the field of economics.

detail.abstract:
International arbitration offers a neutral forum and flexible procedures, making it well-suited for resolving ESG-related disputes. The ability to appoint arbitrators with specialized expertise in areas such as human rights, climate change, and environmental matters is particularly beneficial. Additionally, international arbitrators are adept at handling disputes involving various applicable laws and, in some cases, 'soft law' standards. The enforceability of arbitral awards under the New York Convention presents significant advantages, ensuring global
recognition and enforcement.

Despite these benefits, arbitration in the ESG context has faced criticism, particularly regarding its appropriateness for disputes between corporations and individuals due to potential resource imbalances. Concerns have also been raised about certain investment treaty tribunals not adequately considering environmental or human rights standards and the lack of transparency in proceedings involving public interest matters. Nonetheless, as ESG becomes increasingly important in commercial contexts, the number and variety of ESG-related disputes are expected to rise, with arbitration remaining a preferred dispute resolution mechanism for many corporations engaged in cross-border activities.

title: Would Humans Rely on Government Feeding Under the Impact Of AI? -A New Interpretation of Demand-Pull Technological Progress and Income Growth

detail.abstract: The rapid development of AI has put many people's jobs at risk. Economists, technology experts and policymakers are actively exploring how to deal with this severe challenge. Based on a review of existing related research, this article believes that the common solution of relying on the government to provide income to the people has fatal flaws and needs to explore other possibilities. We establishes a general equilibrium model in which companies pay for consumer data to achieve consumer income growth and ensure continuous innovation of new products and continuous technological progress, assuming that technological innovation requires access to consumer data. The model provides a new solution for the balance between human income and technological (AI) development. Our theoretical model suggests that resolving AI challenges critically depends on establishing consumer data ownership, perfecting data markets, and developing the requisite data technologies for both.

detail.title: Hear Your Code Fail, Voice-Assisted Debugging for Python
detail.abstract: This research introduces an innovative voice-assisted debugging plugin for Python that transforms silent runtime errors into actionable audible diagnostics. By implementing a global exception hook architecture with pyttsx3 text-to-speech conversion and Tkinter-based GUI visualization, the solution delivers multimodal error feedback through parallel auditory and visual channels. Empirical evaluation demonstrates 37% reduced cognitive load (p<0.01, n=50) compared to traditional stack-trace debugging, while enabling 78% faster error identification through vocalized exception classification and contextualization. The system achieves sub-1.2 second voice latency with under 18% CPU overhead during exception handling, vocalizing error types and consequences while displaying interactive tracebacks with documentation deep links. Criteria validate compatibility across Python 3.7+ environments on Windows, macOS, and Linux platforms. Needing only two lines of integration code, the plugin significantly boosts availability for aesthetically impaired designers and supports multitasking workflows through hands-free error medical diagnosis. Educational applications show particular promise, with pilot studies indicating 45% faster debugging skill acquisition among novice programmers. Future development will incorporate GPT-based repair suggestions and real-time multilingual translation to further advance auditory debugging paradigms. The solution represents a fundamental shift toward human-centric error diagnostics, bridging critical gaps in programming accessibility while establishing new standards for cognitive efficiency in software development workflows.

detail.abstract: Political activism labeled as "violent" has seen a significant increase worldwide. A common feature of this movement is the growing use of property damage as a protest strategy. While efforts have been made to structure a framework for politically motivated property damage, some situations seem to fall outside. This is evident in cases of student activism at universities against symbolic property, such as statues, linked to the colonial past. In these instances, a peculiar silence regarding property discourse may indicate the difficulty of employing it under certain circumstances. This article aims to analyze the conditions that hinder the use of this narrative in favor of others, such as debates on historical revisionism and the legacies of the people or times represented by these statues. We outline two main features that may hinder the use of property discourse in these cases: the participation of an entitled group in these mobilizations and the highly symbolic nature of these types of property. More than describing the peculiarities of cases of property discourse, this paper seeks to contribute to a framework for politically motivated property damage, highlighting property discourse as one of the various narratives that can be mobilized to protect ownership.

detail.abstract: The financial industry is increasingly embracing cloud-native technologies to ensure scalable, reliable, and secure deployment of AI/ML models for critical applications such as fraud detection, risk assessment, and real-time customer analytics. Traditional on-premise or monolithic deployment approaches limit agility and scalability, particularly in environments requiring high-frequency data processing and compliance adherence. This paper explores a comprehensive framework for cloud-native model deployment tailored specifically for financial applications, incorporating containerization, orchestration, CI/CD pipelines, and microservices architecture. The proposed approach emphasizes modularity, enabling models to be trained, versioned, and deployed independently across cloud platforms with minimal downtime. Utilizing tools like Docker, Kubernetes, Kubeflow, and model serving layers such as TensorFlow Serving and TorchServe, the system facilitates seamless updates and real-time inference with minimal operational overhead. Additionally, the architecture is designed to adhere to data privacy laws and financial compliance standards (e.g., GDPR, PCI-DSS), with builtin monitoring and logging for audit trails. This study further benchmarks the performance of cloud-native deployments in terms of latency, scalability, and fault tolerance when compared with traditional model-serving techniques. Through realworld financial use case simulations, the results demonstrate significant improvements in deployment velocity, model reproducibility, and system resilience. The paper concludes by proposing future enhancements such as integration with serverless infrastructure, edge deployment for low-latency use cases, and explainable AI modules for regulatory transparency.
