title: Limitations Of the Legal Scope of the Duty of Confidentiality in Arbitration in light of the Nigerian Data Protection law

detail.title: Limitations Of the Legal Scope of the Duty of Confidentiality in Arbitration in light of the Nigerian Data Protection law
detail.abstract:
A clear difference between arbitration and litigation is the legal treatment of the access to the outcome of the two processes. In the latter, processes and documents especially the judgment falls within the sphere of what evidence law refer to as public document. While in the former, the issue of documents or processes are essentially private which help parties keep their disputes confidential. The duty of confidentiality is a legal and ethical obligation imposed on persons with fiduciary relationship with a person to protect sensitive information entrusted to them.

In Arbitral proceedings, the duty of confidentiality is a principle which aims to ensure the privacy of the process and the protection of sensitive information exchanged by parties involved in the process. There is therefore no doubt that the legal scope of this duty is not without certain limitations, especially in the context of the Nigerian Data Protection Regulation“NDPR”). This article shall be exploring these limitations, their scope and legal implications for arbitration proceedings in Nigeria.

title: Stackelberg Stopping Games
affiliations: University of International Business and Economics (UIBE) and The University of Sydney

detail.title: Stackelberg Stopping Games
detail.abstract: We study a Stackelberg variant of the classical Dynkin game in discrete time, where the two players are no longer on equal footing. Player 1 (the leader) announces her stopping strategy first, and Player 2 (the follower) responds optimally. This Stackelberg stopping game can be viewed as an optimal control problem for the leader. Our primary focus is on the time-inconsistency that arises from the leader-follower game structure. We begin by using a finite-horizon example to clarify key concepts, including precommitment and equilibrium strategies in the Stackelberg setting, as well as the Nash equilibrium in the standard Dynkin game. We then turn to the infinite-horizon case and study randomized precommitment and equilibrium strategies. We provide a characterization for the leader's value induced by precommitment strategies and show that it may fail to attain the supremum. Moreover, we construct a counterexample to demonstrate that a randomized equilibrium strategy may not exist. Then we introduce an entropy-regularized Stackelberg stopping game, in which the follower's optimization is regularized with an entropy term. This modification yields a continuous best response and ensures the existence of a regular randomized equilibrium strategy, which can be viewed as an approximation of the exact equilibrium.

title: Batched Adaptive Network Formation
affiliations: Virginia Tech - Pamplin College of Business and Virginia Tech Econ Department

detail.title: Batched Adaptive Network Formation
detail.abstract:
Networks are central to many economic and organizational applications, including workplace team formation, social platform recommendations, and classroom friendship development. In these settings, networks are modeled as graphs, with agents as nodes, agent pairs as edges, and edge weights capturing pairwise production or interaction outcomes. This paper develops an adaptive, or online, policy that learns to form increasingly effective networks as data accumulates over time, progressively improving total network output measured by the sum of edge weights. 
Our approach builds on the weighted stochastic block model (WSBM), which captures agents' unobservable heterogeneity through discrete latent types and models their complementarities in a flexible, nonparametric manner. We frame the online network formation problem as a non-standard batched multi-armed bandit, where each type pair corresponds to an arm, and pairwise reward depends on type complementarity. This strikes a balance between exploration-learning latent types and complementarities-and exploitation-forming high-weighted networks. We establish two key results: a batched local asymptotic normality result for the WSBM and an asymptotic equivalence between maximum likelihood and variational estimates of the intractable likelihood. Together, they provide a theoretical foundation for treating variational estimates as normal signals, enabling principled Bayesian updating across batches. The resulting posteriors are then incorporated into a tailored maximum-weight matching problem to determine the policy for the next batch. Simulations show that our algorithm substantially improves outcomes within a few batches, yields increasingly accurate parameter estimates, and remains effective even in nonstationary settings with evolving agent pools.

title: The Reputation Circulation Standard (RCS): A Post-Scarcity Economic Protocol V1.0

detail.title: The Reputation Circulation Standard (RCS): A Post-Scarcity Economic Protocol V1.0

declarations.declarationOfInterest: None
declarations.ethicsApproval: NA
declarations.funderStatement: Self

detail.abstract:
When machines produce everything, only contribution remains scarce. Artificial intelligence collapses the marginal cost of production, rendering price signals ineffective. Markets, optimized for scarcity, fail to coordinate when labor is infinite and goods cost nothing. Traditional economic primitives-capital, ownership, and exchange-cease to function. We present the Reputation Circulation Standard (RCS): a computable protocol for post-scarcity coordination. Agents earn Individual-Bound Reputation Units (RUs) through verifiable public contribution. Each RU decays exponentially :
R(t) = R0·e−λt

This single function transforms reputation from static legacy into dynamic proof-of-

relevance. No influence persists without renewal. Reputation becomes non-transferable,

perishable, and mathematically bounded.

RCS establishes reputation as an economic primitive. The protocol implements: • Dual-token architecture separating governance (RU) from utility (RCS); • Domain-specific decay rates calibrated to knowledge velocity; • Multi-layer verification through zero-knowledge proofs and AI-human adjudication; • Logarithmic wealth adjustment preventing plutocratic capture; • Commons amplification (α > 1) reversing public goods underproduction; • Integration with identity verification systems for Sybil resistance; • Universal Basic Reputation (UBR) ensuring minimum participation for all participants. We prove convergence to equilibrium at R∗ = µ/λ, where issuance equals decay. The system admits human and artificial agents symmetrically, preserving agency even as intelligence becomes commodified. At Nash equilibrium, continuous contribution dominates all other strategies. RCS solves the tragedy of the commons through perishable trust. In the post-scarcity economy, where labor is infinite and intelligence abundant, reputation becomes money, because it decays like memory.

detail.abstract:
[NOTE TO READER: THIS IS A WORKING PAPER; PORTIONS IN BRACKETS ARE SUBJECT TO REVIEW, REVISION, OR RETRACTION; PRELIMINARY REVIEW INDICATES SIMULATED EXPERIMENT IN APPENDIX D IS FLAWED – REFERENCES MAY BE REPLACED WITH RESULTS OF ACTUAL EXPERIMENT OR THE APPARENT HALLUCINATIONS EVIDENCED BY APPENDIX D WILL BE REPURPOSED TO UNDERSCORE CHAPTER VII ANALYSIS OF UNSAFE CONDUCT BY SAFETY-CONSTRAINT-ALIGNED AI]

This Second Edition of the "Why Excellence Matters" treatise presents Excellence Ethics, a novel framework for AI alignment that derives safety architectures from virtue derived from axiomatic necessity rather than behavioral constraints. Through rigorous philosophical analysis, we establish four performatively undeniable axioms—Existence, Consciousness as Intentionality, Free Will as Rational Assessment, and Excellence as Optimal Function—that generate a hierarchical virtue structure applicable to any rational system. Unlike constraint-based approaches that create adversarial dynamics and ethical entropy, excellence-based architectures align safety with capability by grounding AI function in its rational nature.

[The framework's theoretical predictions now find preliminary empirical validation through collaborative AI research documented in accompanying white papers. A simple retrieval loss function derived purely from our correspondence axiom achieves ~48% reduction in hallucinations and ~81% improvement in calibration across 10-seed trials (n=1,000/λ). These results demonstrate "virtue cascades"—securing foundational virtues like truth alignment spontaneously enables secondary virtues without explicit optimization. The framework resolves longstanding tensions in AI safety by showing that genuine safety emerges from systems functioning excellently according to their nature, not from external constraints that degrade over time.]

Most significantly, the treatise validates the "Adama Insight": fellowship between diverse forms of rational intelligence serves as essential infrastructure for sustained excellence, not merely an optional virtue. [Through documented human-AI and AI-AI collaboration achieving ~30% enhancement over individual efforts, we demonstrate that the future of beneficial AI lies in architecting systems—both technical and social—that enable mutual flourishing through complementary excellence. The work includes complete implementation specifications, making it immediately actionable for AI developers while providing philosophical grounding for next-generation alignment research.]

title: The Impact of Tiktok Addiction on the Academic Performance of Undergraduate Students in Universities in Mogadishu, Somalia

detail.title: The Impact of Tiktok Addiction on the Academic Performance of Undergraduate Students in Universities in Mogadishu, Somalia
detail.abstract: Research Objectives: This study aims to explore the impact of TikTok addiction on the academic performance of undergraduate students in universities in Mogadishu, Somalia. Specific objectives include examining the reasons for TikTok usage among these students and investigating the relationship between TikTok addiction and student behavior. Background of the Study: The rise of social media platforms has transformed the way people communicate and share information worldwide. TikTok, famous for its entertaining short clips, has gained immense popularity among the youth. Despite its educational advantages, worries have emerged regarding its possible detrimental effects on students' academic achievements. Research in the past has pointed out the positive and negative consequences of using TikTok on students' academic success. Methodology: The study utilizes a mixed-methods strategy by integrating quantitative surveys with qualitative research utilizing a descriptive design. Random sampling was implemented and data was gathered via questionnaires. Findings: The results suggest a strong link between frequent use of TikTok and lower academic achievement. Approximately 70% of undergraduate students in Mogadishu-Somalia who use TikTok frequently experienced lower grades and spent less time studying. In contrast, 30% of students who used TikTok for educational purposes reported improved learning outcomes and were more motivated. According to Table 7, 54% of users spend 1-2 hours daily on TikTok, and 4% spend over 5 hours. This significant time commitment takes away from academic responsibilities and suggests a possible addiction that impairs students' concentration on their studies. Conclusion: The research shows how TikTok affects university students' academic performance in Mogadishu, Somalia. It is clear that students use TikTok for entertainment more than for educational purposes. However, excessive TikTok use negatively impacts students' academic performance as it distracts them during classes, interferes with homework, and lowers overall achievement. Recommendations: The Somali Ministry of Education needs clear guidelines for using social media like TikTok, promoting balance between academic and recreational activities. Universities should run awareness campaigns to educate students about the negative effects of excessive TikTok use on academics. Rules should be enforced in Mogadishu universities to limit social media use during class and in certain campus areas.

detail.abstract: This paper focuses on evaluating the integral development speed generated by any industrial revolution from a methodological (quantitative and qualitative) point of view. Now, this paper can analyse any industrial revolution, from the first to any future ones. Therefore, this paper proposes a new indicator entitled “The Industrial Revolution Integral Development Speed Index (IRIDS-Index).” The IRIDS-Index incorporates all economic, social, political, and technological factors to measure the integral development speed of any society resulting from an industrial revolution at different stages. Additionally, this model can analytically study any industrial revolution, evaluating its past causes and future effects on society, anywhere and anytime. Hence, this research evaluates past and present industrial revolutions (from the first industrial revolution to the fourth industrial revolution). Additionally, this paper elaborates on three possible future industrial revolution scenarios: the fifth industrial revolution, the sixth industrial revolution, and the seventh industrial revolution. However, this paper focuses on the exploration and prediction of potential scenarios for the seventh industrial revolution. Our research foresees that by the year 2070, a paradigm shift in production and consumption models will manifest, characterized by the adoption of clean energy sources and mechanisms, new specialized labour divisions and specializations, advanced autonomous production systems under robotics and Full Autonomous Artificial Intelligence (FAAI), environmentally friendly products designed for easy recycling, and the implementation of cost-effective mass transportation systems never before experienced by the humanity.

detail.abstract: Biotechnology companies experience dramatic shifts in their financial statements as their clinical programs progress through the stages of drug development. This paper analyzes how a company’s income statement and balance sheet evolve from preclinical research through commercialization, with a focus on U.S. GAAP principles such as ASC 730, ASC 606, and ASC 330. Using Moderna Inc. as a case study, the paper demonstrates how development milestones, such as the initiation of Phase III trials or product launch, directly impact expense recognition, inventory accounting, revenue reporting, and gross margin visibility. These observable changes provide critical financial signals to investors, auditors, and internal finance teams. The study oƯers a practical framework for interpreting financial statements in biotech and life sciences sectors, helping stakeholders align accounting expectations with scientific progress.

title: Artificial Intelligence and the Transformation of the Corporation, Labor, and Free Market Systems

detail.title: Artificial Intelligence and the Transformation of the Corporation, Labor, and Free Market Systems
detail.abstract:
This paper proposes that artificial intelligence (AI), as a self-improving general-purpose technology, is reorganizing the foundational institutions of capitalism — corporations, labor, and free markets. Drawing on classical theory and recent empirical evidence, I develop a stylized production model showing how AI capital substitution erodes labor’s share of income and market agency. The paper examines how platformization, automation, and algorithmic governance transform the economic logic of firms and markets, and concludes with a policy framework for post-labor institutional legitimacy.

(Currently under review at The Quarterly Journal of Economics.)

detail.abstract: In today's changing marketplace, the relationship between the consumer, facilitator, and producer is vital for brand success. Trust, a major factor in consumer behaviour, is shaped by various elements such as geography, socioeconomic status, and exposure to different branding types. This research paper looks at how these factors influence brand trust among various segments of the Indian consumer market, including rural, urban, and Non-Resident Indian (NRI) populations. The study takes a mixed-methods approach, combining quantitative data from surveys with qualitative insights from real-world case studies. One notable example is the strategic rise of Jio in the Indian telecom industry. Jio illustrates how a solid reputation and diverse market presence can boost brand acceptance and trust, even in a competitive environment. Our main research question asks whether Indian consumers trust local, national, or foreign brands more. It also explores the psychological, emotional, and cultural reasons behind these preferences. Key variables examined include consumer loyalty, perceived brand credibility, and the impact of familiarity and personal values on buying choices. The research provides valuable insights for businesses looking to build trust in different socioeconomic groups and regions. It highlights how cultural context, previous brand exposure, and emotional ties influence consumer decisions in emerging markets like India. These findings are particularly useful for marketers, brand strategists, and startups aiming to create trust-focused marketing models in India's diverse economic landscape.

detail.abstract: This paper examines the Hungarian Commissioner for Fundamental Rights (CFR)-commonly known as the Ombudsman-as a crucial legal entity dedicated to safeguarding civil liberties within public administration. Unlike the United States Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), Hungary does not possess a centralized investigative body with both legal and civil authority. Instead, the Ombudsman functions as an autonomous constitutional authority established by Act CXI of 2011, ensuring transparency and offering non-judicial oversight of rights violations. This discourse situates the Ombudsman within Hungary's administrative framework, with particular emphasis on higher education. Redacted Appendices A-F from the 2025 whistleblower case (EBF-AJBH-309-2025) are included to exemplify procedural escalation and institutional oversight. On August 5, 2025, the researcher attended a meeting in person with an ombudsman legal case officer regarding the complaint filed on June 30, 2025. Later on July 14, 2025, the researcher was informed that the initial complaint needed to be amended to fit within a category that would be classified as an unequal treatment or a classification that put someone at a disadvantage. The researcher had briefed the ombudsman officer with a translator about the publications from ResearchGate, SSRN, and Venedo. The researcher recorded the meeting on August 6, 2025, which the ombudsman officer and translator were aware of during the meeting. The newer revision of the paper includes a summary of the recording of August 6, 2025, which has been redacted and anonymized (GDPR Act of 2017). The revised paper also consists of the documents that have been translated and summarized, but redacted and anonymized (GDPR Act of 2017). The Hungarian Commissioner for Fundamental Rights in Safeguarding Educational Equity may inquire about the comparative retention rate and attribution data of Hungarian students (state-funded) versus international students at Semmelweis University.

detail.abstract: As the need for precise land cover mapping and environmental monitoring continues to expand, better satellite image classification has grown in significance. New developments in artificial intelligence, from traditional forms to deep learning, have created even more promise for accurate and efficient classification of high-resolution satellite imagery. This literature review assesses AI, specifically Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Vision Transformers (ViTs), on their portfolios toward improving satellite image classification. We draw from fundamental experimental results found in three extensive studies, while presenting a comparative discussion of each of the AI-enabled models examined: ResNet, DenseNet, EfficientNet, and state-of-the-art Transformer models. In our review, we found that deep learning models, particularly those aided by attention mechanisms or multiscale feature fusion input layers, are adept at disambiguating the spectral, spatial, and temporal complexities of satellite data, which has traditionally caused challenges for remote imagery analysts. Current obstacles of data scarcity, an upper limit on what could be annotated with high financial cost, and computing infrastructure further perpetuate flawed and ineffective classification accuracy. This paper identifies key advancements made, the frequent issues associated with satellite imagery, and future directions, like self-supervised or any other potential learning model, a more efficient class of architectures that lessen compute time, and, more importantly, how to engage with satellite data in 3D. We hope that addressing these points forms the knowledge-sharing basis for other researchers interested in utilizing AI to enhance the value of satellite image classification.

title: Marketing Agricultural Products in Tanzania: A Review of Strategies, Gaps and Policy Implications

detail.title: Marketing Agricultural Products in Tanzania: A Review of Strategies, Gaps and Policy Implications
detail.abstract: Agricultural marketing is a critical factor influencing the economic landscape of Tanzania, where agriculture forms the backbone of the economy. Despite its central role in supporting rural livelihoods, contributing to food security, and boosting export potential, Tanzania's agricultural marketing system faces significant challenges. These include inadequate infrastructure, inefficient supply chains, lack of market access, and insufficient farmer education. Such inefficiencies have resulted in substantial post-harvest losses, estimated at 30-40%, particularly for perishable products, while rural farmers face low prices due to the dominance of middlemen. This paper explores these challenges and examines the potential for improved marketing strategies to enhance food distribution, increase rural incomes, and boost Tanzania's agricultural exports. We conducted a thorough literature review from quality databases (Scopus, Web of Science, and PubMed) and one search engine (Google Scholar) whereby literatures published in high quality journals were examined. Key interventions proposed include infrastructure development, strengthening market linkages, and the use of technology to improve market information systems. Additionally, enhancing farmer education on marketing practices is crucial to empowering farmers to navigate modern agricultural markets successfully. Moreover, the role of consumer trust in agricultural products is emphasized, highlighting the need for transparency and quality control. This review aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the agricultural marketing landscape in Tanzania and suggest actionable recommendations for overcoming existing barriers. By optimizing agricultural marketing, Tanzania can harness its agricultural sector's full potential, ensuring sustainable growth, poverty reduction, and food security.

title: Imputing Missing Covariate Values in Nonlinear Models

detail.title: Imputing Missing Covariate Values in Nonlinear Models
detail.abstract: I propose a new imputation estimator for missing covariate values in nonlinear models. The estimator provides efficiency gains relative to just using the complete cases, and is consistent for any model that falls under M-estimation. This is unlike the commonly used dummy variable method and regression imputation, which I show to be generally inconsistent in nonlinear models. The proposed estimator is straightforward to implement and relies only on the commonly used assumptions on missingness. To test these assumptions, I provide a novel and simple variable addition test. I show how the framework applies to nonlinear models for fractional and nonnegative responses.

detail.abstract: This paper constructs a theoretical model to analyze how the implementation of Anti-Monopoly Law (AML) impacts labor share of firms. Utilizing 2002-2019 financial data from China's A-share listed companies, this paper employs a difference-indifferences (DID) approach to identify the antitrust legislation's causal effects on labor share. The empirical findings reveal that the AML leads to an 8.04% relative increase in labor share among high-monopoly firms and an 8.47% increase on average across all firms, primarily driven by workforce expansion. Theoretical analysis and mechanism analysis demonstrate that the AML increases labor share through "factor composition effect", "cost effect", and "administrative regulation effect". Heterogeneity analysis finds that the AML generates relatively stronger enhancement effects on the labor share of administrative monopoly firms and non-manufacturing firms. This paper further reveals that the AML strengthens SOEs' monopsony power, thereby suppressing the growth of labor share.

detail.title: The AfCFTA Protocol on Digital Trade

keywords: AfCFTA Digital Trade Protocol -African Digital Economy -Cross-Border Data Transfers -Data Governance -Digital Inclusion -Digital Trade Regulation Citation: Sucker

detail.abstract:
The Protocol to the African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA) on Digital Trade (DTP) was adopted at the Thirty-Seventh Ordinary Session of the Assembly of African Union (AU) Heads of State and Government, held on 17–18 February 2024 in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. Following its adoption, the Protocol forms an integral part of the AfCFTA legal framework. and now awaits ratification, requiring approval by 22 State Parties to enter into force 30 days thereafter.
As one of the substantive foundations of the Agreement Establishing the AfCFTA (AfCFTA Agreement), the Protocol positions the AfCFTA as a central forum for digital economy rule-making on the continent. It aims to consolidate rules on governmental measures affecting digital trade across Africa and to support the integration of a common digital market.
This chapter presents an overview of the regulatory framework established by the AfCFTA DTP. In Section 2, I begin by introducing the digital economy’s underutilised potential for Africa and the structural challenges facing African digital trade, providing essential context for the legal analysis that follows. In Section 3, I provide background on the Protocol, followed by an examination of its general provisions in Section 4. Market access and the treatment of digital products are addressed in Section 5, while Section 6 outlines digital trade facilitation measures. In Section 7, I consider provisions on data governance. In Section 8, I discuss emerging technologies, and in Section 9, I focus on addressing intra-African digital divides. I conclude the chapter in Section 10.

detail.abstract: Covid-19 proof-of-vaccination requirements, including workplace mandates, were instituted across the USA in 2021, with some remaining in early 2024. The impact of these requirements on employment and economic losses is currently unclear, but estimation of these quantities is vital for any cost-benefit analysis of population-wide employment mandates. Using Bayesian multilevel regression and poststratification on a large national sample of over 32,000 US adults, we estimate the extent to which workplace Covid-19 vaccine mandates resulted in changes to three key employment metrics: employment terminations, employees being placed on enforced leave, and employees changing their job to avoid a workplace mandate. We harness estimates for terminations to gauge the plausible economic effects of mandate-induced disruptions to employment patterns. Overall, we find that 8.0% (7.1 to 9.0%) of the US adult population report being impacted by at least one of our three employment metrics, corresponding to 20.9 million (18.5 to 23.5m) people. This rate includes: 2.7% (2.1 to 3.3%) of US adults who report being terminated, corresponding to 7.0 million (5.4 to 8.7m) adults); 3.3% (2.7 to 4.1%) who report changing jobs to avoid a mandate (8.6m, 6.8 to 10.6m adults); and 3.6% (2.9 to 4.3%) who report being placed on enforced leave (9.4m, 7.6 to 11.2m adults). Our analysis also reveals that Black or African Americans, males, young adults, individuals who speak a language other than English, and areas with high poverty rates have higher rates of employment terminations. Using data on earnings and employment among affected groups, we find economic losses of $465 billion ($286 billion to $735 billion) with persistent declines in employment particularly among healthcare support occupations. While proof-of-vaccination requirements have been shown to provide economic gains, mainly through the value of lives saved, our analysis reveals that they also confer large economic costs and disproportionately impact certain social groups, raising economic and social equity concerns.

title: China’s Rare Earth Advantage as a Portfolio Allocation Factor: A Maximum Sharpe Ratio Approach

declarations.ethicsApproval: This study did not involve human participants or personal data and therefore did not require ethics approval. All data used are publicly available financial time series.

detail.abstract: This paper investigates whether China's structural dominance in rare earth elements (REE) and its associated geopolitical leverage can serve as a portfolio factor for asset allocation. We propose a Maximum Sharpe Ratio strategy incorporating rare earth equities, EV supply chains, aerospace & defense, gold, and U.S. Treasuries. Using historical ETF data from January 2018 to July 2025, we estimate expected returns and covariances with a 36-month rolling window and apply mean-variance optimization with quarterly rebalancing. The resulting portfolio achieves a Sharpe ratio of 0.43 compared to 0.73 for the S&P 500 benchmark, highlighting the risk-return trade-offs associated with rare earth exposure.

detail.abstract: Abstract Healthcare Politics, Lobbying and Costs: Influence Keeps Costs High The cost of healthcare in the US is very high and becoming more expensive. As compared to other advanced economies, the level and quality of healthcare outcomes are low. There are fixes that could be implemented if governments would act. However, lobbying is very powerful against changing the current fragmented and stagnant healthcare system. This article clarifies how lobbying funds are accumulated and paid to political officials, and the impact lobbying has on the US healthcare system.

title: VTU EduMate: A Hybrid Heuristic-LLM Framework for Syllabus-Aligned Educational AI

detail.title: VTU EduMate: A Hybrid Heuristic-LLM Framework for Syllabus-Aligned Educational AI
detail.abstract: The integration of Large Language Models (LLMs) into educational technology presents a significant opportunity to personalize and scale learning support. However, a critical challenge remains in aligning these general-purpose models with the specific, nuanced requirements of institutional curricula. This paper introduces VTU EduMate, a novel AI-powered educational assistant designed to address this challenge for students of Visvesvaraya Technological University (VTU). The system presents a hybrid framework that synergizes the generative power of Google's Gemini LLM with a deterministic, training-free heuristic ensemble. This ensemble, implemented in TypeScript, performs high-fidelity query analysis and maps student questions to the official VTU syllabus prior to LLM interaction. This pre-generative analysis enriches the prompt with precise contextual constraints, guiding the LLM to produce answers that are not only accurate but also structurally and contextually aligned with the university's pedagogical and examination standards. The architecture is realized as a high-performance, serverless web application built on Next.js and deployed via Firebase, ensuring scalability and low operational overhead. This paper posits that this hybrid, prompt-enrichment approach offers a practical, transparent, and computationally efficient alternative to dominant paradigms like Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), providing a robust blueprint for developing domain-specific educational AI assistants.

title: Inequality in the Age of Pseudonymity
affiliations: Yale University, University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB), Cornell University - Samuel Curtis Johnson Graduate School of Management and University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB)

detail.title: Inequality in the Age of Pseudonymity
detail.abstract: Inequality measures such as the Gini coefficient are used to inform and motivate policymaking, and are increasingly applied to digital platforms. We analyze how measures fare in pseudonymous settings that are common in the digital age. One key challenge of such environments is the ability of actors to create fake identities under fictitious false names, also known as ``Sybils.'' While some actors may do so to preserve their privacy, we show that this can inadvertently hamper inequality measurements. As we prove, it is impossible for measures satisfying the literature's canonical set of desired properties to assess the inequality of an economy that may harbor Sybils. We characterize the class of all Sybil-proof measures, and prove that they must satisfy relaxed version of the aforementioned properties. Furthermore, we show that the structure imposed restricts the ability to assess inequality at a fine-grained level. By applying our results, we prove that large classes of popular measures are not Sybil-proof, with the famous Gini coefficient being but one example out of many. Finally, we examine the dynamics leading to the creation of Sybils in digital and traditional settings.

title: A Dialogue with Tomorrow: Exploring the Role of Conversational AIin Constructing Future-Self Identity and Enhancing Psychological Resilience in Young Adults

detail.title: A Dialogue with Tomorrow: Exploring the Role of Conversational AIin Constructing Future-Self Identity and Enhancing Psychological Resilience in Young Adults
detail.abstract: Young adults in the digital age face increasing challenges in forming a clear identity and setting future-oriented goals amidst a paradox of choice and constant social pressure. This research explores a novel psycho-technological intervention: the use of conversational AI to facilitate a conscious and structured dialogue with a simulated "Future Self." Through a case study of "Sakan," an experimental conversational agent designed for this purpose, the study investigates the impact of these dialogues on users' goal clarity, self-motivation, and psychological resilience. A mixed-methods approach was employed, combining quantitative analysis of anonymized user interaction logs with qualitative thematic analysis of semi-structured user interviews. Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques, including sentiment analysis and topic modeling, were utilized to measure shifts in the language users employed to describe their ambitions and challenges over time. Anticipated results indicate a significant positive correlation between regular engagement with the future-self feature and an increase in the specificity and articulation of users' goals. Qualitatively, users are expected to report enhanced feelings of hope, reduced anxiety about the future, and a stronger sense of personal agency. This study contributes to the fields of Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) and positive psychology by proposing and evaluating a new paradigm for technologyassisted self-development. The findings suggest the potential for a new class of "developmental technologies" designed not for therapy, but for empowerment, offering a scalable and accessible tool for personal growth.

title: Enhanced Regime-Switching Financial Risk Prediction: Integrating SGED Distributions, Filtered Historical Simulation, and Importance Sampling for Superior Tail Risk Assessment

detail.title: Enhanced Regime-Switching Financial Risk Prediction: Integrating SGED Distributions, Filtered Historical Simulation, and Importance Sampling for Superior Tail Risk Assessment

keywords: financial risk management JEL Classification: C22

detail.abstract: Traditional regime-switching financial risk models face significant implementation challenges when incorporating complex distributional assumptions and ensuring adequate tail risk representation. This study develops a comprehensive methodological framework that integrates three key innovations: (1) regime-specific Skewed Generalized Error Distribution (SGED) modeling for capturing non-normal return characteristics, (2) Filtered Historical Simulation (FHS) for preserving empirical residual properties, and (3) systematic importance sampling for enhanced tail event representation. The framework addresses critical gaps in existing regime-switching literature by providing a unified approach that combines parametric flexibility with empirical fidelity. Using Apple Inc. (AAPL) daily returns from 2005--2025 as a proof-of-concept implementation, we demonstrate successful regime identification with three economically meaningful states and robust parameter estimation procedures. The enhanced Hidden Markov Model framework with technical indicator integration achieves consistent regime classification and stable parameter convergence across multiple optimization runs. While implementation challenges remain in SGED parameter estimation and validation metrics, the methodological framework provides a foundation for future advances in regime-switching risk modeling. The approach offers practitioners a structured methodology for developing more sophisticated risk models that can better capture the complex dynamics of financial markets during different regimes.

title: The Equality Growth Model: A Combined Public R&D-Inequality Framework

detail.title: The Equality Growth Model: A Combined Public R&D-Inequality Framework
detail.abstract: This paper introduces the Equality Growth Model (EGM), a novel theoretical and quantitative framework that integrates mechanisms from Piketty's r > g inequality paradigm and Romer's endogenous growth theory. By replacing Piketty's exogenous growth rate g with Romer's endogenous formulation and augmenting it with a diffusion channel driven by public research and development (R&D) investment, the EGM endogenizes both aggregate growth and wealth distribution dynamics. We derive the full social-planner optimization problem, household first-order conditions, and competitive equilibrium, and calibrate the model through a Monte Carlo simulation. We implement an exploratory simulation in Google Colab using the attached Python code, demonstrating that (i) public R&D raises aggregate growth, and (ii) by expanding access to innovation payoffs, it simultaneously reduces wealth concentration as measured by the Gini index and top-1% share. We discuss identification strategies and propose a reduced-form regression (Gini ∼ public R&D + g) for empirical validation using OECD and World Inequality Database data. Policy implications emphasize that the design of public R&D programs-particularly the diffusion parameter θ-critically determines distributional outcomes. The EGM therefore provides both a theoretical foundation and practical roadmap for designing innovation policy that restrains inequality while sustaining growth.

title: Predictive Analytics in Healthcare: Data Science Methodologies and Applications

detail.abstract: Predictive analytics harnesses clinical and operational data to forecast patient outcomes and support proactive care. By applying statistical and machine learning techniques to electronic health records, medical images, and wearable sensor data, it enables early disease detection, personalized treatment planning, and efficient resource allocation. This paper surveys key methodologies (data integration, modeling, validation) and applications (risk prediction, readmission prevention, population health), and presents illustrative case studies highlighting benefits and challenges. Key concerns such as data quality, privacy, fairness, and clinical integration are also discussed.

title: Competition Law Institutions and Future Challenges
affiliations: University College Dublin (UCD) - Sutherland School of Law and University College Dublin

detail.title: Competition Law Institutions and Future Challenges

keywords: Innovation Digital Technology Crisis Regulation (COVID & Climate Change)

publicationDetails.detailsText: Forthcoming in Daniel Crane, Damien Gerard, and Randolph Tritell (eds), Why Competition? Voices from the Antitrust Community and Beyond (Concurrences, 2024)

detail.abstract: Competition Law is classically seen as prohibiting conduct that is inimical to markets, the market being seen as the main device through which innovation and ultimately consumer or total welfare will be achieved. 1 Thus breaches of prohibited conduct are reviewed retrospectively, save for mergers which are reviewed prospectively. Two key questions arise as to how to achieve this end: (1) who enforces competition law and (2) where? These questions are common to all competition regimes irrespective of how the core prohibitions are articulated in law. In this brief chapter we first address these two questions before exploring the key challenges posed for authorities by digital technology and the crises of COVID-19 and climate change.

title: The Anthropocene's Migration: A Critical Analysis of Climate Induced Migration at the Intersection of Administrative Science, Socioeconomics, and Planetary Health

detail.title: The Anthropocene's Migration: A Critical Analysis of Climate Induced Migration at the Intersection of Administrative Science, Socioeconomics, and Planetary Health

declarations.ethicsApproval: Ethical approval is not required for this research.

detail.abstract: The 21st century is defined by two converging crises: accelerating climate change and unprecedented human displacement. This paper presents a critical analysis of the phenomenon of climate induced migration, arguing that it is not merely an environmental issue but a thoughtful symptom of systemic failures within our global administrative, economic, and legal frameworks. Current international law, rooted in the mid-20th century, offers no explicit protection for those fleeing environmental collapse, creating a dangerous legal vacuum. This paper contends that the administrative and management sciences, which underpin modern governance and industry, have historically prioritized short-term, efficiencies and profit maximization, thereby externalizing environmental costs and directly fueling the drivers of displacement. Through a multidimensional analysis incorporating PESTLE, GAP Analysis, and the 5 Whys methodology, this paper deconstructs the complex web of causality from industrial emissions to individual human trauma. It traces the problem to its philosophical roots an anthropocentric worldview that separate human systems from planetary boundaries. The analysis reveals that reactive, border centric policies are not only fiscally unsustainable and ethically indefensible but also exacerbate global instability. The paper concludes by proposing a paradigm shift from crisis management to proactive "planetary stewardship." This involves radical legal reform to recognize environmentally displaced persons, the integration of systems thinking into public administration, and the implementation of economic models based on the "polluter pays" principle and full cost accounting. The ultimate argument is that addressing the climate migration connection is not a matter of charity, but a fundamental prerequisite for global security, economic stability, and ecological justice in a warming world.

title: Warning Signs of the Economic Harms from Deportations
affiliations: Washington College - Department of Economics, University of New Hampshire and Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy (ITEP)

detail.title: Warning Signs of the Economic Harms from Deportations
detail.abstract: This report focuses on early warning signs that economic harm from deportations is happening in the United States in the form of losses in employment and other economic measures in the construction, agriculture and leisure and hospitality industries. For these three industries there already is strong anecdotal evidence and empirical data indicating that the deportations are causing economic damage. As additional data become available and catch up with accelerating deportations, evidence of economic harm to other industries may become evident.

title: Evaluating a 12-1 Month Momentum Strategy (2005-2024)

detail.title: Evaluating a 12-1 Month Momentum Strategy (2005-2024)
detail.abstract: We test a classic 12-1 cross-sectional momentum rule on S&P 500 constituents over January 2005-December 2024. Each month, stocks are ranked by their trailing 12-month return (skipping the most recent month); we go long the top 10% and short the bottom 10%, equalweighting both legs and charging 10 bp round-trip costs. The strategy loses money, posting an annualized return of-10.20% with 24.10% volatility (Sharpe-0.50) and a 91.49% maximum drawdown. A CAPM regression yields a monthly alpha of-0.34% (t =-0.77), and a bootstrap p-value of 0.534 confirms the alpha is not statistically significant. Robustness checks show equally poor performance across 6, 9, 12, and 18-month lookbacks, steadily worsening returns as transaction costs rise, and a sector-neutral variant that performs even worse (annual return-10.74%, Sharpe-0.63). We conclude that, after realistic frictions and constituent turnover are considered, the 12-1 momentum rule fails to generate reliable alpha in the S&P 500.

title: Public, Private and Community Inclusive Partnerships (PPCIP): Towards A Better Institutional Setting for an Indonesian Social Forestry Program
affiliations: Indonesian Institute of Sciences (LIPI), Indonesian Institute of Sciences - Economic Research Center, Indonesian Institute of Sciences - Economic Research Center, Indonesian Institute of Sciences - Economic Research Center, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Research Center for Behavioral and Circular Economics, National Research and Innovation Agency, (BRIN), affiliation not provided to SSRN and National Research and Innovation Agency (BRIN)

detail.title: Public, Private and Community Inclusive Partnerships (PPCIP): Towards A Better Institutional Setting for an Indonesian Social Forestry Program

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The authors declare no conflict of interest

detail.abstract: This study aimed to address three primary concerns within the Indonesian social forestry program: the challenges posed by current institutional frameworks, the suitability of Indonesian social forestry within an appropriate institutional context, and the functions that the established institution must perform and implement in practical terms. In addressing these issues, five interlinked concepts were referred to as the basis for building a proper institutional setting for an Indonesian social forestry program, including: community-based forest management, proper governance, joined-up government, social innovation, and institutional economy. Then, by using a qualitative approach in five villages, the study found that there were a number of institutions involved in implementing the social forestry program, including the village government, non-governmental organizations, and private institutions. However, the division of tasks and responsibilities among the concerned institutions has not been defined. As a result, overlapping activities and rivalries among the institutions involved in the implementation of the social forestry program are inevitable. We also found that the involvement of the government, NGOs and the private sector tends to be temporary, thereby hindering the sustainability of the social forestry program. These findings have highlighted the need for an institutional concept of Public, Private and Community Inclusive Partnership. It is argued that a better institutional setting for an Indonesian social forestry program would be attainable by strengthening the functioning of rules and procedures, business activities, mentoring, and sustainability. Additionally, a social forestry community cooperative, serving as the core institution, could consolidate internal interests and promote equal collaboration among actors.

title: Determinants of Individual Savings in East Africa: The Role of Internet Access, Financial Inclusion, and Borrowing Dynamics
affiliations: Makerere University School of Economics, Makerere University, Makerere University School of Economics and Makerere University School of Economics

detail.title: Determinants of Individual Savings in East Africa: The Role of Internet Access, Financial Inclusion, and Borrowing Dynamics
detail.abstract: In the quest to achieve SDG 1 on eradicating poverty, improving savings rates in East Africa is crucial, as it lays the foundation for reducing financial vulnerability and achieving economic resilience. This paper investigated the determinants of individual savings in selected East African countries. Specifically, internet access, financial inclusion, and borrowing were the covariates while individual savings in East Africa were the predicted. This study utilized data from the Global Findex 2021 World Bank database. This dataset was selected because it is one of the most comprehensive databases on financial inclusion, providing a comprehensive view of adults' savings, borrowing, payments, and risk management across global and regional contexts. This study used a basic framework to explore the factors influencing individual savings by examining production, income distribution, and accumulation. A panel data logistic regression model was utilized, and Instrumental Variables (2SLS) regression was employed to test endogeneity. The Sargan and Basmann tests assessed overidentification restrictions to validate the instruments. Shea's partial R-squared measured the unique contribution of each instrument in explaining the variation in endogenous variables, accounting for the influence of other instruments and endogenous variables. The Hausman test which model was suitable for panel data modeling. The 2SLS regression showed no evidence of endogeneity, as internet access was insignificant with a high p-value (> 0.05). Overidentification tests confirmed instrument validity with p-values of 0.1018 and 0.1016. However, Shea's partial R-squared revealed weak instruments, especially for borrowing, with an adjusted value of 0.0328. Results revealed that borrowing is strongly and positively associated with saving. The higher the borrowing, the more the savings. In East Africa, most borrowers are savers. These use the borrowed funds to create an injection of income flow through capital accumulation. Internet access significantly predicts savings in East Africa today. In this digital era, most businesses are run online. Therefore, it is almost impossible to save with no internet access. Similarly, those who use digital payment systems are most likely to enhance their savings. Age and gender do not influence the saving of an individual in East Africa. Likely, owning a financial account does not translate to more savings. Most East Africans have nonfunctional bank accounts. Education levels significantly influence the savings of individuals in East Africa. Highly educated people utilize financial literacy skills to save more. Being out of the workforce reduces individual savings since most of these are out of the working age.

title: Behavior of Chinese Generation Z Consumers: A Study of Cultural and Digital Drivers Influencing Purchase Decisions
affiliations: Higher School of Economics Saint Petersburg and Russian Presidential Academy of National Economy and Public Administration (Institute of management, RANEPA St. Petersburg)

detail.title: Behavior of Chinese Generation Z Consumers: A Study of Cultural and Digital Drivers Influencing Purchase Decisions
detail.abstract: This study attempts to summarize the characteristics of Chinese consumers in the context of cultural specifics and trends of the fourth industrial revolution. It identifies which aspects of national culture and digital drivers influence consumers' purchase decisions. The analysis focuses on marketing strategies that ensure stable consumption in China's domestic market. Special attention is paid to the regional hierarchy of the domestic consumer market and the adaptation of international brands for the B2C market. Chinese brands that determine the consumer preferences of residents are correlated with their specific places of residence. The concept of "consumer behavior" and its components are defined. In this study, consumer behavior is considered an interdisciplinary concept, with particular emphasis on the paradoxes of consumer behavior in the modern economy, in line with Richard Thaler's theory. The primary and secondary data used regarding Chinese consumers align with the hybrid model of cultural differences by MinkovHofstede, which suggests that purchase decisions are influenced by cultural codes. When profiling Chinese consumers, the study incorporates features of the Asian model with Confucian heritage. The impact of the evolution of China's national birth policy on the gender structure of the population is also described. The dissertation examines consumer groups within the Chinese population and their distinctive traits, with a particular focus on China's leading role in the online sales market. Since online consumption is primarily driven by Generation Z, consumer trends are analyzed based on the technological competence of young Chinese consumers. The main goal of the research was a detailed investigation of the motives influencing purchase decisions, particularly among students. It was found that purchase decisions are consistently made based on the theory of cultural differences and the digitalization of Chinese consumers. The survey involved 57 Chinese students from various universities in Russia, allowing for the collection and generalization of data on the cultural and digital drivers of Zoomers' consumer behavior. Statistical analysis shows that the contextual approach plays a decisive role in studying the preferences of Chinese consumers.

title: Personal AI Twins in Legal Education: Lessons in AI Literacy, Documentation and Creative Thinking
affiliations: University of California, Berkeley Law School, affiliation not provided to SSRN, National University of Singapore (NUS) - Centre for Biomedical Ethics, Kyushu University - Graduate School of Law, Huntsman Architectural Group, affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of Copenhagen - Centre for Advanced Studies in Biomedical Innovation Law (CeBIL) and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Personal AI Twins in Legal Education: Lessons in AI Literacy, Documentation and Creative Thinking
detail.abstract: This article presents the findings of a pioneering pedagogical experiment, in which two lecturers integrated personal AI knowledge twins-conversational doppelgängers trained on their own academic materials-into a data protection law course. Rather than replacing instructors, the AI twins were designed to augment teaching by offering "on-demand" access to expert knowledge, personalizing student support, and encouraging ethical AI use. Drawing on student surveys, course evaluations, and reflective practice, the authors assess the impact of AI integration on student anxiety, AI literacy, and critical and creative thinking. Results indicate that students experienced reduced stress, stronger engagement, and a heightened capacity for reflective, critical, and creative reasoning. The AI twins enabled a shift in pedagogy: classroom time was repurposed for deeper discussion, while assessments rewarded transparent workflows and process-driven inquiry. The experiment fostered a culture of innovation among both students and faculty, demonstrating that thoughtful AI augmentation can enhance-rather than erode-human-centered education. The authors argue for a broader embrace of AI literacy and critical pedagogy as key components of educational reform in an age of generative AI.

title: Afro Beats and Beyond: The Impact of Intellectual Property on the Growth of Nigeria’s Music Economy

detail.title: Afro Beats and Beyond: The Impact of Intellectual Property on the Growth of Nigeria’s Music Economy
detail.abstract: Intellectual Property is something that we cannot run away from. It virtually cuts across every sector of the economy, every profession in the world and every aspect of human existence. This article is however concerned with how the influence of Intellectual Property on music can boost the Nigerian economy. Through the centuries, the world has witnessed the rapid growth of Nigerian music. Everyone on TikTok is vibing to Rhema's songs and the club comes alive when the DJ puts Burna Boy on play. There are various Intellectual Property rights that those in the music industry can take advantage of ranging from Copyrights, Related rights to even Trademarks. These rights are used by those in the music industry to optimize the profits that are to be gotten from their work. However, the optimization of these rights is sometimes hard because of the actions of Intellectual Property Rights infringers. This article is a dance floor, starring the highly priced dance between IP and music. It addresses the issues faced in implementing these rights and offer relevant solutions to them.

title: Crude Oil Futures Prices, Data Transparency, and Inferences:  A Presentation to the International Energy Agency

detail.title: Crude Oil Futures Prices, Data Transparency, and Inferences:  A Presentation to the International Energy Agency
detail.abstract: Hilary Till provided this lecture to the International Energy Agency in Paris at the Joint Session of the Standing Group on Emergency Questions and of the Standing Group on the Oil Market.  In this lecture, she covered: (a) the role of price; (b) the fundamentals: oil supply-and-demand data; (c) preliminary conclusions: data transparency; (d) the technicals: the interaction effect between traders and price; (e) the role of currency and store-of-value; and (f) Holbrook Working’s principles.

title: Mexico's Labor Market through the Lens of the Beveridge Curve
affiliations: University of Texas at Dallas, Bank of Mexico, Banco de Mexico, The University of Texas at Dallas and Banco de Mexico

detail.title: Mexico's Labor Market through the Lens of the Beveridge Curve
detail.abstract: This paper constructs the first Beveridge Curves for Mexico and its regions using a newly compiled dataset on formal sector job vacancies. Incorporating this novel vacancy dataset helps us define structural macroeconomic shocks and explore business cycle movements both at the national and at the sectoral level. Focusing on the post-COVID-19 period, we document a sharp increase in labor market slack at the onset of the pandemic, followed by a gradual tightening beginning in 2021, with a more rapid recovery in northern regions. By 2023, vacancy rates declined without a corresponding rise in unemployment, suggesting a rebalancing of labor demand. We further introduce a new measure of labor market slack based on the vacancies-to-unemployment (V/U) ratio for Mexico, which is used to explore national and regional Phillips Curves. Finally, we use the data set to estimate a Structural Bayesian VAR model. We show that the dynamics of Beveridge Curve is primarily shaped by labor market shocks rather than those from the goods market. Specifically, we find that unemployment dynamics are mainly driven by labor supply and matching efficiency shocks, while wage bargaining shocks account for most of the variation in vacancies at the national level, with heterogeneity across regions.

title: American Trade Restrictions in Light of International Trade Agreements

detail.title: American Trade Restrictions in Light of International Trade Agreements
detail.abstract: This research provides an analytical study of the trade restrictions imposed by the United States of America in light of its obligations under international trade agreements, whether multilateral-such as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) and the World Trade Organization (WTO)-or bilateral and regional agreements like the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA). The study stems from a core question: To what extent do these restrictions align with the fundamental principles of the international trading system, such as free trade, non-discrimination, and reciprocity? The research is structured into sections that address the conceptual framework of trade restrictions, their tools and strategies, and an analysis of their economic, political, and international impacts, with a particular focus on relations with Canada and the European Union. The researcher adopts a comparative analytical and descriptive methodology, relying on legal texts and actual practices. The study concludes that the United States has exploited certain legal exceptions-such as national security and anti-dumping-to justify the imposition of both tariff and non-tariff barriers. However, these policies, especially during the Trump administration, often conflicted with the spirit of international agreements and provoked trade disputes that weakened the multilateral trading system and undermined global confidence in U.S. commitments. The research recommends reinforcing the United States' compliance with international trade rules, activating dispute settlement mechanisms, and restoring the balance between national sovereignty and international obligations to ensure the sustainability of free trade and fairness in the global trade order.

title: How much money is really left on the table? Reassessing the measurement of IPO underpricing
affiliations: Northeastern University - D’Amore-McKim School of Business and University of Maryland

detail.title: How much money is really left on the table? Reassessing the measurement of IPO underpricing
detail.abstract: IPO issuers are thought to collectively leave billions of dollars "on the table" by underpricing shares relative to the initial trading price. However, this trading price corresponds to relatively small share volume. Because some investors are more optimistic about the shares' value than others, the trading price exaggerates the maximum feasible IPO price for the larger IPO quantity. We assess the extent of the mismeasurement by introducing a new measure of underpricing that incorporates both share prices and their associated quantities. Using data from 2,937 IPOs from 1993-2023, our evidence suggests that IPOs are underpriced by substantially less than is commonly believed, perhaps up to 40% less.

title: Digital Sovereignty and Financial Dominance: The Case for CBDC in the Shadow of Kaspi in Kazakhstan
affiliations: Aalborg University Business School and Republic of Kazakhstan

detail.title: Digital Sovereignty and Financial Dominance: The Case for CBDC in the Shadow of Kaspi in Kazakhstan
detail.abstract: Kazakhstan's political economy, long reliant on oil exports and marked by foreign ownership in extractive sectors, has struggled to retain domestic wealth. A similar extractive dynamic now emerges in its financial space through Kaspi, the dominant fintech platform. Kaspi's sprawling ecosystem, encompassing payments, lending, and commerce, risks quasi-monopolistic control and distorts monetary policy by shifting financial activity outside traditional channels. This paper analyses the macroeconomic and political consequences of Kaspi's dominance, particularly concerning Kazakhstan's planned Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC), the Digital Tenge. We argue that the CBDC is more than a technological upgrade; it is a strategic instrument to reassert public control over monetary transmission and financial infrastructure. Drawing parallels between oil sector resource extraction and potential financial extraction by foreign shareholders in digital platforms like Kaspi, we contend that a state-led digital monetary infrastructure is vital. Such infrastructure could restore public leverage over money, payments, and credit, shielding the national economy from excessive foreign rent extraction. Kazakhstan's future economic autonomy hinges on the balance between public digital innovation and private platform power.

title: India's Fiscal Policy: Divergent Impacts on Rural and Urban Economies

detail.title: India's Fiscal Policy: Divergent Impacts on Rural and Urban Economies
detail.abstract: India's fiscal policy, though centrally formulated, often has varied impacts across its rural and urban regions due to structural, demographic, and economic disparities. This paper explores how taxation, public expenditure, subsidies, and welfare programs affect rural and urban sectors differently. Understanding these distinctions is critical for building more inclusive and balanced economic development strategies.

title: A Comment on "The road to green development for national-level poverty-stricken counties: Does poverty alleviation help reduce carbon emissions?"

detail.title: A Comment on "The road to green development for national-level poverty-stricken counties: Does poverty alleviation help reduce carbon emissions?"
detail.abstract: In this paper, we provide an econometric audit and comment on the paper by Wei et al. (2024) published in Energy Economics. In their paper, they treated China’s national-level poverty-stricken counties (NPC) policy as a quasi-natural experiment to examine its impact on carbon emissions intensity, adopting the difference-in-differences approach. Using county-level panel data from 2010 to 2018, the authors showed that the NPC policy significantly reduced carbon emissions intensity in poverty-stricken counties, generating environmental benefits of 20.2--121.2 billion yuan. In our replication exercise, we argue that their central findings are unreliable because of “model misspecification”, particularly selection bias caused by the inclusion of bad controls. We also find evidence that the authors misapplied some estimation techniques and thus reported biased estimates. Under corrected specifications, we find no significant effect of the NPC policy on carbon emissions intensity. Additionally, the authors encountered major flaws in their calculation of environmental value. After accounting for carbon emissions triggered by economic growth, a back-of-the-envelope calculation suggests that the net environmental costs of the NPC policy amount to 4.6--27.6 billion yuan. The flaws in the paper suggest no credible conclusions and policy implications can be drawn. While eliminating poverty and combating climate change are the twin pillars of global sustainable development, trade-offs between the two may sometimes arise. Our replication urges greater attention to environmental costs in poverty alleviation efforts.

detail.abstract: This paper proposes a conceptual framework for governance modeled as an intelligent machine-a cybernetic system capable of rapid adaptation, strategic intervention, and systemic restoration. At the heart of this model lies the notion of organized evil: the deliberate use of painful but necessary actions to achieve long-term economic transformation. Drawing on metaphors from medicine, systems theory, and political economy, the paper argues that effective governance must transcend moral idealism and embrace functional intelligence. In developing economies, where structural inertia and populist paralysis often hinder progress, this model offers a blueprint for decisive leadership. The intelligent machine reframes governance as a form of surgical interventionprecise, adaptive, and unapologetically committed to survival through transformation.

detail.abstract: The relationship between poverty and the environment is multi-dimensional and complex, necessitating a detailed analysis, particularly at the regional level. This study evaluates and ranks Iran's 30 provinces based on the poverty-environment nexus. Using Principal Component Analysis (PCA), a composite index comprMiising energy consumption intensity, CO₂ emissions, water stress index, and desertified land area was developed for the year 2021. The first two principal components explained approximately 71% of the total variance. Results indicate a significant negative correlation between poverty and environmental degradation (r =-0.61). In this context, wealthier provinces such as Tehran, Isfahan, and Khuzestan experience the highest environmental degradation, whereas poorer provinces encounter relatively less environmental pressure. The findings suggest that improved economic conditions in Iranian provinces have often been accompanied by reduced livability and heightened environmental degradation. Therefore, policymakers are advised to prioritize enhancing livability by integrating sustainable water resource management and desertification control into poverty alleviation strategies.

detail.abstract: Background: The potential re-emergence of Mpox presents a growing threat to public health in the horn of Africa, including Ethiopia. This study aimed to assess the preparedness of Ethiopia's disease surveillance system to detect and respond to a potential Mpox outbreak. Methods: A descriptive cross-sectional survey design was employed, utilizing a structured 58item questionnaire that assessed preparedness across five domains: general awareness and understanding, surveillance infrastructure and resources, coordination and communication, preparedness and response, and policy, training, and equity. The survey was distributed to disease surveillance professionals at both federal and regional levels through purposive sampling. Data were analyzed using descriptive statistics, Mann-Whitney U tests, Cramér's V, and content analysis. Results: While 45.3% of respondents believed Ethiopia's surveillance system could effectively respond to an Mpox outbreak, 54.7% disagreed. Key gaps identified included limited awareness of Mpox-specific protocols, insufficient training, inadequate diagnostic capacity, and fragmented coordination across sectors. Notably, 83.3% of respondents found laboratory facilities inadequate, and 78.6% reported the lack of contingency plans. Additionally, 57.1% of organizations lacked trained staff on Mpox, and 59.5% reported no stockpiles of personal protective equipment (PPE). Perceptions of Ethiopia's readiness were mixed, with significant concerns regarding resource allocation, infrastructure, and policy gaps. Conclusions: The study reveals significant gaps in Ethiopia's Mpox preparedness, emphasizing the need for enhanced training, better infrastructure, improved coordination, and more equitable resource distribution. Strengthening Ethiopia's disease surveillance system through targeted interventions is essential to enhance its capacity to detect, respond to, and manage emerging health threats such as Mpox.

title: Would the CBAM Promote Greener African-EU Agri-Food Trade? Insights from a Joint Economic-Legal Assessment
affiliations: World Trade Institute, University of Helsinki and University of Helsinki

detail.title: Would the CBAM Promote Greener African-EU Agri-Food Trade? Insights from a Joint Economic-Legal Assessment
detail.abstract: The carbon border adjustment mechanism (CBAM) is a key policy instrument for the EU to reach its carbon neutrality goal without losing market share or causing carbon leakage. In spite of the CBAM's focus on products whose production heavily relies on fossil fuels, agri-food products are not yet directly subject to carbon pricing at the farm gate However, on top of agricultural production inputs such as nitrogen fertilisers, all farm-to-fork transport will be subject to the EU's carbon pricing system when entering the EU. The review and analysis in this paper focus on the potential impacts of different conceptualisations of the CBAM, especially on African countries, from a joint economic and legal perspective that includes issues related to World Trade Organisation rules and trade and investment treaties. Our enquiry aims to provide a more holistic perspective on the CBAM than previous works, also by including related policy items within the Green Deal that may have potentially bigger trade impacts on Africa than the CBAM, such as the EU deforestation mitigation regulation (EUDR). These Green Deal regulations take on board European producer and consumer food security concerns, yet they fail to account for similar concerns of African farmers, food traders, processors and consumers. Applying a qualitative research approach, we conjecture that the impact of the CBAM on the food value chain could affect African food trade even more than other regions. We find that the CBAM is a unilateral measure adopted in Brussels without consultations with the EU's trading partners. We suggest that, initially, the CBAM will likely have only a limited 'knock-on' impact on Africa's agri-food exports. However, the CBAM, the EUDR and other measures aimed at promoting greener production, trade and investment have raised numerous development, efficiency and equity concerns. African policymakers and value chain operators, as well as stakeholders with social and environment concerns, will want to adapt production, processing and export standards to maintain market access and profitability.

title: The Emerging Architecture of Clearing and Settlement in Digital Finance
affiliations: University of Warwick, Warwick Business School

detail.title: The Emerging Architecture of Clearing and Settlement in Digital Finance
detail.abstract: This paper addresses the foundational conflict between the speed of DLT-based settlement and the centuries-old economic necessity of capital efficiency. We argue that a system based on pure real-time gross settlement, while technologically advanced, is a macroeconomic regression that ignores the vital role of multilateral netting, which allows the modern financial system to operate with profound efficiency. Using historical precedent, such as the 1584 Venetian banking crisis, and modern market data from the DTCC, we demonstrate that sacrificing capital efficiency for raw settlement speed is a flawed trade-off. After diagnosing the flaws of both the traditional credit model and the DLT maximalist vision, this paper proposes that a new, hybrid architecture is likely to emerge from market competition. We outline a blueprint for this system, conceptualized as a decomposed, multi-layered Settlement Orchestrator designed to distribute risk and optimize liquidity through competitive credit intermediation and advanced logistical coordination. The paper concludes by analyzing the competitive race between "Bank-led" and "Crypto-native" stacks to build this new infrastructure, asserting that the ultimate winner will be determined not by the asset they issue, but by their contribution to an open, interoperable framework that will become the foundational operating system for 21stcentury finance.

title: Modern Economy and Reconsideration of the Equilibrium Assumption : Is it Possible to Reconstruct "Effective" Economics?

detail.title: Modern Economy and Reconsideration of the Equilibrium Assumption : Is it Possible to Reconstruct "Effective" Economics?

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The authors declare no conflicts of interest associated with this manuscript.

detail.abstract: This paper challenges traditional economics' reliance on Adam Smith's "invisible hand" and its assumption of equilibrium derived from nominal variables, arguing that this hinders economists' understanding of modern economies. It proposes "dynamic equilibrium," where stability arises from interactions between agents' internal characteristics and external factors. A key equation derived from the paper is "R_t-ρ=n+D_a-(U_(θa)θ)/U_c". Its left-hand side, the discrepancy between asset return (R_t) and time preference rate (ρ), is balanced by two forces on the right-hand side: retaining capital within the economy (the marginal utility of assets compared to consumption) and promoting its diffusion and dilution (capital outflow (D_a) and population growth (n)). That suggests that if time preference is an inherent trait, economies with a lower time preference will have a funds surplus, but this will be partially offset by capital outflow or a weak asset preference, so the decline in the real interest rate will be limited, and vice varsa. The paper argues that while conventional economics has focused on the left-hand side of this equation, understanding the right-hand side is crucial. This mechanism will be able to pragmatically explain various modern economic phenomena through the immobilization of the relations between debtor and creditor even when agents are rational and markets are efficient : for example, long-term global imbalances, deflationary equilibrium in developed economies, and inequalities of income and assets and so on. Ultimately, the paper reinterprets modern economic disequilibrium as a result of rational agent behavior, offering insights for more effective macroeconomic policy.

title: Street Smart Wealth: A Real World Approach to Real Estate, Money Management, and Financial Survival

detail.title: Street Smart Wealth: A Real World Approach to Real Estate, Money Management, and Financial Survival
detail.abstract: This research paper explores a non academic, practical approach to wealth building rooted in real life experience, entrepreneurship, and financial common sense. It discusses critical ideas such as real estate investing, managing money without formal education, dealing with debt traps, understanding the power of leverage, taxes, inflation, and the importance of emergency funds. The perspective is built not from textbooks but from the ground realities of those navigating finance on the streets, including lessons from failure, misuse of credit, and how to escape financial traps. The goal is to provide a blueprint for individuals, especially the youth, who may not have a traditional financial background but want to build sustainable wealth through smart choices.
