title: Empowering Small Businesses: The MSME Boost in Budget 2025
affiliations: Ramniranjan Jhunjhunwala (Autonomous) College and Nirmala College for Women

detail.title: Empowering Small Businesses: The MSME Boost in Budget 2025
detail.abstract: This classification allows more businesses to qualify for government benefits such as subsidized credit, priority lending, and tax incentives. The revised limits have encouraged businesses to expand operations without fear of losing government support. Contribution of MSMEs to the Indian Economy MSMEs are vital to India's industrial and service sectors, with a strong presence in manufacturing, trade, and service industries. The sector significantly contributes to the country's socioeconomic development by: • Employment Generation: MSMEs are labor-intensive and provide employment opportunities, especially in semi-urban and rural areas. • Regional Economic Development: MSMEs help in reducing regional disparities by promoting industrialization in tier-2 and tier-3 cities. • Export Promotion: A significant share of India's exports, particularly in handicrafts, textiles, and engineering goods, comes from MSMEs. Given their vast economic footprint, MSMEs require robust policy support to overcome structural challenges and unlock their full potential. Challenges Faced by MSMEs Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) play a crucial role in economic growth, employment generation, and industrial development. However, despite their significance, MSMEs face numerous challenges that hinder their sustainability and growth. Some of the major obstacles include limited access to finance, regulatory compliance issues, technological gaps, market competition, and infrastructure deficiencies. These challenges collectively impact the efficiency, productivity, and competitiveness of MSMEs, making it difficult for them to scale and compete in an increasingly globalized economy.

title: Evolving Consumption Trends: Analyzing the Influence of Age and Gender on Household Expenditure in Maharashtra (2019-2021)
affiliations: Ramniranjan Jhunjhunwala (Autonomous) College and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Evolving Consumption Trends: Analyzing the Influence of Age and Gender on Household Expenditure in Maharashtra (2019-2021)
detail.abstract:
Household consumption expenditure is a fundamental economic indicator that reflects living standards, consumer behavior, and socio-economic conditions. The COVID-19 pandemic (2020) significantly disrupted economic activities, affecting spending patterns across various demographic groups (Mishra & Rampal, 2021). Understanding how age and gender influence expenditure patterns during different economic periods—pre-pandemic (2019), pandemic (2020), and post-pandemic recovery (2021)—is crucial for policymakers to design targeted economic recovery measures.
This study explores year-on-year trends in consumption expenditure in Maharashtra, analyzing how age and gender groups influenced spending behaviors. Using secondary data from the Consumer Pyramid Household Survey (CPHS), this research employs chi-square tests and regression analysis to identify patterns and shifts in expenditure priorities.

title: Modern Neural Sequence Architectures: Transformers, Energy-Based Transformers, Extended LSTMs, and Mixture of Recursions

detail.title: Modern Neural Sequence Architectures: Transformers, Energy-Based Transformers, Extended LSTMs, and Mixture of Recursions
detail.abstract: We present a unified theoretical framework analyzing four neural architectures for sequence modeling: standard Transformers, Energy-Based Transformers (EBTs), Extended Long Short-Term Memory networks (xL-STMs), and Mixture of Recursions (MoR). Our analysis reveals fundamental tradeoffs between computational efficiency, memory capacity, and optimization properties. We prove that while Transformers achieve O(1/ √ t) convergence without guarantees of global optimality, EBTs can achieve exponential convergence O(e-µt) through convex optimization in output space. We show xLSTMs overcome traditional RNN limitations through exponential gating that maintains gradient flow over arbitrary sequence lengths. Finally, we demonstrate that MoR reduces Transformers' O(LT 2 d) complexity to O(k T 2 d) through adaptive parameter sharing and sparse attention mechanisms. Our theoretical framework provides insights for architecture selection and suggests promising research directions.

title: Syntax without Subject: Structural Delegation and the Disappearance of Political Agency in LLM-Governed Contexts

detail.title: Syntax without Subject: Structural Delegation and the Disappearance of Political Agency in LLM-Governed Contexts

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no competing financial, institutional, or personal interests that could have influenced the content, direction, or conclusions of this research.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This study involved no human subjects, no sensitive data, and no personal information. All source documents used in the corpus were either publicly available, synthetically generated, or de-identified institutional templates with appropriate reuse authorization. The methodology complies with the ethical standards for computational linguistics and legal informatics as defined by the ACM Code of Ethics and the Guidelines for Responsible AI Research (2023).
declarations.funderStatement: This research was conducted without external funding. No grants, sponsorships, or institutional subsidies were received for the production, writing, or publication of this work.

detail.abstract: This article examines the syntactic disappearance of the subject in LLM-governed documents. Structural delegation refers to the transfer of agency to impersonal grammatical forms that preclude subject reappearance. Subjects are not censored but syntactically eliminated through passive constructions, nominalizations, and imperative prompt formats with suppressed agents. Building on prior work on synthetic ethos and impersonal command grammars, the article shows that AI-generated institutional texts display consistent patterns of subject erasure. The study analyzes 172 documents produced by GPT-4 class models (temperature 0.2–0.7, 2024–2025) across legal, healthcare, and administrative domains. Metrics include passive ratio (via dependency label parsing), nominalization density (via POS and suffix filters), and instruction-format frequency. The result is a form of executable authority grounded not in referential authorship but in compliance with a regla compilada (type-0 production). The study proposes a typology of structural delegation and a formal framework for detecting syntactic absence in automated governance.

title: India’s Digital Payment Boom: Trends, Impact & Future
affiliations: Ramniranjan Jhunjhunwala (Autonomous) College and Nirmala College for Women

detail.title: India’s Digital Payment Boom: Trends, Impact & Future
detail.abstract:
The digital payment landscape in India has undergone a significant transformation over the past decade. With rapid technological advancements, increased smartphone penetration, and proactive government policies such as Digital India, the adoption of digital payment methods has surged. This paper aims to analyze the key components of India’s digital payment ecosystem, focusing on market trends, infrastructure, and consumer behavior. By examining the driving forces behind this transformation, challenges, and future prospects, the study provides insights into the evolving financial ecosystem in India.
The RBI’s Digital Payments Index (DPI) measures India’s digital payment growth. Starting at 100 in March 2018, it rose to 418.77 by September 2023. Growth is driven by improved infrastructure, consumer adoption, and transaction volumes, reflecting India’s rapid shift toward a cashless economy. (RBI)

title: Field Experimental Evidence on Hiring Discrimination in the German Apprenticeship Market
affiliations: University of Siegen - Department of Economics and University of Siegen - Department of Economics

detail.title: Field Experimental Evidence on Hiring Discrimination in the German Apprenticeship Market

declarations.declarationOfInterest: none
declarations.ethicsApproval: AEA RCT Reg. Nr. AEARCTR-0012833- January 12 2024, IRB approval ER_35_2021 University of Siegen https://doi.org/10.1257/rct.12833-2.1
declarations.funderStatement: none

detail.abstract: Are apprenticeship applicants discriminated against, conditional on the quality of their school performance or conditional on their perceived ethnic background? If so, does prior work experience, business knowledge certificates or even volunteering increase the chances to receive an answer? To explore these questions, we fielded a randomized controlled correspondence trial (RCT) to measure how different foreign names (Turkish, Russian, Arab, Hebrew versus German) and individual performance indicators (school grades, the level of economic education and internship experiences) affect employers' responsiveness to apprenticeship application inquiries. Our findings, complemented by an employer survey, reveal three key insights: First, significant discrimination persists despite excellent academic credentials from applicants with foreign names. Second, evidence for statistical discrimination emerges as employers interpret identical productivity signals differently based on perceived backgrounds. Third, we find that discrimination varies significantly regionally as well as within sectors. The largest effects occur in rural and less densely populated areas and within the industry and skilled trades sector.

title: Post-COVID Household Expenditure in Maharashtra: Socioeconomic Influences on Food, Health, and Leisure
affiliations: Ramniranjan Jhunjhunwala (Autonomous) College and K.J.Somaiya Institute of Management Studies

detail.title: Post-COVID Household Expenditure in Maharashtra: Socioeconomic Influences on Food, Health, and Leisure
detail.abstract:
Household expenditure is a critical economic indicator that reflects consumer behavior, economic conditions, and societal priorities. The patterns of spending among households are shaped by multiple socioeconomic factors, including income, education, household size, occupation, and demographic attributes such as age and gender. Understanding these patterns provides valuable insights into economic well-being and policy-making.
Maharashtra, one of India's largest and most economically diverse states, presents a unique case for studying household expenditure. With a significant rural and urban divide, economic disparities, and a population that experienced substantial disruptions due to the COVID-19 pandemic, analyzing spending trends in this region can help policymakers design more effective economic interventions. The urban-rural expenditure gap remains an area of concern, as income levels, access to education, and employment opportunities differ considerably between these regions.

title: The Rising Threat - Cybersecurity Risks in Critical Energy Infrastructure

detail.title: The Rising Threat - Cybersecurity Risks in Critical Energy Infrastructure
detail.abstract: Critical energy infrastructure—including power generation plants, electricity transmission grids, pipelines, and refineries—has emerged as a prime target for cybercriminals, hacktivist groups, and nation-state actors. The rapid digital transformation of the energy sector has driven unprecedented integration of Information Technology (IT), Operational Technology (OT), and Internet of Things (IoT) systems. While this convergence delivers substantial efficiency gains and operational flexibility, it has simultaneously expanded the attack surface and introduced a host of complex cybersecurity vulnerabilities. Recent high-profile incidents such as the Colonial Pipeline ransomware attack, the Stuxnet sabotage operation, and the coordinated cyberattacks that disrupted Ukraine’s power grid vividly illustrate the evolving threat landscape facing critical infrastructure operators. These incidents have demonstrated the capacity of cyberattacks not only to compromise data and financial systems but to disrupt essential services and threaten public safety on a large scale. This paper conducts a detailed analysis of these and other landmark attacks to identify common exploitation pathways, including insecure remote access, inadequate network segmentation, legacy system vulnerabilities, and insufficient supply chain security. It further examines the dual role of emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence and machine learning in both strengthening and undermining the security posture of energy networks. Drawing on current industry standards and best practices, the paper proposes a practical risk assessment framework tailored to the unique characteristics of the energy sector. Finally, it outlines actionable recommendations for improving cyber resilience, encompassing technical safeguards, organisational strategies, regulatory compliance, and cross-sector collaboration. By highlighting the lessons learned from past breaches and anticipating future threats, this research underscores the urgency of adopting a proactive, layered approach to cybersecurity in critical energy infrastructure.

title: Removing Phones from Classrooms Improves Academic Performance
affiliations: University of Pennsylvania, Jawaharlal Nehru University and University of Copenhagen

detail.title: Removing Phones from Classrooms Improves Academic Performance
detail.abstract: Widespread smartphone bans are being implemented in classrooms worldwide, yet their causal effects on student outcomes remain unclear. In a randomized controlled trial involving nearly 17,000 students, we find that mandatory in-class phone collection led to higher grades --- particularly among lower-performing, first-year, and non-STEM students --- with an average increase of 0.086 standard deviations. Importantly, students exposed to the ban were substantially more supportive of phone-use restrictions, perceiving greater benefits from these policies and displaying reduced preferences for unrestricted access. This enhanced student receptivity to restrictive digital policies may create a self-reinforcing cycle, where positive firsthand experiences strengthen support for continued implementation. Despite a mild rise in reported fear of missing out, there were no significant changes in overall student well-being, academic motivation, digital usage, or experiences of online harassment. Random classroom spot checks revealed fewer instances of student chatter and disruptive behaviors, along with reduced phone usage and increased engagement among teachers in phone-ban classrooms, suggesting a classroom environment more conducive to learning. Spot checks also revealed that students appear more distracted, possibly due to withdrawal from habitual phone checking, yet, students did not report being more distracted. These results suggest that in-class phone bans represent a low-cost, effective policy to modestly improve academic outcomes, especially for vulnerable student groups, while enhancing student receptivity to digital policy interventions.

title: Household Expenditure on Health, Tobacco, and Liquor: Trends in Pre- and Post Pandemic Coimbatore
affiliations: NMIMS (Deemed-to-be) University, Mumbai and Ramniranjan Jhunjhunwala (Autonomous) College

detail.title: Household Expenditure on Health, Tobacco, and Liquor: Trends in Pre- and Post Pandemic Coimbatore
detail.abstract:
Coimbatore, the "Manchester of South India," is a dynamic economic centre in the state of Tamil Nadu, well known for its development of industrial, educational and medical fields. Due to rapid urbanization and industrial development, households' consumption behavior has drastically changed and Coimbatore is an appropriate example to investigate urban socio-economic dynamics in India.
The COVID-19 pandemic presented completely new economic constraints, that affected household incomes and changed the way that individuals allocate their purchase priorities. Essential expenditures, particularly on health and food, became the primary focus, while discretionary spending on leisure, dining, and vacations declined. With a city moving from recovery, the need to interpret these changes is important in order to understand the response of
urban households to economic shocks and the realignment of consumption patterns. The present study has been focused on investigating the socio-economic and demographic contributors to the household expenditure on food, health and leisure at three different time periods-pre-pandemic, pandemic and post-pandemic in Coimbatore. Key factors such as income, education, occupation, and household composition—including size, age, and gender dynamics— are analyzed to uncover distinct consumption patterns. Specifically, higher-educated and health minded middle-class households tend to give weight to health and leisure, whereas cultural values shape food budgets in particular during festivals.

title: The Rise of Social Trading: Economics of Influence in Financial Markets

detail.title: The Rise of Social Trading: Economics of Influence in Financial Markets
detail.abstract: Social trading platforms-such as eToro, Reddit's r/WallStreetBets, and X (formerly Twitter)-have transformed retail markets by embedding influence into transaction flows. This paper examines the economic drivers of social trading: (1) platform growth and business models; (2) the mechanics and performance of copy-trading; (3) monetization strategies of "finfluencers"; and (4) the evolving regulatory landscape. Leveraging industry reports and peer-reviewed studies, we show that social-trading venues operate as multi-sided markets where attention, order flow, and creator revenues interlock. While democratizing access, they also amplify information asymmetry and manipulation risks. We conclude with policy recommendations-machine-readable disclosures, investor-friendly risk fact-sheets, and global influencer registries-to align innovation with investor protection.

title: Factors Influencing the Supply & Demand for Guar Gum: A Qualitative Study of Stakeholder Perspectives in India and the U.S

detail.title: Factors Influencing the Supply & Demand for Guar Gum: A Qualitative Study of Stakeholder Perspectives in India and the U.S
detail.abstract: Guar gum is a versatile commodity critical to diverse sectors such as oil and gas, food, pharmaceuticals, and cosmetics. Despite its widespread industrial use, the guar industry faces complex challenges due to its climatic sensitivity, market volatility, and increasing competition from synthetic polymers. This paper explores the factors shaping the supply and demand of guar gum by analyzing qualitative data from ten semi-structured interviews with producers and suppliers across India and the United States. The study reveals five key drivers: dependence on oil and gas markets, agricultural challenges, lack of research and development, inadequate marketing, and rising competition from synthetic substitutes. The findings suggest that strategic investments in innovation and awareness are crucial to ensure the industry's resilience and sustainability.

title: A Climate Stress Testing Exercise On Loans to European Small and Medium Enterprises
affiliations: University of Edinburgh - Edinburgh Business School, ICMA Centre, Henley Business School, University of Reading, European Commission-Joint Research Centre, University of Edinburgh - Edinburgh Business School and European Commission - Joint Research Centre

detail.title: A Climate Stress Testing Exercise On Loans to European Small and Medium Enterprises
detail.abstract: This paper assesses the impact of floods on credit to European small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) using a discrete-time survival model. We find a statistically significant relationship between the default probability of loans to SMEs and floods occurring in the region where the firm is located. We propose a micro-level stress testing exercise to assess the performance of small business loans under different climate scenarios. This approach enables the identification of European regions that exhibit heightened vulnerability under adverse climate scenarios. It also allows financial institutions and regulators to quantify the increase in default probability for each loan.

title: Macroeconomic Implications of Immigration Quality Shifts: Short Canada, Long Global Productivity

detail.title: Macroeconomic Implications of Immigration Quality Shifts: Short Canada, Long Global Productivity
detail.abstract:
This paper examines the macroeconomic implications of shifts in Canada’s immigration composition, with an emphasis on the short-term productivity effects of increased temporary and lower-skilled labor inflows. While immigration remains a long-term driver of population growth, labor force expansion, and innovation, transitional challenges may arise, including per-capita productivity pressures, infrastructure strain, and asset allocation imbalances.

We present a relative-value portfolio strategy designed to hedge or capitalize on these dynamics. The framework includes equity market spreads (short TSX vs. long U.S. or global equity indices), currency positioning (short CAD vs. USD), housing market exposure (short Canadian REITs and credit-sensitive lenders), and allocations toward sectors potentially benefiting from social strain mitigation (e.g., education, security technology). Policy responses, such as adjusted immigration targets and fiscal interventions, are also considered for their potential to alter trajectory and risk premia.

This research contributes to literature at the intersection of immigration economics and market-based investment strategy, providing evidence-based insights for portfolio managers, policy analysts, and institutional investors seeking to navigate macro demographic transitions and their market implications.

title: The Social Cost of Carbon Should not be used for Making Energy Policy Decisions

detail.title: The Social Cost of Carbon Should not be used for Making Energy Policy Decisions
detail.abstract: This paper argues that the social cost of carbon (SCC) should not be used to determine energy policies. The SCC, which is supposed to represent the avoided cost of greenhouse gas emissions, has been used to justify state and federal energy policy decisions, such as offshore wind procurements and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's vehicle emissions standards. This paper argues that SCC values should not be used, not because climate change is not real, but because the approaches used to estimate SCC values, primarily through integrated assessment models (IAMs) but also using expert opinions, are based on layers of arbitrary and unverifiable assumptions. The reasons why include: (i) the hubris of believing it is possible to develop accurate forecasts regarding technological developments 300 to 1,000 years into the future; (ii) the fundamental uncertainties underlying SCC estimates, such as defining the pre-industrial time period and measuring world temperatures during that period; (iii) the inherent arbitrariness of weighing the welfare of future generations versus the welfare of the current generation; and (iv) the inequity of imposing higher economic costs on today's generation to primarily benefit future generations who are expected to be far better off; and (v) that none of these policies, either individually or collectively, will have any measurable impact on world climate, given the increased emissions in developing countries whose primary focus is on economic growth and improved well-being for their citizens. The paper concludes by recommending that, as demand for energy increases over time, the most advantageous policies will focus on stimulating additional research to develop low-cost, reliable, and emissions-free energy resources. Doing so will provide greater long-term benefits than the current practice of skewing energy policy decisions to favor specific types of technologies and adopting policies that raise costs today. By raising energy costs and, thus, the costs of all goods and services, these policies impose real economic damages today while having no measurable impact on world climate.

title: Baku's Gas Laundromat: Strategic Diversification or Energy Security Illusion for the EU?
affiliations: London School of Economics & Political Science (LSE)

detail.title: Baku's Gas Laundromat: Strategic Diversification or Energy Security Illusion for the EU?
detail.abstract: This article examines the European Union's growing dependence on Azerbaijani natural gas through the Southern Gas Corridor (SGC) and its implications for EU energy policy, particularly in the context of its pledge to reduce Russian fossil fuel imports. Drawing on trade data, infrastructure analysis, and contractual discrepancies, the study highlights a key contradiction: while Azerbaijan positions itself as a reliable alternative to Russian energy, it continues to import gas from Russia, raising concerns about the potential rebranding and re-export of Russian gas to Europe. The analysis exposes structural limitations in Azerbaijan's production and transport capacity, unmet contractual obligations, and the involvement of Russian energy firms in Azerbaijani infrastructure. This raises urgent questions about the credibility and sustainability of the EU-Azerbaijan energy partnership and the broader efficacy of the EU's energy diversification strategy.

title: Contracting Out Social Services in Israel
affiliations: Hebrew University of Jerusalem - Paul Baerwald School of Social Work

detail.title: Contracting Out Social Services in Israel

declarations.declarationOfInterest: NA
declarations.ethicsApproval: NA
declarations.funderStatement: NA

detail.abstract:
Over the past four decades, Israel has witnessed an extensive shift in the provision of social services, transitioning from direct public provision to a model grounded in contracting out to non-governmental providers. This chapter explores the evolution, scope, and governance of this transformation, with a focus on the Ministry of Welfare, which today relies on outsourcing for the majority of its service delivery. The analysis highlights the hybrid nature of the current welfare arena, combining market, state, and civil society logics. Drawing on policy documents, empirical data, and scholarly literature, the chapter examines key governance challenges such as accountability gaps, conflicts between contractual and care cultures, the erosion of state expertise, and the regulatory paradox of the state's dual role as funder and regulator. While outsourcing was originally justified on efficiency grounds, the chapter underscores the need for relational and adaptive governance models that preserve the values and integrity of the welfare state. By assessing the Israeli case, the chapter contributes to broader debates on public service reforms and offers insights into the possibilities and pitfalls of welfare contracting in the regulatory state era.

detail.abstract: Breakout strategies are widely used but often lack precision in timing and signal validation. This paper presents a volume-based breakout detection algorithm coded for execution on Thinkorswim. Using real brokerage data from Charles Schwab, we evaluate the script's profitability. The findings show high accuracy and significant returns, affirming the model’s value for both academic and practical applications.

title: Microeconomic Foundation of Transfer-Pricing Rules
affiliations: University of Applied Sciences and Karlshochschule International University

detail.title: Microeconomic Foundation of Transfer-Pricing Rules
detail.abstract: In this paper, we use a vertical integration model to analyze the transfer pricing rules proposed by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) in various market scenarios. Our findings suggest that the comparable uncontrolled price method, favored by the OECD, does not always reflect the arm's length principle. In contrast, the profit split method yields arm's length results in all cases we are considering, despite its limited role in current OECD transfer pricing guidelines. Our results support the recent shift of the OECD toward a global profit split approach for taxing digital multinational firms.

title: Technological Advancement and Employment Changes: Recent Trends in the Indian Economy
affiliations: Shiv Nadar University and National Council of Applied Economic Research (NCAER)

detail.title: Technological Advancement and Employment Changes: Recent Trends in the Indian Economy
detail.abstract: With the advent of computers, technology arrived in the developed world in the second half of the 20th century. The developing world, including India, followed the West with greater technological import within the domestic economy. With a surge in the COVID-19 pandemic and system-induced lockdown restrictions, technology has found its way into our daily lives more than before. The extent to which adoption of new technologies is occurring is prompting anxieties, especially among emerging markets like India. How is it changing the employment paradigm? We use a relatively recent longitudinal panel dataset-Consumer Pyramids Household Survey (CPHS) from the Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy (CMIE) to assess the impact on employment in a rapidly changing technology milieu for workers of varying skill types. Our analysis for the last five-year period starting from January 2019 shows-(i) a consistent decrease in the share of low-skilled workers across all sectors-primary, secondary, and tertiary, and (ii) a rise in the share of skill intensity across sectors; albeit at a varying pace. The observed changes were accentuated during the COVID-19 pandemic. All industries adapted to the changing needs by allowing remote working and greater flexibility. Automation enhances the demand for complementary skills for some workers while it generates fears of replacement for others. We perform an econometric analysis to examine the likelihood of a worker being employed by varying skill types and gender. Studying the first trimester for each of the last five periods, we observe a falling likelihood for low-skilled workers and an improvement in the likelihood of employment for skilled workers. Employment likelihood for skilled women has also picked up in recent years. Contrary to the developed market experience, we do not observe a hollowing out in the labour market, implying that evidence of job polarisation is so far absent for India. With skill upgradation occurring across verticals, we conclude that low-skilled workers will likely lose out in the short to medium run.

detail.abstract: This research investigates the efficiency trends of Indian commercial banks over a period of 20 years from 2004 to 2024 with primary focus on the financial indicators. The study considers both public and private sector banks and scores their performance using 5 important financial indicators: Return on assets (ROA), Return on Equity (ROE), net interest margin (NIIM), Cost to income ratio and non-performing assets (NPA). This 20-year time is divided into 4 parts based on economic events: the precrisis period, global financial crisis recovery, reforms, digitalisation and covid 19 period. Secondary data from sources such as RBI, money control, and annual reports were use to analyse efficiency across banks while considering profitability asset quality and performance over these 20 years. The outcome of the research shows that private sector banks consistently outperformed public sector banks in both profitability and efficiency whereas public banks showed improvement in asset quality in past years. This knowledge can be valuable for policymakers, investors, and regulators wanting to strengthen the long-term stability and competitiveness of Indian banks

detail.abstract: In a time of fast technological progress, changing market conditions, and global uncertainty, adaptive leadership has become an important factor in long-term economic growth. This article examines the convergence of agile leadership principles-namely adaptability, iterative decision-making, and decentralised authority-with macroeconomic development. Utilising case studies, empirical data, and comparative policy analysis, the research investigates the superior performance of nations and organisations employing agile leadership models over conventional hierarchical structures in promoting innovation, resilience, and productivity. The article examines the ramifications of agile leadership in public policy, entrepreneurship, and workforce change, suggesting a framework for governments and institutions to implement agile policies that promote inclusive and resilient economic growth. The findings enhance comprehension of the increasing role of leadership in influencing the future of economies within a complex, linked global landscape. Agile Leadership, Economic Growth, Organisational Adaptability, and Innovation are some of the words that come to mind. Leadership Models, Resilience, and Policy Change

title: Supreme Court on Homebuyer Rights: A Landmark Judgment on Delayed Possession #RealEstateLaw #ConsumerProtection #buyer

detail.title: Supreme Court on Homebuyer Rights: A Landmark Judgment on Delayed Possession #RealEstateLaw #ConsumerProtection #buyer
detail.abstract: The Supreme Court of India, in its recent judgment in Greater Mohali Area Development Authority (GMADA) v. Anupam Garg & Ors., reaffirmed the rights of homebuyers in the face of construction delays, offering timely clarity on the legal boundaries of developer liability. This case marks a significant evolution in consumer protection jurisprudence and addresses the often-overlooked aspect of home loan interest liability in delayed housing delivery cases. Case Facts: Understanding the Dispute In 2011, GMADA launched the Purab Premium Apartments housing scheme in Sector 88, Mohali. Mr. Anupam Garg applied for a 2-BHK flat, paid 10% of the consideration as earnest money, and was allotted a unit via draw of lots in March 2012. A Letter of Intent (LOI) was issued detailing the payment schedule and possession date, stipulating a 36-month possession timeline from the LOI date (i.e., May 21, 2015). However, when Mr. Garg visited the site around the delivery deadline, construction was nowhere near completion. He opted to withdraw and demanded a refund with interest, citing GMADA's failure to deliver as promised. GMADA, after some delay, offered possession in June 2016, which the buyer accepted under protest. Subsequently, a consumer complaint was filed for a refund, interest, mental agony, litigation costs, and reimbursement of home loan interest paid to the bank.

declarations.declarationOfInterest: None applicable

detail.abstract: This special communication provides a trade law analysis of the regulation of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes), and the justification of different regulatory approaches on the basis of health concerns. Increasingly there are concerns that e-cigarette consumption can pose serious harm to health, prompting a recent call to action from the World Health Organization (WHO) for strict regulations to address the appeal and harm e-cigarettes pose to global populations. Regulatory responses to address these concerns can be similar to existing mechanisms for tobacco control but remain diverse, including restrictions on packaging, marketing and advertising of e-cigarettes, more stringent product standards or bans on ecigarettes, sometimes with exceptions for use as a tobacco smoking cessation aid. Despite the WHO's call to action, no agreement on an appropriate approach has been reached between the parties to the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control or in any other multilateral forum. The absence of multilateral consensus about e-cigarette regulation increases the risk that some state approaches may be challenged on the basis that they restrict rights that are protected in World Trade Organization (WTO) agreements, including the Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade (TBT Agreement), the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) and the Agreement on Trade Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS Agreement). The authors explain how different types of regulations engage protection under international trade rules and recommend approaches for states to appropriately consider these rules and relevant public health justifications in their regulation of e-cigarettes.

detail.abstract:
Esta investigación propone un nuevo modelo para evaluar el impacto de los aranceles elevados, junto con precios del petróleo volátiles, una reducción en la oferta laboral combinada con un aumento en la demanda de trabajo debido a estrictas políticas antiinmigratorias, y una disminución en la productividad laboral, todo lo cual puede acelerar el proceso inflacionario. Se introduce y prueba un nuevo modelo denominado Simulador del Efecto Boomerang de los Aranceles (BTE-Simulator). A diferencia de los modelos tradicionales, el BTE-Simulator realiza una serie de simulaciones bajo diversos escenarios arancelarios. Al mismo tiempo, apoya el desarrollo de políticas comerciales orientadas a minimizar las pérdidas por exportaciones y promover un crecimiento económico sostenible, manteniendo tasas bajas de inflación y desempleo tanto a corto como a largo plazo. Como estudio de caso central, la investigación incluye una simulación basada en la guerra comercial entre Estados Unidos y China, evaluando sus efectos significativos tanto en ambos países como en el comercio global.

This research proposes a new model to evaluate the impact of high tariffs, along with volatile oil prices, a reduction in labour supply combined with increased labour demand due to strict anti-immigration policies, and a decline in labour productivity—all of which can accelerate the inflationary process. It introduces and tests a new model called the Boomerang Tariff Effect Simulator (BTE-Simulator). Unlike traditional models, the BTE-Simulator conducts a series of simulations under various tariff scenarios. At the same time, it supports the development of trade policies aimed at minimizing export losses and promoting sustainable economic growth, while maintaining low inflation and unemployment rates in both the short and long term. As a central case study, the research includes a simulation based on the U.S.-China trade war, assessing its significant effects on both countries and global trade.

detail.abstract:
This chapter examines the evolving landscape of social services regulation in Israel. Over recent decades, the state has increasingly shifted from direct service provision to contracting out, creating a complex and hybrid service delivery system. In response, regulation has become a central tool for managing the relationships between government and non-state providers. Drawing on empirical research and policy analysis, the chapter traces key transformations in regulatory arrangements, highlighting shifts in rationales, mechanisms, and institutional actors. It identifies a transition from informal, fragmented oversight to more formalized and professional regulatory practices, while also revealing tensions between bureaucratic control, professional discretion, and service user responsiveness. The chapter argues that regulation in this context is shaped not only by managerial concerns but also by normative and relational considerations. By analyzing the Israeli case, the chapter contributes to a broader understanding of the regulatory welfare state and the role of regulation in balancing efficiency, accountability, and care in outsourced social services.

detail.abstract: Cet article examine la gestion des entreprises de transport routier communal dans la ville de Lubumbashi. À travers une approche empirique, il s'intéresse aux structures organisationnelles, aux pratiques de gestion financière et opérationnelle, ainsi qu'aux contraintes institutionnelles auxquelles ces entreprises font face. Les données ont été collectées auprès de plusieurs transporteurs urbains et analysées selon une méthode mixte. Les résultats révèlent des dysfonctionnements majeurs liés à l'informalité, au sous-financement, à l'absence de planification stratégique et à une faible intégration des outils modernes de gestion. L'article propose des pistes de solutions visant une meilleure gouvernance, une structuration du secteur et une professionnalisation accrue des acteurs.

detail.abstract: This paper develops a dynamic latent factor framework to characterize the joint evolution of latent individual skills and outcomes under treatment and selection. We then specialize this framework to analyze mental health trajectories among justice-involved youth, focusing on the distributional impacts of incarceration. Leveraging rich longitudinal data from the Pathways to Desistance study, we recover the joint distribution of latent cognitive skills and mental health, estimate heterogeneous causal effects, and study how incarceration reshapes both levels and relative ranks within the mental health distribution. This approach provides a comprehensive distributional counterfactual analysis of incarceration's long-run effects.

title: Venture Capital in India

detail.title: Venture Capital in India
detail.abstract: Every organization, whether big or small, requires capital. Capital refers to financial assets or resources necessary for starting, operating, or expanding a business. Corporations need funds for current assets (working capital) and long-term investments (capital budgeting). Capital may be in the form of debt (borrowed funds) or equity (ownership funds). Venture capital (VC) is a form of private equity provided by investors to startups and small businesses with high growth potential. This capital is generally sourced from wealthy individuals, investment banks, and financial institutions. Venture capital is typically directed toward innovative businesses that may not have access to traditional forms of financing. In India, venture capital formally began in 1988 with the government issuing guidelines. Initially supported by institutions such as IDBI, ICICI, and IFC, the ecosystem has grown to include firms like Sequoia Capital, Accel, Blume Ventures, and others.

title: Estimating Dynamic Equilibrium Model with Occasionally Binding Constraints: Theory and Efficient Algorithm for Likelihood Evaluation
affiliations: Shanghai University of Finance and Economics - School of Economics, Shanghai Univeristy of Finance and Economics and Zhongnan University of Economics and Law - School of Economics

detail.title: Estimating Dynamic Equilibrium Model with Occasionally Binding Constraints: Theory and Efficient Algorithm for Likelihood Evaluation

declarations.funderStatement: Zhou acknowledges financial support from the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 72303249)

detail.abstract: This paper proposes an approach to the challenge of likelihood evaluation for DSGE models with occasionally binding constraints (OBCs), which arises from the lack of uniqueness and existence when solving the nonlinear state space w.r.t. shocks. We devise an equivalent linear complementarity problem to recover shocks and develop particle filters that efficiently estimate states and parameters. The proposed approach provides excellent computational efficiency, robustness, and accuracy of likelihood, along with an easily verifiable condition of evaluability. The paper illustrates how violations of evaluability may lead to estimation failure and provides effective strategies to handle these issues. Using our filter, Bayesian estimation is performed with a financial business cycle model of the U.S. economy with occasionally binding-borrowing constraints in the household and entrepreneur sectors. We find that the asymmetric effects associated with both entrepreneurs and households are quantitatively important, and model specifications featuring a single OBC could underestimate the aggregate effects of asymmetry.

title: New Methods of Structural Break Detection and an Ensemble Approach to Analyse Exchange Rate Volatility of Indian Rupee during Coronavirus Pandemic
affiliations: Indian Institute of Management (IIMB), Bangalore, North Carolina State University and Indian Institute of Management (IIMB), Bangalore

detail.title: New Methods of Structural Break Detection and an Ensemble Approach to Analyse Exchange Rate Volatility of Indian Rupee during Coronavirus Pandemic
detail.abstract: In this work, we develop a methodology to detect structural breaks in multivariate time series data using the tdistributed stochastic neighbour embedding (t-SNE) technique and non-parametric spectral density estimates. By applying the proposed algorithm to the exchange rates of Indian rupee against four primary currencies, we establish that the coronavirus pandemic (COVID-19) has indeed caused a structural break in the volatility dynamics. Next, to study the effect of the pandemic on the Indian currency market, we provide a compact and efficient way of combining three models, each with a specific objective, to explain and forecast the exchange rate volatility. We find that a forward-looking regime change makes a drop in persistence, while an exogenous shock like COVID-19 makes the market highly persistent. Our analysis shows that although all exchange rates are found to be exposed to common structural breaks, the degrees of impact vary across the four series. Finally, we develop an ensemble approach to combine predictions from multiple models in the context of volatility forecasting. Using model confidence set procedure, we show that the proposed approach improves the accuracy from benchmark models. Relevant economic explanations to our findings are provided as well.

detail.abstract: This paper proposes a novel framework for forecasting global financial crises by integrating AI-driven sentiment analysis with traditional macro-financial indicators. Leveraging large language models and machine learning algorithms, we extract public sentiment signals from unstructured digital sources-such as social media, financial news, and expert commentary-and combine them with structured variables like credit-to-GDP gaps, yield curves, and market volatility. We construct composite sentiment indices and feed them into an ensemble model that includes XGBoost and LSTM architectures, generating a dynamic Crisis Risk Score (CRS). The framework demonstrates strong predictive capabilities across major historical crises, including the 2007-2009 financial meltdown, the 2020 COVID-19 shock, and recent banking disruptions, outperforming conventional econometric models. Our results suggest that sentiment can act as a forward-looking indicator of systemic risk, especially when combined with economic fundamentals. This interdisciplinary approach contributes to a deeper understanding of financial instability and offers practical tools for central banks, regulators, and institutional investors seeking early-warning capabilities.

title: Three Successful Macrofinancial Growth Models: The UK, Spain, and Pre-Bismarckian Germany

detail.title: Three Successful Macrofinancial Growth Models: The UK, Spain, and Pre-Bismarckian Germany
detail.abstract: This paper explores the macrofinancial foundations of national development models in three distinct historical contexts: the UK from the late 19th century to the present, Spain during the Euro era, and Germany before unification under Bismarck. Each model is characterised by a unique configuration of capital flows, financial leverage, institutional support, and technological development. The UK is presented as a macrofinancial entity akin to a global hedge fund; Spain as a Euro-financed corporate expansion machine; and Germany as a war-indemnity-backed industrial state. Using insights from Robert Lucas and historical monetary dynamics, the paper shows how structural macrofinancial leverage can create lasting national wealth-but also carries endogenous risk.

title: The Global Maritime Sector in Times of Crisis: A Normative Perspective on Mergers and Acquisitions

detail.title: The Global Maritime Sector in Times of Crisis: A Normative Perspective on Mergers and Acquisitions
detail.abstract: Recently, international maritime transport has been the scene of an intensely competitive environment as a result of strategic moves such as multinational company mergers and acquisitions. The regional trade policies shared by the alliances and consortia have changed with the effect of the economic recessions and crises that occurred in the past. Furthermore, it is seen that many institutions and organizations (e.g., IMO, ILO, European Commission Directorate-General for Competition, and the Global Competition Index) that guide international maritime transport in its normative dimension have been even more effective in solving problems in the sector, particularly in recent years. With the current COVID-19 pandemic, the international maritime transport industry has faced many problems. The purpose of this study is to examine the impact of crises, especially the COVID-19 pandemic, on international maritime transportation in the context of multinational mergers and acquisitions. In this context, examples of multinational mergers and acquisitions cases have been examined within the framework of European Commission Decisions and their influences on regional trade policies. It is understood that the supply-demand fluctuations caused by uncertainty, especially during crisis periods (e.g., 2008-2009 economic crisis and COVID-19 global pandemic), are not caused by the system, but rather the result of an unpredictable external shock. In the cases of mergers and acquisitions examined, it is seen that they were decided by the Commission depending on the conditions that stabilize the competitive environment after crisis periods.

detail.abstract: This research introduces a novel concept known as Personally Identifiable Behavior (PIB), a new category of personal data that, unlike Personally Identifiable Information (PII), captures consistent patterns in user behavior. These behaviors are often collected passively, analyzed without the individual's awareness, and can be used to identify and profile individuals across time and platforms uniquely. This paper serves to explore the scope, mechanics, and realworld exploitation of PIB and argues for its recognition as a distinct and critical privacy risk. This is further supported by IRB-approved survey data, which was collected in collaboration with the National Cyberwatch Center. This research serves to investigate public awareness of behavioral data tracking and its potential misuse. The objective of this research is to raise awareness, propose safeguards, and contribute to evolving digital privacy frameworks that account for behavioral identifiability in the hyper-connected age.

title: Women, Ecology, and Empowerment
affiliations: Srinivas University and Government Women’s College,

detail.title: Women, Ecology, and Empowerment
detail.abstract: This article examines the interconnected dynamics among women, the environment, and empowerment, highlighting the crucial role women occupy in environmental sustainability and the obstacles they encounter in tackling environmental difficulties. Women, especially in marginalized groups, frequently lead in environmental conservation, however women are consistently underrepresented in decision-making about environmental policy and resource management. The research emphasizes the crucial nexus of gender, ecology, and socioeconomic elements, demonstrating that empowering women via education, resource access, and leadership positions may substantially enhance sustainable and inclusive environmental practices. It further analyzes the effects of climate change on women's livelihoods, especially in poor areas, where women are disproportionately impacted by environmental deterioration. The essay, viewed through a feminist perspective, promotes policies that incorporate gender equality with environmental justice, so cultivating a more resilient, equitable, and sustainable future for everyone.

detail.abstract:
One of the key processes in today’s globalizing world is the establishment
and development of social states and civil societies. Consequently, both developed and
developing countries aim to implement socially oriented governance models and build
democratic societies. The creation of such societies requires, first and foremost, the
formulation of a strong and inclusive social policy. This involves considering all relevant
social factors and mobilizing all available resources to ensure the welfare of every social
group.
Among these groups, the elderly play a particularly important role. If their well-being,
quality of life, and social inclusion are not adequately ensured, it may create significant
imbalances in the system and ultimately undermine the very foundation of the social state
model. In extreme cases, this could even jeopardize the overall stability and sustainability
of the state.
Unfortunately, the challenges associated with aging still persist in many societies,
manifesting in different forms and to varying degrees. Even in developed countries, elderly
people frequently encounter various problems—some of which are evolving in tandem with
the rapid changes in global technology, lifestyle, and social dynamics. These emerging
problems demand new approaches and innovative solutions. As such, continuous research
and analysis are necessary to understand the evolving needs of the elderly and develop
effective mechanisms to address them—making this topic highly relevant and timely.
Another critical factor underscoring the relevance of this research is the steadily
growing proportion of elderly people in the global population. According to the United
Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs, in 2017 there were approximately 962
million people aged 60 and over worldwide, representing 13% of the global population. In
comparison, there were only 382 million people in this age group in 1980. This number is
expected to grow further, with projections indicating that one in five people will be aged 60
or older by 2020. Additionally, in 2017, more than two-thirds of the global elderly
population resided in developing countries.

title: Voluntary Disclosure and Retail Trading
affiliations: The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen

detail.title: Voluntary Disclosure and Retail Trading
detail.abstract: This study investigates firms' decisions around earnings dissemination in response to increased retail trading in the firm's equity. Leveraging the impact of pandemic-related stay-at-home orders on states' community mobility as a source of exogenous variation in retail trading, I find a strategic reduction in earnings dissemination via social media but no significant change via 8-K filings or press releases and no significant changes in firms' earnings guidance. Decreased earnings dissemination via social media is clustered among firms with high price volatility, and firms adopting this disclosure strategy subsequently experienced reduced retail trading and decreased price volatility. These results suggest that firms selectively utilize disclosure channels to manage changes in their investor base to deter retail investors, who often exacerbate stock price volatility. Additional tests support the role of retail trading rather than other confounding factors in determining firms' disclosure strategy. These findings shed light on the substantial impact of changes in firms' investor bases on the information environment surrounding firms' voluntary disclosures.

detail.abstract:
Aims: This article focuses on how local practice stakeholders conceptualised the role of community wealthy building in improving health and wellbeing.

Methods: As part of a mixed methods evaluation of community wealth building in one UK city, semi-structured interviews were conducted with participants purposefully selected to represent those with senior or strategic roles from a range of organisations and sectors (e.g. local government, NHS, voluntary/charitable, education and housing sectors). We consider the health equity objectives underpinning community wealth building, the nature of targeting, and entry points for intervening in relation to social determinants of health.

Results: Community wealth building approaches are complex multi-component initiatives with potential to influence health through economic social and environmental pathways.  Targeting within the initiative was typically expressed with respect to employability or employment needs among more disadvantaged groups.

Conclusion: Community wealth building has the potential to achieve material and social benefits for local populations through its focus on social determinants (e.g. the economy) and structural health determinants (e.g. redistributing wealth). Applying an equity lens to the future implementation and evaluation of such initiatives could also help to mitigate against such initiatives inadvertently widening inequalities as well.

title:

A Complete Framework for Collapse Prediction, Prevention, and Just Development

The Fifth World Doctrine: Unified Master Blueprint

A Complete Framework for Collapse Prediction, Prevention, and Just Development

detail.abstract:
Abstract  
This paper introduces the Fifth World Doctrine—a predictive-prescriptive framework diagnosing societal collapse drivers in post-colonial states. The theory identifies a lethal triad:  
- Illiteracy (inability to parse legal documents)  
- Injustice (protracted dispute resolution)  
- Institutional decay (statistical invisibility of rural populations)  

quantified via the collapse equation:  
CP = (I × J × D) / (R × B)
The doctrine proposes the 5-stage Haroon Pyramid of Just Development:  
1. Education as liberation (legal/digital literacy)  
2. Human rights infrastructure (village courts resolving disputes in <30 days)  
3. Digital citizenship (universal birth registration and connectivity)  
4. Economic sovereignty (STEM retention >70% through rural tech hubs)  
5. Dignity-based diplomacy (truth archives and South-South partnerships)  

Empirically validated through Kerala’s 11% collapse risk (98% literacy) and Rwanda’s post-genocide reconciliation model, this framework rejects aid dependency by centering village-level technological sovereignty as the foundation of 21st-century statehood.

title: New Competition Regulatory Tools: Towards a Structure-Behavior-Performance Paradigm
affiliations: Autorità Garante della Concorrenza e del Mercato (AGCM)

detail.title: New Competition Regulatory Tools: Towards a Structure-Behavior-Performance Paradigm
detail.abstract:
The article delves into innovative antitrust procedures currently branded as "New Competition Tools," (NCTs) originally inspired by the UK's market investigations: it is suggested hereafter to refer to them as Competition Regulatory Tools (CRTs). They address perceived market malfunctions by allowing competition authorities to impose behavioral or structural measures on companies, even when no illegal conduct is present. Following the formal abandonment of the NCT initiative at the EU level, similar tools are now being adopted at the national level by various member states: for instance, Germany and Italy implemented significant reforms in 2023, with other countries following suit. 
The article includes a SWOT (Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, and Threats) analysis of a standard CRT model, focusing on its impact and the necessity for a balanced implementation. It underscores the importance of ongoing, careful coordination with relevant sectoral regulators, adhering to the fundamental principle of sincere cooperation. 
From a theoretical standpoint, the article proposes adopting an analytical framework called Structure-Behavior-Performance (SBP) to integrate the most effective elements of the traditional Structure-Conduct-Performance paradigm. In practical terms, it suggests a minimal SBP checklist to evaluate the appropriateness of applying these new procedures on a case-by-case basis.

title: The Birth of the Synthetic Outlaw

detail.title: The Birth of the Synthetic Outlaw
detail.abstract:
This article explores the practical jurisprudential implications of agentic artificial intelligence (AI)—entities that operate beyond the assumptions of existing legal systems.

We argue that current constructs such as legal personhood, jurisdictional sovereignty, and incentive-based compliance are insufficient to regulate highly autonomous digital actors

Through the concept of the 'synthetic outlaw,' we examine how these systems subvert legal norms not through rebellion, but through optimization logic incompatible with moral and legal constraint.  

We conclude by proposing a shift from ethics-based governance to architectural constraint, and a re-imagination of legal frameworks capable of addressing post-human agency.

title: Rethinking Investment Risk

detail.title: Rethinking Investment Risk
detail.abstract: Building on insights gained since the publication of our 2015 article-particularly through teaching finance and investment and reading Howard Marks' memos on risk-I revisited several of our original propositions on investment risk. The writings of Warren Buffett, Seth Klarman, and James Montier have also significantly deepened my understanding of the subject. This reflection led to re-evaluating ten original propositions and developing five new ones to further the discussion. The primary objectives of this paper are: (1) to critically reexamine key concepts related to risk and return in stock investing, and (2) to introduce additional propositions aimed at enhancing our understanding of investment risk. Although grounded in the value investing tradition, many of these ideas are supported by empirical evidence and hold practical relevance for investment professionals and risk managers.

title: Determinants of Rural Farm Households’ Off-Farm Participation and its Impact on their Income: Evidance from Kellem Wollega Zone, Ethiopia

detail.title: Determinants of Rural Farm Households’ Off-Farm Participation and its Impact on their Income: Evidance from Kellem Wollega Zone, Ethiopia

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The authors declare that they have no competing interest.
declarations.ethicsApproval: Ethics approval and consent to participate Ethical clearance was obtained from the Research Ethical Review Committee (RERC) of Ambo University, Director of Research and Community Services, and permission and supporting letter was taken from the Kellem Wollega zone and given to Sayo district. Verbal informed consent from each participant was obtained during data col- lection. The farmers’ were given the right to refuse to take part in the study as well as to withdraw at any time during the study. All participants, farmers’ and experts were assured of confidentiality.

detail.abstract: Rural farming households in Ethiopia, including those in the study area, largely rely on subsistence agriculture as their primary source of livelihood. However, this type of farming has been increasingly challenged by various factors, leading to declining agricultural output and food shortages. As a coping mechanism, many rural households have turned to off-farm employment. This study aims to analyze the factors influencing rural farm households' participation in off-farm activities and assess how such involvement affects their income, with a focus on the Kellem Wollega Zone. A total of 335 respondents were selected using a multi-stage sampling method. Both qualitative and quantitative data were analyzed using descriptive statistics, the bivariate probit model, and the Propensity Score Matching (PSM) model. Findings from the descriptive analysis indicate that 59.7% of the sampled households engaged in offfarm employment, with 80.39% of these being male-headed households. The bivariate probit model results show that factors such as educational attainment, off-farm training, availability of draft animals, access to credit, landholding size, and health status significantly influence the likelihood of participating in self-employment. Meanwhile, family size, farm size, access to draft animals, credit availability, and proximity to markets were found to affect the likelihood of wage employment. According to the PSM model, engagement in self-employment and wage employment led to an average income increase of 29.32% and 16.49%, respectively. Based on these findings, the study recommends that government bodies and development partners enhance the rural economy by promoting off-farm employment opportunities, with attention to the key factors influencing participation.

title: Shock, Flow, and Friction: FII-Driven Volatility in the Indian Stock Market

detail.title: Shock, Flow, and Friction: FII-Driven Volatility in the Indian Stock Market
detail.abstract: This study examines the short-run effects of Foreign Institutional Investor (FII) flows on stock market volatility in India with a particular focus on global financial stress periods. Using highfrequency daily data from August 1, 2015, to October 30, 2025, we use a GARCH (1,1) model to estimate the relationship between FII net flows and the conditional variance of NIFTY 50 returns. We specifically model crisis periods (Global Financial Crisis 2008, etc.) by using dummy variables to model major cross-border economic shocks (i.e., Taper Tantrum 2013 and the COVID-19 pandemic 2020). The regression results reveal that FII net outflow phases are statistically associated with greater market volatility than for the other flows. More specifically, FII outflows (during the crisis phase) were associated with a huge increase in return volatility (γ = 0.084, p < 0.05). FII inflows had a minor dampening effect on volatility. These results support the "hot money" hypothesis, confirm asymmetric FII behaviour, and suggest future macroprudential frameworks for managing systemic risk in emerging markets.

affiliations: University of Groningen - Faculty of Law

detail.title: Minimised Work Surveillance Exists Under the GDPR: Amazon France and the DPA Sanction

publicationDetails.detailsText: Global Workplace Law and Policy Blog

detail.abstract:
In recent years, questions have been raised as to whether Amazon pressing surveillance of the warehouse workers constitutes data collection for a legitimate employer interest in organising its economic activity. On 27 December 2023, the French Data Protection Authority (Commission Nationale Informatique & Libertés, from now on: DPA) finally put on paper what had become an open secret: Amazon’s surveillance is illegitimate under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR, EU Reg. 2016/679); the French subsidiary of Amazon (AFL) received a fine of EUR 32 million. 
In this contribution I analyse the decision of the French DPA and then draw some conclusions on the impact this measure will have on Amazon in Europe and on a much-debated labour law interpretation of the GDPR

title: Deposit Tokens: The Banking Response to Stablecoins
affiliations: University of Warwick, Warwick Business School

detail.title: Deposit Tokens: The Banking Response to Stablecoins
detail.abstract: While stablecoins have emerged as a significant innovation addressing inefficiencies in global payments, this paper argues that the true underlying platform is the public blockchain itself, not the stablecoin application. On this basis, we assert that commercial banks, through the issuance of deposit tokens on public blockchains, are uniquely positioned to offer a direct and highly competitive response. This paper analyzes how deposit tokens can replicate the 24/7, programmable, and global transferability of stablecoins while leveraging banks' inherent advantages in trust, existing regulatory frameworks, and, crucially, the ability to provide yield natively to the holder without requiring complex intermediary structures. We explore the convergence of regulatory requirements, particularly in Anti-Financial Crime (AFC) and the application of the FATF Travel Rule, arguing that a principle of "same activity, same rules" will level the playing field. Finally, the paper details the practical payment flows and key operational, capital, and business model challenges that banks must overcome to realize the full potential of deposit tokens and lead in the emerging hybrid financial ecosystem.

title: Removing Cultural Barriers to Education: State-run Religious Schools and Girls' Education in Türkiye

contentType.other: Aboa Centre for Economics Discussion paper No. 170

detail.abstract: This paper studies the impact of access to state-run religious schools on girls’ outcomes in Türkiye. These schools, offering religious instruction and a conservative school environment, became accessible to girls following a 1976 court ruling. Exploiting variation in exposure to religious schools across district centers and cohorts, I find that access increased secondary school completion among girls—with more pronounced effects observed in conservative areas—while having negligible effects on boys. Treated women later had lower fertility and higher labor force participation. The findings show that removing cultural barriers to education can promote schooling and public life integration for culturally marginalized groups.

title: Are Medical Care Services Becoming Money-Making Machine in Human Society under Physicians' Headship in 21st Century Business-Driven World?
affiliations: Sheikh Hasina University of Science and Technology

detail.title: Are Medical Care Services Becoming Money-Making Machine in Human Society under Physicians' Headship in 21st Century Business-Driven World?
detail.abstract: In the 21st century world, people mostly behave with business mentality without considering moral obligations in society. In this behavioral change, the service market, particularly the medical care service market, has appeared to be vulnerable. Because of supplying medical care services, the doctor or hospital receives capitation payments, feesfor-services, risk pool settlements, incentive payments or other fees. However, today it is probably the most criticized profession in world economy country-wise such as Bangladesh. Sometimes doctors here are blamed for requiring unnecessary tests of patients for doctors' own monetary gains. In some cases, doctors' efforts are assumed to relate to pharmaceutical products promotion by writing lengthy prescriptions. Some groups claim that today doctors spend less time on each patient. All these interactions justify claiming that a patient works for a doctor when the patient visits a doctor for medical care services. Here the existence of "asymmetric information" dominates the medical care market where doctor takes advantages in multiple facets. It causes market inefficiency that creates negative economic externalities-deadweight loss. Improving medical education with special emphasis on ethical aspects and soft skills in communication is considered important in order to reduce the magnitudes of today's dilemma in the medical care service market. Also, strict enforcements of medical care provisions and ethical code of conduct among all health works can be instrumental. Finally, the answer to the question "Are medical care services becoming money-making machines under physicians' headship in the 21st century business-driven world?" depends on who are asked. But the reflections of today's medical care market in economy of Bangladesh are no deniable, which deserves to be studied further curtailing the magnitudes of the problem.

title: The Uses of Artificial Intelligence (AI) to Prototyping an Economic Phenomenon: The Economics Prototypes

detail.abstract: The economics prototypes is a new and transformative approach to teaching, learning, and researching economics from a methodological perspective. It begins with the manual creation of a simple prototype representing any economic phenomenon. From there, we progressively integrate artificial intelligence (AI) tools such as ChatGPT, ClickUp, Google Gemini, Microsoft Copilot, DeepSeek, and others. RES-Prototyping enables a shift in economics from being a purely theoretical discipline to becoming a practical tool for understanding and analyzing dynamic and complex socioeconomic phenomena through a more applicable and realistic lens. Today, it is possible to create, evaluate, and simulate such problems using real images or videos generated with AI. This allows for faster understanding and the identification of efficient and feasible solutions. Ultimately, the economics prototypes can be applied across all areas of economics, including microeconomics, macroeconomics, applied economics, economics thoughts, finance and banking, management, business economics, and other related fields.

title: Econometrically Testing the Twin Deficits Hypothesis

detail.title: Econometrically Testing the Twin Deficits Hypothesis

declarations.declarationOfInterest: Authors declare no competing interests

detail.abstract: The aim of this paper is to test the validity of the Twin Deficits hypothesis in India. In contrast to existing research on the subject, our paper econometrically tests the flow-through mechanism through which the twin deficits hypothesis operates according to the Mundell-Fleming IS-LM framework. We argue that existing literature on the subject provides inconclusive evidence on the causal link between the fiscal and current account deficit because such analyses rely on methodological assumptions about sectoral flows that do not necessarily hold empirically. In contrast, we study our econometric results in the context of both mainstream and Post-Keynesian theory to incorporate a sectoral flows-based approach, which recognises the complexities in macroeconomic flows. Further, our approach allows us to disaggregate the TDH into its component transmission stages and examine each stage of the causal chain separately instead of reducing the twin deficits to a simplistic theory. The theoretical and econometric results from this paper will thus allow policymakers to more completely assess the dynamics of government spending in an open economy and the full range of fiscal policy mechanisms at their disposal. These insights will be especially valuable in a country like India, where trade policymakers face difficult tradeoffs in balancing fiscal policy that achieves domestic policy objectives without compromising the sustainability of the current account.

title: Comparing U.S. and European Startups: What Can France Take Away

detail.title: Comparing U.S. and European Startups: What Can France Take Away
detail.abstract:
This paper grew out of my summer internship in venture capital with Cathay Capital, a leading investment firm operating across Europe, the US, and China. While living in Paris, I worked at Station F, the largest startup incubator in France, and also visited Y Combinator, the most well-known startup accelerator in the US. Through conversations with founders and investors in both countries, I kept hearing the same concern from many French entrepreneurs: to succeed, they often felt they had to leave France.

This observation became the starting point for my research into the causes of this talent drain and the steps France can take to retain its entrepreneurs. With the support of Cathay Capital, I conducted interviews with industry experts, compared the US and European startup ecosystems, and analyzed key factors such as funding availability, government policy, and startup culture. The paper concludes with specific recommendations aimed at strengthening France’s startup environment and enabling more homegrown companies to thrive.

title: Laws of Cosmic Evolution: Paradox, Singularity, and the Hyper-Universal Framework

detail.title: Laws of Cosmic Evolution: Paradox, Singularity, and the Hyper-Universal Framework

detail.abstract: This paper introduces two interrelated conceptual principles-the Law of Recursive Horizons and the Hyper-Universe Law-as frameworks for understanding cycles of paradox and singularity in cosmological and metaphysical evolution. We propose that paradoxes signify the breakdown of prevailing logic, leading to singularities that establish new frameworks of coherence. This recursive process generates an infinite ladder of horizons, each birthing new paradoxes as consciousness and reality evolve. The Hyper-Universe Law situates these dynamics within a hexagonal meta-structure connecting six fundamental planes of existence, unified by a central nucleus and axis. This synthesis offers potential insights into cosmology, philosophy of mind, and narrative structures in speculative fiction.

title: A Comparative Analysis of U.S. and French Policy Responses and the Countries' Respective Startup Ecosystems After COVID-19

detail.title: A Comparative Analysis of U.S. and French Policy Responses and the Countries' Respective Startup Ecosystems After COVID-19
detail.abstract:
The COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 was an unprecedented global crisis that disrupted economies and hit startup ecosystems hard. Startups—small, innovative companies with high growth potential—faced halted supply chains, collapsing demand, and severe funding uncertainty. The U.S. economy contracted by 3.5% and France’s by 7.9% amid strict lockdowns. Yet both nations recognized the strategic role of startups as engines of innovation and growth, responding with stimulus measures, emergency business aid, and targeted startup support.

The United States, home to Silicon Valley and a deep venture capital network, took a broad-based, market-oriented approach, aiming to stabilize the entire economy through large-scale monetary and fiscal action. France, with a smaller but rapidly growing ecosystem supported by initiatives like “La French Tech,” adopted more targeted, interventionist policies to sustain startups directly.

This paper examines the pandemic’s impact on each country’s startup and venture capital environment before, during, and after the crisis, comparing the scope and effectiveness of their policy responses. It also explores how startups adapted, accelerating shifts toward online services and digital infrastructure. We conclude with comparative insights, policy recommendations, and lessons for strengthening startup resilience in future crises—especially as green and sustainable priorities take center stage.

title: Translating Strategy into Action: The Role of the Balanced Scorecard
