detail.abstract: The Balanced Scorecard (BSC) is an integrated management model that transforms an organization's strategic goals into measurable criteria covering four main perspectives: finance, customers, internal processes, and organizational learning and development. Unlike traditional models, the BSC provides a link between financial and non-financial indicators through logical and time dependencies, thus facilitating strategic planning and control. The model is based on stakeholder theory and combines elements of value-based management. Its application encourages the introduction of modern methods for measuring intangible assets and creates a basis for developing strategic budgets. The BSC is not a universal template, but an adaptive framework tailored to the specific strategy, market environment, and competitive advantages of the organization.

title: Digitally Delivered Services Are Undertaxed: What the Data from Ghana, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa Show

detail.title: Digitally Delivered Services Are Undertaxed: What the Data from Ghana, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa Show

declarations.funderStatement: Open Society Foundation via grant made to the House of Fiscal Wisdom

detail.abstract: This paper examines the taxation of digitally delivered services (DDS) across Nigeria, Kenya, Ghana, and South Africa using comprehensive trade, revenue, and digital economy data from 2014-2023. The findings show that traditional trade statistics capture less than 15% of taxable digital economic activity, with Nigeria's implied tax base of USD 33.4 billion dwarfing its recorded digital imports of USD 4.2 billion. Despite having the lowest VAT rate at 7.5%, Nigeria collects USD 2.5 billion annually achieving USD 306 per internet user compared to Kenya's USD 12 per user with a 16% rate demonstrating that enforcement mechanisms and simplified compliance matter more than tax rates. Comparing international proposals reveals their inadequacy for developing countries: OECD's Amount A would generate less than USD 50 million across all four countries due to its EUR 20 billion threshold; a similar approach to India's Equalisation Levy would yield USD 200-300 million with its narrow scope; and UN Article 12A requires lengthy bilateral negotiations for USD 500-800 million. In contrast, the study's proposed comprehensive framework: covering all digital services through existing VAT systems with development-adjusted rates and simplified compliance could generate USD 7.8 billion annually, with USD 4.8 billion in untapped revenue identified. The findings challenge conventional approaches to digital taxation and demonstrate that developing countries can successfully mobilise significant revenues through appropriately designed unilateral measures. Implementation requires only 6-12 months using existing infrastructure, compared to years for treaty-based alternatives. For UNFCITC negotiators, the evidence strongly supports adopting comprehensive, simplified frameworks over complex multilateral proposals that fail to address developing country revenue needs and administrative constraints.

It examines key achievements, including increased industrial production, reduced unemployment, and improved access to labor markets, as well as challenges such as declining remittances and the need to diversify the economy. Particular attention is paid to cooperation with Russia and China, including projects in the energy, transport logistics, and mining sectors. The article emphasizes the importance of systemic reforms for Kyrgyzstan’s sustainable development.

title: Balance of Payments in the Republic of Moldova

detail.title: Balance of Payments in the Republic of Moldova

keywords: International Monetary Fund (IMF) Jel Classification: E60

detail.abstract: The Balance of Payments (BoP) is a fundamental macroeconomic tool that records all economic transactions between a country and the rest of the world over a specific period. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the structure, significance, and policy relevance of the BoP in both theoretical and practical contexts. It explores the major components of the BoP-the current account, capital account, and financial account-and their interrelationships in shaping national economic performance. Special attention is given to the role of BoP in economic policy formulation, including its influence on exchange rate management, monetary and fiscal policies, and external debt sustainability. The paper also addresses key challenges in BoP analysis, such as data limitations, classification ambiguities, and the complexity of global capital flows. A case study of the Republic of Moldova illustrates how small, open economies navigate BoP dynamics amid external vulnerabilities, reliance on remittances, and structural reform efforts. The study underscores the importance of external support, institutional reforms, and regional integration in achieving macroeconomic stability. Overall, the paper concludes that while the BoP is an indispensable tool for understanding external economic relations, it must be interpreted with caution and supplemented with broader macroeconomic and structural analysis. As the global economy becomes more interconnected and volatile, accurate and timely BoP analysis remains essential for effective policy response and longterm economic resilience.

title: DBT in Fertilizer Subsidy and its impact on Agricultural Productivity -Evidence from plot level data in India

detail.abstract: Our paper provides evidence on the effectiveness of Direct Benefit Transfer policy in fertilizer (DBT-F)in India on crop (wheat) yield, consumption of fertilizers, and changes in the prices of fertilizers. The policy was introduced in pilot districts across the country where some districts provided intervention while others kept out of the program for the first 12 months. We use difference in difference (DiD) methodology to study the impact of the policy. Our DiD estimate shows introduction of DBT-F has enhanced yield meaningfully. We also observe there is increase in the consumption demand of fertilizer K. However we do not find any changes in the consumption demand of fertilizers (N & P) as well as changes in the price of fertilizer (NPK) due to policy implementation. We conjecture that the policy might have led to timely availability of fertilizers and an improvement in the quality of fertilizers that could be driving a gain in yield.

detail.abstract: Since the onset of intensified sanctions pressure against Russia, the issue of federal budget balance has become increasingly relevant. In 2022 and 2023, the federal budget deficit amounted to 3.3 and 3.2 trillion rubles, respectively, primarily due to the annual growth of the country's expenditure obligations. At the same time, the general concept of Russia's public finance policy is typically based on maintaining a balanced budget-where total expenditures are either commensurate with or only slightly exceed revenues 1. Thus, ensuring budgetary balance becomes a fundamental aspect of Russia's economic security under sanctions. The aim of this study is to analyze the impact of the federal budget deficit and external debt on the overall balance of the Russian federal budget.

title: MGR's Food Eating Scenes and Social Advocacy in Tamil Cinema

MGR, who served as Tamil Nadu's Chief Minister from 1977 to 1987, used cinema as a powerful medium to address social issues while creating memorable culinary moments that resonated deeply with audiences. His films consistently portrayed food as both a source of sustenance and a symbol of social equality, while simultaneously challenging caste-based discrimination through carefully crafted narratives.

detail.abstract: India faces a profound mental health crisis, marked by the largest population in the world, a high prevalence of disorders and a severe shortage of qualified professionals. Recent policy initiatives, including the National Education Policy (NEP) 2020 and the National Commission for Allied and Healthcare Professions (NCAHP) Act 2021, aim to reform psychology education to address these challenges. This article critically examines the evolving landscape of psychology higher education in India, focusing on the curricula proposed by the NCAHP and the Rehabilitation Council of India (RCI). While the NCAHP's B. Psy model curriculum represents a commendable step towards competency-based education, it faces implementation hurdles related to restrictive entry requirements, regulatory ambiguities, and infrastructural demands. Concurrently, the RCI's introduction of a B.Sc. Clinical Psychology (Hons.) program, with its nomenclature and scope of practice, creates further discord and potential jurisdictional overlaps with the NCAHP and the University Grants Commission (UGC). This article analyses these competing frameworks, their alignment with existing legislation and international standards, and their implications for the standardisation and regulation of psychology professionals. It proposes recommendations for fostering synergy among regulatory bodies, clarifying professional roles, and enhancing the accessibility and quality of psychology education to build a robust mental health workforce. Strengthening psychology education and professional regulation is a national imperative and central to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), particularly SDG 3 on good health and well-being.

title: Scheduled for Risk: Dynamic Pricing, Algorithmic Management, and Occupational Risks in Platform Work
affiliations: Public Policy Research Centre and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Scheduled for Risk: Dynamic Pricing, Algorithmic Management, and Occupational Risks in Platform Work
detail.abstract: This study examines occupational safety and health (OSH) risks stemming from dynamic pricing and algorithmic management in food delivery platforms. It contributes to International Labour Organization (ILO) discussions on safe working environments (ILO, 1981, 2006, 2022) by showing how algorithm-driven wage structures and performance incentives shape worker safety, well-being, and risk-related behaviours. Framing earnings volatility as a structural OSH concern within algorithmic wage systems, the study draws on Labour Process Theory and Regulatory Theory and engages with the socio-technical dynamics that co-produce work risk. While the EU Platform Work Directive addresses algorithmic transparency and worker classification, it remains largely silent on the OSH implications of dynamic pricing (European Commission, 2024). To bridge this gap, the study introduces the "algorithmic risk cycle," a conceptual model illustrating how dynamic compensation structures create recursive incentives for risky behaviours, including speeding, long hours, and skipped breaks. This approach complements existing research that has identified links between platform pay systems and health outcomes but advances the analysis by focusing more tightly on the interplay of scheduling models, wage variability, and risk governance. The study investigates: How do shift-based and flexible scheduling models affect worker OSH? What regulatory limitations contribute to the persistence of risks linked to dynamic pricing and AM? How can OSH policy frameworks better protect platform workers? Based on 20 qualitative interviews with Serbian couriers (Wolt and Glovo), the research reveals how algorithmically structured earnings influence behavioural patterns with OSH consequences. The paper concludes by outlining a regulatory model including wage stabilisation, algorithmic risk audits, and extended OSH coverage aligned with ILO and OECD standards.

title: Anticipating AI Revolution: How Future Narratives Corrupt Present Morals

detail.title: Anticipating AI Revolution: How Future Narratives Corrupt Present Morals
detail.abstract: This study investigates the psychological impact of anticipating a socially transformative future driven by artificial intelligence (AI). While global debates focus on the material consequences of AI deployment, the preemptive effects of its societal imaginary remain underexplored. We hypothesize that exposure to narratives of a revolutionary AI future induces structural uncertainty about prevailing social and moral norms, which in turn fosters moral disengagement and opportunistic, self-serving behavior. This hypothesis was tested through two lab-in-field experiments conducted in Goma and Bukavu, Democratic Republic of Congo (N=105 and N=180, respectively). Participants were randomly assigned to a treatment group, primed with the revolutionary capabilities of AI, or a control group. Unethical behavior was measured using a coin-flip task with a financial incentive for dishonesty, and moral disengagement was assessed with a validated, context-specific scale. The results consistently show that the AI-primed group reported a statistically significant higher proportion of advantageous outcomes in the coin-flip task, indicating increased dishonesty (Hypothesis 1 supported). This group also scored significantly higher on the moral disengagement scale (Hypothesis 2 supported). However, mediation analyses revealed that moral disengagement did not account for the increase in dishonest behavior, suggesting a direct link between the anticipation of an AI revolution and unethical acts (Hypothesis 3 rejected). These findings demonstrate that AI's societal influence is not merely technological but also profoundly psychological, capable of eroding moral conduct through anticipatory narratives alone.

title: Will the Indian Youth Pay an Equal Amount for an Indian Brand or an Indian-Made Product as They Would for a Foreign Brand? A Dive into the Spending Psychology of the Indian Youth

detail.title: Will the Indian Youth Pay an Equal Amount for an Indian Brand or an Indian-Made Product as They Would for a Foreign Brand? A Dive into the Spending Psychology of the Indian Youth
detail.abstract: India's consumer landscape is experiencing a notable shift, particularly among its rapidly growing youth demographic. While global brands have long held prestige-often associated with quality, style, and social status-this dynamic is shifting. Factors such as increased local pride, government initiatives like "Make in India" and "Vocal for Local," and the influence of social media are reshaping how young Indians perceive and interact with brands. This research explores whether Indian youth are genuinely willing to spend the same amount on Indian brands as they do on international ones. Drawing insights from a primary survey of over 125 respondents aged 15 to 25, the study captures authentic youth perspectives on brand preference and spending behavior. It also incorporates secondary research from sources such as Mintel, McKinsey & Company, and the Boston Consulting Group to frame the findings within a broader economic and psychological context. The results highlight a thoughtful but cautious consumer mindset. While many young Indians express patriotic sentiments and a growing willingness to support local products, their purchasing decisions are still significantly influenced by perceived quality, social pressure, and the aspirational appeal of foreign labels. Indian brands are steadily gaining trust and traction-particularly in food, personal care, and apparel-but will need to continue building credibility and emotional resonance to compete with established global names fully.

detail.abstract: The traditional taxation system is experiencing systemic failure under the impact of the digital economy, and the rise of stablecoins further accelerates tax base erosion and the weakening of national fiscal sovereignty. This paper identifies 33 structural problems within legacy tax regimes and introduces the theory of “Structural Taxation” as an institutional response. By using “receipt-side structural nodes” as the sole tax base, structural tax automates collection, feedback, and redistribution through the logic embedded within digital currency systems. The research demonstrates that this model addresses 29 chronic flaws in traditional taxation, exhibits adaptive capability under extreme conditions (e.g., war or capital shock), and provides a new governance paradigm for the digital currency era.

title: The effects of psychological empowerment on intention to quit job: the mediating role of job satisfaction among Airforce personnel
affiliations: Woxsen University, IIT Roorkee and IIT Roorkee

detail.title: The effects of psychological empowerment on intention to quit job: the mediating role of job satisfaction among Airforce personnel
detail.abstract: This study is based on variables of job satisfaction, psychological empowerment and intention to quit job. It establishes relationship among psychological empowerment, intention to quit and job satisfaction over first four ranks of the Indian Air Force (IAF) i.e. Aircraftsman, Leading Aircraftsman, Corporal and Sergeant. These four ranks make majority of the human resource of IAF. Purposive sampling method is used to take responses from 315 respondents. Measures of Job descriptive index and job in general scale (Smith et al.,1983, Brodke et al., 2009), psychological empowerment (Spreitzer, 1995) and Intention to quit job (Wayne et al., 1997) are used for the study. Pearson correlation and Structural Equation Modelling (SEM) were used for data analysis. Findings of the study suggest that psychological empowerment is negatively correlated to intention to quit and positively correlated to job satisfaction. In the presence of job satisfaction, direct effect of psychological empowerment on intention to quit diminishes and overall impact of psychological empowerment on intention to quit job is negative (r=-.24) in the presence of job satisfaction. In the five dimensions of Job Descriptive Index 'supervision satisfaction' was found to be the biggest negative predictor of intention to quit job, followed by, 'work satisfaction', pay, promotion, 'work satisfaction' and co-worker. It is the first study of its kind in the context of the Indian Air Force.

title: Regulation of the Use of Remuneration Consultants in South Africa: Proposals for Legislative Reform
affiliations: University of South Africa, University of South Africa and University of South Africa (UNISA)

detail.title: Regulation of the Use of Remuneration Consultants in South Africa: Proposals for Legislative Reform
detail.abstract: Over the years, companies have turned to remuneration consultants for guidance on remuneration matters. Their assistance is often sought when companies’ remuneration committees lack sufficient time, knowledge or data to decide effectively on executive remuneration. The assistance extends to accounting, tax and legal issues pertaining to executive remuneration. However, problems like potential conflicts of interest for remuneration consultants stem from factors such as the selection process, the duration of their contracts, and the services they provide to the company. A further challenge is benchmarking. Using remuneration consultants may contribute to excessive remuneration of executive directors, which in turn contributes to South Africa’s substantial socio-economic problems. Accordingly, the use of remuneration consultants must be strictly regulated in South Africa. This article examines how remuneration consultants are regulated by the Companies Act 71 of 2008, the JSE Limited Listings Requirements, and the King IV Report on Governance for South Africa, 2016. It compares the ways in which remuneration consultants are regulated in the United Kingdom, Australia and the United States of America. This article argues that the use of remuneration consultants is not sufficiently regulated in South Africa, and it makes recommendations to help enhance this regulation.

detail.abstract: Classical finance views asset value as the discounted sum of expected cash flows, implicitly assuming that the structural conditions enabling those flows are already in place. This paper advances a universal valuation principle: economic scarcity, defined as the monetizable intersection of desirability and constrained access. The concept applies across asset classes, from equities and commodities to digital assets, but blockchain networks provide a uniquely transparent laboratory for its study. In these systems, scarcity and incentives are implemented directly through protocol design, with key parameters observable on-chain. We develop a structural valuation framework that links five foundational value elements, Purpose, Incentives, Consensus, Tokenomics, and Network Effects, to both economic scarcity and the core architectural layers of distributed systems. This mapping bridges protocol engineering and asset pricing, showing how design choices shape scarcity conditions and monetizable value. The framework is formalized into a general network value function and applied in a comparative case study of Bitcoin, Ethereum, and Bittensor, which represent distinct paradigms in blockchain architecture and economic design. Our approach offers a unified analytical lens for valuing technologydriven and traditional assets alike, grounded in the structural origins of value rather than in cash flow projections alone.

detail.abstract: Hoạt động mua bán hàng hóa quốc tế đã hình thành từ lâu đời, đóng vai trò trọng yếu trong thương mại toàn cầu và ngày càng trở nên quan trọng trong bối cảnh hội nhập. Hợp đồng mua bán hàng hóa quốc tế, với tư cách là hình thức pháp lý cơ bản của giao dịch này, chịu sự điều chỉnh không chỉ bởi pháp luật quốc gia mà còn bởi nhiều văn kiện pháp lý quốc tế, trong đó nổi bật là Công ước Liên hợp quốc về Hợp đồng mua bán hàng hóa quốc tế năm 1980 (CISG). Từ khi ra đời, CISG đã được đông đảo quốc gia ủng hộ và áp dụng rộng rãi, trong đó Việt Nam trở thành thành viên thứ 84 vào năm 2015. Thực tiễn xét xử tại nhiều quốc gia cho thấy việc kết hợp trích dẫn án lệ nước ngoài và bình luận học thuật đã góp phần đảm bảo sự giải thích và áp dụng thống nhất, hiệu quả Công ước. Trong bối cảnh thương mại toàn cầu chịu tác động nghiêm trọng của đại dịch Covid-19 và các sự kiện quốc tế đầy biến động sau đó, CISG càng khẳng định vai trò là công cụ pháp lý bảo đảm công bằng, minh bạch và bảo vệ quyền lợi của thương nhân. Tác phẩm này giới thiệu những quy định cơ bản của CISG, minh họa bằng các án lệ tiêu biểu được chọn lọc và tóm tắt, hướng đến cung cấp cơ sở thực tiễn đáng tin cậy cho giới nghiên cứu và thực hành pháp luật, đồng thời mở đường cho những nghiên cứu chuyên sâu hơn trong các ấn phẩm tiếp theo.

title: Social infrastructure law in the UK, EU and US
affiliations: School of Law, King's College, London; Centre for Business Research, University of Cambridge

detail.title: Social infrastructure law in the UK, EU and US
detail.abstract: What should be the goals of social infrastructure, and the best means to achieve them? Social infrastructure is a new term to describe the welfare state, whose conceptual foundations were laid in Lord Beveridge’s Report, Social Insurance and Allied Services (1942). A good government, said Beveridge, should tackle five evil ‘giants’, namely disease, ignorance, squalor, idleness, and want. These could be overcome with a universal free health service, public education, public housing, full employment, and income insurance (especially old age pensions and unemployment). Today, nearly every country has policies to achieve these goals, but varying success. This chapter focuses on unequal fulfilment of the rights to universal free higher education, to health care, and to social security, full employment with fair pay, and housing, as shaped by central bank monetary policy. It focuses on the UK, EU and US. It contends that public education and health, free at the point of use, with democratic governance, produce the best outcomes: found more in Europe, not the US. It contends that central bank goals that place full employment and inflation on equal levels are superior: found more in the US than in Europe. All systems are far from fulfilling universal human rights.

detail.abstract: Political institutions often intervene in institutionalized disputes (e.g., litigation, labor conflicts, legislative standoffs) through de-escalation policies such as mediation, arbitration, or procedural reform. But mistimed intervention can backfire. We develop a dynamic bargaining model showing that early de-escalation can prolong or escalate disputes, even under perfect enforcement and minimal bargaining frictions. Two mechanisms explain this result. The Strategic De-escalation Paradox shows that early relief lowers conflict costs, encouraging delay. Strategic Concession Deferral reveals that parties postpone settlement to exploit institutional support. Using 440,000 U.S. federal lawsuits and a staggered rollout of court-mandated mediation, we find that premature ADR increases case duration by 20% and reduces the probability of settlement following procedural milestones by 4-7 percentage points. Estimated per-case costs exceed $225,000 (2023 USD), totaling $16.1 billion. Timing is not merely a detail of institutional design: it is central to effective interventions.

title: Climate Change and Air Conditioner: Heat Wave Effects Across Countries

detail.title: Climate Change and Air Conditioner: Heat Wave Effects Across Countries
detail.abstract: Climate change mitigation policies face implementation challenges due to unequal costs and benefits across countries and individuals. Air conditioning exemplifies this tension: while it reduces personal heat discomfort, it also contributes to global warming through energy consumption and refrigerant emissions. This paper examines how consumers' relative interest in climate change versus air conditioning evolves in response to heat waves, using Google Trends data across countries and over time. I find that in high-income countries, heat waves lead to increased interest in air conditioning relative to climate change, while in low-income countries, the opposite occurs. These patterns are associated with differences in income, electricity access, and inequality. Addressing such disparities requires policies that support sustainable and equitable adaptation. I examine one such intervention: an exogenous policy change introducing air conditioning restrictions in several European countries in 2022. The results show that these restrictions significantly reduced interest in cooling. The findings highlight the need for more equitable climate strategies and for promoting sustainable consumption patterns in wealthier nations.

title: Stochastic Boundaries in Spatial General Equilibrium: A Diffusion-Based Approach to Causal Inference with Spillover Effects

detail.title: Stochastic Boundaries in Spatial General Equilibrium: A Diffusion-Based Approach to Causal Inference with Spillover Effects

keywords: Artificial intelligence adoption JEL Classification: C31

detail.abstract: This paper introduces a novel framework for causal inference in spatial economics that explicitly models the stochastic transition from partial to general equilibrium effects. We develop a Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Model (DDPM) integrated with boundary detection methods from stochastic process theory to identify when and how treatment effects propagate beyond local markets. Our approach treats the evolution of spatial spillovers as a Lévy process with jump-diffusion dynamics, where the first passage time to critical thresholds indicates regime shifts from partial to general equilibrium. Using CUSUM-based sequential detection, we identify the spatial and temporal boundaries at which local interventions become systemic. Applied to AI adoption across Japanese prefectures, we find that treatment effects exhibit Lévy jumps at approximately 35km spatial scales, with general equilibrium effects amplifying partial equilibrium estimates by 42%. Monte Carlo simulations show that ignoring these stochastic boundaries leads to underestimation of treatment effects by 28-67%, with 1 particular severity in densely connected economic regions. Our framework provides the first rigorous method for determining when spatial spillovers necessitate general equilibrium analysis, offering crucial guidance for policy evaluation in interconnected economies.

title: Forward Guidance and the Yield Curve
affiliations: Miami University - Department of Economics and Miami University

detail.title: Forward Guidance and the Yield Curve
detail.abstract: An inverted yield curve has traditionally predicted recessions by signaling market expectations of falling short-term interest rates. We document a structural break in June 2009 that weakens this predictive relationship. Using a New Keynesian model with Epstein-Zin preferences and stochastic volatility, we show that forward guidance compresses the term premium and flattens the yield curve. By reducing the risk households associate with holding long-term bonds, forward guidance dampens the response of yields to shifting economic conditions. The model replicates the decline in predictive power observed in the data, suggesting that forward guidance has muted the yield curve's informational content.

detail.title: Does government debt and degree of openness and oil price on the inflation rates in GCC countries: Evidence from PARDL and PNARDL approach
detail.abstract: This study explores the linear and non-linear effects of government debt, trade openness, and oil prices on inflation rates in Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) countries from 1980 to 2024. The study uses both the Panel Autoregressive Distributed Lag (PARDL) and Panel Nonlinear ARDL (PNARDL) models to analyze asymmetric long-run and short-run dynamics while accounting for stationarity, co-integration, and causal links. The findings indicate that government debt, openness, and oil prices all have considerable and asymmetric effects on inflation, with positive shocks to openness greatly magnifying inflationary pressures. The error correction terms support long-term convergence. Bootstrap causality tests indicate bidirectional and crisis-sensitive correlations between variables, most notably during the 2007-2008 financial crisis and the COVID-19 pandemic. The findings highlight the importance of tailored fiscal and monetary policies that account for structural inequalities and external shocks.

detail.abstract: This paper examines the convergence dynamics of inflation, economic development, and exchange rates in six North African countries-Algeria, Egypt, Libya, Mauritania, Morocco, and Tunisiafrom 1980 to 2024. The analysis uses a unique econometric approach, including panel unit root tests, multivariate convergence and stability models, and Dumitrescu-Hurlin panel causality tests, to determine whether these macroeconomic variables show symptoms of convergence and dependency. The findings suggest statistically significant but diverse convergence tendencies, with better synchronization in Morocco, Tunisia, Algeria, and Libya, while Egypt and Mauritania continue to diverge. Notably, the analysis finds strong bidirectional causality between inflation, exchange rates, and economic growth, underscoring inflation's critical role in regional macroeconomic interactions. Conversely, the weak causal relationship between exchange rates and growth highlights structural impediments to effective monetary transmission. These findings have significant implications for policy coordination, inflation targeting, and regional monetary integration, particularly in the context of a possible North African monetary union. The paper suggests specific convergence tactics and structural reforms to improve macroeconomic alignment and integration throughout the area.

title: The end of the era of increasing home sizes
affiliations: German Institute for Economic Research (DIW Berlin)

detail.title: The end of the era of increasing home sizes
detail.abstract: Since at least the 1940s, there has been a significant increase in home size and housing availability. Improved welfare enabled the construction of larger homes, a trend likely fueled in part by the baby boom. However, a pivotal turning point emerged in the early 2000s, leading to a reversal of this trend. In this context, I explore the evidence of this shift and thoroughly investigate three potential contributing factors, including shrinking household sizes, rising housing prices, and land-use regulations that restrict the construction of single-family homes.

title: A 2025 Labour Market Analysis: Reframing Sabah's Employment Crisis Through Wage Policy and Informal Labour Absorption

detail.title: A 2025 Labour Market Analysis: Reframing Sabah's Employment Crisis Through Wage Policy and Informal Labour Absorption
detail.abstract: Background: Sabah's 2025 employment crisis is often attributed to the growing presence of undocumented foreign workers, with public narratives suggesting they are displacing local workers. However, this perception conceals deeper structural failures within the state's labour governance and wage policy frameworks. Scope and Purpose: This brief challenges the dominant narrative of migrant-local labour competition by reframing the issue through a structural lens. It examines the intersection of wage stagnation, informal labour absorption, employer incentives and fragmented regulatory enforcement as the actual drivers of labour market dysfunction in Sabah. Analysis: Using behavioural analysis, institutional critique and current employment data, the study demonstrates how wage policy failure constitutes a form of structural violence. The preference for undocumented labour is shown to be a rational employer response to policy and enforcement gaps. Informality is not incidental but systemically reinforced by the absence of meaningful incentives for formalisation and the lack of coordinated regulatory oversight. Implications: The findings call for a systemic reorientation of Sabah's labour governance. This includes contextual wage calibration, enforcement mechanisms that hold employers accountable, targeted incentives for SMEs to formalise hiring and a broader cultural shift in the valuation of local labour. Without such reforms, the state risks entrenching an exploitative dual labour market that undermines both economic equity and social cohesion.

title: Sustainable Supply Chain Management in Southeast Asian Manufacturing: Practices, Barriers, and Opportunities

detail.title: Sustainable Supply Chain Management in Southeast Asian Manufacturing: Practices, Barriers, and Opportunities
detail.abstract: • Sustainable supply chain management (SSCM) is increasingly vital for aligning manufacturing with global sustainability goals, yet its adoption in Southeast Asia’s dynamic manufacturing sector remains underexplored. This study examines SSCM practices in three ASEAN countries—Vietnam (electronics), Thailand (textiles), and Malaysia (automotive)—using a qualitative case study approach. Drawing on interviews with supply chain managers and secondary data, the research identifies key practices, including green logistics, circular economy principles, and renewable energy integration, alongside barriers such as high costs, regulatory fragmentation, and global supply chain disruptions. Opportunities include regional collaboration, rising consumer demand for sustainable products, and digital technologies like blockchain. The findings highlight industry-specific and regional nuances, contributing to the SSCM literature by addressing a gap in ASEAN-focused research. The study offers practical implications for firms to adopt cost-effective sustainability practices and for policymakers to harmonize regional regulations, supporting the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs 8, 12, and 13). By providing a Southeast Asian perspective, this research advances the global discourse on sustainable industrial growth in emerging economies.

title: Population Ageing and Intergenerational Conflict: A Post-Keynesian View
affiliations: University of York - Department of Economics and Related Studies

detail.title: Population Ageing and Intergenerational Conflict: A Post-Keynesian View

publicationDetails.detailsText: Journal of Economic Studies, Vol. 19, No. 2, pp. 26-37, 1992

detail.abstract: Population ageing has been seen as creating economic problems often described as a worsening intergenerational conflict for resources.  A rising dependency ratio is said to increase the 'burden' on the working population by forcing sacrifices in their consumption.  Such apparently intuitive ideas are based on the assumption of a binding aggregate resource constraint, as would occur if resources were fully utilised.  From a post-Keynesian perspective, however, unemployment and excess capacity are normal to the functioning of capitalist economies, and resources are not in general fully utilised.  This paper argues that the Keynesian process of national income determination precludes any immediate relationship between population ageing and the 'burden' imposed on income recipients.  Below full employment, a rising dependency ratio is not guaranteed to reduce the expenditure share of income recipients or raise their tax rates.  An exclusive emphasis on intergenerational conflict can give a misleading impression of the consequences of population ageing.

title: Comparing Black Scholes Model Hedging and the Moore Hedge Ratio Original May 3. 2022 Last revised August 4, 2025

detail.title: Comparing Black Scholes Model Hedging and the Moore Hedge Ratio Original May 3. 2022 Last revised August 4, 2025
detail.abstract: The discounted cash flow hedge, Moore's R, is evaluated alongside several hedge ratios established in previous research. Distinctions are identified among the Black-Scholes hedge ratio, its practitioner variant, and the present value option model-derived Moore's R. These discrepancies are most apparent for out-of-the-money options, where the Black-Scholes model tends to produce larger errors. The natural logarithm of the ratio between Moore's R and the standard Black-Scholes hedge serves as an effective model for relative error within the Black-Scholes framework, whereas using the logarithm for the Practitioner Black-Scholes ratio compared to the basic Black-Scholes hedge shows less explanatory power. Moore's R hedge ratio consistently exhibits greater alignment with empirical observations and may provide improved performance. It demonstrates a linear relationship across the data. Users may consider evaluating its practical applications. .

title: Deep Learning and Geospatial Analytics for Real-Time Urban Air Pollution Forecasting

detail.title: Deep Learning and Geospatial Analytics for Real-Time Urban Air Pollution Forecasting
detail.abstract: Rapid urbanization has intensified air quality concerns, prompting the need for accurate and timely pollution forecasting systems. This study presents a framework that integrates deep learning techniques with geospatial analytics to enable real-time prediction of urban air pollution levels. Leveraging heterogeneous datasets such as satellite imagery, ground-based sensor readings, meteorological variables, and traffic flow records, the proposed approach applies convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for spatial pattern recognition and long short-term memory (LSTM) models for temporal trend analysis. Geospatial analytics enhances the predictive model by incorporating spatial autocorrelation and pollutant dispersion patterns, enabling localized and city-wide forecasts. The framework was evaluated using data from a high-density metropolitan area, demonstrating superior predictive accuracy compared to conventional statistical and standalone machine learning methods. Results indicate that combining deep learning with geospatial insights can capture both dynamic temporal fluctuations and complex spatial dependencies, making it a powerful tool for real-time decision support in urban air quality management. This work contributes to smart city development by providing a scalable and adaptive forecasting solution that can guide environmental policy, urban planning, and public health interventions.

detail.abstract: The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development emphasises the necessity of strong institutions, transparent governance, and effective mobilisation of domestic resources. This paper argues that rigorous financial regulation-particularly anti-money-laundering (AML) and counter-terrorismfinancing (CFT) frameworks-acts as a catalytic enabler of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Using Pakistan's 2018-2023 compliance with the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) 40 Recommendations and 11 Immediate Outcomes as a natural experiment, the study shows how enhanced financial transparency, inter-agency coordination, and confiscation policies created socioeconomic conditions conducive to SDG progress. A mixed-methods approach combines regulatory analysis with time-series indicators on illicit financial flows, tax revenues, and social spending. Findings reveal a 22 % reduction in suspicious cash-based transactions alongside a 15 % increase in development-oriented public expenditure. Comparative regional data indicate that Pakistan's post-compliance trajectory outperforms Bangladesh and India on SDG 16 (Institutions) and SDG 17 (Partnerships). The paper offers a conceptual framework linking financial integrity to SDG acceleration and proposes policy recommendations for other developing economies.

title: Sukavichinomics: The 1994 Bangkok Smart Sports City

detail.title: Sukavichinomics: The 1994 Bangkok Smart Sports City
detail.abstract: This study revisits and re-evaluates one of Thailand's most forward-thinking but ultimately unrealized urban development initiatives: the 1994 Bangkok Smart Sports City, conceptualized under the leadership of His Excellency Mr.Sukavich Rangsitpol, then Deputy Prime Minister overseeing national infrastructure. As a core element of Sukavichinomics-a development paradigm centered on human capital, integrated planning, and institutional coherence-the project was designed not merely as a venue for the upcoming 1998 Asian Games, but as a prototype for inclusive, sustainable, and future-ready urban development in Southeast Asia.

title: Retirement-age Extension and Investment in Health Capital

detail.title: Retirement-age Extension and Investment in Health Capital
detail.abstract: This study investigates the effect of retirement-age extension on individuals' investment in health capital. Using microdata from the Korean Labor and Income Panel Study (KLIPS) between 2009 and 2019, we apply a regression discontinuity design (RDD) and a difference-indifferences (DID) approach. Our findings show a significant increase in exercise time-a proxy for investment in health capital-among individuals affected by the reform. These results are robust to various specifications and suggest that individuals respond to expected increases in lifetime earnings by adjusting their health-related behaviors.

title: Emergence of Entropy from Asymmetric Exchange

detail.title: Emergence of Entropy from Asymmetric Exchange
detail.abstract: I present a new framework in which entropy arises as the shape record of cumulative asymmetry in exchange systems, rather than as a scalar summary of combinatorial microstates. By abandoning strict conservation assumptions and modeling purely asymmetric and dissipative interactions, I derive a generalized gamma-type stationary distribution from a minimal exchange rule. I then reinterpret entropy as a dynamic trajectory functional, offering a generative, process-based understanding of uncertainty that connects structural asymmetry to distribution shape.

title: Digital Dirham - A Primer on the UAE's Central Bank Digital Currency
affiliations: Central Bank of the UAE, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Copenhagen Business School, Central Bank of the UAE, European Central Bank (ECB), Central Bank of the UAE, Central Bank of the UAE, Central Bank of the UAE, Central Bank of the UAE, Central Bank of the UAE and BIS Innovation Hub

detail.title: Digital Dirham - A Primer on the UAE's Central Bank Digital Currency

publicationDetails.detailsText: Policy Paper No. 01/2025 (Abu Dhabi: Central Bank of the UAE), available at https://www.centralbank.ae/media/lczb23l4/cbdc-short-report_july.pdf

detail.abstract:
The Central Bank of the UAE (CBUAE) will soon be launching the UAE’s central bank digital currency (CBDC) – the “Digital Dirham” in all formats (wholesale and retail) – in response to the evolving needs of a digital economy while also future-proofing central bank money for the digital era. The Digital Dirham will serve as a digital version of the UAE’s national currency, enabling instant settlements and widespread accessibility with the security and trust of traditional central bank-backed money.

The Digital Dirham is a core element of the CBUAE’s multi-year Financial Infrastructure Transformation (FIT) programme, which aims at modernising the UAE’s payment system and monetary framework. The CBUAE has explored the possibility of issuing a CBDC since 2019, recognising that the use of alternative forms of money could marginalise access to central bank money, and, thereby, impede the ability of central banks to meet their policy mandates. In January 2024, the first Digital Dirham as legal tender was issued on the issuance platform, when His Highness Sheikh Mansour bin Zayed Al Nahyan, Chairman of the CBUAE, initiated the first cross-border payment on the mBridge minimum viable product (MVP) using the Digital Dirham. Project mBridge was collaboration between the BIS Innovation Hub, the Bank of Thailand, Hong Kong Monetary Authority, the Digital Currency Institute of the People’s Bank of China and the CBUAE. During the same time, the CBUAE also carried out a real-value retail pilot to evaluate the future design, technology and advantages of the Digital Dirham and developed four digital economy use cases to assess the feasibility and effectiveness of the Digital Dirham as an innovative universal payment method, which – in its planned configuration – can open up new business models and spur financial innovation through flexible interoperability, accessibility, and programmability.

The CBUAE will introduce the Digital Dirham in phases, with key design features aimed at mitigating risks while enabling innovation, including an intermediated two-tier distribution model and wallet-based access. The Digital Dirham at launch will be a non-interest bearing CBDC to encourage the primary use as a means of payment (rather than a substitute for savings) and will be fully fungible with other forms of the Dirham (cash, deposits). A cautious, flexible and collaborative approach aims to maximise the Digital Dirham’s success based on effective use cases for retail, wholesale, and cross-border transactions.

This report summarises the key policy and design factors that informed the development of the Digital Dirham as secure, trusted and convenient form of money. It also provides an update on the current progress and preparatory steps before the full roll out to the general public, business, and government entities in the near future. A detailed analysis of the relevant policy issues and the CBUAE’s impact analysis of introducing the Digital Dirham can be in found in a working paper (“Digital Dirham: Selected Issues and Policy Considerations”).

title: Misery and Prosociality: the Long-run Impact of Early-life Adversity on Prosocial Behavior in China's 1959-1961 Great Famine

detail.title: Misery and Prosociality: the Long-run Impact of Early-life Adversity on Prosocial Behavior in China's 1959-1961 Great Famine
detail.abstract: We study the early origins of prosocial behavior by using exogenous exposure to the Great Chinese Famine during early childhood. Using a cohort-based difference-indifferences approach, we find that individuals exposed to the famine between ages 1 and 3 years at its onset exhibit significantly higher charitable donations six decades later. This effect is especially strong for individuals who had siblings during the famine. We provide suggestive evidence that the increase in prosociality is driven by enhanced intra-household interactions during the famine, rather than by income or religiosity effects. These findings highlight the role of family interactions in fostering social altruism, especially in the context of early-life adversity.

title: Deep Causal Inequalities
affiliations: University of Washington - Michael G. Foster School of Business, Arizona State University (ASU) - Department of Information Systems, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Meta

detail.title: Deep Causal Inequalities
detail.abstract: Many econometric problems can be expressed as systems of inequalities derived from agents’ observed behavior. While such inequality-based formulations have been explored in the partial identification literature, existing approaches are typically parametric and do not scale well to high-dimensional or unstructured data. We extend this framework to the non-parametric setting and develop the Deep Causal Inequalities (DeepCI) estimator—a flexible minimax procedure that uses neural networks to approximate the underlying functions. The key idea is to replace direct use of observed labels with moment inequalities inferred from revealed preference, which allows us to factor out endogenous components and address unobserved confounding without requiring strong instruments. We establish consistency under mild conditions and derive adaptive estimation error bounds in the projected root mean squared error norm, appropriate for the ill-posed nature of these problems. While our framework applies broadly, we illustrate its effectiveness in the context of demand estimation for differentiated products, using both low-dimensional (structured) and high-dimensional (unstructured) data. Monte Carlo experiments show that DeepCI accurately recovers the underlying functions even under substantial endogeneity.

title: How Casino Match Play Promotions Can Hook Gamblers (and Non-Gamblers) ---WORKING PAPER, NOT FOR CITATION
affiliations: Georgia College & State University and College of Charleston - Department of Economics

detail.title: How Casino Match Play Promotions Can Hook Gamblers (and Non-Gamblers) ---WORKING PAPER, NOT FOR CITATION
detail.abstract: Casino operators frequently use the promotional gambling vouchers, free play and match play. In the case of free play, customers are offered gambling credits that function much like real money and patrons are able to quickly turn their promotional play into cash without risking their own money. Match play, however, can only be employed at table games and their use necessitates gamblers to wager their own funds. We conduct a thorough analysis of how match play can affect gamblers' individual behavior. First, we assess the value of match play promotions, which we argue is ambiguous. Then, using behavioral economics concepts, we consider how match play promotions affect the risk appetite of casino patrons. While our analyses suggest that profit seeking casino operators are wise to prioritize match play promotions, we provide evidence that match play offers could be used to target and exploit problem gamblers. As such, their usage as marketing tools may not align with responsible gambling initiatives.

title: Did Higher Individual Taxes Spur Firm Investment? The 2013 Obama Individual Investment Tax
affiliations: Loyola Marymount University - Department of Finance, University of Texas at San Antonio - Department of Finance and Loyola Marymount University - College of Business Administration

detail.title: Did Higher Individual Taxes Spur Firm Investment? The 2013 Obama Individual Investment Tax

keywords: 2013 Investment Tax Increase JEL classification codes: H24
2013 Individual Investment Tax JEL classification codes: H24

detail.abstract: This paper examines the largest tax increase on individual investment income in U.S. history and its impact on corporate investment. Despite concerns about disrupting capital formation, firms with investors most affected by the tax increase reduce dividends and increase investment relative to less-affected peers. Research and development (R&D)-intensive firms redirect cash from dividend reductions to fund more R&D, yielding more highly cited patents, while non-R&D firms increase acquisitions. To support our main findings, we conduct a series of placebo, falsification, and robustness tests. These complementary tests provide strong support for the validity of our identification strategy and the causal interpretation of our main results. Overall, this paper contributes to the literature on taxation and corporate behavior, providing novel evidence that increases in individual-level taxes influence corporate financial policies and investment decisions.

title: A Non-Conservative Kinetic Framework for Econophysics

detail.title: A Non-Conservative Kinetic Framework for Econophysics
detail.abstract: This paper presents a novel kinetic framework for macroeconomics grounded in the asymmetric microstructure of trade. Unlike classical models that assume value conservation, utility maximization, or equilibrium, this framework introduces three primitives-surplus generation, monetary exchange, and nonlinear decay-to model the economy as a non-equilibrium system with endogenous flows. Drawing on Boltzmann and Fokker-Planck dynamics, I derive agent-level transitions and aggregate macro variables such as wealth, money supply, surplus, decay, and inflation. I characterize laminar flow attractors, cyclic booms and busts, inflationary divergence, and inequality bifurcations as emergent patterns within the distribution of agents. This approach reframes macroeconomic behavior not as equilibrium outcome, but as flow geometry within a dissipative system.

title: The Long and Winding Road to Growth: Terrain, History, and Economic Development in India
affiliations: London School of Economics & Political Science (LSE)

detail.title: The Long and Winding Road to Growth: Terrain, History, and Economic Development in India
detail.abstract: This paper provides causal evidence on the impact of national highways on local GDP per capita in India. To isolate exogenous variation in modern highway density, I implement a dual-instrument strategy that combines terrain features with historical road networks from the pre-independence period. I extend an original spatial dataset by digitizing Indian road maps from 1928, 1969, 2011, and 2021 using supervised image classification techniques, and merge this with high-resolution grid-level GDP data. Two-stage least squares estimates with state fixed effects show that a one percentage point increase in national highway density raises local income by 11-14 percent on average. However, these gains are highly uneven: the effects are concentrated in the richest regions, while poorer areas experience little to no benefit. The results are robust to a range of checks, including reverse causality tests and leave-one-state-out specifications. To interpret these patterns, I develop a dynamic model of regional capital accumulation with threshold effects. In the model, infrastructure investments raise productivity only in high-capital regions, generating divergence even under equitable allocation. Together, the empirical and theoretical findings highlight how capital complementarities and historical path dependence can entrench spatial inequality-despite large-scale infrastructure expansion.

title: AI governance in African higher education: Status, challenges, and a futureproof policy framework
affiliations: African Leadership University, African Leadership University, African Leadership University and African Leadership University

detail.title: AI governance in African higher education: Status, challenges, and a futureproof policy framework
detail.abstract: As artificial intelligence (AI) reshapes global education systems, African higher education institutions (HEIs) face pressure to adopt and govern AI ethically and effectively. This study investigates five questions: (1) What is the status of AI governance in African HEIs? (2) How ready are institutions to adopt AI policy? (3) What ethical and operational risks are emerging? (4) How do institutional and national AI strategies align? and (5) What future-proof governance framework can be proposed? Using a desk-based meta-synthesis, the study analyzes over 30 publicly available institutional, national, and regional documents. The analysis is guided by Resource Dependence Theory, Diffusion of Innovation, and Complexity Theory. No human subjects were involved, and international ethical standards were followed; PRISMA guidelines were deemed not applicable due to the qualitative scope. Findings reveal wide disparities in policy development and readiness. South Africa, Nigeria, and Rwanda are early adopters, aligning institutional policies with national digital strategies (RQ1 & RQ4). Most institutions remain in aspirational phases, limited by infrastructure and human capacity (RQ2). Where policies exist, they emphasize academic integrity and responsible use, though enforcement is uneven and impact largely unevaluated (RQ3). Cross-national alignment varies, with regional frameworks lacking strong enforcement mechanisms (RQ4). Evidence suggests that institutions with structured policies invest more in training and faculty engagement (RQ2 & RQ5). The study proposes a phased, ethically grounded governance framework tailored to Africa's educational context (RQ5). It contributes new insights into readiness differentials, governance diffusion, and policy convergence, offering a foundation for inclusive, future-oriented AI policy in African higher education.

title: Does ESG adoption improve public traded companies' performance?
affiliations: Queen's University - Department of Economics, University of Quebec at Rimouski - Department of Management Sciences and University of Quebec at Rimouski - Department of Management Sciences

detail.title: Does ESG adoption improve public traded companies' performance?
detail.abstract: Publicly traded companies often have incentives to externalize societal costs, raising the question of how firms can maintain financial performance while voluntarily adopting socially desirable policies such as environmental, social, and governance (ESG) criteria. Estimating this relationship is complicated by endogeneity and sample selection bias, which can overstate the benefits of ESG adoption. Using Refinitiv's ESG dataset, we investigate the distinct contributions of each ESG dimension to firm performance. To establish causality, we implement a switching model with a flexible instrumental variable. Results show that ESG adoption increases return on assets (ROA) in the short term, but these gains fade over time. In contrast, return on capital employed (ROCE) improves persistently. Among ESG components, the social dimension consistently enhances performance in both the short and long term. These findings offer valuable insights for corporate leaders and policymakers seeking to balance sustainability with profitability.

title: Bitcoin e a transformação do sistema financeiro: uma análise da adoção institucional e seus impactos regulatórios no contexto brasileiro (Bitcoin and the transformation of the financial system: an analysis of institutional adoption and its regulatory impacts in the Brazilian context)

detail.title: Bitcoin e a transformação do sistema financeiro: uma análise da adoção institucional e seus impactos regulatórios no contexto brasileiro (Bitcoin and the transformation of the financial system: an analysis of institutional adoption and its regulatory impacts in the Brazilian context)
detail.abstract: This study analyzes the transformative role of Bitcoin and cryptoassets in the global financial system, with specific focus on growing institutional adoption and its regulatory impacts in the Brazilian context. Through documentary analysis and systematic review of specialized literature, we examine the evolution of central banks' positioning, traditional financial institutions, and regulatory frameworks regarding digital assets between 2020-2024. Results demonstrate a paradigmatic shift in institutional perception of Bitcoin, transitioning from speculative asset to store of value and portfolio diversification instrument. In Brazil, we identify a progressive regulation process that seeks to balance financial innovation and systemic stability. The study reveals that institutional Bitcoin adoption not only legitimized the cryptoasset market but also forced a reorganization of traditional regulatory structures. Conclusions point to an irreversible integration of cryptoassets into the global financial system, requiring continuous regulatory adaptations and compliance strategies adequate to the unique characteristics of these assets.

title: Dealer Tiering Framework for Auto Lending: A Risk-Aligned Incentive Model to Reduce Delinquency

detail.title: Dealer Tiering Framework for Auto Lending: A Risk-Aligned Incentive Model to Reduce Delinquency

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The authors declare no conflicts of interest. This paper reflects independent research and does not represent the views of any institution.
declarations.ethicsApproval: No ethical approval was required for this study, as it does not involve human subjects, identifiable personal data, or sensitive information.
declarations.funderStatement: Not Funded

detail.abstract: This paper presents a dealer tiering framework that reduces delinquency rates by 15-21% while improving fair lending compliance across auto lending portfolios. Through three realworld case studies (national lender, regional credit union, and BHPH chain), it demonstrates how risk-aligned incentives lower defaults and markup disputes. The framework uses transparent performance metrics to segment dealers into tiers with dynamic thresholds validated via machine learning (AUC-ROC: 0.82). Regulatory safeguards include geospatial bias testing and BISG proxy analysis, with implementation blueprints provided for lenders.

title: The Architecture of Division: A Theoretical Synthesis of Elite Racial Formation and Community Sovereignty Frameworks Integrating Historical Analysis of Manufactured Whiteness with Psychological Liberation Strategies Through AI-Assisted Methodology

detail.title: The Architecture of Division: A Theoretical Synthesis of Elite Racial Formation and Community Sovereignty Frameworks Integrating Historical Analysis of Manufactured Whiteness with Psychological Liberation Strategies Through AI-Assisted Methodology

declarations.declarationOfInterest: None. The author used AI assistance for literature synthesis but maintains full responsibility for all theoretical claims and analysis.
declarations.ethicsApproval: Not applicable - theoretical paper analyzing existing published scholarship with no original data collection or human subjects.
declarations.funderStatement: Self-funded independent research with no institutional or grant support.

detail.abstract: This paper presents a theoretical synthesis of two complementary frameworks for understanding racial formation and resistance in North America. By integrating historical analysis of elite racial strategies with the Community Sovereignty Manifesto's psychological liberation framework, this study demonstrates how manufactured whiteness functions as both a structural and psychological mechanism of control spanning four centuries (1607-2025). Drawing on the Community Sovereignty Manifesto's analysis of Post-Traumatic Slave Syndrome (Morrow, 2003; DeGruy, 2005), Black Nihilism (Warren, 2018), and corrective remembrance methodologies (Harriot, 2022), this synthesis reveals how elite racial strategies exploit psychological conditioning to prevent cross-racial solidarity. The paper contributes: (1) a theoretical model linking elite crisis responses to racial formation, (2) analysis of how psychological conditioning enables structural oppression, (3) the Systemic Invisibility Framework for understanding contemporary control mechanisms, and (4) demonstration of AIassisted methodology for theoretical synthesis.

title: Juventud, cohesión social e innovación para el desarrollo local argentino: un análisis oportuno de la experiencia italiana en la región Emilia-Romagna

detail.title: Juventud, cohesión social e innovación para el desarrollo local argentino: un análisis oportuno de la experiencia italiana en la región Emilia-Romagna
detail.abstract:
The focus of this essay revolves around youth, social cohesion, and innovation as the main drivers of local development. In particular, it examines the distinctive factor of the Emilia-Romagna Region compared to other innovative developments in northern Italy. The aim is to unravel the set of characteristics and potential of the Emilian territory—distinguished in terms of design and innovation—and present them alongside other local developments experienced in other regions, in order to compare this reality with contemporary Argentina. Among the proposed conclusions, the most prominent are: a strong industrial culture, low post-war emigration, and a socially cohesive structure, rich in relationships, with a proportion of young people that fueled entrepreneurial momentum.

Resumen
El tema de este ensayo gira en torno a la juventud, cohesión social e innovación como factor principal del desarrollo local. En particular, se analiza el factor distintivo de la Región Emilia Romagna respecto de otros desarrollos innovadores del norte de Italia. El propósito es desentramar el conjunto de características y potencial del territorio Emiliano, que se distingue en términos de diseño e innovación, y exponerlos junto a otros desarrollos locales experimentados en otras regiones, de modo de comparar dicha realidad con la contemporaneidad argentina. Entre las conclusiones que se proponen, principalmente sobresalen: la alta cultura industrial, la baja emigración de posguerra y una estructura social cohesionada, rica en relaciones, con una proporción de juventud que caracterizó al empuje emprendedor.

title: Digital Inclusion and Urban AI: Strategic Roadmapping and Policy Challenges
affiliations: Ikerbasque Foundation UPV/EHU and Diputación Foral de Bizkaia - Bizkaiko Foru Aldundia

detail.title: Digital Inclusion and Urban AI: Strategic Roadmapping and Policy Challenges

declarations.declarationOfInterest: N/A
declarations.ethicsApproval: N/A
declarations.funderStatement: Province Council of Gipuzkoa. Human Rights and Democratic Culture Directorate.

detail.abstract:
This extended introduction to the DiscoverCities Special Issue charts the conceptual and policy transition from the “Smart City” paradigm toward an emergent framework of Urban Artificial Intelligence (Urban AI). Drawing on insights from the AI4SI research programme and the International Summer School on Digital Inclusion & Generative AI (San Sebastián, July 2025), the paper critically examines how AI technologies—particularly UrbanAI and GenAI—are reshaping urban, rural, and city-regional governance. It frames this transition through Richard R. Nelson’s enduring “Moon shots” vs. “Ghetto problems” distinction, underscoring the challenge of translating technical capacity into equitable, inclusive, and democratic outcomes.

The editorial introduces the Special Issue’s thematic scope, focusing on digital rights, data governance, algorithmic accountability, and the integration of AI into territorial innovation systems. It emphasizes the need for participatory governance architectures, cross-sectoral policy coordination, and mechanisms such as data cooperatives to ensure that AI deployments serve the public interest. By situating these debates in a global context—while grounding them in the specific case of Gipuzkoa’s City Science Lab collaboration with MIT Media Lab—the text calls for contributions that bridge digital divides, mitigate algorithmic bias, and foster human–AI systems that enhance social cohesion. Ultimately, it argues for the development of an Urban AI Social Contract, informed by Polanyi’s embeddedness, Schumpeterian innovation dynamics, Sennett’s urban ethics, Castells’s network society, Brenner’s planetary urbanisation, Geddes’s regionalism, Greenfield’s critical technology narratives, and Arendt’s human condition, to steer AI-enabled cities toward just, resilient, and democratic futures.

title: National Gold Reserve Trust (NGRT) - Partly Privatized Gold Reserve

detail.title: National Gold Reserve Trust (NGRT) - Partly Privatized Gold Reserve

keywords: securitization of a nation’s gold reserves

detail.abstract: The National Gold Reserve Trust (NGRT) is a proposed framework for partial privatization and securitization of a nation’s gold reserves. A portion of gold reserves would be placed into a publicly listed trust. Shares in the trust would be tradable in the private market. Shares could be used as collateral in central bank lending, with strict collateral ratios (e.g., 10% of loan value) and dynamic haircuts based on gold price volatility. Dividends from NGRT’s lending-related profits would be reinvested in gold, growing the reserve base over time.

title: Exploring Financial Performance in terms of Industry Effect: A Worldwide Evidence from 8 Sectors in 10 Stock Exchanges
affiliations: Ain Shams University and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Exploring Financial Performance in terms of Industry Effect: A Worldwide Evidence from 8 Sectors in 10 Stock Exchanges
detail.abstract: This paper aims at exploring financial performance in terms of industry effect, as it tries to present a worldwide evidence using profitability, liquidity, activity and leverage indicators of 735 listed companies from 8 sectors in 10 stock Exchanges during the period from 2015 to 2022. Testing hypotheses has been conducted using GMM technique, where Z-moments are projected into the column space of instrumental variables. This technique minimizes variance and enhances parameter estimate precision by focusing on Z-moments and applying GLS techniques. Results indicate that each of Retail, Communication and Chemicals sectors seem to have no significant effects on financial performance of companies listed in the selected stock markets. Besides, Construction sector seems to have a positive significant effect on profitability, while Oil sector seems to have a positive significant effect on leverage and Finance sector seems to have a positive significant effect on liquidity. In addition, Transportation sector seems to have positive significant effects on profitability and liquidity and a negative significant effect on activity, while Food sector seems to have a positive significant effect on liquidity. Robustness checks have been conducted for each stock market and supported these results.

reference: Marquette Intellectual Property Law Review (forthcoming)
title: History and Tradition in First Amendment Intellectual Property Cases: A Critique

detail.title: History and Tradition in First Amendment Intellectual Property Cases: A Critique
detail.abstract:
There are indications that the "history and tradition" approach the Supreme Court applied to gun rights and abortion restrictions may be coming for First Amendment doctrine. In intellectual property cases, it already has, with the Court using historical analogies for the right of publicity, copyright, and trademark. Unlike in the Second Amendment context, where the Court has reasoned from things earlier regulators didn’t do to strike down gun regulations today, in “history and tradition” First Amendment law the Court has reasoned by broad analogy to allow new speech restrictions.   

One lesson is that the history and tradition approach does not meaningfully constrain Justices even in low-political-salience areas like copyright and trademark, outside highly politicized contexts. The manipulability of levels of generality in making historical analogies has been justly criticized, but the IP cases provide a particularly clear contrast in outcomes from those in the Second Amendment cases, despite putatively using the same method of looking to historical models before—and even in place of—applying a means-ends test or other non-analogic scrutiny.

detail.abstract: Equity-linked assets such as futures on the S&P 500 have been considered as hedging instruments for systematic risk in high yield bonds (HYB) portfolios. We construct macro-dependent hedge ratios to rebalance monthly HYB portfolios. For the period spanning March 2000 to October 2020, we estimate hedging ratios that vary with the macroeconomic and market volatility factors. title: A Tale of Two Cities: Suzhou, Shenzhen, and Decentralization

detail.title: A Tale of Two Cities: Suzhou, Shenzhen, and Decentralization
detail.abstract: Suzhou and Shenzhen are among the top cities in China by GDP, and both have performed exceedingly well in terms of cultivating technological industries and attracting foreign investment. This is in spite of the fact that neither city is a provincial capital nor a centrally administered city like Shanghai and Beijing. Yet, the two cities embody very different administrative models with respect to their relationship with the provincial and central governments. Shenzhen, in particular, has a closer relationship with the central government than almost any non-centrally administered city in China, whereas Suzhou is a city that remains closely in coordination with the provincial government even as its economy has grown by leaps and bounds. This begs the question of which city's model will prevail moving forward: the Shenzhen model, typified by "re-centralization" of power, or the Suzhou model, which represents more of the conventional regional decentralization model that has been prevalent in China since the 1980s. The article attempts to argue that even though Shenzhen is of pivotal importance to the central government's policies, it will remain an outlier for the time being so as to avoid disturbing the delicate balance between the central and provincial governments, barring an unforeseen economic or political crisis.

detail.abstract: We derive from microfoundations a law of motion for knowledge growth, dg/dt=-κψg^2, where ψ represents institutional risk asymmetry. Termed the Asymmetry Principle, this law demonstrates that for any ψ>0 (a universal condition in modern economies), long-run growth is not a stable state but a transient phenomenon that, in the absence of countervailing forces, must systematically decay toward zero. This core mechanism reveals the productivity slowdown, the r_e>g divergence, and systemic fragility to be the natural and necessary consequences of this decay. The theory endogenizes institutional change (showing how the r_e-g gap drives ψ higher) to explain the path dependence that governs divergent long-run national fates.
